fields.headline: Experiments in sound
fields.standfirst:
London Premieres: Lindberg, Matthews/ Maxwell Davies
Royal Albert Hall, London/ Radio 3
**** / ***
fields.trailText:
London Premieres: Lindberg, Matthews/ Maxwell Davies
Royal Albert Hall, London/ Radio 3
**** / ***
fields.body:
This is the fourth successive Proms season to premiere a major score by Magnus Lindberg. It is a testament not only to the BBC's continuing faith in the importance of this 42-year-old Finnish composer, but also to his ability to invent bold and dramatically colourful orchestral music.

The new work, Fresco, received its first performance in Britain at the beginning of the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra's programme on Saturday, conducted by Sakari Oramo. At 22 minutes, it has got the scope and style of a major orchestral showpiece. The frescos of Giotto and Piero della Francesca were a starting point for Lindberg, who admired their epic content and refinement of detail. He has filled his orchestral canvas with big, strongly characterised musical ideas and teeming filigree textures, organising the whole with harmonic sureness.

There's no explicit programme for Fresco, but in the careful integration of the thematic material, and the ordered return of significant ideas, there is the whiff of a single-movement symphony. Perhaps it is five minutes too long but Lindberg is such a master of instrumental sonority that the fine print of his score is constantly absorbing. It would have been good to hear more of the inner lines than one did, but that was the hall's fault.

The acoustics befuddled many of the mid-range textures in Oramo's account of The Planets too. This was the first time that Holst's suite had been performed in London with Colin Matthews's codicil, Pluto - the Renewer.

Matthews has added another scherzo to the three in Holst's original scheme, and it is as different in character from them as they are from each other. Pluto moves very fast, and often very quietly, opening a wholly new and elusive musical dimension. Designed to grow seamlessly out of the ending of Holst's last movement, Neptune, the piece still manages to define its own musical space. While introducing new material, Matthews also refers back to the opening of the whole suite. If such a "completion" had to be done at all, it is hard to imagine that anyone could have done it better than him.

On Friday another London premiere was the centrepiece of the BBC Philharmonic's second proms appearance of the week. Sir Peter Maxwell Davies has marked the end of his spell as the orchestra's associate composer with the first performances of his Seventh Symphony.

The composer has declared that this will be his last symphony, implying that the new work completes the journey that began with his Symphony No 1. Perhaps it does in some respects, but there is no real sense that the latest work is any kind of convincing apotheosis. Although there are some marvellous, stirring passages, especially in the slow third movement, the problems of Davies's symphonic writing - the predictable manipulation of dramatic tension, the matt colouring of the orchestration, the lack of really strong melodic ideas - seem no nearer to solution now than they were a quarter of a century ago.

fields.headline: Post-bop pianist
fields.trailText: Joey Calderazzo *** Pizza Express Jazz Club, London
fields.body:
Joey Calderazzo *** Pizza Express Jazz Club, London

Joey Calderazzo, a favourite accompanist for Michael Brecker through the 90s, is one of the best post-bop pianists of recent years. As often happens when improvisors with regular partners have to play with impromptu bands instead, the atmosphere at this show has a compelling grit and edge. Not that he's starting completely from cold - his drummer is his UK-resident brother Gene, a performer with similar directness and bite, and his bassist Orlando LeFleming is no stranger to pianists who don't let the grass grow under their pedals.

Calderazzo's originals have a movie-score evocativeness that stays the New York side of sentimental. The Oracle began as a tone-poem, but quickly accelerated to a McCoy Tyner-rumble, pushed by Gene Calderazzo's clattering backbeats. Bill Evans's Time Remembered showcased the pianist's sensitivity to contrast, as a flowing spontaneous melody was capped by a stabbed chord. Calderazzo likes conversation too, often picking up LeFleming's bass figures and bouncing them back at him. The original piece, Midnight Voyage, was an instantly accessible melody over rolling mallet-work, that turned into the kind of bright swing that could have easily sat Calderazzo on Wynton Kelly's stool in a late-50s Miles ensemble.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Working at self-control
fields.standfirst: Everyone manages somebody in their job, but how good are you at managing yourself, asks Judi James
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: Everyone manages somebody in their job, but how good are you at managing yourself, asks Judi James
fields.body:
Control freak is a popular phrase in the press at the moment. And fresh from its stint in Downing Street and Westminster, it is currently appearing for its summer season at an office near you, being applied to anyone and everyone in a position to wield an ounce of power or authority, from the chief exec to the guy in charge of the car park.

So where does the effective boss end and the control freak begin? Probably the moment you give an order that someone else takes exception to. Getting your own way doesn't necessarily come any easier when you have the word manager in your job title. Leaders can only lead when others agree to be led.

Even if you are not a manager by title your job will still include management skills. The five-way manager manages upward, sideways, downwards and outwards. This means that you manage your boss and those above you; your colleagues and other members of your team; the people you delegate work to; and external clients and suppliers. Oh, and you also manage yourself, which can be the hardest job of all. Below we explain how not to behave if you want to get things done, and offer tips on the gentle art of workplace persuasion.

1. The spoilt brat

If sulking were an Olympic sport you'd win the gold. In your quest to bend others to your will, you leave no stone unturned in terms of childish and brattish behaviour. You are moody, temperamental and the queen of the flounce. It was a dark day when they invented the open-plan office because it meant there were no doors left for you to slam in your wake. Your bottom lip is jutted so often you've begun to resemble a bulldog taking part in a gurning contest.

2. The wobbly-thrower

It's easy to spot the symptoms when someone says no to you. Your face reddens and your eyes bulge. All the devil-may-care sophistication strips away like nose-skin after sunburn and you start to lose it, big-time. Threats and ultimatums are your house style, although muttered revenge is another popular option and one you will share with all your long-suffering colleagues. They will hear your shriek of disbelief three floors down in IT and everyone will make a mental note to keep clear of the loos for the rest of the day because it is there that you will set up camp to regale anyone unfortunate enough to pop in for a pee with the details of your most recent slight.

3. The manipulator

You study people for a living and know just which strings to pull to get your own way. You are a stranger to the word dignity and will stoop lower than a turtle's undercarriage to get what you want. One of your most nauseating displays is the girlie routine that you employ regularly on both male and female colleagues alike. This involves hand-clutching body language, and a voice that would make a five-year-old blush with shame. "Would oo like to do this likkle job for moi?" is the sort of verbal treacle that trickles out of your mouth. People do what you want just to avoid an attack of projectile vomiting.

4. The martyr

You will never ever ask for what you want at work. In fact, if and when it is offered you will usually turn it down. And then you will play the martyr, falling silent for days, with your face twisted into a mask of suffering that would turn a saint green with envy. You think delegation is for wimps, and your favourite phrase is: "If you want anything done around here you have to do it yourself." What you are hoping for is that all your colleagues will feel so guilty at the sight of your suffering that they will bend so far backward that you will be able to snap them in two.

5. The bossy-boots

Never persuade when a simple command will suffice is your motto. And if that command is relayed via a shout, so much the better. You are an aggressive bully who uses spoken or implied threats to get your own way. You are so task-focused you see no need to consider who you tread on to get the job done. It's a matter of ends, not means with you. You are constantly surprised at the amount of staff who leave your team each year, but ultimately conclude that they "couldn't stand the pace".

Persuading and influencing - a beginner's guide

 Know your bottom line. Negotiation is vital, but only if you know your limits beforehand. Negotiating on something you have no intention of being flexible over is a waste of time and energy.

Keep an open mind. Be non-judgmental. Never get into an "I'm-right-and-you're-wrong" mindset.

 Work to their values. Understand what is important or influential to the other person. Never assume that what is important to you is naturally going to be of importance to them.

 Never push. Once people begin to feel that they are being pushed they tend to dig their heels in and defend their position to the death, whether they sympathise with your viewpoint or not.

 Listen. Work to understand the other person and their viewpoint. When you do, your own comments will be more accurate.

 Remember the WIIFM (what's in it for me?) factor. Bring the other person around to your viewpoint by throwing in something that is important for them.
 Speak their language. Is the person you are dealing with a gut-reactor or logical thinker? Are they creative or strictly factual? Are they quick on decisions or do they like to take their time? Are they more swayed by the excitement of a proposal or by the fact that the idea has historic credentials (it has been used successfully somewhere before)? Link into their behavioural values to persuade more effectively.

fields.headline: Triumphant evening
fields.trailText: Unbelievable Truth **** King Tut's Wah Wah Hut, Glasgow
fields.body:
Unbelievable Truth **** King Tut's Wah Wah Hut, Glasgow

Kicking off with a rousing version of their recent single, Landslide, Unbelievable Truth set the tone for a triumphant evening, playing material from their new album sorrythankyou with aplomb. Brooding guitar, fierce beats and mournful organ, all complementing the enormous vocal talent of Andy Yorke - initiated an all too short airing for the band's musical palimpsest: layers of rich music and beautiful lyrics. This was an elegant, mesmerising cacophony.

As Yorke's Morrissey-tinted voice soared, so did the songs' subjects. From the search for happiness to love found and lost, Unbelievable Truth's take on these staple subjects of pop music made you feel you had never heard them addressed before. Delicate epics were built from nothing and faded to nothing again or else transformed themselves into the carnage of thrashing guitar, particularly in sorrythankyou.

Live, their intellectual melancholia is oddly uplifting: there is hope in their lyrics and the energy in their music seems to pulse from their hearts. No longer signed to Virgin, Unbelievable Truth are evidently enjoying the creative freedom they now have. In their element in front of an audience, any notion of the trio as cerebral cold fish is dispelled; as are comparisons with Yorke's older brother, Radiohead's Thom. Here is a great band with composed, wonderfully emotional music.

Unbelievable Truth play the Wedgewood Rooms, Portsmouth (02392 863911), tonight, then tour.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Axa to reveal details of 'orphan estate' payments

fields.headline: Axa to reveal details of 'orphan estate' payments
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Details of controversial payouts to Axa Equity & Law policy holders and shareholders are expected to be revealed tomorrow, in a scheme that could pave the way for a flurry of windfalls of as much as £10bn from rival insurers.
fields.body:
Details of controversial payouts to Axa Equity & Law policy holders and shareholders are expected to be revealed tomorrow, in a scheme that could pave the way for a flurry of windfalls of as much as £10bn from rival insurers.

The payments to Axa's policy holders will come from its so-called "orphan estate", the money that has been accumulated through non-payment to "lost" policy holders. Analysts estimate that Axa's orphan assets are at least £1.7bn while rival insurer Prudential is estimated to have accumulated as much as £5bn and the newly merged CGNU as much as £2bn.

The insurers have been locked in negotiations with the regulators for years over how to deal with the money and Axa is thought to be the first major group to reach a conclusion in a process which was delayed slightly during its complicated restructuring earlier this year.

Axa, which was unavailable for comment yesterday, is thought to have reached a deal with the regulators that is different to those which have been used in the past when policy holders received 90% of the unclaimed assets and shareholders 10%. In a groundbreaking move, however, Axa may have managed to alter the equation, getting permission to distribute more of the orphan estate to shareholders.

According to some industry sources, shareholders may be in line to receive as much as 40% of the estate in the form of a special dividend while policy holders will be paid the remaining 60%.

The terms of the payments to policy holders, who are expected to have a vote on the issue, and shareholders are thought to be complicated and may not involve dividing up the entire orphan estate. Some of the assets may be retained which may make it more difficult to calculate the precise ratio which is being used to divide up the assets.

The insurance companies with orphan estates, which some analysts estimate run to at least £20bn, are thought to have been searching for ways to distribute more of the assets to shareholders in an attempt to boost their stock market ratings. If Axa has managed to achieve this goal, rival groups are expected to be ready to follow a similar route once Axa has dealt with fall-out from policy holders who might have hoped for a larger share of the assets and complain of unfairness.

Axa's announcement is now expected in the week the leading insurance companies, including Legal & General and the Pru, are scheduled to publish their interim profits.

webTitle: Stockbrokers to be tempted with £3m windfall

fields.headline: Stockbrokers to be tempted with £3m windfall
fields.standfirst:
Bonus offer for exchanges merger

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The prospect of a £3m cash windfall is likely to be dangled under the noses of the City's smaller stockbrokers who hold key votes in the proposed merger of the London and Frankfurt exchanges.
fields.body:
The prospect of a £3m cash windfall is likely to be dangled under the noses of the City's smaller stockbrokers who hold key votes in the proposed merger of the London and Frankfurt exchanges.

The bonus will come in the form of shares as the London stock exchange begins trading today. The exchange is expected to be valued at between £600 to £900m when trading starts at lunchtime, giving each of the 297 member firms that gained a holding of 100,000 shares, following the demutualisation vote in March, a stake worth between £2m and £3m.

At the higher end of the range some smaller stock-brokers may be tempted to cash in on the merger, with the City's leading investment banks expected to buy any shares on offer in an attempt to make sure the controversial link-up between the London and Frankfurt bourses succeeds.

For the merger to go ahead a 75% "yes" vote is needed at London's make-or-break emergency general meeting on September 14.

Any shares purchased in the market before then can be voted on at the meeting and large investment banks will be allowed to build a stake of up to 4.9%. Each share carries one vote.

The market in London shares, which will be handled by broker Cazenove on a matched-bargain basis, is also expected to attract the attention of pension funds and systems companies.

"There are a number of partnerships and brokers for whom a couple of million pounds is a significant windfall," one broker who refused to be named said.

But many smaller brokers, who fear a large portion of their business dealing in small and medium-sized companies will migrate to Frankfurt, are expected to sit tight - at least until they have had more details.

This week the board of the London exchange embarks on a campaign to persuade shareholders to vote in favour of the merger, which will create a company called iX.

The public relations campaign follows the publication of a prospectus on the merger last week, which was widely criticised for lacking detail on key issues such as clearing and settlement and regulation.

Under the merger plans, trading in blue chip shares will be based in London and there will be a market for high-growth companies in Frankfurt.

Meanwhile, a survey of smaller company fund managers published today by trade body, the Quoted Companies Alliance, has highlighted the level of opposition to the merger.

Of 60 fund managers surveyed, over 40% named the creation of iX as the biggest threat to investment in smaller quoted companies, followed by the strength of sterling.

fields.headline: Notts glad to survive
fields.standfirst:
Sussex 472 and 278-3 dec
Nottinghamshire 344 and 245-2
fields.trailText:
Sussex 472 and 278-3 dec
Nottinghamshire 344 and 245-2
fields.body:
Nottinghamshire have only won one championship match since last August, an unwanted statistic they threatened to erase before a valiant run chase petered out in the evening sun. No quarter is given or asked in these situations, with points at a premium in the quest for promotion, and an attritional edge pervaded an absorbing final day.

The outlook at the start was probably more rearguard action than major offensive, but a punishing third-wicket stand of 222 between Jason Gallian and John Morris changed all that on an excellent durable surface. Morris finished with 115, his 50th first-class century and first for Notts, off 142 balls with 16 fours and a six.

Gallian's effort was more sedate but no less ebullient and the captain eventually equalled his career best for Notts, 120. However, both went in quick succession prefacing a middle order collapse instigated by the left arm orthodox of Umer Rashid who returned a creditable season's best 4-93.

Fifty-four were needed off the last ten overs and Usman Aszaal continued the assault until Jason Lewry bowled him for 54. When Chris Read drove Lewry to mid off, Notts shut up shot and no one could blame them.

Facing a formidable target of 407, they were 19 without loss overnight, but Guy Welton was trapped LBW offering no shot to James Kirtley's fourth ball of the morning then Darren Bicknell, who took an age to get moving in the first innings, was smartly held at short leg by Richard Montgomerie off Rashid. Gallian and Morris paved the way for a thrilling finale but the pitch was arguably the real winner.

The square is badly scarred but this track on the short score board side bore up well.It was deceptively green at first, but Michael Bevan would gladly roll it up and preserve it for posterity. No wickets have been relaid here in living memory and Bob Major, a ground-staff stalwart of 30 years and reluctant replacement for the sadly departed Peter Eaton, is in no hurry to change things.

A lasting legacy is due to be unveiled next April, though, when 14 manicured practise pitches are installed at the adjacent 'Peter Eton, HG Memorial Ground'. A new head groundsman will be installed by September while Major wrestles with the demands imposed by practise on the square.

Earlier Gallian, now captain at Trent Bridge, was nothing but the consummate professional, grafting steely determination into his effort, having run himself out in the fist innings. Morris was the perfect rumbustious foil on such a reliable batting strip, expanding his repertoire after lunch with a clutch of thunderous on-drives as Nottinghamshire sniffed an improbable victory.

The bowling lacked the requisite variety and a truly effective front-line spinner, essential on a pitch as flat as a fluke, and Bevan, for all his magnificence with the bat, was not the man to provide it. Left-arm Chinamen and googlies is a demanding art at the best of times, and Gallian and Morris exacted full toll when the inevitable loose stuff came along.

Last September Nottinghamshire lost here inside three days after Gallian put in Sussex and saw their openers rack-up a century opening standas Nottslost inside three days. Thankfully for everybody here this year's match was far more entertaining and Notts can take heart in the fact that they very nearly pulled off a stunning victory. At the end of the day they did not lose.

webTitle: Success is all in Bob's details

fields.headline: Success is all in Bob's details
fields.trailText: Norman Harris goes behind the scenes of the county circuit
fields.body:
A phone call to Bob Woolmer while his team are batting can be quite instructive. It can give a clue to why, of the 11 England-qualified batsmen currently averaging over 50, five are from Warwickshire. As Woolmer talks, the smooth flow of words is suddenly interrupted by a short expletive. Another wicket has fallen. Some 30 seconds later he mutters, of the lbw: 'It was, as well.'

The Warwickshire coach has just seen a slow motion replay, but not on TV or on a giant screen. This is county cricket, and Woolmer is watching a personal monitor attached to a computer. Upstairs, sports scientist Simon Hollyhead has video-ed and logged each ball according to the type of shot that was played and the outcome. The coach can access the information immediately.

Other counties have similar systems, but the one Woolmer requested from his employers at Edgbaston - a South African system called Crickstat - is certainly state of the art. Batsmen invariably visit his room after their dismissal, and their belief at how they were out is not always borne out. Far from getting an 'unplayable ball' they may be confronted with the evidence that they simply missed a straight one, or they were on the crease when they thought they were well forward.

Says Woolmer: 'It does away with any guesswork. We can soon identify from the system what a batsman is doing wrong, especially if we know what he does when he's playing well. If he had an ear-piece we could tell him straight away. But that's not on at the moment, unfortunately.'

Last Sunday, when Gloucestershire were chasing Worcestershire's 145, and they had slumped to 76 for seven after 38.1 overs, they were minus 43 according to Duckworth/Lewis, the system that determine the outcome when rain intervenes. Happily there was no question of rain, and Gloucestershire charged on to an unlikely win.

But someone is missing a trick in not displaying the D/L figure throughout the second innings of one-day games. From the runs made, wickets and overs remaining, the calculation determines precisely the degree to which the batting side is winning or losing, and in effect states the odds better than the bookmakers.

Also last Sunday, Zimbabwe were losing by 30 when they were 104 for four against West Indies. But their excellent recovery put them ahead of par some five overs before the finish. Their six-wicket margin of victory could as easily have been recorded at plus 13. Indeed, Frank Duckworth thinks that is a better measurement when the chasing side reach their target.

Perhaps that will happen when the tables invented by Messrs Duckworth and Lewis reach the end of a two-year international trial, and their full potential is then exploited. Who knows, maybe a sponsor will come in and provide a new name. Marketing men might think the 'Oracle Odds', or the 'Barclays Balance', more sexy than 'Duckworth/Lewis' - and they could be right.

Ian Botham has been accused of swearing on television. Not so, declare his employers at Sky. When he fluffed his pitch report, prior to last Sunday's Zimbabwe-West Indies encounter, the great man delivered a one-word exclamation as he terminated his spiel and strode irritably away. Of course, the report was filmed again. Unfortunately, the wrong one was subsequently played, and surprised viewers witnessed live what should have been an out-take. But we can confirm that the single word in question was 'smuck'. Could it ever have been otherwise for this model professional?

fields.headline: Spin wins for Lancashire
fields.standfirst: Cricket roundup
fields.trailText: Cricket roundup
fields.body:
Lancashire moved back into second place in the County Championship with a six-wicket win over Durham.

They bowled the visitors out for 206 with all the wickets being shared by the spinning Garys - six to left-armer Keedy and four to off-spinner Yates - which meant only one in the match for the England-contracted leg-spinner Chris Schofield on the now- traditional spinner-friendly track at Old Trafford. Keedy and Yates bowled 94 of the 114 overs in the innings, with Schofield adding 10 more.

Mike Atherton then guided Lancashire home, scoring an unbeaten 64 from 99 balls with seven fours in his side's 132 for four. Pity Graham Lloyd, though, who was caught and bowled by Nick Phillips with the scores level.

Rahul Dravid guided Kent safely to victory over Hampshire by six wickets in the last championship match to be played at Portsmouth.

Dravid added an unbeaten 73 to the 137 he scored in the first innings as Kent completed their task in the last over before lunch.

Kent began the last day requiring 88 runs for victory over their fellow relegation candidates, and they reached 182 for one without any alarms despite a long spell from Shane Warne. The leg-spinner bowled almost 32 overs without taking a wicket and the four that did fall were claimed by off-spinner Shaun Udal.

Dravid and Robert Key put on 115 for the second wicket before a mini-collapse when Kent needed 23 for victory. Key batted for five hours for 50 before he top-edged a delivery from Udal, and Warne ran back to hold the catch.

Dravid batted for 202 minutes, faced 140 deliveries and hit 11 boundaries, making light of a wicket which offered some slow turn for Warne and Udal.

Udal finished with figures of four for 42 from 20 overs as Warne went wicketless for 69 and was punished for some loose deliveries.

Sri Lanka were pushing towards a win over South Africa after the third day of the first Test in Colombo. South Africa, forced to follow on for only the second time since their return to international cricket eight years ago, were digging in at 112 for two in their second innings.

Muttiah Muralitharan again did most of the damage with six for 87 as South Africa were dismissed for 238 in reply to Sri Lanka's 522, but he failed to take a wicket in the second innings as South Africa followed on, 284 runs in arrears.

Openers Neil McKenzie and Gary Kirsten, who put on 58 for the first wicket, were the men dismissed, with Kirsten run out in the last over of the day for 55.

Jacques Kallis was unbeaten on 25 as South Africa ended the day still requiring 172 runs to avoid an innings defeat.

On a dusty and cracking pitch taking a lot of spin, only Daryll Cullinan stood firm against Muralitharan. He batted resolutely to be unbeaten on 114, his 11th Test century and his fourth against Sri Lanka, having defied the bowling for 274 minutes. Cullinan had 12 fours and a six in his 231-ball knock

Muralitharan, aiming at the cracks appearing at one end of the pitch, was unplayable at times as the ball turned and bounced sharply. His figures of six for 87 were the best by a bowler in a Sri Lanka-South Africa series, improving on Brett Schultz's five for 48 in 1993-94.

Kumar Dharmasena took the wicket of Lance Klusener, his first Test wicket for nearly two years after being out of international cricket following a suspect bowling action which he has since rectified.

Dravid and Robert Key put on 115 for the second wicket before a mini-collapse when Kent needed 23 for victory. Key batted for five hours for 50 before he top-edged a delivery from Udal, and Warne ran back to hold the catch. Dravid batted for 202 minutes, faced 140 deliveries and hit 11 boundaries, making light of a wicket which offered some slow turn for Warne and Udal. Udal finished with figures of four for 42 from 20 overs as Warne went wicketless for 69 and was punished for some loose deliveries. Sri Lanka were pushing towards a win over South Africa after the third day of the first Test in Colombo. South Africa, forced to follow on for only the second time since their return to international cricket eight years ago, were digging in at 112 for two in their second innings. Muttiah Muralitharan again did most of the damage with six for 87 as South Africa were dismissed for 238 in reply to Sri Lanka's 522, but he failed to take a wicket in the second innings as South Africa followed on, 284 runs in arrears. Openers Neil McKenzie and Gary Kirsten, who put on 58 for the first wicket, were the men dismissed, with Kirsten run out in the last over of the day for 55. Jacques Kallis was unbeaten on 25 as South Africa ended the day still requiring 172 runs to avoid an innings defeat. On a dusty and cracking pitch taking a lot of spin, only Daryll Cullinan stood firm against Muralitharan. He batted resolutely to be unbeaten on 114, his 11th Test century and his fourth against Sri Lanka, having defied the bowling for 274 minutes. Cullinan had 12 fours and a six in his 231-ball knock Muralitharan, aiming at the cracks appearing at one end of the pitch, was unplayable at times as the ball turned and bounced sharply. His figures of six for 87 were the best by a bowler in a Sri Lanka-South Africa series, improving on Brett Schultz's five for 48 in 1993-94. Kumar Dharmasena took the wicket of Lance Klusener, his first Test wicket for nearly two years after being out of international cricket following a suspect bowling action which he has since rectified.

fields.headline: Stewart reigns supreme
fields.trailText: The victory was emphatic, though not particularly entertaining. With Alec Stewart in command, just as he has been in the previous three games, England cruised to victory by six wickets so that they could enjoy the rare experience of hoisting a trophy to the skies. Stewart has hit a rich vein of form and like the pros of old he made damn sure in the past week that he made the most of it.
fields.body:
The victory was emphatic, though not particularly entertaining. With Alec Stewart in command, just as he has been in the previous three games, England cruised to victory by six wickets so that they could enjoy the rare experience of hoisting a trophy to the skies. Stewart has hit a rich vein of form and like the pros of old he made damn sure in the past week that he made the most of it.

After hundreds at Edgbaston and Trent Bridge - not to mention an unbeaten 74 at Chester-le-Street - Alec the avaricious struck a handsome 97 yesterday, which enabled a simple victory against the Zimbabweans, still plucky at the end of their interminable trek around the globe, but patently out-gunned. The England camp can only hope that Stewart has got some runs in reserve for the Test series - he scored a mighty 408 in the triangular tournament.

He needed a little help from Graeme Hick, who hit a subdued 41, but not much. Stewart was still at his dismissive best at his beloved Lord's, driving silkily on either side of the wicket and pulling effortlessly whenever the chance arose. It was a shock that he edged Streak when seeking the boundary that would have a brought another hundred. But he would readily concede - he's that sort of chap - that the foundation for victory was laid by the bowlers in the morning.

We could all marvel at the superb efficiency of the English attack even though their discipline denied us a marvellous occasion. By restricting the Zimbabweans to a paltry 169 for seven from their 50 overs this final lacked any drama. But I don't suppose we should cavil too much about England's new-found competence.

Not that the performance of their bowlers surprised us. Throughout the whole tournament they have been remarkably trustworthy. Their opposition may not have been in the highest league since there are obvious limitations to both the Zimbabwean and West Indian sides, but I cannot recall an English one-day team purring so consistently in the field since the early stages of the 1992 World Cup.

In fact the Zimbabweans did well to reach 169. After 15 overs they were languishing at 31 for four with both of their exiles-to-be, Neil Johnson and Murray Goodwin, back in the pavilion. This pair are returning to Western Province and Western Australia respectively in search of fresher challenges and fatter pay packets. However those true stalwarts of Zimbabwean cricket, the Flower brothers, with a little skittish help from another, Heath Streak, at least ensured that we had a contest.

The Flowers added a devoted 89 together; Streak clobbered two sixes from the penultimate over, as well as bowling bullishly later on.

Until Streak fleetingly cut loose, the Zimbabweans had been compelled to plod after an incisive opening spell from Gough under early morning cloud cover. Gough's first ball, a standard loosener, removed Guy Whittall, who edged to Hick in the slips. His next wicket resulted from a more special delivery from Barnsley.

To Goodwin, Gough propelled his off spinner. It pitched nine inches outside the off stump, turned down the slope sufficiently to penetrate the gap between bat and pad and to clip the off bail. Illy would probably have been proud of that one; Gough certainly was. Mullally soon accounted for Campbell, prodding limply to cover, while Johnson threatened with several trademark square drives. But in attempting another, he was bowled off the inside edge by Caddick.

So the Flowers had to dig in and England allowed them no liberties. After 25 overs Zimbabwe had stumbled to only 51 for four. Eventually Ealham allowed Andy the odd opportunity to play his favourite cut shot; Grant hung on gamely; the Flowers neither wilted nor blossomed but they fought furiously.

They had taken the score to 120 when Andy Flower became a victim of Craig White's reverse swing. This is a White speciality, very handy when bowling around the wicket to left-handers, and this knack will surely influence the selection of the next Test side, which will be announced tomorrow, much earlier than usual.

Old Trafford usually provides a hard, dry and abrasive surface, which encourages the ball to reverse swing relatively early in the innings. Good news for White. Others keenly awaiting tomorrow's announcement will include Marcus Trescothick, even though he failed yesterday, Graham Thorpe and Ashley Giles. Mark Ramprakash, Nick Knight and Andrew Flintoff will be listening out for news with rather more trepidation.

There was a little flurry at the end of the Zimbabwean innings thanks to Streak, who contrived two off-side sixes off White, but the target was modest even after the indomitable Streak had struck in the third over. First Trescothick cut and was neatly held by Campbell at first slip.

This was his first failure in international cricket in his seven outings, so let's not carp too much. Like most left-handers, the area around off-stump is where he's most vulnerable - and productive. The dismissal of Flintoff, bowled for a duck, is cause for more long term concern. His confidence is crumbling. Unlike Alec Stewart's.

webTitle: Mix and match era suits Stewart

fields.headline: Mix and match era suits Stewart
fields.trailText: Alec Stewart, at 37, has again reminded us that he's indispensable, whether as a stand-in captain, efficient wicketkeeper or quality batsman. The English selectors must dread an injury to Stewart more than any other player in their squad. It's possible to conjure up a few credible alternatives if Andy Caddick, Darren Gough or Mike Atherton were to tweak their backs in bending down to pick up their ECB pay cheques, but replacing Stewart would be a nightmare. It is amazing to think that his place was in jeopardy last autumn or that he was omitted from the one-day squad in Southern Africa last winter.
fields.body:
Alec Stewart, at 37, has again reminded us that he's indispensable, whether as a stand-in captain, efficient wicketkeeper or quality batsman. The English selectors must dread an injury to Stewart more than any other player in their squad. It's possible to conjure up a few credible alternatives if Andy Caddick, Darren Gough or Mike Atherton were to tweak their backs in bending down to pick up their ECB pay cheques, but replacing Stewart would be a nightmare. It is amazing to think that his place was in jeopardy last autumn or that he was omitted from the one-day squad in Southern Africa last winter.

The likeliest lads to replace him, Paul Nixon and Rob Turner, are fading. Chris Read flickered but there are still doubts about the quality of his keeping (I remember wandering around Old Trafford last year with Bob Taylor, who was aghast at Read's foot movements when standing up to the spinners).

There was a time when the English viewed their wicketkeepers like their goalkeepers, making the happy assumption that they were the best in the world. That no longer applies in football or cricket. There are still some doughty keepers on the circuit, who are not much younger than Stewart, like Adrian Aymes and Karl Krikken. Keith Piper has good hands, but is reckoned to be inconsistent and a modest run scorer. I've heard good reports of James Foster from Essex, another Durham student, but he's yet to play a first class game. The conclusion is that Stewart, if he stays fit (not to be taken for granted) and hungry (never much doubt about that) could keep the job until he's 40.

Moreover the requirements of the modern wicketkeeper have changed. Now he must be able to bat; in the past this was merely a bonus; it was possible for ordinary batsmen like Bob Taylor or Keith Andrew to justify a place in the England team simply because of their keeping. No longer. This change of emphasis now applies to almost every kind of cricketer. Only a paceman or a wrist-spinner (if there are any good ones) can anticipate an international cap despite being unable to contribute with the bat. The age of the specialist is fast disappearing.

This is especially true of finger spinners. For example, the English selectors will be mulling over which spinner to take to Old Trafford for the next Test, which starts on 3 August. In Manchester the wicket usually demands at least one slow bowler in the side. Arguably the best available finger spinners are still Peter Such and Phil Tufnell, but neither will be summoned away from county cricket next week. (In fact Such has only just won his place back in the Essex side.) For they offer nothing but their bowling.

So the choice for the Old Trafford Test will be between Robert Croft, who can bat a bit and bowl a length, or possibly Warwickshire's Ashley Giles, a better batsman than Croft but an unproven spinner at the highest level. Likewise look at the two Northamptonshire off-spinners. Jason Brown is clearly a better bowler than Graeme Swann, but it was the multi-purpose Swann who made England's winter tour party.

Selectors and coaches everywhere now crave dual purpose cricketers. Yet true all-rounders seem to be becoming a rarer commodity (we were spoilt in the decades of Ian Botham, Imran Khan and Kapil Dev). So the brightest sparks to join the England side - Michael Vaughan and Marcus Trescothick - not only bat but can toss down a few useful overs of off-spin and medium pace respectively. We are in a mix-and-match era.

Only the exceptional cricketer can now afford to neglect any aspect of their game. This is a pragmatic rather than romantic advance. There was a bizarre delight in watching Devon Malcolm or Tufnell bat or David Gower bowl. I hope this trend does not mean that the truly gifted 'one-dimensional' cricketer is not scorned immediately - because he's slow in the field and incapable of bowling or batting. But any intelligent youngster must now devote himself to every discipline of the game.

However, in the past fortnight I've noticed one modern trend being reversed. Prior to last year's World Cup there was much talk about England's one-day 'specialists' being drafted into the squad - the likes of Vince Wells, Ian Austin and Adam Hollioake. I didn't like the idea much then and it appears the selectors have had second thoughts now. Apart from Mark Ealham, who is a very worthwhile member of the one-day team, all the members of the side playing against Zimbabwe yesterday are in the selectors' minds for Old Trafford. The disparity between the Test team and the one-day team has been greatly reduced and that is a good sign. For it reassures us that quality counts.

fields.headline: Summer Tales from the Tabs
fields.trailText: GIN: ARE YOU A MAN? John Gregory has told David Ginola to join Villa and prove himself as a man: 'He could go to France for the easy life,' says Gregory, 'or flog his guts out here.'
fields.body:
GIN: ARE YOU A MAN? John Gregory has told David Ginola to join Villa and prove himself as a man: 'He could go to France for the easy life,' says Gregory, 'or flog his guts out here.'

PANUCCI: FORGET IT Inter Milan full-back Christian Panucci has told Gianluca Vialli he'll never move to Chelsea. 'I thanked him for his interest.'

Arsenal

Real Madrid have made Thierry Henry a £20m target. Real's interest comes on top of a firm new Barcelona bid for Marc Overmars. Arsene Wenger is also thinking over a shock swap deal involving Ray Parlour, several million pounds and Sunderland's Kevin Phillips.

Aston Villa

John Gregory has again blocked Ugo Ehiogu's move to Sunderland . 'I am keeping Ugo in touch with developments, but he's not going anywhere. The price is not right - if we have to make him sit here for the next two years and run down his contract, that's the way we'll have to do it.' He's also dismissed a move for Juninho: 'It's time-wasting.'

Bradford

Nicky Summerbee will complete his £1.5m move this week - Liverpool's David Thompson remains a target for Chris Hutchings after Niclas Alexandersson rejected a move to Valley Parade.

Charlton

Alan Curbishley believes he'll break the club's record transfer fee, set by Claus Jensen at £4m, within the next two weeks - he's chasing South African striker Shaun Bartlett and Leeds defender Michael Duberry.

Chelsea

Gianluca Vialli will release two top strikers this week: Fulham have lined up a massive salary offer for George Weah, and Crystal Palace have agreed a season-long loan deal for young Mikael Forssell after Vialli refused to sell.

Coventry

Gordon Strachan is favourite to land Blackburn's transfer-listed midfielder Lee Carsley after lodging a new £3.75m bid. Strachan's first offer of cash plus Noel Whelan was rejected, but the new deal should be cleared this week.

Derby

Mart Poom will hear tomorrow if his work permit appeal has been successful.

Everton

The club have finalised a £2.8m deal for Hamburg midfielder Thomas Gravesen, taking Walter Smith's close-season spending to almost £13m. He's also opened talks for £2m-rated Bristol Rovers striker Jason Roberts.

Ipswich

David Johnson has signed a new four-year contract - and chairman David Sheepshanks is ready to back George Burley's transfer plans: 'We missed out on Claus Jensen, but now we're actively pursuing our other options.'

Leeds

David O'Leary could sell Michael Duberry to Charlton - he's ready to release the defender if Alan Curbishley can find over £4m.

Leicester

Peter Taylor has again told Celtic to stay away from Neil Lennon: 'Neil is staying here. I've signed one important part of our midfield in Muzzy Izzet on a new long-term deal, and now I want the other.'

Liverpool

Middlesbrough have again refused to listen to Liverpool's interest in Christian Ziege. 'Bryan [Robson] spoke to Christian at length yesterday and he's staying,' says Viv Anderson. 'We're getting a little fed up with all the rumours.'

Man City

City are ready to go back to Aston Villa with a massive new £7m offer for Ugo Ehiogu: 'Dialogue is continuing,' says chief operating officer Chris Bird. 'We're in no great rush.' Paul Dickov, meanwhile, is set to quit for Sheffield United .

Man Utd

Peter Kenyon has again denied any Milan bids for David Beckham: 'We've had no offer from Milan and if we did, we'd reject it.' Posh Spice, though, is believed to be pressing hard for the move. Alex Ferguson, meanwhile, could move for Villa's Gareth Southgate.

Middlesbrough

Finidi George is talking up his possible move to the Riverside. 'I have finished my holidays,' says George. 'There are no concrete offers yet so I cannot say anything. So I am just waiting to see what will happen.'

Newcastle

Marcelino has been told by Bobby Robson to find a new club. 'It's a shock,' says the Spaniard. 'I had been looking forward to the new season, but I have to accept the manager's decision.' Robson wants £4m - Deportivo La Coruna are keen. Paul Robinson should join Wimbledon for £1m.

Southampton

Marian Pahars has signed a new four-year deal - but several teammates are set to go. Luis Boa Morte, Richard Dryden, John Beresford, David Hughes, Tore-Egil Soltvedt and James Beattie are all set to be listed.

Sunderland

Peter Reid has lined up a £3.5m move for one of Argentina's top young talents, Julio Arca. Arca's club, Argentinos Juniors, say talks are already under way. Reid has also enquired about Juve's Italian international Antonio Conte.

Tottenham

Espen Baardsen could be set for a move to Watford after giving up on a first-team place at Spurs. David Ginola, meanwhile, should leave this week.

West Ham

Harry Redknapp has ruled out a move for Leyton Orient left-back Matthew Lockwood. Man City are ready to bid again for Paul Kitson.

Chelsea Gianluca Vialli will release two top strikers this week: Fulham have lined up a massive salary offer for George Weah, and Crystal Palace have agreed a season-long loan deal for young Mikael Forssell after Vialli refused to sell. Strachan's first offer of cash plus Noel Whelan was rejected, but the new deal should be cleared this week. Derby Mart Poom will hear tomorrow if his work permit appeal has been successful. Everton The club have finalised a £2.8m deal for Hamburg midfielder Thomas Gravesen, taking Walter Smith's close-season spending to almost £13m. He's also opened talks for £2m-rated Bristol Rovers striker Jason Roberts. Ipswich David Johnson has signed a new four-year contract - and chairman David Sheepshanks is ready to back George Burley's transfer plans: 'We missed out on Claus Jensen, but now we're actively pursuing our other options.' Leeds David O'Leary could sell Michael Duberry to Charlton - he's ready to release the defender if Alan Curbishley can find over £4m. Leicester Peter Taylor has again told Celtic to stay away from Neil Lennon: 'Neil is staying here. I've signed one important part of our midfield in Muzzy Izzet on a new long-term deal, and now I want the other.' Liverpool Middlesbrough have again refused to listen to Liverpool's interest in Christian Ziege. 'Bryan [Robson] spoke to Christian at length yesterday and he's staying,' says Viv Anderson. 'We're getting a little fed up with all the rumours.' Man City City are ready to go back to Aston Villa with a massive new £7m offer for Ugo Ehiogu: 'Dialogue is continuing,' says chief operating officer Chris Bird. 'We're in no great rush.' Paul Dickov, meanwhile, is set to quit for Sheffield United . Man Utd Peter Kenyon has again denied any Milan bids for David Beckham: 'We've had no offer from Milan and if we did, we'd reject it.' Posh Spice, though, is believed to be pressing hard for the move. Alex Ferguson, meanwhile, could move for Villa's Gareth Southgate. Middlesbrough Finidi George is talking up his possible move to the Riverside. 'I have finished my holidays,' says George. 'There are no concrete offers yet so I cannot say anything. David Ginola, meanwhile, should leave this week. West Ham Harry Redknapp has ruled out a move for Leyton Orient left-back Matthew Lockwood. Man City are ready to bid again for Paul Kitson.

webTitle: Dandy comes under fire as Brazil stutter

fields.headline: Dandy comes under fire as Brazil stutter
fields.standfirst: The immaculately dressed Wanderley Luxemburgo seems to care more about appearance than results
fields.trailText: Brazil could find themselves playing off against Australia, New Zealand or even Vanuatu for a place at the 2002 World Cup if they do not improve on their current position in the qualifiers.
fields.byline: Brian Homewood in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
Brazil could find themselves playing off against Australia, New Zealand or even Vanuatu for a place at the 2002 World Cup if they do not improve on their current position in the qualifiers.

Tuesday's 2-1 defeat in Paraguay left them fifth in the South American group, and if they are still there when the marathon 18-month contest ends next year, they will have to face the winners of the Oceania region home and away.

Brazilians still refuse to believe that their team will do anything other than finish in the top four and earn an automatic place in Japan and South Korea. But not many believe that manager Wanderley Luxemburgo is the man to take them there, particularly not after the team's first defeat against Paraguay in 21 years.

Luxemburgo, who provided the first recorded case of a Brazilian manager wearing a suit on the touchline, has seemed more interested in his wardrobe than his team. An unseasonably cold winter night in subtropical Asuncion gave him a chance to show off his winter collection: glasses, long black coat and leather gloves which made him look more like a Gestapo agent than the Brazil manager.

Brazilian Football Confederation president Ricardo Teixeiras went so far as to blame Luxemburgo's dress sense for his unpopularity. 'It alienates him from the fans,' he said, suggesting a track suit against Argentina next Wednesday. The media, meanwhile, want less chopping and changing of the team and some sort of recognisable tactics. While Luxemburgo was immaculately turned out, his team were the football equivalent of a pile of unwashed laundry, a hopeless mess with the players looking unsure of themselves and their role on the pitch.

Roberto Carlos and Rivaldo have aggravated the situation by saving their best for their Spanish clubs, and the latter did himself no favours before the game when he criticised the 1970 team, saying they would not have succeeded in modern football - a declaration which, in Brazil, amounts to near sacrilege.

To complete the scenario, Brazil's next game is on Wednesday against an Argentina side who have dominated the competition. The Argentines have maximum points and have been in a different class.

'Argentina get better every day,' said Ecuador manager Hernan Dario Gomez, after his team lost 2-0 in Buenos Aires. 'Any team that plays against them runs the risk of being embarrassed.'

fields.headline: Riedle teaches India a lesson
fields.standfirst: Nick Callow sees Fulham win 2-0 over India's pioneers
fields.trailText: A couple of punters overheard before the game veered between the patronising and downright racist as they laughed their way through the names on the India teamsheet. But they were just an odd couple in an otherwise appreciative and attentive 5,373 crowd as the international language of football won through.
fields.body:
A couple of punters overheard before the game veered between the patronising and downright racist as they laughed their way through the names on the India teamsheet. But they were just an odd couple in an otherwise appreciative and attentive 5,373 crowd as the international language of football won through.

Sure, it all had a surreal feel early on, but this was not novelty football. India departed with their reputation enhanced after Fulham's German international striker Karl Heinz Riedle had scored at the end of each half to secure a win they were made to work hard for within the limitations of a July pre- season friendly.

It was a puzzling fixture for some. 'I didn't know Fulham had a cricket team,' was a genuine comment from the first sporting expert I encountered yesterday morning. 'They'll get thrashed by India.' Wrong. They don't have a cricket team at Craven Cottage, or a hockey side as someone else suggested. The real surprise here was that India had a national football XI.

That is why they were in town, to get some long-overdue attention. There should be no shame for knowing little of India's love of the beautiful game, as this was their first match in England.

Broadcast live across Asia, it is hoped this fixture and next Saturday's international against Bangladesh will raise the profile of the game both back home and among the kids from Asian families here, traditionally strangers to English football in any significant number.

India have a footballing history dating back to the 19th century, and some Bengali club sides boasted crowds of 100,000 in the Sixties, but the game is very much a minor sport there today and their fledgling professional league is only two years old.

But they have come a long way since they narrowly lost to France in the 1948 Olympics playing bare-footed. Now that is hard. Ranked 115 in the world, their aim is World Cup qualification by the end of the decade, and the young side on show against Fulham played with many of the better modern traits. They lacked a cutting edge and physical presence, though, and Fulham, in Jean Tigana's first home game as their new manager, deserved to lead at the break after Karl Heinz Riedle had scored on the stroke of half-time.

Fulham fielded a strong side. India's only real star name was Bhaichung Bhutia. He plays in England for Bury and is India's first footballing export. But maybe more will follow. The game was well-supported, with Indian fans bearing their distinctive orange, green and white flags seeming to outnumber the Fulham faithful. India's presence at The Cottage represented a serious breakthrough for those supporting their tour, from the All India Football Association to football's anti-racist group Kick It Out.

The FA here have set up an Asians In Football working group and Mark Sudbury, who works on the project, said: 'People within football believe Asians are not interested in the game, and there are physical issues such as them being too slight. We are trying to break down those stereotypes. Football is the most popular sport among Asian youngsters in this country.'

Meanwhile, India's striker I.M. Vijayan produced one good save from Maik Taylor, but most of the action was at the other end. Riedle almost scored Fulham's second goal midway through the second half, as India appeared to tire of chasing the ball, and it needed an excellent save from Verender Singh to keep him out.

It all seemed to keep both sets of fans happy in a summery atmosphere alien to the harsh realities of the midweek winter football yet to come.

fields.headline: Clubs face 'homegrown quotas'
fields.trailText: European football may be allowed to introduce limits on the number of foreign players for the first time since the Bosman ruling - but only on players up to the age of 21.
fields.body:
European football may be allowed to introduce limits on the number of foreign players for the first time since the Bosman ruling - but only on players up to the age of 21.

Under the scheme, a significant percentage of a club's players under 21 would have to be homegrown youngsters who are eligible to play for that country's national team. For clubs in the UK, 'national' would mean anyone born in England, Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland.

The plan has been put forward during discussions between Uefa, Fifa and the European Union about how to tackle the growing influx of overseas players into European leagues, including the Premiership.

Negotiators have talked about setting the domestic-overseas ratio at 80-20. If that was adopted, clubs such as Arsenal or Chelsea would already have to have on their books four UK-born players under 21 for every overseas player of the same age they wanted to recruit.

The scheme is intended to force clubs to invest in nurturing homegrown young talent and curb their growing tendency continually to shop overseas. It is hoped that having had to rear plenty of young British talent, clubs would then continue to use them after they reached 21.

As well as a quota system for under-21s, the EU and football authorities are also discussing forcing buying clubs to pay transfer fees for young players who do move overseas as a way of compensating the selling clubs for developing them.

The plan combines both carrot and stick. The incentive for clubs would be a ready supply of cheaply- produced homegrown players whose presence would save them spending huge sums on foreign stars. The double disincentive to recruiting youngsters from abroad would be the transfer fee involved and obligation to have four homegrown players already at the club.

If it goes ahead, this scheme will kill off Uefa's hope of persuading the EU to agree a special legislative 'protocol' letting sport as a whole opt out of its strict laws governing the free movement of labour. EU sources say Uefa's demand has no chance of success.

As The Observer revealed on 2 July, such a protocol would let Uefa require clubs to field at least six homegrown players so they are 'properly representative' of their country. Uefa privately admit that plan may well fail due to lack of political support within the EU.

Restricting the number of young foreigners may be the best deal football can secure. An EU source said: 'A protocol or directive along these lines could recognise and reward the special social role which clubs can play in communities through the development of young players. Such a policy would fit within the EU's social dimension but would not let football go back to the pre-Bosman situation. This is as far as we are prepared to go.'

Brendan Batson, deputy general secretary of the Professional Footballers Association, welcomed the plan. 'Anything that encourages or forces clubs to develop their own homegrown youngsters, rather than looking overseas, has to be good news.

'We will have to see what talent comes out of clubs' [youth] academies. But clubs will be putting money down the drain if they invest in academies but then the manager looks for the quick-fix by buying abroad.'

Whether clubs with many overseas stars, such as Chelsea, will agree with Batson is debatable. But the PFA knows a compromise is inevitable.

Batson conceded that the campaign for a full-blown protocol - which is backed by Fifpro, the association of players' unions - was 'facing an uphill struggle'.

Sports Minister Kate Hoey agreed the EU-Uefa plan was worth exploring, saying: 'Something has to be done about the pressures which the growing number of overseas players coming into the country are creating. If it means that there is some sort of halfway house protocol to allow a ratio of homegrown to foreign young players, then so be it.'

fields.headline: Getty finds satisfaction
fields.standfirst: The reclusive multi-millionaire has fallen in love with the most English of games
fields.trailText: When one of the world's richest men - and certainly one of its most generous - invites you to be his guest, it's not an offer you want to turn down. When he's inviting you to his own cricketing Shangri-la, it's irresistible.
fields.body:
When one of the world's richest men - and certainly one of its most generous - invites you to be his guest, it's not an offer you want to turn down. When he's inviting you to his own cricketing Shangri-la, it's irresistible.

So it was last Sunday that I made for Wormsley Park, the magnificent 2,500-acre Oxfordshire estate of Sir Paul Getty, alias John Paul Getty II, the American-turned-Briton and son of the late oil billionaire. He was hosting the match between his own select XI and the MCC. This was definitely a red-ringed date in my diary.

Cricket in the Chilterns? Oh yes. This Getty venue is already becoming the stuff of legend, secluded behind the kind of security one would expect at such a family's private retreat. He has created a superb oval ground, carved partly out of a hillside, and it is only a few years since I was privileged to run up the Wormsley Park flag above the splendid thatched pavilion for the first time. You see Sir Paul (the address is formal now following his 1986 KBE and subsequent 1998 metamorphosis from American citizen to British subject) is a complete cricket nut.

Strange, perhaps, to think of a man whose wealth was estimated at £1.3 billion in the mid-Nineties to be so taken with this most English of games. But taken he is. Very taken indeed.

I can't honestly remember the first time I met Sir Paul but I knew of his fascination with the game long before he asked me to raise his standard above the pavilion for the first time when the ground opened. Yet his introduction to the game was somewhat bizarre.

It goes back, so he tells it, some years when he owned a villa on the Caribbean island of Mustique and Rolling Stone Mick Jagger was one of his near neighbours. Jagger's love of cricket is well known and he would have the videos of England's Test matches flown in to the island long before satellites made such steam-engine technology obsolete. At the time, Getty was suffering from a serious bout of insomnia, so Jagger suggested he might get some satisfaction, so to speak, by spending the wee small hours watching some top class cricket.

Once hooked, it was inevitable that Sir Paul would make a big impact. This, remember, is the man who has seen fit to give away some £140 million of his fortune, according to some shrewd observers. He tells the story of a request from an African who wrote complaining that he was always sacked from jobs because he suffered from sleeping sickness. He asked Getty for £1m, and it may not be apocryphal that a cheque was duly despatched.

Causes closer to his adopted home have benefited greatly. New works for the National Gallery? £30m? No problem, in fact let's make it £50m. The British Film Institute? Here's £20m. Cricket was not forgotten. Before concentrating on his own oval, the new Mound Stand at Lord's was underpinned by £2m worth of Getty largesse.

Last Sunday's slice of generous hospitality began with drinks for guests on arrival late morning: Pimms, Buck's fizz or Champagne. Sir Paul emerged later to greet players and guests. He is a lovely man and I was saddened to see him watching the action in a wheelchair. I knew he had been poorly recently but his determination to be a lively host remains undimmed and he joined my wife, Veronica, and I for a chat. There was only one subject: cricket.

There could be nothing else on the agenda when other great companions were around this charming ground, with its thatched scoreboard complementing the pavilion, its majestic playing area meticulously prepared and picturesque marquees for the guests.

There was Keith Miller, my old Aussie sparring partner and great mate. He was a sporting god in his pomp and he lived hard and played hard - harder than he like to let on in the middle. He was a terrific bowler, as fast as anyone when he let his quick one go, and a very dangerous batsman. He could turn a game with bat or ball in just a few overs.

Our paths first crossed in 1953 - the final Test at The Oval when England won back the Ashes - but I always remind him of the Lord's Test in the 1956 series when I got him out in both innings. For his part, he reminded me (again) of his 260-odd for the Aussies against the Combined Services when I was in the RAF. I remember it too. I marked out my run-up at the start of the innings only to be told by some Colonel Blimp that I'd not been told I was bowling. I rather lost interest after that and at one point I sat on the sightscreen. The colonel reprimanded me at the end of the game and said I'd never play for Combined Services again. 'Too right,' I replied. 'I'm getting my discharge papers tomorrow.'

Keith was a giant of a player, so I'd been concerned to hear that he was using a frame to help him walk - even if he is an old man of 80 now. I need not have worried as he was walking well, aided only by a stick. Age does creep up on us all, however, and I felt mine when chatting to another guest, Sir Richard Hadlee. I recalled that I'd played for Yorkshire against his father, Walter, who skippered the 1949 Kiwis. Richard's nickname is 'Paddles' because of his huge feet.

There was Ted Dexter, a great mate, and his wife Suzie; Colin Ingleby-Mackenzie stopped to chat - he never changes, a big loveable, affable bear of a man. Like Keith and myself, he probably finds some aspects of today's game a little foreign_ even our host, Sir Paul, is in that club.

Miller, for one, does not understand this era of helmets and arm and chest protectors, not to mention £500,000-a-year cricketers. But on this Sunday afternoon at Wormsley Park, all that is forgotten. For Sir Paul lets it be known that the England - and the game - he fell in love with is not necessarily the 21st century version.

This ground, he tells me, is a joy to him. It reeks of old England. To me, it is like a Tardis, transporting me back to the days of playing in front of stately homes or in some noble lord's grounds. I'm taken back to playing on Lord Scarborough's estate. It's not just the face of old pal Brian Johnson wrought into the weather vane atop the pavilion; not just the Pimms. It's the people, the old friends, the striped blazers and dazzling, colourful summer dresses. It is Old England, brought to us on a plate by a 67-year-old child of San Francisco.

No wonder Getty says: 'It's probably true that the Britain I love is not the Britain which exists today. But it is still closer to that than anything else.'

It's a reflection that suggests his contentment with his British way of life after years of well-chronicled mid-life excess. He spent years in Italy after leaving his father's business and, if rum was his favourite tipple, then many other temptations eventually prompted him to seek sanctuary and cleansing in the London Clinic. Stability with his third wife, Victoria, has reached a new, high plane on the Wormsley estate.

His generosity also peels back layers of apparent contradictions. He has confessed to being a great admirer of Margaret Thatcher and enjoyed the company of fellow cricket lover John Major, yet he was quick to write a cheque for £100,000 to support the striking miners during their 1984 conflict with the Thatcher government.

He bridles at suggestions that it takes big Getty bucks to bring cricketing greats to play at his paradise in the Chilterns. Pay them? Not at all. Their reward is a good lunch (beef wellington), a hot shower and a clean towel.

And then it's over. Sir Paul's side wins by three wickets, boosted by a Graham Gooch century. My wife and I head back for the Yorkshire Dales and, as I'm driving, I've ignored the Pimms and bubbly. As for Sir Paul, it's clear that he enjoys the company of cricketers. He had the 1997 Australians here - he was overheard describing that as 'the greatest day of my life' - hosted the Sri Lankans last year and the West Indians will be coming to play soon. He genuinely likes the men who play this game - and how the game is played: 'It is so much more than a game_ It's the surroundings as well. I love it all. I think that's what sets cricket apart. There is a whole way of life about it which I adore. And I like cricketers. Not because they all have names with four initials - they come from all walks of life and then tend to be wonderful people.'

I drink to that when I can - when I'm out of my car and back in Yorkshire later that night with a bag of fish and chips, washed down by a glass of wine at last. I'd been to a different world - but a wonderful one.

I can't honestly remember the first time I met Sir Paul but I knew of his fascination with the game long before he asked me to raise his standard above the pavilion for the first time when the ground opened. Yet his introduction to the game was somewhat bizarre. It goes back, so he tells it, some years when he owned a villa on the Caribbean island of Mustique and Rolling Stone Mick Jagger was one of his near neighbours. Jagger's love of cricket is well known and he would have the videos of England's Test matches flown in to the island long before satellites made such steam-engine technology obsolete. At the time, Getty was suffering from a serious bout of insomnia, so Jagger suggested he might get some satisfaction, so to speak, by spending the wee small hours watching some top class cricket. Once hooked, it was inevitable that Sir Paul would make a big impact. This, remember, is the man who has seen fit to give away some £140 million of his fortune, according to some shrewd observers. He tells the story of a request from an African who wrote complaining that he was always sacked from jobs because he suffered from sleeping sickness. He asked Getty for £1m, and it may not be apocryphal that a cheque was duly despatched. Causes closer to his adopted home have benefited greatly. New works for the National Gallery? £30m? No problem, in fact let's make it £50m. The British Film Institute? Here's £20m. Cricket was not forgotten. Before concentrating on his own oval, the new Mound Stand at Lord's was underpinned by £2m worth of Getty largesse. Last Sunday's slice of generous hospitality began with drinks for guests on arrival late morning: Pimms, Buck's fizz or Champagne. Sir Paul emerged later to greet players and guests. He is a lovely man and I was saddened to see him watching the action in a wheelchair. I knew he had been poorly recently but his determination to be a lively host remains undimmed and he joined my wife, Veronica, and I for a chat. There was only one subject: cricket. There could be nothing else on the agenda when other great companions were around this charming ground, with its thatched scoreboard complementing the pavilion, its majestic playing area meticulously prepared and picturesque marquees for the guests. There was Keith Miller, my old Aussie sparring partner and great mate. He was a sporting god in his pomp and he lived hard and played hard - harder than he like to let on in the middle. He was a terrific bowler, as fast as anyone when he let his quick one go, and a very dangerous batsman. He could turn a game with bat or ball in just a few overs. Our paths first crossed in 1953 - the final Test at The Oval when England won back the Ashes - but I always remind him of the Lord's Test in the 1956 series when I got him out in both innings. For his part, he reminded me (again) of his 260-odd for the Aussies against the Combined Services when I was in the RAF. I remember it too. I marked out my run-up at the start of the innings only to be told by some Colonel Blimp that I'd not been told I was bowling. I rather lost interest after that and at one point I sat on the sightscreen. The colonel reprimanded me at the end of the game and said I'd never play for Combined Services again. 'Too right,' I replied. 'I'm getting my discharge papers tomorrow.' Keith was a giant of a player, so I'd been concerned to hear that he was using a frame to help him walk - even if he is an old man of 80 now. I need not have worried as he was walking well, aided only by a stick. Age does creep up on us all, however, and I felt mine when chatting to another guest, Sir Richard Hadlee. I recalled that I'd played for Yorkshire against his father, Walter, who skippered the 1949 Kiwis. Richard's nickname is 'Paddles' because of his huge feet. There was Ted Dexter, a great mate, and his wife Suzie; Colin Ingleby-Mackenzie stopped to chat - he never changes, a big loveable, affable bear of a man. Like Keith and myself, he probably finds some aspects of today's game a little foreign_ even our host, Sir Paul, is in that club. Miller, for one, does not understand this era of helmets and arm and chest protectors, not to mention £500,000-a-year cricketers. But on this Sunday afternoon at Wormsley Park, all that is forgotten. For Sir Paul lets it be known that the England - and the game - he fell in love with is not necessarily the 21st century version. This ground, he tells me, is a joy to him. It reeks of old England. To me, it is like a Tardis, transporting me back to the days of playing in front of stately homes or in some noble lord's grounds. I'm taken back to playing on Lord Scarborough's estate. It's not just the face of old pal Brian Johnson wrought into the weather vane atop the pavilion; not just the Pimms. It's the people, the old friends, the striped blazers and dazzling, colourful summer dresses. It is Old England, brought to us on a plate by a 67-year-old child of San Francisco. No wonder Getty says: 'It's probably true that the Britain I love is not the Britain which exists today. But it is still closer to that than anything else.' It's a reflection that suggests his contentment with his British way of life after years of well-chronicled mid-life excess. He spent years in Italy after leaving his father's business and, if rum was his favourite tipple, then many other temptations eventually prompted him to seek sanctuary and cleansing in the London Clinic. Stability with his third wife, Victoria, has reached a new, high plane on the Wormsley estate. His generosity also peels back layers of apparent contradictions. He has confessed to being a great admirer of Margaret Thatcher and enjoyed the company of fellow cricket lover John Major, yet he was quick to write a cheque for £100,000 to support the striking miners during their 1984 conflict with the Thatcher government. He bridles at suggestions that it takes big Getty bucks to bring cricketing greats to play at his paradise in the Chilterns. Pay them? Not at all. Their reward is a good lunch (beef wellington), a hot shower and a clean towel. And then it's over. Sir Paul's side wins by three wickets, boosted by a Graham Gooch century. My wife and I head back for the Yorkshire Dales and, as I'm driving, I've ignored the Pimms and bubbly. As for Sir Paul, it's clear that he enjoys the company of cricketers. He had the 1997 Australians here - he was overheard describing that as 'the greatest day of my life' - hosted the Sri Lankans last year and the West Indians will be coming to play soon. He genuinely likes the men who play this game - and how the game is played: 'It is so much more than a game_ It's the surroundings as well. I love it all. I think that's what sets cricket apart. There is a whole way of life about it which I adore. And I like cricketers. Not because they all have names with four initials - they come from all walks of life and then tend to be wonderful people.' I drink to that when I can - when I'm out of my car and back in Yorkshire later that night with a bag of fish and chips, washed down by a glass of wine at last. I'd been to a different world - but a wonderful one.

fields.headline: Things to do
fields.trailText: Enjoy a day of ups and downs | Flight fantastic | Calypso beat
fields.body:
Enjoy a day of ups and downs

Watch your knuckles turn white on the world's longest rollercoaster at Lightwater Valley, Ripon, North Yorkshire. Young daredevils anxious to prove their mettle can try the Viper or the Heatwave, while younger or more gentle souls can entertain themselves on the Ladybird or the Toadhole. 10am-5pm every day. Prices range from free for those under one metre tall to £12.50 for the loftier family members. 01765 635 368

Flight fantastic
Blackpool Kidz Megafest welcomes the Red Arrows Display team today as the RAF swoop along the seafront between North and Central Piers. Let's hope they watch out for the tower. From 12.30pm. Free. Phone 01253 478 222.

Calypso beat
Cardiff goes Caribbean at the MAS Carnival on Mermaid Quay on 29 July. Entertainment includes a costumed parade featuring masks and giant mobile sculptures. The city's Oval Basin sees the culmination of the festival with DJs and a fireworks display. 8pm-11pm. Free. Phone 029 2087 3936.

Maze crazy
Find your way through a brand-new maze at Maize Maze, Byrkley Park Centre, Burton upon Trent, Staffordshire. The maze is cut into a growing field of maize and opens on 25 July. Costumed staff, treasure trails and quizzes will help people find their way around and there will be something to nibble if you get lost. £2.50. 10.30-5pm every day. Phone 01283 716 467.

Let's glow
Special gas that glows in the dark will be pumped into 26 hot air balloons that will rise over Lower Gardens, Bournemouth for a Balloon Night Glow on 27 July. There will be musical accompaniment to the spectacle which is part of a programme of summer events. Free. From dusk. Phone 0906 802 0234.

Glasto for kids
Now it's the children's turn to have fun in Glastonbury's rolling fields, or at least in Abbey Park Playground. The Glastonbury Children's Festival 2000 takes place over four days from 28 July and features 20 performances in the theatre marquee and open air stage, as well as a velcro wall, rides for younger children and circus workshops. From 10.30am-5pm every day. Adults £3, children £5. Phone 01458 832925.

Day to treasure
Celebrate National Archaeology Day today with a find of your own at Worcestershire County Museum, Kidderminster. The County Archaeologist will be on hand to help with the clean ing and identification of any treasures that your children want to bring along, while a giant sandpit will be full of hidden coins so that everyone is guaranteed to take home some buried treasure. Adults £2.20, children £1.10, members of the Young Archaeologists Club go free. 2pm-5pm. Phone 01299 250 416.
