By stepping down, he is allowing a contest to take place which, he hopes, will end the squabbling. Alex knows his Burns and about the best-laid schemes of mice and men. Neil may have more going for him than it seems, but I fancy not.

fields.headline: High noon for Swinney
fields.standfirst: Alex Salmond's surprise decision to quit as SNP leader leaves the way open for a showdown with the Jim Sillars camp.  Arnold Kemp reports
fields.trailText: When John Swinney comes home to Blairgowrie tomorrow morning after a holiday in England, he will be taking one thing at a time. He is the favourite, of bookies and pundits alike, to win the leadership of the SNP in succession to Alex Salmond.
fields.body:
When John Swinney comes home to Blairgowrie tomorrow morning after a holiday in England, he will be taking one thing at a time. He is the favourite, of bookies and pundits alike, to win the leadership of the SNP in succession to Alex Salmond.

But Swinney, 36, a methodical man with an immense capacity for hard work, believes in due process. And so, he told The Observer last week, he will consult colleagues and friends before deciding to take on Alex Neil, 48, who has already thrown his hat into the ring for the election, which is to be held at the party's annual conference in Inverness in September.

Last week Salmond, who stunned the Scottish political world with his announcement on Monday that after 10 years as leader he had decided to 'hand on the torch while it was burning brightly', was in relaxed and cheerful mood. Yesterday he went to the Open Championship at St Andrews, continuing to assert that behind his decision to stand down there was no hidden agenda. He challenged the Scottish press, its ears cocked for the rattle of skeletons in the cupboard, to investigate his affairs as thoroughly as it liked. There was nothing to find, he insisted.

He will continue as an MSP and will undertake any job the party asks him to do. But his immediate aim is go back to his old métier - he is a professional economist - of developing the party's economic policies. He believes that a consensus is building, among Tories and Liberal Democrats, as well as Nationalists, that the Scottish Parliament should have fiscal autonomy.

Yet many analysts think that behind his decision lies a curious and interesting subtext. They argue that the leadership contest Salmond has so suddenly provoked is a showdown with his old enemy, Jim Sillars. But the two old gunfighters will stay in the saloon while their proxies fight it out on the street.

Their enmity, a running sore in the party since 1990 when Salmond beat Margaret Ewing for the leadership and Sillars stood aside, broke into the open last week. Sun columnist Sillars greeted the leader's departure with rare biliousness. 'I will not join in the hypocritical praise that will be heaped upon Alex Salmond now that he has snuffed out his political life at the top. He was never big enough for the times. He was nothing but a manipulator, and remains so right to the end.'

Sillars's wife, the MSP Margo MacDonald, who has for long made little secret of her dislike of Salmond, also believes that the retiring leader has underestimated the resentment that has built up among ordinary party members. 'They are fed up with autocratic decisions being imposed on them,' she said last week. 'The party does not like being bounced into policy positions.'

She believes that Neil has a fighting chance of winning. The leadership, she says, has also underestimated the support Neil has built up by indefatigably cultivating the branches up and down the country. Even his celebrated gaffe - when he compared George Robertson, then Shadow Scottish Secretary, to 'Lord Haw Haw' at a party conference - will not hurt him. 'It never really bothered party members anyway,' she said with a chuckle, though to many observers the comment, re-run on television last week as soon as Neil announced he was standing, continues to pose a question about his judgment.

Neil is nothing if not a Sillars acolyte, his constant sidekick from the days when Sillars first came to prominence in Ayrshire as a rising Labour star, through the brief and traumatic life of the breakaway Scottish Labour Party in 1975, to both men's final migration into the SNP. He has been policy vice-convener since 1994 and is MSP for Central Scotland .

Criticism of Salmond centres on the election campaign for the Scottish Parliament last May. He is accused of making serious misjudgments and arriving at key decisions without adequate consultation. Among his errors, his critics say, were his decision to denounce the Nato action in Kosovo, to campaign on the slogan of 'Scotland's penny' (reversing Labour's tax cut) and, when the going got tough, to waste the party's money on a tabloid paper that 'nobody read'.

At last year's conference MacDonald told members that some people had 'lost the plot'. Forget buzzwords like modernisation, she said: the real issue, neglected by the leadership, was independence.

It was at the conference, too, that Salmond's problems with party treasurer Ian Blackford surfaced. Blackford implicitly held Salmond accountable for the party's mounting debts - recently put at £400,000 but now being paid off - and explicitly denounced his 'dereliction of duty' in failing to make independence the party's top pri ority. In June the party executive passed a vote of no confidence in Blackford in his absence. Salmond's friends saw in the episode the hand of Sillars once again. 'Blackford,' said one last week, 'is just a Sillars cypher.' This skirmish, as much as anything, seems to have convinced Salmond that the time had come to crush the Sillars faction.

This interpretation is lent weight by Salmond's continuing buoyancy. This is not a man tired of life or of politics. His predecessor, Gordon Wilson, quit after 10 years in the job because the workload in his Dundee legal practice was overwhelming him.

Wilson, now an elder statesman on the party's National Council, recollected last week: 'Things which were once interesting and exciting became drudgery.' His verdict on Salmond is a generous one. 'The absence of his debating gifts, for example, will be a real loss.'

Yet Wilson also acknowledges that the party has been given the chance to reassess its constitutional options as the general election app-roaches. It will be fighting all 72 seats and more than half the candidates have already been chosen. But its six Westminster MPs have all chosen Holyrood instead.

Strategists believe that in its eagerness to establish its credibility in the Scottish Parliament the party has allowed its core message to become muted. The manifesto for the Scottish elections last year, for example, made no mention of seeking to expand the Parliament's powers.

Such anxieties spread beyond the Sillarsite faction. Matters came to the boil at a National Council in March when a motion sponsored by Salmond - that the party should campaign at elections for a referendum on independence - was passed but by a majority narrow enough to amount to something of a rebuff. The motion was seen as a dilution of the party's traditional view that a majority of seats at Westminster or votes at Holyrood would be a mandate for independence.

The leadership has since changed tack and modified its rhetoric to reassert the core aims. Expanding the Parliament's powers is now a key theme. But Swinney's friends say he is also anxious not to frighten off the so-called 'soft vote' - people who might choose the SNP as an alternative to Labour or Tory without necessarily buying the goal of independence.

Salmond has not publicly endorsed Swinney, though clearly he would be very comfortable with his leadership. But friends say he could live with other choices - even with Roseanna Cunningham, the lawyer, Star Wars fanatic and long-time republican who is making a considerable reputation for herself as chairman of the Parliament's justice committee.

Salmond, his friends say, continues to believe that one day Nicola Sturgeon, 30, will lead the party. The MSP is parliamentary spokesman on children and education. Observers say her performance has so far been slightly disappointing but Salmond has boundless faith in her.

Salmond likes a punt on the horses - but he is canny too. He is fond of saying that his Herald racing column has put him right up among Britain's top newspaper tipsters. On Swinney, you might say, he has placed an each-way bet.

fields.headline: I approved Adams bug - Mowlam
fields.standfirst: TV confession of tracking device on Sinn Fein car during peace talks
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam triggered fresh controversy yesterday by admitting that she approved the bugging of a car used by Sinn Fein leaders during peace talks.
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam triggered fresh controversy yesterday by admitting that she approved the bugging of a car used by Sinn Fein leaders during peace talks.

The former Northern Ireland Secretary defended the operation during the recording of a television chat show to be broadcast tomorrow night. It was condemned by Gerry Adams, president of Sinn Fein, as a 'hugely serious breach of faith' when the tracking device was found by republicans last year.

But while the confirmation that she authorised the bugging will not surprise anyone involved, it breaks a long-held convention that politicians do not comment in public on security matters.

Tories yesterday accused her of an 'appalling' indiscretion, while republican sources suggested she could be called on to defend her actions in court.

The bug was discovered inside the body of a Ford Mondeo loaned by a woman supporter to Adams and Martin McGuinness - education minister in the devolved Northern Ireland executive - amid speculation that their driver was the real surveillance target.

Asked about the bugging on the pre-recorded BBC1 show You Only Live Once , hosted by Nick Hancock, Mowlam said it was part of efforts to break a deadlock on decommissioning, adding: 'Lives were being lost. A lot was done to make sure we knew what was going on.'

Although the Government has always refused even to confirm that British intelligence services were involved, it was clear at the time such a politically sensitive operation could only have been cleared at the highest levels within the Northern Ireland Office.

But it is thought to be the first time a secretary of state has discussed the bugging of political opponents so openly.

A Sinn Fein spokesman said her admission was 'disappointing but not surprising. There can be little doubt that this was part of a "securocrat" agenda which is still intent on subverting the peace process.

'Bad faith is a trait which appears inherent in the British Government particularly when dealing with Ireland,' he added.

The Observer understands that the original owner of the bugged car is taking legal action against the Northern Ireland Office, arguing that her privacy was breached. Sinn Fein sources say they are looking forward to the prospect of Mowlam having to explain herself in court.

Meanwhile, the Shadow Northern Ireland Secretary Andrew Mackay accused Mowlam of appearing less than statesmanlike. 'These are delicate security matters which are also politically sensitive, so I am appalled that Mo Mowlam has seen fit to blab on a television chat show. It would have been wiser particularly at a time when the process is moving on, for her to remain silent.'

Mowlam makes a point of appearing on unorthodox programmes, arguing that politicians need to reach out to voters who would switch off from a dry current affairs show: her candour and warmth also suit chat shows.

Her recent appearance on the camp Channel 4 show So Graham Norton , giving away a bearded collie in a 'dog wedding' and telling bawdy jokes, went down a storm with viewers but raised the odd eyebrow in Westminster.

Chat shows carry pitfalls for unwary politicians: former Northern Ireland minister Peter Brooke was unwisely inveigled into singing My Darling Clementine on Ireland's The Late, Late Show on the day of the 1992 Teebane massacre in which seven people were killed.

webTitle: Time to sharpen the meat cleaver

fields.headline: Time to sharpen the meat cleaver
fields.trailText: Question: Would Michael Green of Carlton Communications have walked so briskly away from a merger with United News and Media if he had thought his first encounter would be with Granada Media's Charles Allen wielding a meat cleaver (borrowed from the Granada Compass kitchens, no doubt)?
fields.body:
Question: Would Michael Green of Carlton Communications have walked so briskly away from a merger with United News and Media if he had thought his first encounter would be with Granada Media's Charles Allen wielding a meat cleaver (borrowed from the Granada Compass kitchens, no doubt)?

While Mr Green likes a walk on the wild side, he is a man whose passion for his business means he would rather, given the choice, be carried out of it in a box. Quite a luxurious casket, of course, probably with platinum handles. So while one cannot rule out the possibility of a hostile Carlton carve-up coming from the Granada camp, it would appear to be hugely unlikely. First on the menu is the United News and Media assets.

The only question here is whether Lord Clive Hollick and Mr Allen will be able to strike a deal on individual assets, or whether Granada will take out the whole shooting match - complete with Philip Gould's consultancy (the home of the amazing leaking memo is partially owned by United's NOP) - and sell off the parts it finds less edible. The answer to this, like the rest of the ITV puzzle, rests entirely with the logic of pricing and strategy.

Almost two years ago Allen was quite open about the possibility of Granada buying United News and Media. He made it clear then that he viewed a hostile take over of Carlton as a bridge too far, unless legislation were to be changed to allow Granada to hang on to both London franchises, and that will not happen yet. Ultimately Allen is nothing if not consistent, and he may be giving out signals that all options are equally balanced, but it is a useful negotiating tactic to keep United's prices as reasonable as possible.

What Granada may seek to sell from United would probably be everything except the TV assets, which it would divvy up with Green and the RTL Group, selling the HTV licence to the former and the Channel 5 stake to the latter. Allen may hang on to a bit of the online expertise within United: the pooled assets under the Xilerate banner fit with his interest in the internet, and some of it may even pep up the far-from-convincing g-whizz.net - Granada's own online development.

As for the Express titles, there is little chance Granada will want the 'vanity publishing unit' as one executive scathingly called it, but a number of others may want to examine the possibilities of owning a mid-market centre-left tabloid. There are plenty of people keen for a challenge. Trinity Mirror would be the best placed company to take it on and make it work - politically correct, well-resourced and with some of the editorial skills to take on the Mail . The only snag is that chief executive Phil Graf is worryingly sane when it comes to buying assets; he may be beaten by the big chequebook brigade. Step forward the Barclay brothers.

Database and information businesses, of which United has plenty, would attract any number of buyers, though Hollick himself, if he wants to remain in business, may have to decide whether he wishes to start afresh or take part of the company with him.

Given that the disappearance of United News and Media is the more likely scenario, what of Carlton Communications? It is vulnerable, it has slimmed down and focused itself for the merger that never was, it is attractive, but only to a company that wants to mire itself in the high politics of British terrestrial television. BSkyB can't just yet; French state broadcaster TF1 is terrified by the prospect. Vivendi, the French sewage-to-pay-TV conglomerate has just played the python swallowing the goat and bought Seagram. Now it needs a bit of a lie down.

Carlton, should it stay unmolested, has time to reorder its long-term strategy. Its ultimate destiny may still be as part of Granada, should the rules relax sufficiently, but knowing you might die eventually is always better than knowing the world will end in 15 minutes. Green may yet have time to think his way out of the box.

emily.bell@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Have a really ghostly time
fields.standfirst: Want to meet a friendly, or unfriendly, spirit?  Robin Barton on the spookiest places to visit
fields.trailText: Want to meet a friendly, or unfriendly, spirit? Robin Barton on the spookiest places to visit.
fields.body:
As Harry Potter fever sweeps the country get into the spirit of things with our guide to who is haunting what and why...

Dunstanburgh Castle, Northumberland

Who? A knight, Sir Guy the Seeker, and a maiden.

Where? The cliffhanging ruins of fourteenth-century Dunstanburgh, still hinting of its original grandeur, can be found near Alnwick. It is open daily from 10am to 6pm (adults £1.80, children 90p). Tel: 01665 576 231.

Why? The story goes that when Sir Guy rode up to the castle he found the drawbridge lowered and a lantern leading him to an ornate chamber in which a beautiful woman was trapped. He was offered the choice of a sword or a horn to help her and chose to summon help with the horn - at which point the vision vanished. His ghost can be seen lamenting the wrong decision, while the maiden still waits in the ruins for rescue.

Whitby Abbey, Yorkshire

Who? Two nuns, one of whom is St Hilda, the founder.

Where? The thirteenth- century abbey was built on the site of St Hilda's religious community, dating from 657, which also included the poet and monk Caedmon. The ruins were also Bram Stoker's inspiration for Dracula. Open daily from 10am to 6pm (adults £1.70, children 90p). Tel: 01947 603 568.

Why? St Hilda's shrouded ghost has been seen in one of the windows, but a more tragic story is attached to the other ghost, believed to be Constance de Beverley. She broke her vows by falling for a knight named Marmion and as punishment she was led to cell, bricked in and left to die.

Scarborough Castle,
Yorkshire

Who? Piers Gaveston, Edward II's lover.

Where? The site has been strategically important since the Iron Age, but became a royal stronghold in the north in the twelfth century. Open daily from 10am to 6pm (adults £2.30, children £1.20). Tel: 01723 372451.

Why? The Earl of Warwick drove Gaveston to the castle, and beheaded him. The headless ghost still haunts the remains and is said to try to push sightseers off the castle battlements.

Okehampton Castle, Devon

Who? 'Wicked' Lady Howard.

Where? Another set of ruins, this time of the largest castle in Devon, but also with decidedly uneerie woodland walks and picnic spots. Open daily 10am to 6pm (adults £2.30, children £1.20). Tel: 01837 52844

Why? Lady Howard is alleged to have murdered all four of her husbands and then is supposed to have built a coach from their bones. Appropriately, it is also said that she employed a headless coachman and headless horses and rides to the castle every night. Watch out for the one-eyed dog.

Blickling Hall, Norfolk

Who? Anne Boleyn.

Where? Blickling, a superb Jacobean house with parkland and a lake, is open Wednesday to Sunday from 1pm to 4.30pm (£6.50; garden only, £3.70). Tel: 01263 738030.

Why? Anne Boleyn spent much of her childhood in a medieval house around which Blickling Hall was built. Rumour suggests she still returns to the place where she was happy.

Buckland Abbey, Devon

Who? Sir Francis Drake.

Where? Drake secretly bought Buckland from a rival, Sir Richard Grenville, just before setting off with the Armada. It is open daily except Thursdays (adults £4.50, family £11.20). Tel: 01822 853 607.

Why? Drake seems to have inspired many supernatural stories. On display inside the house, along with banners from the Golden Hind, is his drum which is said to sound whenever England is in danger. The last time it was supposed to have been heard was when the German fleet were gathering during the First World War.

Magdalen College, Oxford

Who? Various black-clad figures.

Where? The college, on The High in Oxford, was founded in 1458 by Bishop Waynflete and its original site included a thirteenth-century hospital and burial ground.

Why? It easy to be sceptical, but it appears that these are not apparitions of the alcoholic variety. The most recent manifestation was in February 1987 when a resting language student was woken by the sound of mysterious mutterings and saw the locked door of her room open. A presence then leant over her. The Rev Jeffrey John even felt it was necessary to bless her room. In 1968 a student walking towards the Colonnade arches saw a silent gliding figure, but inside the cowls of its gown there was no face and it vanished in brighter light. Magdalen College is open during the summer from Noon to 6pm (adults £2, children £1) Tel: 01865 276 000.

Meanwhile, in Scotland...

It was at the grimly titled Bloody Stone at Harta
Corrie on the Isle of Skye that a fierce battle was
fought between the MacLeods and the MacDonalds in
1395. People have since reported spectral warriors
fighting among the rocks. The ancestral home of the
MacLeod clan on the island, Dunvegan Castle , is
itself closely associated with fairy legend. A male
clansman is once supposed to have married a fairy,
who gave the family an enchanted flag, which can still
be seen at the castle. The castle is open daily from
10am to 5.30pm (adults £6.50, children £3, family
ticket £15) and boat tours to the loch's seal colony are
also available. Tel: 01470 521 206 or www.dunvegan.com

The Big Grey Man is mountaineering's own
supernatural legend and is old enough to have a Gaelic
name, Am Fear Leath Mor. He haunts Britain's second
highest mountain, Ben Macdhui in the Cairngorms.
Climbers since 1831 have reported the sound of his
footsteps, then feelings of intense melancholy and
despair, followed by terror.

One of Scotland's busiest ghosts is the bearded
sailor who has been sighted walking Sandwood Bay
near Cape Wrath. But the most haunted place is north
of the border is undoubtedly Glamis Castle , which
has witnessed a catalogue of misfortune. Glamis is
Scotland's oldest inhabited castle, home to the
Bowes-Lyon family, the Earls of Strathmore, (the
Queen Mother was born a Bowes-Lyon). In 1034 King
Malcolm II was murdered and bled to death in the
castle (the story is told in Macbeth). The Grey Lady
haunting the corridors is Lady Glamis, burned at the
stake by James V on the grounds she was a witch.
The third Earl of Strathmore was notorious gambler. He
was in the middle of a game with the Earl of Crawford
when he was advised that Saturday night was about to
turn into Sunday morning. He replied that they would
play on and the devil could join them if he wished - the
devil took them up on the offer and condemned them to
play cards until Judgment Day. Rumours persist of a
secret room near which the rattle of dice can be heard.
Glamis Castle (01307 840 393), north of Dundee, is
open daily from 10am to 5.30pm (adults £6, children
£3).

webTitle: Buoyant US giant eyes floundering British titles

fields.headline: Buoyant US giant eyes floundering British titles
fields.trailText: Is that blood that you see in the water? Are those sharks out in the bay? The short sharp season when newspaper editors take their holidays - after the parliamentary recess, before early September's relaunches - will be more than usually restless this year.
fields.body:
Is that blood that you see in the water? Are those sharks out in the bay? The short sharp season when newspaper editors take their holidays - after the parliamentary recess, before early September's relaunches - will be more than usually restless this year.

Consider, bloodily, the circulation figures for June (the ones they'll take to the beach with them). On the surface, not a lot is happening. But the heart of the matter is buried deeper in ABC statistics - in the listing of British and Irish sales at full cover price. No bulk buys, no cut-rate subscriptions: just cash going over the counter in core markets. And the fact here is that only two national dailies (the Sun and the FT) and one Sunday (The Observer) are selling more on this count than in June 1999. All those Euro 2000 tonnes of paper went for naught. Even Sport First lost 20 per cent of its circulation.

Some of the statistics come with a jolt. The Sunday Telegraph sells 80,000 fewer full-price copies than The Observer . The Independent on Sunday has dropped nearly 90,000 year on year, and the Independent 30,000. The Evening Standard, at 337,000, is down from 370,000, and probably writhing as Associated's own Metro freesheet cuts its arteries. (Is this a dagger I see before me? Or a Dacre?)

Of course, you can make too much of the Full Monty test. Most bargain copies are read by someone. A reader saving money for the moment isn't necessarily a defector when the price goes up again. This is business, not some higher morality play. But don't for a moment think the price war (broadly defined) is over: or that a downturn in the economy - abetted by further rises in newsprint costs - wouldn't be nasty.

Which brings us to the sharks, and two potential victims. One (thoughtfully selected for trawling the other day by the Sunday Times) is the barren little Independent fishing ground, which has netted very little - apart from some good journalism. Mr Tony O'Reilly, though, shows no sign of giving up. I'd expect more rejigs and investment there; struggle renewed.

But what about the Daily Express, Sunday Express and Daily Star? You don't have to invent turbulence under Blackfriars Bridge. It comes naturally as the great white whales of Granada, United and Carlton thrash around to decide who'll be the super-spouts of British commercial television.

Perm the takeover combinations, perm the analysts' predictions, and there are plenty of scenarios that put these papers up for sale. Every seller, however, needs a buyer. The Express package may still be unexcitingly profitable, but it continues to be a declining asset - the Sunday down 140,000 June on June (using the same full price formula) and the Daily Express and the Star showing smaller drops (47,000 and 2,000 or so respectively). Do any of the usual cast of characters fancy a burden like that?

The Barclay brothers are ritually mentioned; so are Trinity Mirror and the omnipresent Mohamed al-Fayed. It would be odd to see them all sit on their hands in such circumstances, and odd, too, to contemplate a silent Associated missing this moment of historic triumph.

Nevertheless: don't expect a rush. The two Expresses need pots more investment if Rosie Boycott's determined drive to create a fresher, younger, more liberal brand is to stand any chance of success. Abandoning that strategy makes no sense. Any purchaser must have her flair, guts and a deep pocket.

We're looking, in sum, for a big player who believes in newspapers as a serious business. What about one with nearly 300 UK titles (including 15 dailies)?

It's curious how Gannett, the American owner of Newsquest, avoids the headlines, but its second-quarter figures, fresh out of Arlington, Virginia, make sweet reading. Newspaper revenues 18 per cent up, just like operating cashflow and, by happenstance, ad revenue on USA Today . And last month it bought 21 dailies from Thomson for $1.125 billion and Central Newspapers, (including the Indianapolis Star and Arizona Republic) for $2.6bn.

Gannett has a huge appetite and much ambition. Does it fancy a Britain Today or Europe Today ? Would the Express be a good place to start?

The bizarre assumption in so many of the analyses of Granada, Carlton and United is that print and electronic media don't fit: ITV's new 'world force' will seemingly be screen-led first and always.

But that isn't a choice you'd find Gannett making. It owns 22 television stations in the US and they, like its newspapers, have their own interlocking websites. In the first six months of the year, these sites generated $28m in revenue. More than the beginning of something big.

The closer you look, the harder it becomes to see why the TV whales should harbour any doubts about blending print and electronic media. AOL increasingly wields its CNN news coverage and Time-Warner print resources like a bludgeon against the competition. Dotcom companies (as Frank Houston notes in the latest Columbia Journalism Review ) are now buying newspapers. IServed.com has just bought Stars and Stripes . Space.com has persuaded Hearst to launch a matching print magazine. Electronic magazines such as Slate and Salon are spawning their own TV shows.

Everything connects. Everywhere except, seemingly, Britain, where the sea lanes are too rigidly marked by old buoys and the sharks wouldn't dream of swimming laterally.

fields.headline: Finding common purpose
fields.standfirst:
Landmark decisions in the Shipman and Shayler cases reveal new attitude to free speech
British Secrecy in Question
fields.trailText: Anthony Lester on the courts' new attitude to free speech.
fields.body:
British judges have traditionally undervalued freedom of the press and of speech. That is why cases like Thalidomide (contempt of court), Spycatcher (breach of confidence), Harriet Harman (contempt of court), Tolstoy (libel damages), and Goodwin (journalist's refusal to disclose confidential source) were taken successfully to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. Until recently, only a tiny minority of British judges took free speech seriously. Today, the position is changing dramatically. Our courts, influenced by the European Court of Human Rights, are giving judgments based on a strong commitment to human rights.

Last week's landmark rulings in the Shipman and Shayler cases show how senior judges are protecting free speech more strongly on the eve of the coming into force of the Human Rights Act 1998 on 2 October. Their decisions mean that the Strasbourg Court will probably be less burdened with future British cases fettering freedom of information and public discussion.

In Shipman, the Divisional Court upheld a challenge by families of the victims, supported by the media, to the Secretary of State for Health's decision requiring an inquiry into the issues raised by Dr Harold Shipman's murder of 15 patients to be held in private. Lord Justice Kennedy found that the decision to sit in private was legally irrational and contravened the guarantee of free expression in Article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights because it constituted unjustified government interference with the free communication of information. He quoted from the Strasbourg Court's classic statement of principle that freedom of expression protects information and ideas that 'offend, shock or disturb'; that the exceptions to free expression 'must be narrowly interpreted and the necessity for any restrictions must be convincingly established'; and that it is incumbent on the press, in its vital role as public watchdog, to impart information and ideas on matters of public interest.

The Court treated the right to free expression, anchored in the European Convention, as also being a fundamental principle of the English common law. It ruled that there is a presumption that a public inquiry will proceed in public 'unless there are persuasive reasons for taking some other course'. Because the Minister, Alan Milburn, had failed to give persuasive reasons for excluding the press and the public, he had exceeded his lawful powers.

Judicial recognition of a positive right to free expression rooted in the common law was first made by the Law Lords in 1993 in the Derbyshire libel case. They decided that a government body cannot invoke libel law to vindicate its so-called 'governing reputation'. To allow public authorities to take up the sword of libel law to protect themselves against public criticism would have a 'chilling effect' on free speech. They emphasised that 'it is of the highest public importance that a government body should be open to uninhibited public criticism'. Their decision wove the Convention right into the fabric of English law, and recognised the fundamental importance of a free press in a democratic society.

This major shift in British judicial attitudes was influenced by the European Court's findings that the Law Lords had unnecessarily interfered with free expression by giving excessive weight to other competing rights and interests. European human rights law has had a tonic effect in prompting our courts to discover hitherto hidden potential in the common law.

Last year, in Reynolds' case (an alleged libel on the political reputation of Ireland's former Taoiseach), the Law Lords extended the common law protection of qualified privilege to media reporting of matters of public interest. English libel law has notoriously draconian features reflecting its origins in the seventeenth-century Court of Star Chamber. It puts the burden on the publisher to prove the truth of his allegations. The state of mind and conduct of the publisher are irrelevant unless he is able to claim that the publication was made on an occasion of privilege. In Reynolds, the Law Lords looked at this harsh law in the context of a constitutional or common-law right to free expression. They recognised that the media should be entitled to publish inaccurate information on matters of public interest, provided that they act fairly and reasonably in accordance with proper professional standards. The reasoning in Reynolds has been developed further in a brilliant judgment of the Court of Appeal of New Zealand given last month in Lange.

Again last year, in Simms, the Law Lords ruled that a blanket ban by the Home Office on interviews of prisoners by journalists was unlawful because it deprived prisoners of their basic and fundamental right free expression to gain access to justice through press reporting. They refused to follow the restrictive rulings of the American Supreme Court, Lord Steyn observing that the Supreme Court's approach of 'judicial deference to the view of prison authorities... does not accord with the approach under English law. It is at variance with the principle that only a pressing social need can defeat freedom of expression'. That is a striking observation. A decade ago the American Supreme Court's decisions on the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech were treated as too liberal to influence our law; today, in the area of prisoners' rights American constitutional law is treated as being too restrictive to meet more liberal British legal standards.

Last Thursday's judgment of the Court of Appeal in Shayler is a further example of the enlightened approach that will surely inform our courts' use of the Human Rights Act to protect basic civil rights and freedoms. The Observer and the Guardian are right to claim the judgment as a famous victory. In particular, the leading judgment of Lord Justice Judge is charmingly English, purporting to find the principles of the European Convention 'bred in the bone of the common law', and a part of 'the folk understanding of the community as a whole'. References to Dicey, Voltaire and the great eighteenth-century case of Entick v Carrington are invoked by Lord Justice Judge to lament the pitiful condition of the French under the Bourbons for their inferior status, without benefit of the glorious English constitution in King George III's reign. Vive l'Angleterre!

It also contains some well-deserved shafts of irony at the expense the luckless detective sergeant who expressed the belief that there had been a breach of the Official Secrets Act while knowing virtually nothing about the case.

What is really important about the Shayler judgment is the effective protection it gives to 'fundamental principles' and its emphasis on the need for the judge to be alert to the need to safeguard basic human rights and freedoms against inordinate and excessive claims by the state and its agents. The judgment identifies the risks of self-incrimination and of stifling newspaper investigation of the Shayler story as out- weighing the competing benefit of disclosure to the security services. In Lord Justice Judge's magisterial language: 'Inconvenient or embarrassing revelations, whether for the security services, or for public authorities, should not be suppressed. Legal proceedings directed towards the seizure of the working papers of an individual journalist or the premises of the newspaper or television programme publishing his or her reports, or the threat of such proceedings, tends to inhibit discussion. When a genuine investigation into possible corrupt or reprehensible activities by a public authority is being investigated by the media, compelling evidence would normally be needed to demonstrate that the public interest would be served by such proceedings. Otherwise, to the public disadvantage, legitimate enquiry and discussion and the safety valve of investigative journalism... would be discouraged perhaps stifled.'

British senior judges really are, in Jack Straw's phrase, 'Bringing Rights Home'. What a pity that the Home Secretary does not share their democratic values. His flawed measures, unnecessarily restricting public access to official information, and authorising the interception, surveillance and disclosure of journalistic material without a judicial warrant, will make it necessary for the judges to come to the rescue of British rights and freedoms.

 Lord Lester of Herne Hill QC is a human rights lawyer at Blackstone Chambers who has argued several of the free speech cases to which he refers in English courts and the European Court of Human Rights.

Last year, in Reynolds' case (an alleged libel on the political reputation of Ireland's former Taoiseach), the Law Lords extended the common law protection of qualified privilege to media reporting of matters of public interest. English libel law has notoriously draconian features reflecting its origins in the seventeenth-century Court of Star Chamber. It puts the burden on the publisher to prove the truth of his allegations. The state of mind and conduct of the publisher are irrelevant unless he is able to claim that the publication was made on an occasion of privilege. In Reynolds, the Law Lords looked at this harsh law in the context of a constitutional or common-law right to free expression. They recognised that the media should be entitled to publish inaccurate information on matters of public interest, provided that they act fairly and reasonably in accordance with proper professional standards. The reasoning in Reynolds has been developed further in a brilliant judgment of the Court of Appeal of New Zealand given last month in Lange. Again last year, in Simms, the Law Lords ruled that a blanket ban by the Home Office on interviews of prisoners by journalists was unlawful because it deprived prisoners of their basic and fundamental right free expression to gain access to justice through press reporting. They refused to follow the restrictive rulings of the American Supreme Court, Lord Steyn observing that the Supreme Court's approach of 'judicial deference to the view of prison authorities... does not accord with the approach under English law. It is at variance with the principle that only a pressing social need can defeat freedom of expression'. That is a striking observation. A decade ago the American Supreme Court's decisions on the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech were treated as too liberal to influence our law; today, in the area of prisoners' rights American constitutional law is treated as being too restrictive to meet more liberal British legal standards. Last Thursday's judgment of the Court of Appeal in Shayler is a further example of the enlightened approach that will surely inform our courts' use of the Human Rights Act to protect basic civil rights and freedoms. The Observer and the Guardian are right to claim the judgment as a famous victory. In particular, the leading judgment of Lord Justice Judge is charmingly English, purporting to find the principles of the European Convention 'bred in the bone of the common law', and a part of 'the folk understanding of the community as a whole'. References to Dicey, Voltaire and the great eighteenth-century case of Entick v Carrington are invoked by Lord Justice Judge to lament the pitiful condition of the French under the Bourbons for their inferior status, without benefit of the glorious English constitution in King George III's reign. Vive l'Angleterre! It also contains some well-deserved shafts of irony at the expense the luckless detective sergeant who expressed the belief that there had been a breach of the Official Secrets Act while knowing virtually nothing about the case. What is really important about the Shayler judgment is the effective protection it gives to 'fundamental principles' and its emphasis on the need for the judge to be alert to the need to safeguard basic human rights and freedoms against inordinate and excessive claims by the state and its agents. The judgment identifies the risks of self-incrimination and of stifling newspaper investigation of the Shayler story as out- weighing the competing benefit of disclosure to the security services. In Lord Justice Judge's magisterial language: 'Inconvenient or embarrassing revelations, whether for the security services, or for public authorities, should not be suppressed. Legal proceedings directed towards the seizure of the working papers of an individual journalist or the premises of the newspaper or television programme publishing his or her reports, or the threat of such proceedings, tends to inhibit discussion. When a genuine investigation into possible corrupt or reprehensible activities by a public authority is being investigated by the media, compelling evidence would normally be needed to demonstrate that the public interest would be served by such proceedings. Otherwise, to the public disadvantage, legitimate enquiry and discussion and the safety valve of investigative journalism... would be discouraged perhaps stifled.' British senior judges really are, in Jack Straw's phrase, 'Bringing Rights Home'. What a pity that the Home Secretary does not share their democratic values. His flawed measures, unnecessarily restricting public access to official information, and authorising the interception, surveillance and disclosure of journalistic material without a judicial warrant, will make it necessary for the judges to come to the rescue of British rights and freedoms.  Lord Lester of Herne Hill QC is a human rights lawyer at Blackstone Chambers who has argued several of the free speech cases to which he refers in English courts and the European Court of Human Rights.

webTitle: Leader - Ruling for a more open society

fields.headline: Ruling for a more open society
fields.standfirst: Law is not the servant of politicians
fields.trailText: Lord Hoffman, one of our most eminent liberal judges, once remarked that English judges often spoke in grand terms about the importance of the freedom of speech only to follow their remarks with the words 'but in this case...' before finding some exception to that lofty principle. Last week saw the exception to the Hoffmann rule.
fields.body:
Lord Hoffman, one of our most eminent liberal judges, once remarked that English judges often spoke in grand terms about the importance of the freedom of speech only to follow their remarks with the words 'but in this case...' before finding some exception to that lofty principle. Last week saw the exception to the Hoffmann rule. In a landmark ruling, three English judges, re-examined the first historic principles of common law, and in their judgment have reasserted the public interest in a free press and the rights of the individual.

In a ruling which has wide resonance not simply for the media but for wider society as well, the Court of Appeal on Friday judged that an attempt to compel The Observer, the Guardian and our reporter Martin Bright to surrender material held about David Shayler - the former MI5 agent who alleges that officers of the British Security Services conspired to assassinate Colonel Gadaffi in 1996 - was dangerously wrong.

In overturning a production order for any documents or emails held by The Observer relating to the Shayler case, handed down earlier this year by Judge Martin Stephens QC at the Old Bailey, the Court of Appeal ruled that Stephens' order contravened basic principles of common law in almost every respect. It breached what the media properly defends as its right of free speech: to seek, hold and disseminate information in the public interest. And in his leading judgment Lord Justice Judge added that the order was also flawed in attempting to remove the individual's right to be protected against self-incrimination in being compelled to supply information that could lead to his own prosecution. Lord Justice Judge continued that to let the order stand would mean that the state could curtail and infringe private property rights as it chose, in the process narrowing and stifling society's safety valve of investigative journalism.

In effect, he warned, it would allow the public interest to be defined by the state alone and not by the wider community.

The Observer is delighted to learn that the essential press freedoms that we take for granted - but which have come under increasing attack during New Labour's time in government in a series of high profile cases against journalists who have fallen foul of our draconian Official Secrets Act - are 'bred in the bone of common law'. We can only regret that other British judges over the years have not been as alert to the precedents set in the eighteenth century. We may not have a written constitution like America's, which guarantees freedom of expression under the First Amendment, but the implication of Friday's landmark judgment is that freedom of the press is an inalienable right.

But the importance of Lord Justice Judge's leading judgment is not simply confined to the critical reiteration of first principles already enshrined in the common law, which have been more notable for their lack of application by the same judiciary over the years in similar cases. What is equally significant is that the Court of Appeal has decided to intervene at this juncture. For if the judiciary is now more aware of the importance of the protection of individual freedoms in common law - rather than Tory notions that the executive is always right - it has come late in the day, empowered by the impending implementation of the Human Rights Act, which incorporates the European Convention on Human Rights. It is this that is helping the judiciary to reaffirm its role of protector of traditional freedoms rather than as a mere servant of the executive.

We can only hope now that those in government so eager to support such a fundamentally flawed order against this paper - and who continue to pursue other British journalists through the courts - will recognise with Lord Justice Judge that society is better served by a free press, regardless of the potential for embarrassment, than a media on trial.

webTitle: How a bomb in Libya led to a legal earthquake

fields.headline: How a bomb in Libya led to a legal earthquake
fields.standfirst: A judge's comments in the case concerning former MI5 officer David Shayler gave the most ringing defence of freedom of expression heard in Britain for years. Martin Bright reports on a momentous ruling
fields.trailText: A judge's comments in the case concerning former MI5 officer David Shayler gave the most ringing defence of freedom of expression heard in Britain for years, says Observer journalist and defendant Martin Bright.
fields.body:
Four years ago, in the Libyan coastal city of Sirte, there was a small explosion. It scattered the cavalcade of Colonel Gadaffi, who was attending a party congress in his home town and alternative capital. In the shoot-out that followed between the Libyan leader's personal bodyguards and Islamic fundamentalists hoping to spark a coup, several innocent civilians were killed.

At the time, apart from a few lines in the Arab press, the attack attracted little media coverage - another day, another attempt on the Libyan leader's life. Such is the haziness surrounding the events, it is still not known whether the explosion was caused by a bomb under one of the cars in the cavalcade or a grenade thrown from the crowd. The fundamentalists had failed where many had tried before.

But last week, the shockwaves from that blast in an obscure part of a distant and barely understood country reverberated through the highest courts in England. On Friday, in Court No1 of the Royal Courts of Justice, Lord Justice Igor Judge found that the Guardian and The Observer were right to resist police attempts to force them to hand over documents relating to claims by former MI5 officer David Shayler that the British intelligence service had been involved in the Sirte bombing.

Invoking the spirit of Voltaire and Pitt the Elder, the judge made the most ringing defence of freedom of expression heard in an English courtroom for many years. He said freedom of expression was 'bred in the bone' of English Common Law.

His decision established, beyond all doubt, the right of the press to investigate and report allegations of serious crime even when they involve members of the security services. Recognising the full gravity of the alleged assassination attempt, Lord Justice Judge said: 'If true, it is difficult to overestimate its enormity: a conspiracy to murder the head of another state, resulting not in his death, but in the deaths of innocent people who were not its intended targets.'

He added: 'Again, if true, the circumstances in which such a plan was conceived and developed, and the identity of those who were informed about and approved it, or turned a blind eye to it, and equally those who were deliberately kept in ignorance, raise critical public issues about the activities of the security services and those responsible for them.'

In a ringing endorsement of the role of the press in a free society, he added: 'The story of the Gadaffi plot is either true or it is false, and unless there are compelling reasons of national security, the public is entitled to know the facts, and as the the eyes and ears of the public, journalists are entitled to investigate and report the facts, as I hope they would, dispassionately and fairly, without prejudgment or selectivity.'

When Shayler's claims were originally made public in August 1998, the Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, described them as 'pure fantasy'. A top secret document that appeared on the internet in February appeared to undermine this claim. The so-called CX-report demonstrated that MI6 had full knowledge of a plot to kill Gadaffi in 1995. Shayler, who worked in the Libyan section of MI5 at the time, claimed that an MI6 officer paid money to the plotters and later claimed credit for the assassination attempt.

The Mail on Sunday originally attempted to publish his claims in August 1998. Hours after editors at the paper submitted the article to government lawyers, who decided it was too hot to publish, French intelligence officers swooped on the Paris hotel where Shayler was staying and arrested him for extradition to Britain. Journalists who worked on the story for the Mail on Sunday remain convinced the two events are connected. Shayler spent three months in La Santé prison in Paris before the French courts threw out Britain's extradition request. The story of the plot was eventually revealed in a BBC Panorama programme and published in an American newspaper before the British press felt able to publish.

Lord Justice Judge made it clear that, in future, the police should not interfere with journalists investigating the Shayler affair. As one journalist involved in the story told the human rights magazine Index on Censorship: 'They put us in the position that we have to break the law to break the news.'

The police first approached The Observer and the Guardian for documents in March this year. The Guardian had printed a letter from Shayler complaining about an article by their resident expert on the intelligence services, Richard Norton-Taylor. In court, the police argued that they needed a copy of the original email sent by Shayler to the Guardian because it might reveal his email address and prove that the former MI5 man had made revelations that were in breach of the Official Secrets Act. Last week's judicial review hearing threw this out without ceremony.

In the words of the judgment, The Observer case was 'more difficult'. On 27 February 2000, we published a story entitled 'Two Spies Named in Libya Plot'. In this we claimed that Shayler had written to Jack Straw in November 1999 with full details of what he knew about the assassination attempt. He demanded a full investigation and identified the officers he thought were responsible, or knew about the plans.

After legal advice and discussions with the Treasury Solicitor and MI5, no injunction was sought against the paper. Only afterwards did the police inform the newspaper that there had been a serious breach of national security. On Wednesday of the following week, Special Branch told The Observer that it was investigating offences, not only under Section One of the Official Secrets Act, which refers to revelations by former employees, but also Section Five, which refers to the passing on of information by third parties, such as journalists.

At the end of March the newspapers were in court for refusing to produce the documents. After three days of argument in the Old Bailey, Judge Martin Stephens QC stated: 'In my judgment, it is in the public interest that the material sought should be made available.' It was this decision that was successfully appealed on Friday.

The arguments in this case have largely concentrated on rights enshrined in the European Convention on Human Rights, which is expected to become part of British law on 2 October. Lawyers acting for the newspapers said that the police action was clearly in breach of Article 10 of the convention, which guarantees freedom of expression. But they also argued that the action was in breach of Article 6, which guarantees the rights of suspects not to incriminate themselves. As the Crown Prosecution Service had consistently refused to give an undertaking that The Observer journalists would not face prosecution, it was said that they were protected by the convention.

Lord Justice Judge stated that most of the rights being claimed by the newspapers' lawyers were already enshrined in English common law. His remarks were therefore as much a celebration of the English judicial system as they were a celebration of free speech. In an extraordinary flourish he turned to the words of former first minister William Pitt who famously said: 'The poorest man may in his cottage bid defiance to all the forces of the Crown.'

In a clear swipe at Europe he added that 'these principles were clearly understood in this country while an absolute monarch still reigned in France.' He said that the Bourbon monarch Louis XV would simply not have tolerated such language. Voltaire, he said, imprisoned twice by the French government, had a great respect for the English constitution. It is something of an irony in this case that while, in the 18th century, Voltaire had to find refuge in London for speaking out, David Shayler has been forced to find refuge in Paris.

The full implications of Lord Justice Judge's decision will take some time to emerge. But his conclusions about the inadequacy of the police operation will certainly have an immediate effect on the way Special Branch proceeds against newspapers in the future. The judge said: 'Inconvenient or embarrassing revelations, whether for the security services or for public authorities should not be suppressed. Legal proceedings directed towards the working papers of an individual journalist or the premises of a newspaper or television programme publishing his or her reports, or the threat of such proceedings tends to inhibit discussion.'

Some believe this judgment will have serious implications for the future of the Official Secrets Act. People who blow the whistle tend to do so to the press. It is hard to imagine how the police will be able to secure convictions without being able to gather evidence from journalists. The forthcoming trial of Shayler, who is expected to return to Britain at the end of August, will be an interesting test case. The trial of Nigel Wylde, the army intelligence officer who is the alleged source for Tony Geraghty's book about secret British Army operations in Ireland, The Irish War, will raise similar questions.

The case also raises issues around the so-called Defence Advisory or 'D-notice' committee, a loose collection of civil servants and senior journalists to which reporters can submit articles before publication to assess whether they breach national security. The system was not used by The Observer when it published the story about the Libyan plot. Some believe that journalists are effectively submitting to state censorship by working within the system.

Stephen Dorril, author of MI6: Fifty Years of Special Operations, published this year, said: 'This judgment is great news. But if editors want to put more teeth into investigative journalism, the first thing they should do is withdraw all co-operation from the D-notice committee. It is totally corrosive.'

Others welcomed Friday's ruling while regretting the case had been brought at all. Ian Hargreaves, professor of journalism at Cardiff University and former editor of the Independent, was surprised such a decision was needed under a progressive government: 'There has been a shocking inattentiveness to basic values. It is a pretty extraordinary thing for those of us who have supported this government, that it is consistently left to judges or the House of Lords to assert these kinds of principles.'

He added: 'What is going on with this Government, which claims its commitment to freedom of information, but consistently shows slight and insufficient regard for basic personal liberty and personal expression.'

Hargreaves said recent legislation initiated by Straw on Internet encryption and football hooliganism and the watering down of Freedom of Information legislation all caused serious concern.

Meanwhile, the Government has consistently refused to set up an inquiry into the Libyan affair.

There is no doubt that the decision in the Royal Courts of Justice struck a blow for freedom of expression in this country, but it is still likely to be a long time before we get anywhere near the full truth about that explosion in an obscure city in northern Libya.

fields.headline: Videos
fields.standfirst: Summer of Sam | Goldfinger | Rosetta | Sleepy Hollow | Lovers of the Arctic Circle
fields.trailText: Summer of Sam | Goldfinger | Rosetta | Sleepy Hollow | Lovers of the Arctic Circle
fields.body:
Summer of Sam (1999, 18, Fox-Pathé, VHS/Rental)
Spike Lee's crudely effective view of the long, hot summer of 1977 when New York baked, blacked out and went crazy as the serial killer David Berkowitz, who styled himself Son of Sam, terrorised the Bronx. In a movie that invites damaging comparisons with Fritz Lang's M, Berkowitz is a shadowy background figure with the foreground occupied by a fictitious group of macho blue-collar Italian-Americans who form a vigilante group and target as Sam-suspect an innocent punk rocker. The hysterical atmosphere is palpable and Mira Sorvino is touching as a put-upon wife.

Goldfinger (1964, PG, MGM, DVD/Retail)
Sean Connery got firmly into his charming stride with this confident third Bond movie in which 007 is kitted out with his technological wardrobe and given his Aston Martin DB5 to pursue master criminal Goldfinger (Gert Frobe) and his Sapphic pilot Pussy Galore (Honor Blackman). After missing out on From Russia With Love (because he was working on Dr Strangelove) Ken Adam was given his head and a much enlarged budget to design fantastic sets, most especially his masterly interior of Fort Knox. Ex-movie critic Paul Dehn's witty script improves on Fleming's novel. This is the third Bond thriller on DVD and, like its hero, comes with concealed extras including a 'Making of' documentary.

Rosetta (1999, 15, Artificial Eye, VHS, Rental/Retail)
Co-directed by the Belgian Brothers Luc and Jean-Pierre Dardenne, this dour slice of life, which some think a masterpiece, won the Palme d'Or at Cannes and shared the prize for best actress. Emilie Dequenne is impressive as an angry 18-year-old living with her alcoholic mother in a beat-up trailer park in a nondescript Belgian town. She has a desperate need for order and a settled life but can't hold down the few jobs she finds. It's a brief, convincing, depressing film, but needs a larger social context.

Sleepy Hollow (1999, 15, Fox Pathé, VHS/Rental, DVD/Retail)
Washington Irving's story of a headless horseman stalking eighteenth-century New England has been turned by Tim Burton into a gothic Hammer horror flick. Johnny Depp (in his third Burton film) plays a likeably bungling scientific detective sent to investigate a series of grisly murders in a small town beside the Hudson that may be the result of human conspiracy or the work of a Hessian mercenary's ghost. Despite the creaky plotline, it's handsome, scary entertainment with excellent special effects, but it's not for young children.

A bittersweet romantic tale from the gifted Spanish writer-director Julio Medem, tracing a series of elaborate coincidences (or tricks of fate) that tantalisingly draw together two young Spaniards (handsome Fele Martinez, beautiful Najwa Nimri) and then keep them apart over 20 years. The events stretch from Spain to Finland and the story is told in alternate chapters from the different characters' points-of-view. It's a sort of art-house date-movie.

In a movie that invites damaging comparisons with Fritz Lang's M, Berkowitz is a shadowy background figure with the foreground occupied by a fictitious group of macho blue-collar Italian-Americans who form a vigilante group and target as Sam-suspect an innocent punk rocker. The hysterical atmosphere is palpable and Mira Sorvino is touching as a put-upon wife. fields.headline: Ode to a right royal charmer
fields.standfirst: Euan Ferguson meets Andrew Motion, and discovers how he coped with his laureate duties
fields.trailText: The poet laureate argues now that had the post been allowed to die that would have been a poor thing for poetry. But how did he cope, a year on, caught between the sneers of fellow poets and the sighs of those such as Auberon Waugh who think that, if he's going to do it, then at least it should rhyme ?
fields.body:
Poetry and royalty. Two of those things we can sometimes do with quiet brilliance; two of those things we do, rather more often, unutterably badly. Like the way we do days at the sea and inventions and cleavage and picnics and murder, our royals and our poets are half-hearted and gauche; and yet, occasionally, unforgettable.

Or as the poets would doubtless have it:

Like sea-days, wet whipped wanderings,
wet like cleavage. Cleav'd, cleaving, heaving clear to murder:
The unicorn of crime-beasts. White sweat-flecked in dreams, yet fled when awake, and only empty black remains

Anyway, there you go. A bit under 30 seconds to write that little gem, and you get the idea. It is as easy to write bad poetry as to breathe - easier, perhaps, if like me you've been dry-heaving for most of the week over the cloacal bilge lapping the privileged toes of Britain's favourite granny/appeaser, snob of ballroom and Blitz, our very own rhinestone Flintstone - goodness and this bad writing's catching, but you know who I mean.

Most of us grow out of poetry shortly after those terrible bits of scribbled teenage angst (Roses are red/Violets are blue/I hate my parents), leaving us with only two strains worth watching: the memorably bad and the memorably good. There's a heap of fun to be had researching the first - my favourites must be the line from Acadia, by Joseph Howe (1804-73), which runs: 'The gay moose in jocund gambol springs', closely followed by Browning's fantastically shitty 'Irks care the crop-fed bird?' - but the second's a bit harder to deal with.

For there are good poets. There were, are, a host of British poets who still manage, as Motion describes, to 'link that side of our minds which is writerly, readerly, and that side of our minds which frankly hasn't a clue what's going on in this primeval swamp, until suddenly, instantly, they're together, and the hairs go up on the back of your neck.'

Whether Motion - who, as our Poet Laureate, last week wrote a tribute to the Queen Mum without quite outraging or delighting poets or monarchists - manages this often enough depends on who you listen to. It's probably a bad idea to listen to professional poets, for their closed world is so bitchy it makes your average gay ballet mafia look like a WWII fighter crew; and many harbour a certain bitterness towards him for having taken the post in the first place.

Motion, a friend of New Labour and a low-fat monarchist, accepted the job, and argues now that had the post been allowed to die that would have been a poor thing for poetry. But how did he cope, a year on, caught between the sneers of fellow poets and the sighs of those such as Auberon Waugh who think that, if he's going to do it, then at least it should rhyme ?

'Well, it's a badge of honour for any self-respecting poet to be criticised by Auberon Waugh. But in a lot of ways my poems are very conventional, and it's no big deal for me to write a poem in either free verse or strict form; modern poets can, and do, do both.'

What, I wonder, of his predecessor (and friend), Ted Hughes, whose royal poems, brimming with animal metaphors, were mercilessly lampooned? 'It's difficult to answer this because Ted thought there was a very primitive connection between monarchy and poetry - historically deeply founded, back to the mead hall. And even though few people agreed with him, he was on to something.' (Later, talking about the death of Diana, he comes back to this. He was reported then to be impressed by the quality of the public's poetry. He wasn't, he says. Most of it was 'awful'. But he was impressed by the need to turn to poetry, the primitive connection).

'But yes, Ted was probably over-optimistic, and exposing himself to ridicule.' Even, gently, from Motion: I ask about an oblique salmon reference in last week's poem and he grins. 'Yes. That was a sort of homage.'

So he's used to ridicule, ready for it, but argues strongly that he was right to take the post and keep it alive. 'Thanks partly to the kind of poets that we now have and partly to funding, there's been a gigantic shift in the way poetry is perceived... Poems on the Underground, poets in schools, football clubs, zoos.

'I wanted to reimagine the role, in a way that was respectful of its traditional responsibilities but made them part of a wider pattern of poetry about national incidents, events, preoccupations; and to spend a great deal of time going to schools trying to demystify poetry. While also, importantly, not wanting to dumb it down or pretend the days of 'difficult' poetry are over, because we live in a pluralist culture and there's room for 'difficult' poetry alongside rap and everything else. And poetry won't be for everyone, but everyone should have the choice.

Did he consider not doing the Queen Mum's poem? Or inserting a bit more caustic comment?

'Yes, it did cross my mind. But I think it would be very strange for me having accepted the position in the first place to write a knocking piece. But it would be equally difficult for me to write a piece which didn't want to be realistic. I tried to create a space in the poem where people can think those thoughts if they choose.

'But I can't and don't ever want to write bell-yanking confetti-tossing hat-throwing poems. If people want that they can read Betjeman again.

'So over the last year I've tried to come out of the curious sacred wood in which a lot of laureates have lived. I did the TUC conference, the Paddington rail crash - which produced an extraordinary response - Childline, Mandela.'

Would he write on politics, I wonder, after he's spoken of his 'deep disappointment' at the leaked Blair memo? 'I might, some day. I am a party member so I'll need a lot of persuading to go against them. Although ... I have kind of written up over the door into my mind a phrase of Keats', where he says "We hate poetry that has a palpable design on us." In other words if you pursue a narrow line on anything the chances are it will damage what is poetic in your poem. If we want to read pure ideas we read essays or philosophy; if we want to feel ideas, on our pulses, then we read poems.'

Neither Downing Street nor Buckingham Palace, he says, tells him what to write, 'and I'm not going to write something if it doesn't chime with thoughts I'm having already. The Dome asked me, and I thought about writing on Prince William's birthday, but if nothing chimes... words in order are not enough, these have got to be poems, and I could probably turn something out but it wouldn't be a poem, it would be a ditty.'

He's a charmer, our Poet Laureate, a smoothie. Sandy and suave and mellifluous, a delight to talk to, and one of those easy languid types who can always turn the charm up one more notch when needed; I can't help the suspicion that had I been wearing a skirt the wattage would have moved to open flirting. By the end I've almost forgiven him for the poem. Almost.

webTitle: Graduates hit jackpot in net porn

fields.headline: Graduates hit jackpot in net porn
fields.standfirst: Four who met at Edinburgh University have built a sex site empire from their Antigua haven.  Stuart Millar reports
fields.trailText: Four who met at Edinburgh University have built a sex site empire from their Antigua haven.
fields.body:
The photograph could be of any group of young friends enjoying a beer on a Caribbean beach.

But the four Edinburgh university graduates have more reasons to celebrate than most: since leaving the venerable institution, they have managed to build up a massive internet pornography empire and evade British police for more than 18 months.

Trading under the name Rhino Corporation, the three men and one woman have exploited Antigua's accommodating offshore company laws to put together a hardcore porn operation of such sophistication they have made themselves virtually untraceable.

In two years, they have gone from minnows to major players in the burgeoning net porn industry, running their own lucrative stable of slickly produced, explicit pay sites as well as sponsoring sex sites run by smaller operators.

Since disappearing into the Edinburgh ether in 1998, the four have adopted the names Mark and Jason Rhino, DragonKing and Amber to conceal their real identities. Their vast incomes from the porn business are held in secret numbered Antiguan bank accounts, and they are understood to use Antiguan credit cards to conduct their day-to-day transactions. The authorities in this country have all but given up hope of tracking them down.

They have now taken the audacious step of offering advice via the internet for anyone who wants to follow their example. Their website not only outlines how the owners of Antiguan offshore corporations can mask their identities, move around assets under the noses of the tax authorities and render themselves almost immune from prosecution; it also, for a $2,750 (£1,700) fee, allows would-be offshore businessmen the opportunity to set up a company with the click of a mouse.

The group went into business in 1997 after graduating from Edinburgh, where at least two of them studied for computing degrees. In an attempt to get around Britain's stringent obscenity laws, they launched sex sites using rented web space from American internet host companies specialising in porn. From the start, the operation was highly sophisticated.

All the money from subscription fees to their sites was paid immediately into the Rhino Corporation's anonymous Antiguan offshore account.

Since the island set itself up as an offshore tax haven in 1992, it has been an offence punishable by three years in jail for a bank to reveal details about directors, officers or shareholders of an offshore company. By living off company credit cards, the group removed the possibility of the sites or the profits being traced back to them.

But their enterprise came to the attention of police in Edinburgh, who suspected they were posting pornography on to the web from this country. Even for sites hosted outside Britain, this would have come under the offence of handling and distributing obscene materials.

Officers began monitoring Rhino's activities, but just as they were about to move in, the group disappeared and has not been seen in this country since.

The four claim to have moved permanently to Antigua, but police sources believe they still spend time in Britain, hiding beneath the cloak of their assumed names and their Antiguan credit cards.

Traced by The Observer to the Rhino Corporation's Antiguan base, Amber, from Reading, denied that she or her three colleagues had ever broken the law. 'I don't believe we have ever done anything illegal,' she said. 'Whoever has told you we have is mistaken.'

The company now runs 10 'specialist' hardcore sites, with lurid titles ranging from Wives Exposed and Dirty Dykes to Sex Spy and Simply Gay. Amber runs a site called Dirty Teens, specialising in material involving young girls; it boasts of being a 'highly controversial site which has made international news many times'. Each site carries a monthly subscription fee of $29.95.

The operation has built much of its success on sponsoring smaller sites, under the name Flash Cash. In return for carrying a link to one of Rhino's sites, the operators get a payment for each visitor who then subscribes.

Under their photograph on the Flash Cash promotional site, they state: 'With the ever-changing adult industry and fly-by-night sponsors, it's nice to know there are still solid sponsors who give you the freedom to market as you wish, and the peace of mind that comes with knowing you will be paid honestly and on time for your hard work.'

Amber also denied that the web advice on setting up offshore companies amounted to a blueprint for pornographers to evade obscenity and tax laws. 'We are not really aiming that towards the porn sites. It has nothing at all to do with the porn sites, it's just financial advice.'

But Rhino's company formation operation is clearly targeted at those interested in the web porn industry.

It is offering the operators of smaller sex sites who carry ads for Rhino's service $300 for every customer who signs up. It also encourages the operators to move offshore themselves, allowing them to get all their Rhino sponsor cheques paid into an anonymous, secure bank account.

The company's advice to would-be customers is also forthright.

It states, for example: 'By transferring assets (e.g. domain names, property) to the company, any visible connection between you and your business can be severed.

'It will be almost impossible for anyone to trace you from publicly available information.'

Under the heading, Asset Protection, it continues: 'Antigua does not recognise the authority of the US (or any foreign government) over what it regards as its own internal affairs, so in order to sue, the litigator must first prove that the alleged crime is also an offence in Antigua. Antigua has no personal income tax and therefore will not assist any prosecution for tax evasion. It also does not have stringent obscenity laws.'

The latest venture is certain to infuriate British police. 'They are already making an awful lot of money,' a source in the internet sex industry told The Observer. 'Now, by offering this service, they are really giving the finger to the British authorities.'

Despite the unabashed nature of Rhino's web activities, however, the brains behind the operation remained reluctant to step into the limelight.

'I really don't think we want this sort of publicity,' Amber told The Observer before ringing off. 'It will give the wrong impression.'

webTitle: Made by Spain, filmed in English, sold to Hollywood

fields.headline: Made by Spain, filmed in English, sold to Hollywood
fields.trailText: John Malkovich perches on sunlit rocks, Atlantic rollers crashing, waiting for the call of 'Action'.
fields.body:
John Malkovich perches on sunlit rocks, Atlantic rollers crashing, waiting for the call of 'Action'.

In front of the camera is Javier Bardem, the Spanish film star who is tipped to match the international impact of his friend and former co-star Penelope Cruz.

Bardem tries a few phrases, changing the emphasis each time, wanting to hear how these foreign words should sound. This is a Spanish movie with a Spanish star, but America's Malkovich is the director - and English the language.

Pedro Almodovar may be the champion of modern Iberian cinema, but the Oscar-winning bad boy from Castilla-La Mancha represents only a fraction of the modern Spanish industry.

There is plenty of technological know-how in Spain, as well as acting talent, and no-one cares what language the director of photography speaks. Movie-makers here recognise that Hollywood reigns supreme, and since they can't beat the American industry they must try to emulate it. Fantastic Factory is one example of the new business mood, fruit of a meeting in Sitges, the Catalan beach resort known for its gay night-life and its horror, sci-fi and fantasy film festival.

Julio Fernández of the Spanish company Filmax, fed up with importing genre films for sale in Spain, decided to make them himself for export. Over dinner he hooked up with Brian Yuzna, whose unnerving movie credits include Re-Animator, Return of the Living Dead 3 and, on a more wholesome note, Honey, I Shrunk the Kids.

The first project, Faust: Love of the Damned, directed by Yuzna, is already in post-production. A rather different Barcelona flick is Gaudi Afternoon, a flamboyant comedy directed by Susan Seidelman and produced by Lolafilms, a major production house and winner of the last Spanish Oscar, awarded in 1992 for Belle Epoque. Lolafilms aims to turn out mainstream English-language movies such as Malkovich's directorial debut, The Dancer Upstairs, which finished shooting last week.

This autumn should see the premiere of That Girl from Rio, starring Hugh Laurie as a samba-loving bank clerk who flees his adulterous wife and heads to Brazil with his employer's money.

Andrés Vicente Gómez, doyen of Spanish producers and the man responsible for all four films, says the move to English is simply a question of market forces, even for the heavily subsidised Spanish industry. Since the death of Franco in 1975, governments have strongly supported the local movie business, considered part of the country's cultural heritage.

Under the present rules, any film made here (unless X-rated) is entitled to a state subsidy worth 33 per cent of its budget. This costs the government some 5,000 million pesetas (almost £19m) a year.
