In front of the camera is Javier Bardem, the Spanish film star who is tipped to match the international impact of his friend and former co-star Penelope Cruz. Bardem tries a few phrases, changing the emphasis each time, wanting to hear how these foreign words should sound. This is a Spanish movie with a Spanish star, but America's Malkovich is the director - and English the language. Pedro Almodovar may be the champion of modern Iberian cinema, but the Oscar-winning bad boy from Castilla-La Mancha represents only a fraction of the modern Spanish industry. There is plenty of technological know-how in Spain, as well as acting talent, and no-one cares what language the director of photography speaks. Movie-makers here recognise that Hollywood reigns supreme, and since they can't beat the American industry they must try to emulate it. Fantastic Factory is one example of the new business mood, fruit of a meeting in Sitges, the Catalan beach resort known for its gay night-life and its horror, sci-fi and fantasy film festival. Julio Fernández of the Spanish company Filmax, fed up with importing genre films for sale in Spain, decided to make them himself for export. Over dinner he hooked up with Brian Yuzna, whose unnerving movie credits include Re-Animator, Return of the Living Dead 3 and, on a more wholesome note, Honey, I Shrunk the Kids. The first project, Faust: Love of the Damned, directed by Yuzna, is already in post-production. A rather different Barcelona flick is Gaudi Afternoon, a flamboyant comedy directed by Susan Seidelman and produced by Lolafilms, a major production house and winner of the last Spanish Oscar, awarded in 1992 for Belle Epoque. Lolafilms aims to turn out mainstream English-language movies such as Malkovich's directorial debut, The Dancer Upstairs, which finished shooting last week. This autumn should see the premiere of That Girl from Rio, starring Hugh Laurie as a samba-loving bank clerk who flees his adulterous wife and heads to Brazil with his employer's money. Andrés Vicente Gómez, doyen of Spanish producers and the man responsible for all four films, says the move to English is simply a question of market forces, even for the heavily subsidised Spanish industry. Since the death of Franco in 1975, governments have strongly supported the local movie business, considered part of the country's cultural heritage. Under the present rules, any film made here (unless X-rated) is entitled to a state subsidy worth 33 per cent of its budget. This costs the government some 5,000 million pesetas (almost £19m) a year.

webTitle: Hollywood stars log on to failure in cyberspace

fields.headline: Hollywood stars log on to failure in cyberspace
fields.trailText: If the words 'Britney Spears' and 'internet entrepreneur' ring hollow when heard in the same sentence, how about inserting the names of Cindy Crawford instead, or Michael Jackson or Melanie Griffith?
fields.body:
If the words 'Britney Spears' and 'internet entrepreneur' ring hollow when heard in the same sentence, how about inserting the names of Cindy Crawford instead, or Michael Jackson or Melanie Griffith?

Pop superstars and Hollywood celebrities are queueing to launch dotcom firms. Danny DeVito and Stephen Baldwin were spotted at the Digital Coast Executives' Dinner last week, a forum where internet bigwigs hobnob with Hollywood types to discuss the industry.

Many dotcom companies may be sinking, but that hasn't stopped Crawford launching babystyle.com, or Spears dipping her toe in the ether with sweet16.com.

But the curious thing is that these sites receive so little attention. In an age where a single picture of Posh and Becks can generate an avalanche of gossip, why have so few heard of Griffith's OneWorldLive or Jackson's HollywoodTickets?

Atom Films, an entertainment site which licenses short films, believes the net community simply is not interested in stars. 'Certainly there's an audience that always goes to see Julia Roberts,' said Matt Hulett, Atom's chief online officer. 'But the internet visitor isn't the same breed of audience: our films starring George Clooney (pictured) and Cate Blanchett have proved far less popular than our animated Bikini Bandit series or the Joe Cartoon clips, where you get to mutilate gerbils.'

There seems to be a distinct parting between Hollywood and the internet audience, which wants interactivity.

'Are the celebrities coming to the net willing to dismantle those walls, get their hands really dirty in the day-to-day of a dotcom?' asked Janelle Brown, an internet journalist. 'The celebrity site is just another boring dotcom unless the star chooses to get down with those fans and evangelises interactively.'

webTitle: Comedy film sparks new Enigma row

fields.headline: Comedy film sparks new Enigma row
fields.trailText: The wartime Enigma code is to star in another row about the way Hollywood handles history. The British stand-up comic Eddie Izzard (pictured) and Matt le Blanc, from Channel 4's sitcom Friends, are to make All the Queen's Men, a comic version of the World War II code-breaking story set behind enemy lines.
fields.body:
The wartime Enigma code is to star in another row about the way Hollywood handles history. The British stand-up comic Eddie Izzard (pictured) and Matt le Blanc, from Channel 4's sitcom Friends, are to make All the Queen's Men, a comic version of the World War II code-breaking story set behind enemy lines.

But the jokey plot, which involves cross-dressing and heel-clicking SS officers, has rung alarm bells in the Jewish community. Holocaust survivors are worried by the increasing number of lighthearted film treatments of the Nazi regime.

'When the Italian comedy Life is Beautiful came out there was a great deal of controversy about its humorous attitude,' said Trudy Gold, director of the Jewish Cultural Centre in north London. 'A lot of the people we see in our Holocaust survivor centre were worried by the tone.'

Gold is perturbed by the entertainment industry's growing interest in an era of German history which she feels should not be approached without moral and historical context. The cracking of the German military code encrypted by the Enigma machine brought forward the end of the war by at least a year.

'The whole story of this Enigma machine means a lot to Jews because it saved thousands of lives,' she said.

'I personally believe that certain subjects don't lend themselves to humour. Is comedy a good way to treat issues where so many people suffered?'

The $15 million (£10.2m) budget film will tell the story of allied servicemen in Germany who dress as women in an attempt to gain access to a factory producing the crucial Enigma machine.

The Atlantic Streamline project starts shooting in Vienna and Budapest next month and will follow in the footsteps of this year's controversial submarine adventure, U-571, the Harvey Keitel film in which Americans were shown capturing the first Enigma machine.

U-571 enraged British historians because it was British naval officers who first captured the Enigma machine and code breakers working at Bletchley Park, Buckinghamshire, who cracked the communication system used by the Germans.

All the Queen's Men is destined to hit cinemas hard on the heels of yet another screen version of the Bletchley Park story. Enigma, based on the bestselling Robert Harris novel, stars Kate Winslet and finished filming this spring.

All the Queen's Men is written by the British comedian David Schneider and attempts to stick much more closely to the truth about the Allied effort to defeat Germany than U-571 did, but Schneider knows tackling Nazism with comedy could be perilous. 'We have not taken any liberties with the historical details, I hope,' he said. 'And certainly not in the way that the U-boat film did, but it was still quite difficult handling such a sensitive subject.'

Most of the jokes involve cross-dressing as Le Blanc and Izzard attempt to pass themselves off as female factory workers, but Schneider also had to decide how to portray Hitler's Germany.

'People may be angry about treating these things humorously. It has been a tricky thing to handle. I hope I got round it by being tasteful and by being as truthful as possible about the horrors of the Nazi regime.'

Schneider, who appeared regularly in the BBC sitcom The Peter Principle and in Steve Coogan's Alan Partridge series, is himself Jewish. The film is being produced by a German and directed by an Austrian.

'It has been an interesting journey for me as a Jew, as well as a writer. And it will be an interesting mix,' he said.

But, although the screenwriter is Jewish, Gold believes some subjects are better treated seriously or left alone: 'You have to ask yourself why lines are being crossed now,' said Gold

'It is terribly contentious. It may be that Schindler's List was a turning point. It was a very successful film in its own way, but before that everybody felt it was impossible to make entertainment about what the Nazis did.

'It is true that Chaplin made The Great Dictator and Ernst Lubitsch made To Be or Not to Be about the Nazis; those early comedies were both made before there was much known about the camps.

'We do take Holocaust survivors into schools and I think that kind of thing is very powerful. I know people argue satire can work too, but I am not sure in this case,' she said.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: First Direct | Abbey National | Egg
fields.body:
First Direct, the bank that pioneered telephone banking more than a decade ago, unveiled details of its internet offering last week. Customers of First Direct will get a better deal on their savings and mortgages if they switch to the online service. First Direct is also offering internet customers 24-hour access to staff.

The firstdirect.com current account is paying up to 5 per cent but, as one of its competitors, the Co-op's Smile, pointed out, this rate applies only on balances of £5,000 or more. On balances up to £999, firstdirect.com pays just 1 per cent, compared with Smile's 4.75 per cent and 4.5 per cent from Abbey National's cahoot internet bank. However, even at 1 per cent, firstdirect.com is paying substantially more than its telephone sister account, where all balances earn just 0.1 per cent.

Rates on the savings account are also more attractive than on the telephone equivalent, starting at 5 per cent for balances up to £5,000 and rising to 6 per cent on £100,000. The overdraft rate is 10.9 per cent, against 12.6 per cent on borrowing up to £250 in the telephone account and 16.9 per cent on more than £250.

The account is available now to personal computer users, and First Direct aims to extend it to Apple Mac users and Wap phones in August. Television banking is scheduled for the autumn.

Sharedealing services continue to sprout on the internet. Abbey National's service will deal for investors who hold certificates for their shares (rather than holding them electronically through a nominee account) and will charge £16 for deals up to £1,000; £25 up to £2,500 and £39.50 for deals worth more than £2,500. You can register to use the service by calling 0800 169 3377, and Abbey says a dealing account number will be issued within minutes. Egg, the internet bank 80 per cent owned by the Prudential, has issued details of its online dealing service, which will cost £9.99 per deal, up to a maximum of £50,000, with a £5 monthly administration fee.

Would-be house buyers, or owners seeking to remortgage, now have access to a vast range of research services that will shop around on their behalf. Broker John Charcol is offering first-time buyers advice on surveys, finding a solicitor and the mechanics of conveyancing, in addition to a mortgage-finder service. Charcol hopes shortly to launch an 'email me when' service alerting customers about new deals which suit their requirements; it also plans internet conveyancing.

Personal finance website Moneyextra is launching a service to help credit card users work out which is the best deal for them.

webTitle: Shayler ruling - order sought would have had a devastating effect

fields.headline: The Shayler ruling: 'The order sought would have had a devastating effect'
fields.standfirst:
Abridged extracts from Lord Justice Judge's statement
British Secrecy in Question Observer special
fields.trailText: Abridged extracts from Lord Justice Judge's statement.
fields.body:
The judge began by saying it was impossible to overestimate the enormity of David Shayler 's allegations that MI6 had been involved in a plot to murder Gadaffi.

There are those who would instinctively believe the worst of the security services and, whatever the evidence, would remain invincibly confident that Mr Shayler had lifted a veil over an obscure and dark corner of public life. In their minds, at any rate, something of the smear would stick. No doubt, too, even false allegations of this kind can be used, and would continue to be used, to attack the security services, and to undermine public confidence in their activities.

Nevertheless, in its own way, the refutation of this allegation is also a matter of public importance. The story of the Gadaffi bomb plot is either true or it is false, and unless there are compelling reasons of national security the public is entitled to know the facts, and as the eyes and ears of the public, journalists are entitled to investigate and report the facts, as I hope they would, dispassionately and fairly, without prejudgment or selectivity.

Lord Justice Judge went on to explain that the basic liberties of the freedom against self-incrimination and the freedom of expression (Articles 6 and 10 of the European Convention of Human Rights) were 'bred in the bone' of English law.

THE common law principle was expressed nearly 250 years ago in the famous case of Entick v Carrington [ 1765]. Entick was a clerk whose home in Stepney was broken into by Carrington and three other 'Messengers in Ordinary to the King'. Their defence was that they were acting under the authority of a warrant issued by the Earl of Halifax, a member of the Privy Council, and one of the principal Secretaries of State, which authorised and requested them 'to make strict and diligent search for the plaintiff' and to bring him with his 'books and papers in safe custody to be examined'.

The issue was whether the Secretary of State had jurisdiction to seize the papers 'If this point should be determined in favour of the jurisdiction, the secret cabinets and bureaus of every subject in this kingdom will be thrown open to the search and inspection of a messenger, whenever the Secretary of State shall think fit to charge, or even to suspect, a person to be the author, printer, or publisher of a seditious libel this power is not supported by one single citation from any law book extant.'

He went on to quote William Pitt, Earl of Chatham (1708-1778)

'THE poorest man may in his cottage bid defiance to all the forces of the Crown. It may be frail - its roof may shake, the wind may blow through it, the storm may enter, the rain may enter - but the King of England cannot enter all his force dares not cross the threshold of the ruined tenement.'

The measured language of the judge and the emotion of the orator are encapsulated in the simple phrase that 'an Englishman's home is his castle'. These principles were clearly understood in this country while an absolute monarch still reigned in France. If the Bourbon monarch, Louis XV, had heard of such language used by a prominent politician, and former First Minister, the speaker's best hope would have been for the king to have assumed that he was joking. But even that would not have prevented some fawning minion from dispatching a lettre de cachet to ensure that he was locked up, indefinitely, and without trial. It is hardly surprising therefore, that Voltaire, having twice been imprisoned in the Bastille, and eventually forced to live in exile, and notwithstanding what we can now appreciate were its great defects then, so greatly admired our constitution.

These principles are interlinked.'

In conclusion Lord Justice Judge launched an impassioned defence of the freedom of the press.

Inconvenient or embarrassing revelations, whether for the security services, or for public authorities, should not be suppressed. Legal proceedings directed towards the seizure of the working papers of an individual journalist, or the premises of the newspaper or television programme publishing his or her reports, or the threat of such proceedings, tends to inhibit discussion. When a genuine investigation into possible corrupt or reprehensible activities by a public authority is being investigated by the media, compelling evidence would normally be needed to demonstrate that the public interest would be served by such proceedings. Otherwise, to the public disadvantage, legitimate enquiry and discussion, and 'the safety valve of effective investigative journalism', the phrase used in a different context by Lord Steyn in R v Secretary of State for the Home Department ex parte Simms [1999], would be discouraged, perhaps stifled.

In the wide terms sought in the original application, I believe that an order would have had a devastating and stifling effect on the proper investigation of the Shayler story.

Virtually any journalist who made contact with him, and any newspaper publishing an article based on discussions with Shayler , would be at risk of a similar application to the present. To my mind that would be an unhealthy development, quite disproportionate to any practical advantages to the prosecution process.

fields.headline: Taste test
fields.standfirst: Most journalists would rather taste battery acid than spend four days taking a wine exam that few people pass. But not our correspondent
fields.trailText: Most journalists would rather taste battery acid than spend four days taking a wine exam that few people pass. But not our correspondent.
fields.body:
Candidates preparing for the Master of Wine examination are handed a reading list at the start of the two-year course. Tomes on microbiology, tasting technique and marketing share equal billing with monographs on every first-growth chteau, The Greek Wine Guide and a Compendium of Grape Diseases.

As far as I know, the Institute of Masters of Wine has never recommended Graham Greene's Journey without Maps , but it wouldn't be a bad idea. For when it comes to passing the exam (the only possible reason for reading Biological Principles in Fermentation and the like), the screenwriter William Goldman's first rule of Hollywood applies: no one knows anything.

Ask most MWs how they stumbled through the gruelling, and in some cases never-ending, series of exams and the answer is always the same: they're not sure. 'You're navigating by the stars,' one of them told me with a rueful smile. 'It's almost impossible, but that adds to the sense of achievement if you pass.'

A big if, this one. The MW exam is incredibly difficult. Just consider the statistics: since 1993, 271 people have sat the exam (many of them on three or more occasions), and only 81 have come out the other end clutching a certificate. In that period, nine heroic souls have passed the four written and three tasting papers at the first attempt. This is hardly surprising: how would you fancy answering a three-hour marketing paper 45 minutes after you've finished slurping at a line-up of a dozen sweet and fortified wines? It's hard enough walking in a straight line, never mind penning an essay on the effect of currency fluctuations on the wine business.

If I sound animated about all this, it's because I've just sat the dreaded exam. Alongside 58 other fact-cramming candidates in London, San Francisco and Sydney, I spent the best part of a week blind-tasting and writing essays on anything from filtration to ethical trading. I've never run a marathon, but I can't believe it's any worse than doing the MW. Let's face it, covering 26.2 miles doesn't take more than six hours, even at walking pace; the MW, on the other hand, goes on for four strength-sapping days and you're not even guaranteed a medal for finishing.

How did I do? Well, I identified a top champagne as a Cava, mistook an Italian Pinot Gris for a South African Chenin Blanc and placed a Tuscan red in the Napa Valley during the tasting exams. I also scored a few direct hits, but, as the Institute likes to point out, getting the wines right isn't as important as writing good notes. It's possible to identify all 36 wines correctly and still fail.

Journalists should do better in the written papers, but this is not necessarily so. The Fourth Estate does not have a particularly good record in the exam; from time to time the examiners' report refers disparagingly to 'candidates' use of journalese'. Jancis Robinson passed in one go, as did the Kiwi journalist Bob Campbell, but several other well-known wine writers have failed more than once. No wonder most hacks decide that they'd rather taste battery acid.

For what it's worth, I've enjoyed the experience so far, although I may change my mind if I have to retake both parts next year. Should I pass, I'll have a sense of achievement, a certificate to hang in the loo and a shelf-full of useless books. Anyone want a secondhand copy of Wine Utilities: Planning, Design and Operation? On second thoughts, maybe I should take it to Oxfam.

Ask most MWs how they stumbled through the gruelling, and in some cases never-ending, series of exams and the answer is always the same: they're not sure. 'You're navigating by the stars,' one of them told me with a rueful smile. 'It's almost impossible, but that adds to the sense of achievement if you pass.' A big if, this one. The MW exam is incredibly difficult. Just consider the statistics: since 1993, 271 people have sat the exam (many of them on three or more occasions), and only 81 have come out the other end clutching a certificate. In that period, nine heroic souls have passed the four written and three tasting papers at the first attempt. This is hardly surprising: how would you fancy answering a three-hour marketing paper 45 minutes after you've finished slurping at a line-up of a dozen sweet and fortified wines? It's hard enough walking in a straight line, never mind penning an essay on the effect of currency fluctuations on the wine business. If I sound animated about all this, it's because I've just sat the dreaded exam. Alongside 58 other fact-cramming candidates in London, San Francisco and Sydney, I spent the best part of a week blind-tasting and writing essays on anything from filtration to ethical trading. I've never run a marathon, but I can't believe it's any worse than doing the MW. Let's face it, covering 26.2 miles doesn't take more than six hours, even at walking pace; the MW, on the other hand, goes on for four strength-sapping days and you're not even guaranteed a medal for finishing. How did I do? Well, I identified a top champagne as a Cava, mistook an Italian Pinot Gris for a South African Chenin Blanc and placed a Tuscan red in the Napa Valley during the tasting exams. I also scored a few direct hits, but, as the Institute likes to point out, getting the wines right isn't as important as writing good notes. It's possible to identify all 36 wines correctly and still fail. Journalists should do better in the written papers, but this is not necessarily so. The Fourth Estate does not have a particularly good record in the exam; from time to time the examiners' report refers disparagingly to 'candidates' use of journalese'. Jancis Robinson passed in one go, as did the Kiwi journalist Bob Campbell, but several other well-known wine writers have failed more than once. No wonder most hacks decide that they'd rather taste battery acid. For what it's worth, I've enjoyed the experience so far, although I may change my mind if I have to retake both parts next year. Should I pass, I'll have a sense of achievement, a certificate to hang in the loo and a shelf-full of useless books. Anyone want a secondhand copy of Wine Utilities: Planning, Design and Operation? On second thoughts, maybe I should take it to Oxfam.

fields.headline: Nigel Slater's savoury tart recipes
fields.standfirst: Crumbly, flakey and oh so buttery... nothing lifts your spirits like a slice of oven-warm, home-baked tart
fields.trailText: Crumbly, flakey and oh so buttery... nothing lifts your spirits like a slice of oven-warm, home-baked tart
fields.body:
Nothing tempts like a tart. The buttery crust crumbles under your fork, the savoury filling quivers. You lift it slowly, carefully, from plate to mouth so as not to lose even the tiniest bit down your shirt. The pastry melts in your mouth, the filling dissolves on your tongue. A crumb falls, a crumb that you will rescue later with a licked finger. No roast, no cake, no fruit can tempt and please the way a slice of warm, home-baked tart does.

The other day, a book appeared on my kitchen table which reminded me of this. A book filled with the sort of recipes dreams are made of. Not a vast tome, but a slim and understated one. A book for a day when you have no one but yourself to cook for, a kitchen all to yourself. It was an entire book devoted to the tart. There were tarts of seafood and cream, of spinach and anchovies, of lemons and cherries. There were round potato tarts, oblong pissaladières and crinkle-edged bacon quiches. There were big tarts of leeks and tiny ones of haddock, fat tarts, thin tarts, and tarts to make you laugh, by which I mean one laced with tobacco that has apparently been banned from the American edition. The book had the come-hither title of The Art of the Tart (£16.99, Cassell).

There is something about baking a pastry case and filling it with something good that appeals to me as much as making any cake or tray of biscuits. Every moment of such a recipe is a moment of pure rapture - from the satiny feel of the dough as you push it into the tin with your floury fingers to the quiver of the custard as you proudly take your handiwork from the oven. This is the sort of cooking you always promise yourself you will do more of, because it turns making supper into a recreation rather than work. Making Bakewell tart ain't cooking, it is pure therapy.

Of course, this is not supper in seconds (though a tomato tart can be on the table in 20 minutes), it is cooking in layers. First you must tend to the pastry and bake it, then mix the filling, carefully loading the tart so that it is thick and generous, but not so full that it overflows its crust. You must carry your laden tin oh-so-carefully to the oven, watching the custard ebb and flow perilously toward the rim. And try your best not to lose concentration at the last minute, your egg and cream custard dribbling and burning on the hot oven door.

According to Tamasin Day-Lewis, author of The Art of the Tart, there is nothing complicated about this sort of cooking, it is just that the process is simply longer. Perhaps that explains why I get such quiet delight from it. Nothing complex or showy, just slow, peaceful pottering in the kitchen. You pick your day, making sure you will not be interrupted, and set to it. I think that Radio 4 should be on, or perhaps even some music. Then there is the softly tactile quality of sifted flour in your palms, the richesse of the butter (nothing less will do) and the luxury of the double cream. The raw pastry feels as soft as silk and the smell from the oven is the finest antidote there ever was to the Working Week.

Gazing dreamily at the pictures of Flamiche and Brandade tart, it is easy to forget how practical a great cartwheel of a pie can be. I know it is tempting to do more, but this is what to put on the table when people come round for a light lunch. I do think the pastry should be warm, fresh from the oven, but the rest can be a hotchpotch of the bought and the ready-made. Some hunks of cheese, slices of ham from the bone and some salad (perhaps flageolet beans and rocket) can be scattered round the table for guests to help themselves. Nothing we can make and offer our friends is likely to go down better than home baking. Especially if that baking is savoury. Those of us who do get round to putting pastry in a tart tin are more than likely to do so with pudding in mind. Something filled with vegetables or fish is likely to win even more smiles.

Today I decided on a tart of haddock and watercress. To be honest, it had been a bit of a toss-up between that and one with crab and cream. But the haddock won. Softly smoky, the fish was held lightly in a small amount of custard. An enchanting recipe, but one that took less time than I had envisaged, so I just had to make tomato tarts as well. The crisp pastry, the luscious centre, those elusive crumbs, all sitting on their baking sheet in my kitchen. Nothing, but nothing tempts like a tart.

Tamasin Day-Lewis's tart pastry

120g plain, white organic flour
60g unsalted butter

Sift the flour and a pinch of salt into the food processor, then cut the cold butter into small pieces on top of it. I process it for 20-30 seconds, then add ice-cold water through the top, 1 tbsp at a time, with the machine running. About 2 to 2 should do it. If the paste is still in crumbly little bits after a minute or two, add 1 tbsp more of water, but remember, the more water you use, the more your pastry will shrink when you bake it blind. The moment it has cohered into a single ball, stop, remove it, wrap it in clingfilm and put it in the fridge for 30 minutes.

Smoked haddock and watercress tart

A lovely recipe from The Art of the Tart. It would make a good first course, although I treated it as a main dish and served it warm the other day with a very plain and straightforward green salad. A good dish for this unpredictable summer. Serves 6.

22cm shortcrust pastry case, chilled, made to the above recipe
beaten egg for brushing
325g undyed smoked haddock
300ml Jersey milk
30g butter
1 small onion, finely chopped
1 stick of celery, finely chopped
30g plain flour
nutmeg
a bunch of watercress, stalks removed, finely chopped
2 eggs, beaten
2 tbsp grated Parmesan

Preheat the oven to 190 C/gas mark 5. Bake the pastry blind for 10 minutes, then remove the baking beans, prick the base with a fork and brush with beaten egg. Return to the oven for 5 more minutes.

Put the haddock and milk in a saucepan and bring to the boil, then reduce the heat and simmer for a further 10 minutes. Remove and skin the fish and flake into a bowl. Reserve the milk separately.

Heat the butter in a saucepan, add the onion and celery and cook gently, until softened. Stir in the flour and cook for a few minutes, then add the reserved poaching milk and stir until the sauce has thickened. Season with a little salt, pepper and the grated nutmeg. Remove from the heat and stir into the fish, adding the watercress and beaten eggs.

Pour into the pastry case and sprinkle the top with grated Parmesan. Bake for 25 minutes, when the tart will have risen and be crusted a delectable golden brown. Leave to cool slightly before turning out and eating hot.

Tomato tarts

A recipe I have made for years - but it only really comes to life with the sweet-sharp cherry tomatoes that are around now. I sometimes put in some chopped anchovy with the oil and basil, in which case I tend to use less salt. Makes 6.

425g puff pastry
4 tbsp peppery, extra-virgin olive oil
a small bunch of basil
2 cloves of garlic, peeled and crushed
the leaves of a couple of sprigs of thyme
about 30 small cherry tomatoes

Set the oven at 230 C/gas mark 8. Roll out the pastry - you want it to be really thin, about the same thickness as a pound coin. Using a large saucer as a template, cut six discs of pastry and lift them on to a baking sheet. Place a smaller saucer or large cup in the centre of each circle and score round it without cutting right through the pastry to give a wide rim that will rise and enclose the tomatoes. Prick the centre circles of the pastry lightly with a fork.

Pour the oil into a mixing bowl, tear up the basil finely and add it to the oil with the crushed garlic, thyme leaves and a seasoning of salt and quite coarse black pepper. Cut the tomatoes in half, then toss them in the seasoned oil.

Pile the tomatoes on to inner circles of the pastry, then brush the edges with some of the oil. Brush the tomatoes generously with any remaining oil. Bake for about 12-15 minutes, watching carefully that they don't burn. Drizzle with any remaining basil oil and serve immediately.

fields.headline: Tourist trappings
fields.standfirst: The cream teas, Welsh rarebit and kedgeree being served up at Collingbourne Ducis are good enough to eat even if you're not a day-tripper.
fields.trailText: The cream teas, Welsh rarebit and kedgeree being served up at Collingbourne Ducis are good enough to eat even if you're not a day-tripper.
fields.body:
Collingbourne Ducis is a pretty silly name for a restaurant, even one amid the Georgian splendour and Romanesque ruins of Bath. It sounds like a firm of solicitors or a difficult gymnastics manoeuvre. ('And now Ms Korbet will attempt a triple Collingbourne Ducis.') It certainly doesn't sound like a place you would go for something nice to eat.

The owner, Andrew Mellon, who up until now has been cooking for obscenely wealthy private clients in the United States, says it is the name of the West Country village where his parents live and, for good measure, that it was mentioned in Kazuo Ishiguro's novel Remains of the Day. Collingbourne Ducis has that very establishment, 'been here since the Doomsday Book' feel, which was just what he was looking for. Doubtless, Americans will love it; but Mellon is keen to argue that his new place is not only for US tourists - the locals are getting very excited about it too, apparently, and they are bound to form a major part of the clientele.

I was, I must admit, not hugely inclined to like the place. The first thing they sent me was not a menu - heaven forfend - but a set of annotated architect's plans complete with schematics for the toilets. I like to know where to go in an emergency as much as the next chap, but I don't need directions in advance. There were also horribly fussy textile samples from the interior designers: lots of heavy red and green stripes for the furniture, and pistachio twill for the uniforms. Again, a kind of faux Englishness that might appeal to those damned colonials, trudging about Bath in search of the echt experience of Albion.

Having now been there, though, I have to accept that while, on paper, Collingbourne Ducis is a little contrived, the finished article has a lot going for it and promises greater things to come. It looks not unlike one of those 80s country-house hotels in miniature, only without the bedrooms. There is a pretty, sunlit dining room upfront with a completely over-the-top rococo ceiling, and out back is a woodlined snug of a 'library' for the taking of after dinner drinks and cigars.

That said, the dinner service, which is yet to start, is clearly only a part of the deal. Collingbourne Ducis is designed as an all-day affair: home-made muffins and Irish porridge oats at breakfast, croissants and pastries at morning coffee, salads and sandwiches at lunchtime, scones and cakes and cream and jam at tea, leaving just enough time for Welsh rarebit and kedgeree for high tea. I can't help but feel a warm surge of affection for a place that resurrects high tea, complete with Welsh rarebit and kedgeree.

I went there for lunch on a rainy summer's day when the dining room, with space for only a couple of dozen, was still comfortably unencumbered by anybody else resembling a customer. Must be the weather, the two staff said, cheerfully; the day before, a Sunday, they had been packed out with punters for brunch, but not today. So it was to be just me and them. They handled my splendid isolation admirably, attending to my needs without making me feel like a social outcast.

To be honest, the lunch menu made disappointing reading: a few salads, a couple of sandwiches, the only mark of any ambition a three-cheese soufflé. I chose the Cos salad to start, a Caesar by any other name, at £5.50. The moment it arrived it became clear there was something interesting going on here, a very particular attention to detail. It's easy to turn out a mediocre Caesar, difficult to turn out a great one, and this - even with the odd unorthodox ingredient - was great: slices of rich, crumbly Parmesan, crisp lettuce, a spiky dressing and superb marinated anchovies, all beautifully presented on a frosted glass plate, rimmed with silver.

I followed it with the fish of the day, a fine piece of grilled bream, with smokey chargrilled vegetables, blanched spinach and some buttered spuds at a hugely reasonable £8.50. Sure, this wasn't culinary fireworks. But it was great ingredients really well done, the perfect thing for a blustery day.

Mellon will soon depart the kitchen to make way for chef Stuart Busby, who has worked with Gary Rhodes and Raymond Blanc and who will oversee an ambitious dinner menu packed full of the flicks and twists of modern European cooking. My suspicion is that, despite some of the more mannered bits of Collingbourne Ducis, it will be a fun place to eat. Reports from anybody who tries it for dinner would be greatly appreciated.

 Collingbourne Ducis, 12 George Street, Bath (01225 333 303). Lunch for two, including wine and service, costs around £40. Breakfast or high tea for two, around £20.

PS I have received a response from Ian Schrager, the man behind Spoon at the Sanderson hotel. In a hand-written note - which, generously, he didn't charge me for - he calls me 'nasty' and 'mean spirited', declares himself committed to good service and says that he finds it hard to 'accept' my way of doing things. I, in turn, find it hard to accept a place that charges 15 per cent service at the bar, double charges for a bottle of wine and leaves the service slip open. For reasons known only to himself, Mr Schrager doesn't see fit to mention - let alone apologise for - these particular features of my visit. Perhaps he'll do so when he writes again?

fields.headline: Soldier of mixed fortune
fields.standfirst: Ken Lukowiak transformed himself from ex-Para into an acclaimed author by describing the horrors of the Falklands. Now he turns to the next chapter in his life - drugs and the crime they led him into
fields.trailText: Ken Lukowiak transformed himself from ex-Para into an acclaimed author by describing the horrors of the Falklands. Now he turns to the next chapter in his life - drugs and the crime they led him into.
fields.body:
As an uneasy adolescent growing up in Cornwall, Ken Lukowiak had a friend called Bob who had once been in the Parachute Regiment. His red beret hung on a hook in his bedroom and to Ken, the son of Jehovah's Witnesses, desperate for escape, it was everything. He determined to join the Paras. 'If it was manhood I was looking for,' he would later say, 'they were the ones for me. They were the élite.' In 1979, aged 20, he finally did join the army. And, as he had hoped, it changed his life, but not in the way he expected. He became a writer.

He made his name almost a decade after his discharge from the army, with his first book, A Soldier's Song, published in 1993. It's an unflinching portrait of what it was like to fight in the Falklands War. In raw and staccato language he described the smell of the Argentinian dead and the callous disregard for their sanctity of British troops. He described the crush of noise from jets overhead so loud it would leave him with a fear of sharp noises that endures to this day. And he described, with great compassion, the men who wept their way through windswept nights under fire at Goose Green. 'We could do with fewer artistic visionaries from imaginary worlds and a few more like Lukowiak,' announced Literary Review upon its publication.

Now he has published his second book, Marijuana Time, and once again it draws on his military life. It is the story of what happened immediately after the events of A Soldier's Song, when he was posted to Belize. He travelled the country, met the people and, as the title suggests, bought enormous amounts of high-grade grass off them. Eventually he became involved in a drug-smuggling operation which led to a great fall, the break-up of his marriage and a spell in prison.

'When I was first seeing publishers about A Soldier's Song ,' he says now, 'I had this fear that because I'd done dope smuggling and gone to prison they wouldn't want the book. I was ashamed of it, frankly.' When he told them his dirty secret he discovered it was his problem and nobody else's. 'These people didn't care. They didn't care at all.'

Lukowiak had discovered his Unique Selling Point: he was a man who had done things - not because some editor had sent him out to do them in the name of reportage, but because that just happened to be the way his life had panned out. And now he could write about it all.

It tells an intriguing story: of the man conditioned by British Army training to believe he could manage any situation, who instead got so far out of his depth he could barely see the surface let alone gulp down air.

I first met Lukowiak in the mid-Nineties when he came to write freelance features for a Sunday newspaper supplement where I was also working. Back then we called him Combat Kenny and sent him off to war. What else do you do with a writer who was once a paratrooper, with time in Northern Ireland and the Falklands under his belt? It seemed to make sense.

'We were sending someone with combat experience to describe combat,' says a former editor of that supplement. He went to Bosnia for us three times and managed to get in to the Croat-controlled west side of Mostar when no other journalists were there. He reported the darkness of Rwanda twice and went to Argentina to confront the ghosts of the war he had fought against its people and was almost lynched for his efforts.'

In retrospect it seems odd, this appetite for conflict. A Soldier's Song had been a very visceral and clear-eyed argument against war. And yet, when his writing had secured him a release from the post-army life of the ex-squaddie, he went back into battle. 'I'm Ken, the ex-fucking Para,' he says simply, over a beer (always over a beer; he could drink us soft-bellied hacks under the table any day). 'War is what people wanted me to do so to get work I had to go. On the one hand I hated it but on the other it kept me hanging in there as a writer.' For Lukowiak, staying in the writing game is now what it's all about.

The new book is dedicated to Jill Tweedie, the great feminist writer and journalist, who died of motor neurone disease in 1993 and who, with her husband Alan Brien, was responsible for getting A Soldier's Song published in the first place. Lukowiak met them in the early Nineties when, after a miserable stretch on the dole, he had started making his living as a decorator and was sent to paint their house.

Although he didn't know who Tweedie was, he did know she made her living as a writer. He decided to show her the first part of what eventually became his Falklands book. She in turn sent the manuscript to friends at the Guardian, who decided to publish it, all 15,000 words. 'I knew from the moment I received that first cheque from the Guardian that I never wanted to work again.'

Today Lukowiak knows there are a lot of people in the media and literary circles in which Tweedie moved who mutter darkly about the dynamic of his relationship with her. They will accuse him of using her memory for his gain or of overplaying the strength of their relationship. They will say that, in her last months, he took up too much of her time, stole her away and isolated her from her friends. 'Fuck 'em,' he says, at first. 'I've got nothing else to say.'

But then it turns out he has much more to say. He keeps returning to the subject, niggling away at it even when it seems he is done. It drives him crazy, this rumour and innuendo. 'I always felt the reason I met Jill was not so she could get me published but so I could be there for her at the end,' he says. 'I was the one who could carry her.' Later he says: 'Anyway, I'd already been published by then so I didn't need to hang around.' And he comes back to it once more; changes the subject from dope and Belize and stretches in prison in an attempt to set the record straight: 'I just adored her. I loved her in a way I've never loved another woman in my life, though it wasn't sexual.'

So why the bitching? 'I don't know. When Jill was very ill I answered the phone a lot and nobody got to speak to Jill unless they went through me or Alan. A lot of the time she wasn't able to speak and I'd say that. And they - I call them the Hampstead crowd - it was almost as if they blamed me. That the only reason they couldn't talk to her was because of me.' Finally he says: 'She gave me a soul. By the time she met me I was a piece of human shit. My soul had gone. And I felt that if this woman could love me there had to be some good in me.'

Did you buy dope for her? 'I grew the gear for her. We had a whole bunch of plants. Big buggers they were. She was never a regular smoker but once she became ill she smoked more, a couple of joints a day maybe. The doctors were even suggesting it. Try a bit of that, they'd say. And it was nice to grow it for her because I wasn't contaminating her with any criminality because I didn't have to go out and score.'

And do you still smoke? He smiles. 'Every day,' he says. 'In all honesty I don't really know where I am with it. It doesn't even get me stoned any more. My girlfriend would tell you I need it, and maybe she's right. The people who say marijuana isn't addictive are talking bollocks. But then again maybe I've got an addictive personality.' He says that normally, when he sleeps, he does not dream. 'If I do stop smoking then I start dreaming again.' That, it is clear, is a Very Bad Thing. Lukowiak does not want to dream. He has far too much to dream about.

The curious thing is that he comes across in the book as a truly terrible dope smoker, prone to awful bouts of paranoia. He is forever regretting the weed just purchased, and the last joint smoked. 'Maybe a military environment is not the best one to be getting stoned in.' Too many large men carrying guns. Too many tanks. 'That's the thing about this book,' he says. 'Dope smokers will like it but so will Jack Straw. It's not a positive book about drugs. It's a very dark book. I end up in a very dark place.' It is, he says, the same as A Soldier's Song. 'Mad squaddies loved it and so did the anti-war lobby. It cut both ways.'

He says that everything he does now is in the service of A Soldier's Song ; it is the one piece of work that matters. 'I'll probably never write that well again because I'll probably never feel that much again.' That said there are limits to what he will do in its memory. He intends never to return to a war zone. He lives in Cornwall now, away from the noise and riot of London. He's 41 and he wants a little peace.

'I remember the first night I was in Bosnia I was in a flat and there was fighting going on outside. I was pacing up and down and wondering what I was doing there. This war had nothing to do with me and yet I was there. The truth is I have no wish to be really scared again.'

Whether he will truly be able to disengage though, is another question. He can be prone to acts of sweeping emotion. On returning from one trip to Bosnia, for example, he discovered that his then girlfriend, Sarah Macaulay, had started a relationship in his absence with a Labour politician called Gordon Brown. He used his key to her flat to let himself in and, finding a pile of men's suits, doused them with a pot of emulsion paint. It turned out the suits did not belong to the Chancellor-in-waiting but to Sarah's brother. 'People always overplayed that story,' Ken says now. 'They said it was gloss paint. Emulsion's a very different thing. I should know, I've been a decorator.'

Two years ago he spent a few weeks at the Edinburgh Festival where a stage adaptation of A Soldier's Song was being performed and even there, amid the face painters and jugglers and endless productions of Berkoff, he managed to fight a mini-war all of his own. He identified a performer in a production about Bosnia as a former officer in the murderous Bosnian Croat militia and, through appearances on television and in print, managed to chase him out of the country. Anybody who met Lukowiak in Edinburgh's bars that week would have found a man raging with incandescent fury; there is something intimidating about an angry man when you know he has fought in wars.

He smiles at the memory. 'One of the tools I have - a weapon in my writer's armoury - is my honesty,' he says. 'I just have to be honest. That's what made my name, the honesty of A Soldier's Song .' So that's what he does, whether in Bosnia or a wine bar in Edinburgh: he carries on being honest. 'Anything I do writing-wise is always about how I feel. That's my thing.'

The problem is he may be running out of material to have feelings about. He accepts that there have been two parts to his life, the experiences and the writing about them. But now the experience bank is all but empty. He has a contract to write another book, a collection of his journalism expanded to fill a volume and that, he says is enough to keep him in the game for a couple more years. Then he will have to find something else to write about. And that means only one thing: Lukowiak, the reluctant war reporter, will have to have more adventures. It's what he does.

fields.headline: Meadow sweet
fields.standfirst: Flowering grasses bring a touch of lightness to the garden, turning tired borders into fields of dreams
fields.trailText: Flowering grasses bring a touch of lightness to the garden, turning tired borders into fields of dreams.
fields.body:
Last year at the Chelsea Flower Show there was a garden by James Alexander-Sinclair that he described as a 'tame-flower meadow'. Among other elements, it used the pheasant grass Stipa arundinacea, with biennials and herbaceous perennials poking up through it. This compressed the effect of a meadow with flowers rising up above the soft heads of grass. I liked it very much, especially as Sarah had been rethinking the use of grasses in our jewel garden. Any such planting is not remotely like a real meadow, of course, any more than tropical plants in the garden are like a 'real' jungle. Gardens are not for that. If you want to see nature at its most naturalistic, simply ignore your garden altogether and let it get along without you.

We wanted to add the lightness of touch that grasses give to a border. Also, our jewel garden looks best in the low, slanting light of evening, and grasses pick up that light almost better than any other plant, holding it in the flowerheads and panicles like gentle torches. A real meadow depends on soil with low enough fertility to discourage the grass and encourage the flowers to flower fast, so they can produce seed before running out of nutrients or water.

Too much fertility is always the element that ruins an amateur gardener's wildflower aspirations. Our borders are fat with fertility. The soil breeds itself like a yeast. This is good for raising vegetables, flowers or Herefordshire cattle, but not at all right for a wildflower meadow, which would turn into lush grass in a couple of years. But make a parody of that inside the literal framework of a border and you can get the best of both worlds, with the fullness of a perennial border and the lightness and airiness of an unsprayed hayfield in June. The grasses add veils and layers and constantly move, transcending the slightly stuffy heaviness that a mixed border can arrive at in mid- and late summer.

Last year we planted Stipa giganteas in midsummer and they have grown this year to stupendous, majestic plants. We also had some Deschampsia flexuosa, which looked especially good interplanted with Cosmos atrosanguineus, and the combination kept going right into November. The success of the grasses we had meant we ordered a whole load of them. They were planted last autumn and we can now start to evaluate their effect, although a few will take a couple of years to get established.

We bought the Stipa arundinacea that James Alexander-Sinclair used and, at the moment, it is still modest, not yet in flower and has only a touch of the rusty fringes that make it such a good autumnal grass. We also have quite a few more Stipa gigantea. These must be planted to catch the evening light, as the flower heads will catch the low sunlight and glow like slow-motion sparklers. The initial plant only develops its flower spike in the second season, but if you plant in the autumn it will work next summer. Stipa gigantea are prone to being bashed by the wind and difficult to support, so they should not be in an exposed spot. It is difficult to know whether to plant them in a relatively open position - to enjoy their leaves as well as the extraordinary leaping tracer of flower - or to have them appearing out of a welter of flower at their base. Both look good.

One thinks of grasses as fundamentally green, but both these stipas rely on gold or russet, and if you look at any summer meadow it is hardly green at all - more fawn. It means the green foliage of your flowers does not disappear into the grassiness but works with and against it. I have to admit that this is all pathetically well tried and tested, but I am gleefully enjoying the change it brings to our borders.

I remember doing a bit on grasses on a TV programme, and when I produced the brown sedge Carex comans 'Bronze Form', I would not have inspired more instant revulsion if I had casually held up a dead rat to the camera. But I love it. Any sense of deadness is belied by its obvious vigour: it spills out of itself like a demented pekinese and if given half-decent drainage needs no attention and lasts nearly all year round.

Add to that Carex buchananii, which is similar but has charming wiggly bits at the ends of its leaves, and Carex flagellifera is a really useful extra foil for the border which works well with glaucous leaves such as cardoons, thalictrums, melianthus, macleayas and onopordums as well as lyme grass (Leymus arenarius) and the steely blue of Festuca glauca . By no means all the carex are brown - we have a variegated one called Carex hachijoensis 'Evergold' which has a pale golden stripe down its leaf.

The brown carex looks dry to the touch. As a contrast this is fine but the incredible tactility of some of the grasses comes as a welcome relief. Deschampsia flexuosa is called 'wavy-hair grass', as much for the way that it feels as for its looks, and we have some near enough to the edge to ruffle as you pass. But the most sensually tactile of all is Stipa tenuissima (sometimes labelled Stipa tenuifolia). If you plant it in groups of about five the upright clumps are like the finest, softest handfuls of hair.

Imperata cylindrica ' Rubra' is a mouthful of a name that rather solemnly describes one of the best grasses of all for a mixed border. When it does get going the tips of the leaves are flushed with a blood red. This spreads down the whole leaf as summer progresses, providing a fantastic foil for yellows, blues and surrounding greens. It loves our rich, rather damp soil and prefers not to be in full sun.

We have put in various miscanthuses to get height and volume, including M sinensis strictus, which has horizontal yellow bands. M malpartus has plum-pink flowers and M sinensis 'Silberfeder' has silver-pink ones. Miscanthus nepalensis produces rich, tawny gold plumes 'which can only be described as delicate strands of gold thread' according to Hopecroft Plants' catalogue. We have no plumes yet to report.

I have a tray of Melica altissima 'Atropurpurea' to be planted out. I've never grown this before but Sarah assures me they have deep purply brown panicles with black seeds, and she knows about these things. Among all these grasses the Knautia macedonica looks fantastic and Ligularia przewalskii is an ideal accompaniment. In fact any spikes or spires of flower look good in this tame-flower set up. The delphiniums, when they were in flower, looked just right as do the hollyhocks, inulas, heleniums and echinacea - as well as the gentler sprawlings of the Geranium 'Anne Folkhard', sprawling Clematis viticella and even the roses. It all sings.

My roots

The rain has given the snails a second wind and they have wiped out my first planting of French beans and are doing their best to eat through the third wave of lettuces before they get big enough for us. I cut comfrey to seduce them and perhaps it works, but I never know how you measure the success of these things.

The potatoes got blight at the end of the first week of July. I cut the tops off and used the flame thrower to burn off the haulms and kill the fungal spores. Potato blight indicates a turning point in the year. By the beginning of July the vegetable garden is becoming rich and full, the borders are sliding into sumptuousness and a fat softness takes over. Then it seems to become dissolute almost overnight: the potatoes are hacked back, the hedges are cut, delphiniums cut back and roses over. What is left is sharper, harder, experienced.

It is not worse, but it is certainly something else. One of the areas of the garden that is affected most dramatically is the herb garden, which looks positively tatty if it is not cropped right back by now. It comes again, but looks like a fleeced sheep for a few weeks.

For my birthday the other day, my son Adam gave me Smiling in Slow Motion by Derek Jarman - my favourite garden writer. Derek Jarman's Garden is my favourite gardening book: Howard Sooley's photographs seem so in tune with the subject and it transcends the bleedin' obvious that dogs so much of what is written about gardening.

Jarman's sexuality and illness (he died of Aids in February 1994) are central to the book, but the garden on the beach at Dungeness runs through it like a flowering thread. Gardens are enriched beyond all horticulture by the lives that pass through them. What do they know of gardens who only gardens know?

I am ashamed to say I have never been to see Prospect Cottage - nothing has stopped me except indolence. I wonder how it is now that Jarman has been dead these six years. Gardens move cruelly on, as indifferent to human sentiment as a crow alighting on an injured lamb. I finished the book terribly sad that we have lost a thoroughly good and heroic human being, and angry at the bigotry and hypocrisy that still demeans our society. But, above all, it makes me glad to be a gardener. So, inarticulate and very moved, I went into the garden and picked a bunch of flowers for Derek Jarman.

Your roots

Grasses often look spectacular throughout the winter. For this reason and for the health of the plant, leave the old leaves on until spring and cut them back in April when you see new growth.

Miscanthus need dividing and moving after about five years, to encourage them to retain their vigour. It is important that the divided sections should be growing vigorously as soon as they are planted, so moving or dividing grasses should be done in spring or early summer rather than autumn. (That is the official line - I will move some of ours as and when I want to, on the basis that plenty of water and a big hole will repair most of the traumas of moving anything.)

Resist the temptation to grow gardener's garters or Phalaris arundinacea var. picta . It looks fine for a year or two but then becomes as invasive a weed as couch grass. Keep it to a pot.

Last year we planted Stipa giganteas in midsummer and they have grown this year to stupendous, majestic plants. We also had some Deschampsia flexuosa, which looked especially good interplanted with Cosmos atrosanguineus, and the combination kept going right into November. The success of the grasses we had meant we ordered a whole load of them. They were planted last autumn and we can now start to evaluate their effect, although a few will take a couple of years to get established. We bought the Stipa arundinacea that James Alexander-Sinclair used and, at the moment, it is still modest, not yet in flower and has only a touch of the rusty fringes that make it such a good autumnal grass. We also have quite a few more Stipa gigantea. These must be planted to catch the evening light, as the flower heads will catch the low sunlight and glow like slow-motion sparklers. The initial plant only develops its flower spike in the second season, but if you plant in the autumn it will work next summer. Stipa gigantea are prone to being bashed by the wind and difficult to support, so they should not be in an exposed spot. It is difficult to know whether to plant them in a relatively open position - to enjoy their leaves as well as the extraordinary leaping tracer of flower - or to have them appearing out of a welter of flower at their base. Both look good. One thinks of grasses as fundamentally green, but both these stipas rely on gold or russet, and if you look at any summer meadow it is hardly green at all - more fawn. It means the green foliage of your flowers does not disappear into the grassiness but works with and against it. I have to admit that this is all pathetically well tried and tested, but I am gleefully enjoying the change it brings to our borders. I remember doing a bit on grasses on a TV programme, and when I produced the brown sedge Carex comans 'Bronze Form', I would not have inspired more instant revulsion if I had casually held up a dead rat to the camera. But I love it. Any sense of deadness is belied by its obvious vigour: it spills out of itself like a demented pekinese and if given half-decent drainage needs no attention and lasts nearly all year round. Add to that Carex buchananii, which is similar but has charming wiggly bits at the ends of its leaves, and Carex flagellifera is a really useful extra foil for the border which works well with glaucous leaves such as cardoons, thalictrums, melianthus, macleayas and onopordums as well as lyme grass (Leymus arenarius) and the steely blue of Festuca glauca . By no means all the carex are brown - we have a variegated one called Carex hachijoensis 'Evergold' which has a pale golden stripe down its leaf. The brown carex looks dry to the touch. As a contrast this is fine but the incredible tactility of some of the grasses comes as a welcome relief. Deschampsia flexuosa is called 'wavy-hair grass', as much for the way that it feels as for its looks, and we have some near enough to the edge to ruffle as you pass. But the most sensually tactile of all is Stipa tenuissima (sometimes labelled Stipa tenuifolia). If you plant it in groups of about five the upright clumps are like the finest, softest handfuls of hair. Imperata cylindrica ' Rubra' is a mouthful of a name that rather solemnly describes one of the best grasses of all for a mixed border. When it does get going the tips of the leaves are flushed with a blood red. This spreads down the whole leaf as summer progresses, providing a fantastic foil for yellows, blues and surrounding greens. It loves our rich, rather damp soil and prefers not to be in full sun. We have put in various miscanthuses to get height and volume, including M sinensis strictus, which has horizontal yellow bands. M malpartus has plum-pink flowers and M sinensis 'Silberfeder' has silver-pink ones. Miscanthus nepalensis produces rich, tawny gold plumes 'which can only be described as delicate strands of gold thread' according to Hopecroft Plants' catalogue. We have no plumes yet to report. I have a tray of Melica altissima 'Atropurpurea' to be planted out. I've never grown this before but Sarah assures me they have deep purply brown panicles with black seeds, and she knows about these things. Among all these grasses the Knautia macedonica looks fantastic and Ligularia przewalskii is an ideal accompaniment. In fact any spikes or spires of flower look good in this tame-flower set up. The delphiniums, when they were in flower, looked just right as do the hollyhocks, inulas, heleniums and echinacea - as well as the gentler sprawlings of the Geranium 'Anne Folkhard', sprawling Clematis viticella and even the roses. It all sings. My roots The rain has given the snails a second wind and they have wiped out my first planting of French beans and are doing their best to eat through the third wave of lettuces before they get big enough for us. I cut comfrey to seduce them and perhaps it works, but I never know how you measure the success of these things. The potatoes got blight at the end of the first week of July. I cut the tops off and used the flame thrower to burn off the haulms and kill the fungal spores. Potato blight indicates a turning point in the year. By the beginning of July the vegetable garden is becoming rich and full, the borders are sliding into sumptuousness and a fat softness takes over. Then it seems to become dissolute almost overnight: the potatoes are hacked back, the hedges are cut, delphiniums cut back and roses over. What is left is sharper, harder, experienced. It is not worse, but it is certainly something else. One of the areas of the garden that is affected most dramatically is the herb garden, which looks positively tatty if it is not cropped right back by now. It comes again, but looks like a fleeced sheep for a few weeks. For my birthday the other day, my son Adam gave me Smiling in Slow Motion by Derek Jarman - my favourite garden writer. Derek Jarman's Garden is my favourite gardening book: Howard Sooley's photographs seem so in tune with the subject and it transcends the bleedin' obvious that dogs so much of what is written about gardening. Jarman's sexuality and illness (he died of Aids in February 1994) are central to the book, but the garden on the beach at Dungeness runs through it like a flowering thread. Gardens are enriched beyond all horticulture by the lives that pass through them. What do they know of gardens who only gardens know? I am ashamed to say I have never been to see Prospect Cottage - nothing has stopped me except indolence. I wonder how it is now that Jarman has been dead these six years. Gardens move cruelly on, as indifferent to human sentiment as a crow alighting on an injured lamb. I finished the book terribly sad that we have lost a thoroughly good and heroic human being, and angry at the bigotry and hypocrisy that still demeans our society. But, above all, it makes me glad to be a gardener. So, inarticulate and very moved, I went into the garden and picked a bunch of flowers for Derek Jarman. Your roots Grasses often look spectacular throughout the winter. For this reason and for the health of the plant, leave the old leaves on until spring and cut them back in April when you see new growth. Miscanthus need dividing and moving after about five years, to encourage them to retain their vigour. It is important that the divided sections should be growing vigorously as soon as they are planted, so moving or dividing grasses should be done in spring or early summer rather than autumn. (That is the official line - I will move some of ours as and when I want to, on the basis that plenty of water and a big hole will repair most of the traumas of moving anything.) Resist the temptation to grow gardener's garters or Phalaris arundinacea var. picta . It looks fine for a year or two but then becomes as invasive a weed as couch grass. Keep it to a pot.

webTitle: Hypocrisy, not history, fuels attacks on films

fields.headline: Hypocrisy, not history, fuels attacks on films
fields.trailText: Sounding off: Philip French
fields.body:
What do these movies have in common: The Life and Death of Colonel Blimp, Objective Burma, Sword in the Desert, Braveheart, Michael Collins, Saving Private Ryan, U-571, The Patriot? The answer is that they have been accused of misrepresenting or misappropriating British achievement or the British character and should thus be banned.

Winston Churchill attempted unsuccessfully to suppress Colonel Blimp in 1943 and two journalists, E.W. and M.M. Robson, published a pamphlet charging that Powell and Pressburger's film featured 'a rabid anti-Englishness almost pathological in its intensity'. Objective Burma, which concentrated on a US commando raid and ignored Slim's 14th Army, was withdrawn through press pressure before its West End opening in 1945 and not released until 1952. Sword in the Desert (1949), a Hollywood film suggesting that British troops stationed in Palestine may have acted brutally towards illegal Jewish immigrants, was taken off after three days in the West End following demonstrations and a bomb scare engendered by press attacks; it has never been revived. The prosecution cases against the more recent films are familiar.

For Fleet Street to criticise the film industry for peddling lies and distortions is rather like the Niagara Falls attacking a garden hose for wasting water. This campaign against the movies has little to do with a genuine interest in history, the cinema or the pursuit of truth. It suggests to me the hypocrisy of newspapers, the dishonesty of journalists, the disingenuousness of scholars and the populist blathering of politicians. Everyone is looking for an angle, a source of righteous indignation, a way of avoiding rational argument.

How could you settle down to a calm discussion about the handling of the American War of Independence with an Evening Standard critic who can write: 'It might be a lesson if visiting US stars like Mel Gibson were in future detained for a moment or two at points of entry and asked why their presence should be considered to be in the public interest. Those who rape women run into immigration trouble. Why not those who rape British history?'

How can you respect a columnist writing on history and cinema for the Times when his own proprietor put Henry Ford's 'History is bunk' into the shade by dismissing the cautions of Lord Dacre, the distinguished historian Hugh Trevor-Roper, over the Hitler diaries, with a splenetic: 'Fuck Dacre.'

As for historians, in last Wednesday's Guardian, Francis Wheen showed how ready they were, in writing pieces on the occasion of the Queen Mother's 100th birthday celebrations, to airbrush out any embarrassing details about her political acts and opinions. As Wheen demonstrated, Andrew Roberts's article in the Daily Telegraph said precisely the opposite of what he wrote in his book, Eminent Churchillians.

And can you take Culture Secretary Chris Smith seriously when he says in the House something to the effect that he'll be keeping an eye on films like U-571 that appropriate British history? About as seriously, I'd say, as sensible folk took the ridiculous Duke of Windsor when, as Edward VIII, he visited the depressed south Wales coalfields and said that something should be done about it.

I'm not here to defend Hollywood's treatment of history. I think people who rely on the movies for their knowledge of the past deserve all they get. I've been a sceptic since the day I got a detention at the age of 13 after arguing with a schoolmaster over whether Disraeli financed the Suez Canal or merely bought shares after de Lesseps built it. My evidence was based on having seen the movie Suez.

On the other hand, that admirable novelist George MacDonald Fraser writes in The Hollywood History of the World: 'There is a popular belief that where history is concerned, Hollywood always gets it wrong - and sometimes it does. What is overlooked is the astonishing amount of history Hollywood has got right, and the immense, unacknowledged debt we owe to the commercial cinema as an illuminator of the story of mankind.'

There is something rather sickening in the way cultural condescension and an unacknowledged Americanophobia bring the Left and Right together to attack Hollywood. In his Times essay on U-571 and The Patriot, the ultra-conservative Michael Gove moves into a general assault on Tinseltown, accusing American cinema of being the font of global cultural pollution.

Meanwhile, over at the New Statesman, the left-wing Andrew Stephen moves on from The Patriot to an attack on ordinary Americans who appeared to be enjoying 'this nasty, $70m slash-trash' in the Washington cinema where he saw it. This encouraged him to a furious assault on anti-British prejudice in the States, American education and Hollywood.

His prejudice is partly fuelled by ignorance, as evinced in his claim that the unjust treatment of Indians 'is a verboten subject, both in American schools and in Hollywood studios'. Has he never come across the 1950 Broken Arrow and the 1993 Geronimo, or a hundred movies in between, among them the Oscar-winning Dances with Wolves, which American neo-conservatives attacked as being hostile to paleface society? Incidentally, Stephen uses the word 'verboten' because Roland Emmerich, the director of The Patriot, is German. A touch of Basil Fawlty here.

Behind these reactions, in addition to the indulgence of righteous indignation I've mentioned, is an absurd post-imperial sensitivity on the part of a country that was for too long feared, flattered, and fawned over. In 1940, Harry Watt and Humphrey Jennings collaborated on a documentary about the Blitz, shown in America as London Can Take It and at home as Britain Can Take It.

The commentary, delivered by American journalist Quentin Reynolds, said, referring to the falling bombs: 'Those are not Hollywood sound effects.' Sixty years later, in this first year of a new century, it would seem that what the British can't take are those Hollywood sound effects.

fields.headline: Gong Li
fields.standfirst: China's biggest star is eyeing Hollywood - but he's in no rush
fields.trailText: China's biggest star is eyeing Hollywood - but he's in no rush
fields.body:
Director plucks actress out of nowhere and she decides he is going to make her a star as well as his lover. It is a story as old as the movies, but it comes in slightly different guises, ranging from the momentous (Von Sternberg meets Dietrich) to the bathetic (John Derek meets Bo). Zhang Yimou's encounter with Gong Li falls into the grander side of that tradition.

An experienced cinematographer, Zhang chose Gong - still an acting student - to star in his directorial debut, Red Sorghum (1987). It became the first mainland Chinese film to get a commercial release in the United States and launched the wave of stately Technicolor epics that made China the flavour of the Nineties on the arthouse circuit. And almost all of the big Chinese films of the time - Raise The Red Lantern (1991), Farewell My Concubine (1993) and To Live (1994) - starred Gong.

Many were made with the tacit assumption that they would be banned at home but could provide the state with useful export dollars. By the time she broke up with Zhang in 1995 - after the Thirties gangster movie Shanghai Triad (1995), Gong was the most famous Chinese actress ever outside China and had won a Best Actress award at Venice for Zhang's The Story Of Qui Ju (1992).

But while Zhang's most recent film - Not One Less - is a gritty film about rural poverty made with non-professional actors, Gong's latest - The Emperor and the Assassin - is, unsurprisingly, a big historical movie.

This one goes back further into the past, to the time of the first emperor, and Gong plays the woman torn between the ruler and the man sent to kill him. She is not yet about to drop a winning formula.

She was born in Shenyang in 1965. Her father taught economics at university. She turned to acting only when her singing failed to get her into music school. It was two years later that Zhang came calling.

Out of costume, she seems nothing like the long-suffering symbol of China's sorrows she embodies on film. She's blunt, laying into her adopted home town of Hong Kong: 'The climate here is too humid and there are not many friends here. Most people don't talk about the arts.'

She moved to the philistine island-city to live with Ooi Wei Ming, the tobacco executive she married in 1996. As well as acting, she models for L'Oreal and has said: 'I can spend a whole day choosing cosmetics.'

And she takes the usual celebrity gripes just a little further than most, wanting draconian action taken against the tabloids. 'These should not be ordinary sanctions, but strict sanctions, like closing down the newspaper.'

As for Hollywood, she has never ruled it out. In 1997 she starred with Jeremy Irons in the English-language Chinese Box , a drama set during the Hong Kong handover - that's as close as she's got. She is currently looking for a script to do with Richard Gere. But she is in no rush. After all, when you are the biggest star to emerge from the world's most populous country, the US doesn't seem that big a deal.

Five things you should know about Gong Li

1 She recorded an album of Madonna songs.

2 The French government gave her the status of Officer des Arts et Lettres in 1998 for contributions to the cinema.

3 The Red Hot Chili Peppers have a song called Gong Li named after her.

4 Despite the success of Red Sorghum , she stayed on at Beijing's Central Drama Academy to graduate in 1989.

5 She was on the jury at the 1997 Cannes film festival.

 The Emperor and the Assassin opened on Friday.
