fields.headline: This one's a hit...
fields.standfirst: Stephen Frears's adaptation of High Fidelity is a skilled and witty triumph
fields.trailText: Philip French: High Fidelity is an extraordinarily funny film, full of verbal and visual wit. And it is assembled with immense skill
fields.body:
Nick Hornby's novel High Fidelity is set specifically and convincingly in London. But it touches so amusingly, perceptively and honestly on what it's like to be a confused, self-doubting young man immersed in popular culture in any large city in the Western world at the end of the twentieth century that the transposition to Chicago for the movie version involves surprisingly little reworking.

A fine American actor, John Cusack, plays the central character, Rob Gordon, dedicated, unprosperous proprietor of a specialist record store called Championship Vinyl. Danish actress Iben Hjejle plays his lawyer girlfriend, who has just left him. They are directed by an Englishman, Stephen Frears, whose last movie, The Hi-Lo Country, was an off-beat western.

The script is by four Americans, one of them Cusack himself, who has also co-produced with a couple of Britons and a couple of Americans, while the cinematographer, Seamus McGarvey, comes from Ulster and the editor, Mick Audsley, from London. They all seem very much at home in slightly rundown areas of the Windy City, though the torrential rain that frequently matches the hero's depressed states suggests it might easily be renamed the Rainy City.

Cusack has the rare ability to play characters who have a complex inner life and to suggest a sense of decency that rejects piety - his hitman in Grosse Point Blank, for instance, and the puppeteer in Being John Malkovich. His everyday neurotics are people with whom we can easily identify.

Here, he dominates the film, taking us into Rob's mind. For much of the time, he speaks directly to camera, not just in set-pieces, but while engaged in conversations or talking on the phone or walking down the street. Pop music and films are his obsessive interests, his knowledge of them encyclopedic and, since puberty, he has been troubled by girls, whom he fears, desires and tries to understand.

His tastes define him, and for Rob and the pair of geeky assistants in his shop - the aggressive, overweight Barry (Jack Black) and the shy, shaven-headed Dick (Todd Louiso) - the music and films they admire have become shibboleths to test everyone they meet. 'What matters is what you like,' says Rob, 'not what you are like.'

As many of us do, Rob seeks to impose order on his life by drawing up lists. His most extravagant gesture is to rearrange his vast collection of LPs as a form of autobiography so that he has to think of the personal association a record has to locate it. When Laura leaves him, he rejects her from a list of 'top five most memorable split-ups'. This first takes him down memory lane to recall five of his ex-girlfriends, starting with his first intense kiss when he was 14.

These flashbacks recall Annie Hall and there is a brief appearance by Bruce Springsteen in an imaginary conversation with Rob that brings to mind Woody Allen's encounter with Marshall McLuhan in that picture.

When Rob later sets about looking up the old girlfriends, we think of Julien Duvivier's romantic classic of the Thirties, Un Carnet du Bal, where Marie Bell found nothing but misery when tracking down the swains of her young womanhood.

High Fidelity is an extraordinarily funny film, full of verbal and visual wit. And it is assembled with immense skill. There is a brilliant sequence when Rob reconstructs in his mind a conversation between Laura and their mutual friend, Liz (Joan Cusack), knowing that Laura must have touched on four key moments (those lists again) in their relationship. The film constantly cuts in mid-sentence between Rob talking to camera in a bar and the two women conversing over lunch, and a combination of astute direction, fine acting and spot-on editing gives it an easy, seamless quality.

The picture never scores cheap points off anybody, which does not, of course, mean that the characters involved do not often obtain satisfaction, if only temporarily, by thinking they have won an argument or put someone in his or her place. When Rob is putting his past in order, he often employs a form of chopped logic that briefly satisfies him. At the end, both he and we, the audience, are happily surprised by the way things turn out for him and his assistants, Barry and Dick.

Catherine Zeta-Jones plays Charlie, the hollow sophisticate, memorable break-up number four, who helps Rob see the vanity of the world, and it is good to see her mixing with people her own age.

When Laura leaves him, he rejects her from a list of 'top five most memorable split-ups'. This first takes him down memory lane to recall five of his ex-girlfriends, starting with his first intense kiss when he was 14. These flashbacks recall Annie Hall and there is a brief appearance by Bruce Springsteen in an imaginary conversation with Rob that brings to mind Woody Allen's encounter with Marshall McLuhan in that picture. When Rob later sets about looking up the old girlfriends, we think of Julien Duvivier's romantic classic of the Thirties, Un Carnet du Bal, where Marie Bell found nothing but misery when tracking down the swains of her young womanhood. High Fidelity is an extraordinarily funny film, full of verbal and visual wit. And it is assembled with immense skill. There is a brilliant sequence when Rob reconstructs in his mind a conversation between Laura and their mutual friend, Liz (Joan Cusack), knowing that Laura must have touched on four key moments (those lists again) in their relationship. The film constantly cuts in mid-sentence between Rob talking to camera in a bar and the two women conversing over lunch, and a combination of astute direction, fine acting and spot-on editing gives it an easy, seamless quality. The picture never scores cheap points off anybody, which does not, of course, mean that the characters involved do not often obtain satisfaction, if only temporarily, by thinking they have won an argument or put someone in his or her place. When Rob is putting his past in order, he often employs a form of chopped logic that briefly satisfies him. At the end, both he and we, the audience, are happily surprised by the way things turn out for him and his assistants, Barry and Dick. Catherine Zeta-Jones plays Charlie, the hollow sophisticate, memorable break-up number four, who helps Rob see the vanity of the world, and it is good to see her mixing with people her own age.

fields.headline: The reclusive Mr Kubrick revealed
fields.standfirst: Despite a slim output, Stanley Kubrick still attracts huge critical attention. Philip French on the latest additions to the literature
fields.trailText: Despite a slim output, Stanley Kubrick still attracts huge critical attention. Philip French on the latest additions to the literature
fields.body:
Kubrick
Michael Herr
Picador £10, pp98
Buy it at BOL

The Complete Kubrick
David Hughes
Virgin £15.99, pp303

Buy it at BOL

Stanley Kubrick, Director: a Visual Analysis
Alexander Walker, Sybil Taylor and Ulrich Ruchti
Weidenfeld & Nicolson £25, pp376

Michael Curtiz directed more than 150 films in every genre, a fair number of them popular classics - The Sea Hawk, The Adventures of Robin Hood, Mildred Pierce and, most famously, Casablanca. By all accounts, he was a demanding, aloof figure and anecdotes about his working process abound, but his personality and 50-year career have not excited great interest among cineastes or the public.

There's only one book about him, a slim, rather scholarly work. The demanding, aloof Stanley Kubrick, however, who made only 13 feature films in 50 years, none more enduringly popular than the best-known Curtiz movies (and several not as good), has attracted an astonishing amount of attention.

In the year before his death on 7 March last year at the age of 70, there were two large, unauthorised biographies. Since then there have been books by two of his literary collaborators and revised editions of the officially approved studies by the only film critics he took into his confidence - Michel Ciment in France and Alexander Walker in this country.

What makes Kubrick fascinating is the intensity of his art and his personality which led him to exact extraordinary demands on himself and those around him. In 1960, after bruising encounters with egocentric actor-producers - Marlon Brando fired him from One-Eyed Jacks, Kirk Douglas humiliated him on Spartacus - Kubrick settled in Britain, but remaining intensely American to the last.

He became a combination of Prospero, Howard Hughes and Harry Lime, an eccentric business genius with magical powers and a demonic charm. Living a mysterious, reclusive life, he had everybody else's phone number but never gave out his own.

His lifelong passions (and during the postwar years his principal sources of income) were photography and chess, the first a matter of capturing the precise, fleeting moment, the second a deadly game involving anticipating how to act at crucial times in the future.

Michael Herr, the author of Dispatches, was drawn into Kubrick's world in 1980, initially with the idea of writing a film on the Holocaust, or on Jung, or a version of Schnitzler's Dream Story. They ended up working together on Full Metal Jacket, Kubrick's penultimate picture, set in South Carolina and Vietnam, shot in East Anglia and London's Docklands.

Like most people who met Kubrick and became the recipients of his marathon phone calls, Herr fell under his spell. But like the witnesses in Citizen Kane and The Bad and the Beautiful, he got over being dazzled by the charisma, and in his brief memoir Kubrick he tries to understand this complex artist.

To Herr, Kubrick was both a social Darwinist and a liberal humanist, a combination of tight-fisted capitalist businessman and obsessive artist, a man who made 'art films with blockbuster pretensions'. Contrary to the usual view that Kubrick was a film-maker with no personal life, Herr claims 'it would be more correct to say that he had no professional life since everything he did... was utterly personal'. When you signed on with him (and he drew up tight contracts), you became involved in 'dragging massive blocks nights and weekends and holidays in order to build another one of Stanley's pyramids, and whether cheerful or resentful didn't matter that much to him, although he preferred cheerful'.

Herr's insightful book concludes with a detailed defence of Kubrick's posthumously released film Eyes Wide Shut, with which I largely agree, and an attack on its co-screenwriter Frederic Raphael's memoir of working with Kubrick - Eyes Wide Open - which I think ill-advised. Kubrick's friends and admirers too readily gang up on those who break ranks and Kubrick should have known when he hired Raphael that he wasn't taking on the sort of modest, cinematically inxperienced writer he liked working with.

I was thus amused, and surprised, to read in The Complete Kubrick that Stanley Donen, director of Singin' in the Rain and subject of a bizarre homage in A Clockwork Orange, was planning a film based on Eyes Wide Open starring Frederic Raphael as Kubrick and Tom Conti (Raphael's alter ego in The Glittering Prizes) as Raphael. As John Wayne says in The Searchers: 'That'll be the day.'

There is much stuff like this in David Hughes's The Complete Kubrick, a widely researched account of all the films (and the uncompleted projects), every line packed with accumulated facts, opinions and speculation on the sources, influences, making and impact of the films. The level of accuracy is high (the only obvious serious error is the claim that novelist Howard Fast, author of Spartacus, was one of the Hollywood 10) and the book is both fun to read and valuable for reference.

But turning from The Complete Kubrick to Alexander Walker's Stanley Kubrick, Director, a book on which Hughes extensively draws for quotations and insights, is like exchanging an anorak for a thinking cap. First published in 1971 as Stanley Kubrick Directs, Walker's book has been re-designed by Sybil Taylor and Ulrich Ruchti and is among the best studies ever made of a director.

Like Michael Ciment's excellent Kubrick (translated by Gilbert Adair in 1983, but out of print with no British edition of the revised French version in sight), it uses, at Kubrick's request, frame blow-ups rather than stills. These illustrations truly illuminate the text. People in production stills strike attitudes; frame blow-ups make points.To his affectionate, but not uncritical text, Walker has added a 'personal postscript' that ends with a moving account of Kubrick's funeral.

Both Ciment and Walker help us see what they think makes Kubrick's films special. They direct us to the results of his fastidiousness as they manifest themselves on screen - things that cannot be explained verbally. They have to be seen, experienced visually, to be understood.

Provocatively, Herr claims that a sensitivity to language preceded the image for Kubrick, hence his reverence for Nabokov and Burgess. Perhaps there's something Jewish here, the Old Testament awe for the word. Kubrick's Jewishness is a major subject of contention between Herr and Raphael.

fields.headline: Go for it!
fields.standfirst: Late bargains
fields.trailText: Thailand | Las Vegas | Brighton |Antwerp | Red Sea | Mediterranean | New Zealand | Australia
fields.body:
Holidays

Thailand

Imaginative Traveller's Northern Thailand trip has a little of everything: a boat trip along the River Kwai, night-shopping at a bazaar and a hill trek. There are weekly departures from Heathrow or Manchester from 1 September to 8 December and the price, £920, includes flights, transport, 17 nights accommodation and some meals. Tel: 020 8742 8612.

Las Vegas

From your bank manager's point of view three nights in Vegas is probably long enough. Quest Worldwide (020 8546 6000) has a short break at the Stratosphere Hotel from £399 per person, including return flights from Heathrow. The hotel owns the world's highest rollercoaster, 1,000ft above Las Vegas.

Brighton

Families staying at Brighton's only five-star hotel, the De Vere Grand, will be entitled to free tickets to the Monster Creepy Crawlies exhibition at the Brighton Centre next door. The exhibition features massive spiders and beetles, as well as a giant ant tunnel. Weekend Bug Breaks start at £180 for two nights B&B per person. Tel: 01273 224 300.

Antwerp

Experience Antwerp as it was 400 years ago at the Rubens market. Traders in sixteenth-century dress will peddle their wares on 15 August, and you can bag your two-night stay with Shortbreaks (020 8402 0007) for £179 per person. Price includes B&B at the four-star Astrid Park Plaza and all rail travel.

Red Sea

Catering for the diving obsessive and a not-so-keen partner, Regal Holidays (0870 2201 777) is offering five days diving for one and five days snorkelling for the other in the Red Sea from £489 per person. Flights from Gatwick, seven nights' accommodation and transfers are included. Departures on 18 or 25 August.

Mediterranean

Save £467 by cruising round the sights of the Mediterranean for seven days. Departing from Venice on 12, 19 and 26 August, ports of call include Bari, Santorini, Rhodes and Dubrovnik. A twin cabin, flights, transfers and on-board meals is £499 per person from Mediterranean Shipping Cruises (020 7637 2525).

Flights

New Zealand and Australia

If you are planning a trip to New Zealand or Australia consider Travelbag's offer of two free stopovers in Malaysia for return flights on Malaysian Airlines booked by 15 August. You could stay in Penang, Langkawi, Kuantan or Singapore. The deal is for travel between 16 August and 30 November and between 1 January and 31 March 2001. Call 0870 737 7832 for details.

fields.headline: What comes around...
fields.trailText: Long ago, in the days before the Fleet Street diaspora, there existed a golden age of non-confessional journalism...
fields.body:
Long ago, in the days before the Fleet Street diaspora, there existed a golden age of non-confessional journalism in which newspaper columnists were not obliged to write columns about their knickers and then stretch them shamelessly to the size of a best-selling paperback novel (the columns, not the knickers).

Instead, they were allowed to indulge in spry, amusing word-games, literary jeux d'esprits and frivolous pensées peppered with tongue-in-cheek French phrases, freestyling and riffing from a starting point that might be as simple as the cup of coffee they had that morning, but which would turn into an inventive pastiche of the Old Testament, a meditation on driving in fog or a polemic on Keynesian economics in the style of La Traviata.

Now, of course, merely having the cup of coffee would provide sufficient material for an 800-word column, as long as there was some sex or emotional trauma nearby. But in those days, columns were little stages for improvisation, Whose Line Is It Anyway in print, and the undisputed star of the show was Michael Frayn.

It's chilling to think how near those of us born in the 1970s came to missing the Frayn oeuvre altogether. His columns in the Guardian and The Observer ran from 1952 until 1968, were collected in four books, which in time drifted out of print and might have been lost for good had James Fenton not saved them for future generations by collecting the choicest together in The Original Michael Frayn (1983), reprinted last year by Methuen. But even Fenton could not have predicted the Frayn revival that the turn of the century would bring.

Within the last month, Methuen has published a new collection of columns, The Additional Michael Frayn, while Faber and Faber, which published his Booker-shortlisted novel Headlong last year, has reissued two of his earlier novels, A Landing on the Sun and the one universally known as 'the Fleet Street novel'.

Towards the End of the Morning (its official title) has become a classic in the intervening years, a status confirmed by prefacing this edition with an introduction by the author explaining life in the newspaper industry in the grey, chilly Fifties, lest the references be lost on post-Murdoch readers. While still gut-crunchingly funny, Towards the End of the Morning is also, like the collected columns, touchingly elegiac, a swansong for a way of life and writing now obsolete.

But perhaps not. Frayn's current popularity demonstrates the old truism that if you stand still long enough, fashion catches you up on the next circuit. It's encouraging to see that in a climate where publishers seem concerned only with what is 'hip and edgy', genuine comic writing still stays the distance.

webTitle: What now? Life after Equitable chaos

fields.headline: What now? Life after Equitable chaos
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott's guide for clients of the insurer whose future is on the line
fields.trailText: Maria Scott's guide for clients of the insurer whose future is on the line.
fields.body:
The defeat of insurer Equitable Life in the House of Lords last week ended an 18-month legal battle over an obscure-sounding pension product. But the defeat, which has resulted in Equitable putting itself up for sale, has implications beyond holders of its Guaranteed Annuity Policies (GARs) and even beyond this company.

Here is a guide for the firm's 450,000 customers:

What went wrong and why?

Equitable followed a fashion between 20 and 30 years ago by selling plans that guaranteed to pay investors a minimum income.

Clients were promised pensions worth roughly 11 per cent of of their personal fund on retirement. But the returns available to Equitable in the financial market to pay the guarantees are around only a half to a third of this.

It chose to reduce the customers' final bonuses payable on its with-profit pensions so that it would not have to foot the £1.5 billion bill for honouring the guarantees. Pensioners were left with incomes lower than the insurer had promised.

After a flood of complaints the insurer mounted a legal case to resolve the argument.

Need it have happened?

Yes and no. Equitable did not build up the level of reserves that other insurers did over the years. It believed it should pay the maximum returns to policyholders as it went along, and not hoard money.

The firm also paid generous early surrender values to policyholder during years when rivals were paying derisory amounts, says Ned Cazalet, of Cazalet Financing Consulting.

This philosophy earned Equitable accolades and places in best-buy tables, but left it exposed when interest rates - the deciding factor in setting annuities - fell much lower than expected.

Cazalet says Equitable also suffered from an unforeseen increase in life expectancy, which has raised the cost of honouring the guarantees.

Equitable might be forgiven for having failed to predict these developments, but industry observers believe the firm's handling of the row over the annuities has been poor. It chose to fight an long battle rather than face the problem when it arose. Equitable's sales have fallen during the row; leading financial advisers have been reluctant to recommend it because of the uncertainty.

What other Equitable investments are affected?

Anything that is also invested in Equitable's with-profits fund. The insurer is taking an estimated £1.5bn from elsewhere - a final figure will be confirmed on Wednesday - and transferring it to the 100,000 people with GARs. As a mutual it has nowhere else to get the money.

The result is that returns on products such as mortgage endowments and savings schemes will fall. Nigel Webb of Equitable says: 'To put that back is one reason we are seeking a buyer.'

Investors with unit-linked, and other non with-profits investments will not be affected directly. There must be a question mark, though, over the effect of the uncertainty on the morale, and the results, of investment managers at Equitable.

Is my mortgage less likely to be paid off?

Equitable claims that all its mortgages were on course to be repaid anyway, and the £1.5bn transfer should not have a significant affect.

Do I need to take action?

Advisers are urging investors to sit tight, pointing out that a rash of policy surrenders might rebound by worsening the firm's plight.

Robert Guy, of John Charcol says: 'We believe the insurer will be an attractive buy, given the value of its customers to any potential partner. They simply need the financial support.'

Martyn Laverick, at Chartwell Investment Management, says people contributing to Equitable pensions will have to decide whether it is worth continuing to do so, or possibly to transfer their fund elsewhere. But this decision should not be made until the insurer's future is clearer.

Charges on Equitable policies are low and its existing penalties reasonable, so those who leave should not face heavy transfer fees. But he stresses that investors should not move quickly. 'There are stakeholder pensions and other issues to look at,' says Laverick.

He points out that Equitable also has with profit bonds but, again, investors should not rush to surrender.

Jason Hollands, at Best Investment, recommends that investors should wait 18 months to decide what to do, by which time they may also have received a windfall from the sale of the insurer.

I have a guaranteed policy. What do I do now?

You and the 99,000 other people with these policies are the clear winners from this sad fiasco. Around 27,000 people with these types of policies have reached retirement age. They should now contact their independent adviser or Equitable sales rep. Others with such policies should hang on to them.

Stuart Bayliss, of independent adviser Annuity Direct, who has championed the cause of the Equitable pensioners, says there are a number of outstanding questions for holders of some guaranteed policies. Some people have already used their guaranteed policies to buy annuities elsewhere, and there is a question mark over whether they will be compensated.

Equitable says it will give details in three weeks' time of a review to resolve the position of these policyholders and of those who have died. The review will be overseen by an independent actuary.

Do other insurers have the same problem?

Several do, including such big names as Standard Life, CGNU (the combined Norwich Union and Commercial Union) and Scottish Widows. Most agreed to pay the guarantees, and Ned Cazalet estimates that the total cost of this to the industry is around £10bn . Most have provided for the guarantees.

One smaller insurer, MGM, has refused to pay the guaranteed pensions. It is taking legal advice following last week's judgment. There is speculation that it, too, will have to find a partner, although MGM claims it is stronger than Equitable.

What will Equitable do now?

It is seeking a buyer. Companies believed to be interested include the Prudential, CGNU and European insurance groups.

Will I get a windfall?

Probably, but don't expect too much after a buyer has underwritten the cost of funding the guarantees.

There must be a question mark, though, over the effect of the uncertainty on the morale, and the results, of investment managers at Equitable. Is my mortgage less likely to be paid off? Equitable claims that all its mortgages were on course to be repaid anyway, and the £1.5bn transfer should not have a significant affect. Do I need to take action? Advisers are urging investors to sit tight, pointing out that a rash of policy surrenders might rebound by worsening the firm's plight. Robert Guy, of John Charcol says: 'We believe the insurer will be an attractive buy, given the value of its customers to any potential partner. They simply need the financial support.' Martyn Laverick, at Chartwell Investment Management, says people contributing to Equitable pensions will have to decide whether it is worth continuing to do so, or possibly to transfer their fund elsewhere. But this decision should not be made until the insurer's future is clearer. Charges on Equitable policies are low and its existing penalties reasonable, so those who leave should not face heavy transfer fees. But he stresses that investors should not move quickly. 'There are stakeholder pensions and other issues to look at,' says Laverick. He points out that Equitable also has with profit bonds but, again, investors should not rush to surrender. Jason Hollands, at Best Investment, recommends that investors should wait 18 months to decide what to do, by which time they may also have received a windfall from the sale of the insurer. I have a guaranteed policy. What do I do now? You and the 99,000 other people with these policies are the clear winners from this sad fiasco. Around 27,000 people with these types of policies have reached retirement age. They should now contact their independent adviser or Equitable sales rep. Others with such policies should hang on to them. Stuart Bayliss, of independent adviser Annuity Direct, who has championed the cause of the Equitable pensioners, says there are a number of outstanding questions for holders of some guaranteed policies. Some people have already used their guaranteed policies to buy annuities elsewhere, and there is a question mark over whether they will be compensated. Equitable says it will give details in three weeks' time of a review to resolve the position of these policyholders and of those who have died. The review will be overseen by an independent actuary. Do other insurers have the same problem? Several do, including such big names as Standard Life, CGNU (the combined Norwich Union and Commercial Union) and Scottish Widows. Most agreed to pay the guarantees, and Ned Cazalet estimates that the total cost of this to the industry is around £10bn . Most have provided for the guarantees. One smaller insurer, MGM, has refused to pay the guaranteed pensions. It is taking legal advice following last week's judgment. There is speculation that it, too, will have to find a partner, although MGM claims it is stronger than Equitable. What will Equitable do now? It is seeking a buyer. Companies believed to be interested include the Prudential, CGNU and European insurance groups. Will I get a windfall? Probably, but don't expect too much after a buyer has underwritten the cost of funding the guarantees.

webTitle: Monks picks tough price for euro entry

fields.headline: Monks picks tough price for euro entry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: British entry to the euro could be achieved comfortably only if the pound fell in value to 2.65 deutschmarks, TUC leader John Monks told The Observer last week.
fields.body:
British entry to the euro could be achieved comfortably only if the pound fell in value to 2.65 deutschmarks, TUC leader John Monks told The Observer last week.

He warned that joining at the higher levels proposed recently by pro-euro businessmen could threaten jobs in industry and the public sector as well as vital Government spending on services.

Monks is a leading supporter of early British membership of the single currency. But his views on a 'realistic' level of sterling for going in indicate that he believes this country is unlikely to be able to join soon. The pound was worth DM3.17 last Friday. The last time it was at DM2.65 was in February 1997.

Monks' views are more rigorous than those of businessmen who have attempted to increase pressure on the Government by arguing that improvements in British industry mean it could survive at higher exchange rates.

Earlier this month the outgoing president of the Confederation of British Industry, Sir Clive Thompson, said British productivity had improved enough in the past two years to have raised the realistic rate of entry from DM2.65 to DM2.85. And Last month Vauxhall boss Nick Reilly said he believed Britain could enter at DM3.

But Monks said: 'I think DM2.85 is the upper edge, the top end. We would be much more comfortable with DM2.65. There may be an advantage to manufacturing, but the problems would come to the public sector. People could pay with jobs.'

Despite problems with the exchange rate, he believes the Government should campaign for entry and hold an early referendum. If the exchange rate was unrealistic at the time of the vote, entry itself could be delayed until the rate was more suitable.

Monks' views will interest unions on both sides of the increasingly outspoken debate on the issue.

The sceptics in the TUC include public service union Unison, whose members would be affected by lower public spending, and the Transport & General Workers. The Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union and the big general union, the GMB, are both enthusiastic.

webTitle: Observer review: Promise of a Dream by Sheila Rowbotham

fields.headline: Woman of substance
fields.standfirst: Sheila Rowbotham was there and she can still remember the Sixties. She tells the story of a radical decade in Promise of a Dream
fields.trailText: Sheila Rowbotham was there and she can still remember the Sixties. She tells the story of a radical decade in Promise of a Dream
fields.body:
Promise of a Dream: Remembering the Sixties
Sheila Rowbotham
Allen Lane/the Penguin Press £18.99, pp261
Buy it at BOL

Most of the time, history happens elsewhere, to other people. It acquires a shape and hardens into a meaning as it withdraws into the past. We learn about it in schools, read about it in newspapers, rarely feel on intimate terms with it. But for some people, the Sixties (by which we usually mean the late Sixties and early Seventies) had the exhilarating sense of being history in the making: a grass-roots, present-tense and emotionally charged revolution, a world turned upside down and flooded with new freedom.

And for many other people,who were born too early and who came of age in the grey and tailored Fifties, or who came too late, or who never quite grasped what was going on until they read about it later, there was the feeling of having missed out on something: on a moment, a promise, a dream, a sense of possibility. Philip Larkin wrote that 'sex began in 1963/ which was too late for me'.

A friend of mine was backpacking in Paris in 1968, but never knew he was in the middle of a student uprising; for him, it just meant the trains were delayed and the bars were closed. I left school in the late Seventies. I was hanging on the coat-tails of the decade. By the time I was at university, for instance, women's studies was already on the curriculum.

However hard we tried to be part of a 'movement', it had become a subject and an ism rather than a process. And we hadn't been there, in the trenches sharing adventures and hardship, suffering and triumph. We could never be heroes, just inheritors, with all the grateful, resentful, competitive, disdainful and idealising feelings that inheritors have.

The nostalgia many of us feel for the mythologised Sixties is a curious, fake nostalgia for somewhere we have never been. Reading Sheila Rowbotham's touching memoir of the Sixties, however, it is clear that many people who had been there, involved and excited and touched with the glow of history, also felt this sense of not quite belonging - hence the title, in which two abstract words are yoked together to give a sense of elegy and disappointment.

I had always thought of Rowbotham - feminist historian, seasoned political campaigner, one of the organisers of the first women's liberation conference in Britain - as a secure and assertive feminist; someone who was at the centre. I had not been expecting the raw and uncertain tone of her autobiography; her endearing self-doubts, her vanity and pluck.

When Rowbotham says the Sixties, she means it. Her autobiography starts in 1960, when she was a 16-year-old in the north of England, pushing against the confines of her conservative upbringing at home and struggling with A-levels and cold showers at a Methodist boarding school.

Written down cold, her CV is impressively radical: she spent a year in France, where she was a Paris beatnik, dressed in black, lived with a pavement artist in Marseilles, fell in and out of love. She went to Oxford University, where she became excited about the silent history of ordinary people. She lived in a communal house in Hackney, where nobody cleaned up and everybody was welcome; she taught history for the Workers' Education Association. She was on the editorial board of the radical propagandist magazine Black Dwarf.

She spent her life in meetings, making tea for the men until she learnt that men should be making tea for her, licking envelopes, slogging round from door to door trying to sell her dreams, arranging workshops, marching, chanting, protesting. Her friends were people like Tariq Ali, Robin Blackburn, Eric Hobsbawm, Dorothy and E.P. Thompson, Sally Alexander, Raphael Samuel. She was involved in a Jean-Luc Godard project.

But between the lines of the CV another Rowbotham emerges. She got up and spoke, yes, but she felt sick with fear before and often she stumbled in her delivery; she marched, but thought about what clothes to wear as well; she stood up for herself, but felt easily crushed; she had a good many sexual relationships, often casually, yet continued to be full of romantic yearnings and a sense of her own helplessness; she was part of the woman's liberation movement (though she realised that she was a feminist surprisingly late into her twenties), but wanted men to dominate her; she wept easily enough; she felt humiliated as often as the rest of us feel it; she was angry and needy; funny and earnest.

Her account of herself is emphatically unglamorous. Lots of people are good at writing about their large tragedies, but she is good at writing about her small failures, which is far more rare and revealing. Rowbotham is not used to the subjective voice; she is a historian and her subject has been the previously unheard voices of others (Women, Resistance and Revolution, Women's Consciousness, Man's World, Hidden History and A Century of Women). At times, she falters, can't seem to find the right words for feelings which are complicatedly tangled. She can occasionally fall into the pedagogic tone that comes easily to her, explaining the significance of events to us rather than exploring her own involvement.

But for the most, she remains inside the personal history she tells, deliberately unable to see the wood for the trees. She lost her virginity late and without much pleasure; her first women's meeting was in a lavatory; her Vietnam Solidarity efforts in 1968 were to organise a jumble sale in her house, attended by a few old ladies; she couldn't revolutionise her students; she was chronically low in self-confidence. One of her ex-lovers, Bob Rowthorne, said to her in 1969 that her political significance was as an example. 'People could look at me and feel convinced: "If she can do it so can I." I laughed, but I think there was truth in what he said. I seemed often to bumble almost unconsciously into doing a lot of things in my life.'

To know that Sheila Rowbotham, the unflagging, impressive Sheila Rowbotham, bumbled - well, that's a gift to be cherished.

fields.headline: The sporran legion
fields.standfirst: Alistair MacLeod tells the story of a clan rooted in the past in No Great Mischief
fields.trailText: Alistair MacLeod tells the story of a clan rooted in the past in No Great Mischief
fields.body:
No Great Mischief
Alistair MacLeod
Cape £15.99, pp264

This extraordinary novel, telling the story of the substantial branch of the MacDonald clan that settled on Cape Breton Island off Nova Scotia, offers every satisfaction except an ending as quietly mighty as what has gone before. At the end of the text, Alistair MacLeod acknowledges the 'spiritual assistance' that came his way during its completion, but from a reader's point of view the notes of reconciliation and transcendence in the closing pages license the sentimentality that has been suppressed so long and so well.

No Great Mischief is not a historical novel, except in the sense that the MacDonalds see everything in terms of their ancestry. For them, Glencoe and Culloden occupy the historic present rather than the past tense. Even their Canadian forebears cast long shadows. The narrator's great-great-great-grandfather, Calum Ruadh or Calum the Red, left Scotland in 1779, but he is a constant presence in modern conversations.

His genes display a staying power no less phenomenal, his descendants having hair that is either bright red or intensely black. Many of the redheads have very dark eyes, so that even experienced observers, such as the staff on a maternity ward, pronounce that a newborn's hair will turn dark or his eyes turn blue, on the basis that 'no one looks like that '.

This is a clan with any number of casualties, but apparently no rebels. Marrying outside the gene pool is not so much a betrayal as a waste of effort, since Calum Ruadh's genes are not susceptible to dilution. The narrator's twin sister, having forgotten her Gaelic, married a man called Pankovich and moved to Calgary, might seem to have moved away from the clan's range.

Then one day, her 11-year-old son returns baffled from a bike ride, having met a carful of travellers who asked him what his mother's maiden name was. When he said: 'MacDonald', he was given a $50 note, for the way he looked, as he was told - and what it represented. It speaks well for the clan's character that the money does not change hands within the car, to settle a bet, but is passed on to a relative who will never be seen again, with a cryptic Gaelic message for the boy's mother.

The novel's title quotes General Wolfe, who had fought against the MacDonalds in an earlier conflict but relied on them to take the Plains of Abraham: 'They are hardy, intrepid, accustomed to a rough country, and no great mischief if they fall.' Wolfe regarded the Highlanders as his secret enemies, and was furious at their insistence on carrying their wounded from the field when ordered to retreat. Here in the public record are themes that the book explores more domestically: a self-sacrificial code of honour, and the betrayal that lies in wait for it.

The narrator is three when his parents and brother Colin are drowned, betrayed by the treacherous ice of late March. He and his twin are taken in by their sweet-souled grandpa and grandma, an element of austerity in their upbringing being provided by their other grandfather, who keeps his tenderness better hidden. The older orphans, three boys more or less able to look after themselves, leave school and set up house away from town.

The eldest boy, and the only one of the three to be named, is another Calum, just as the narrator is one Alexander MacDonald among many. The two names seem to alternate like the paradoxical colourings, the red and the dark.

The resemblances between the two named brothers are strong, yet Alexander sees himself as some sort of traitor for having made a success of his life, when Calum went under. Alexander is an orthodontist, a choice of career made to seem more frivolous by an extraordinary scene in which Calum tries to extract an infected tooth from his own jaw with pliers while on a fishing trip, and then finishes the job with the superior traction of Christy, the mare the brothers use to pull their boat up the skidway.

The animals in the story bear the same relationship to their masters as the MacDonalds do to the rest of humanity - they keep their side of the bargain. It's in the dogs, in particular, to care too much and try too hard.

If the past is both a burden and a resource, though, the present is no more than a dead end. A certain effortfulness can be detected in the short, interleaved chapters detailing a visit by Alexander to broken-down Calum, living in a squalid room in Toronto.

As the tide of storytelling recedes, the images that remain lose some of their mystery. They remain magnificent but seem a little worked-over and attach themselves too insistently to the clan or to Calum, its supreme representative: the whale lured by human singing out of the safe depths and disembowelled on the rocks; the freshwater well at the edge of the sea, salinated by storms but clearing itself of taint; the tall, straight tree severed at its stump, so closely intertwined with its fellows as to stay standing as long as they do.

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Deceptively slight, richly atmospheric, utterly modern: this is a novel that will linger long after you've put it down, plus The Code Book, Destiny, Toulouse-Lautrec and the Fin-de-Siècle and Interpreter of Maladies
fields.body:
My Phantom Husband
Marie Darrieussecq
Faber £6.99, pp153
Buy it at BOL

This book is a lesson in subjectivity. One evening a wife - whose name we never find out - who is living in a border town sends her husband out to buy bread; he does not return. The story is written in a searing first-person narrative and we follow the wife's descent into an internal hell.

The overriding sensation of Darrieussecq's writing is one of stark loneliness, an ever-present existential emptiness suddenly revealed by the unexplained disappearance of the husband. Her prose is like nothing so much as modern painting, ranging from the disjointed lines and shapes of abstract impressionism to the detached realism of Lucian Freud to, most powerfully, the hallucinatory rawness of Francis Bacon.

Deceptively slight, richly atmospheric, utterly modern: this is a novel that will linger long after you've put it down.

The Code Book: The Secret History of Codes and Code-Breaking
Simon Singh
Fourth Estate £7.99, pp402
Buy it at BOL

Simon Singh, author of Fermat's Last Theorem, has succeeded in The Code Book in making codes and ciphers intelligible to the layman. The heroes of Singh's absorbing account are code-breakers, 'linguistic alchemists', whose obsessive pursuit of cryptography through the ages has transformed the course of history.

Singh uses historical episodes to describe the evolutionary development of codes, from the trap laid for Mary Queen of Scots by the cunning spy-master Walsingham, to the code-breakers at Bletchley Park, the Allies' secret weapon during the Second World War. It concludes with a discussion of why, in the Information Age, cryptography is assuming new significance. For the very ambitious among his readers, Singh has added a Cipher Challenge, with a prize of £10,000.

Destiny
Tim Parks
Vintage £6.99, pp248
Buy it at BOL

Destiny opens with dissatisfied, middle-aged Christopher Burton in a hotel lobby receiving the telephone call that tells him his schizophrenic son has stabbed himself to death with a screwdriver. Musing on problems of will, character and fate, Burton moves from one sterilised location to the next, from airport to hospital to morgue, as he tries to come to terms with his son's suicide and his failing marriage. Burton's physical odyssey mirrors his internal quest for some kind of explanation of why his life is falling apart: 'The brighter the light, the more evident it is that revelation is denied. The more clearly one sees, I tell myself, the more inescapable enigma becomes.'

Complex and demanding, at bottom humane, Parks's tenth novel is proof (if any were needed) that the serious novel is a genre still both relevant and redemptive.

Toulouse-Lautrec and the Fin-de-Siècle
David Sweetman
Hodder £14.99, pp512
Buy it at BOL

Despite his physical weakness and his mother's determination to protect him, by the early 1880s the young artist Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec had escaped to Montmartre. Here he found a transient world in which he felt he belonged; his friendships with artists and radicals such as Aristide Bruant, Felix Fenelon and Oscar Wilde shaped his work, as did his intense sympathy for the prostitutes he used as models.

He died in 1901, aged 36, ruined by syphilis and alcoholism, leaving almost a thousand paintings of the underworld by which he was obsessed. Toulouse-Lautrec's painting of his former lover, the artist Suzanne Valadon, riding bareback in a circus ring, was placed at the entrance of the Moulin Rouge when it opened in 1889; it came to encapsulate the fin-de-siècle mood of anarchy and debauchery that David Sweetman describes through Toulouse-Lautrec's fascinating life.

Interpreter of Maladies
Jhumpa Lahiri
Flamingo £6.99, pp198
Buy it at BOL

The nine stories in this debut collection by Indian-born, American-based writer Jhumpa Lahiri, for which she won a Pulitzer Prize this year, describe the lives of exiles and outsiders: Indians living in the United States, American-born Indians returning to India and seeing it as a foreign land, Indians displaced in their own country by the upheavals of the last century. Lahiri's beautifully observed characters range from an old woman living on the stairs of an apartment block in Calcutta to a young working girl in Boston swept off her feet by a handsome stranger. The common thread is Lahiri's elegantly measured narrative voice, gentle, wise and unassuming.

One evening a wife - whose name we never find out - who is living in a border town sends her husband out to buy bread; he does not return. The story is written in a searing first-person narrative and we follow the wife's descent into an internal hell. The overriding sensation of Darrieussecq's writing is one of stark loneliness, an ever-present existential emptiness suddenly revealed by the unexplained disappearance of the husband. Her prose is like nothing so much as modern painting, ranging from the disjointed lines and shapes of abstract impressionism to the detached realism of Lucian Freud to, most powerfully, the hallucinatory rawness of Francis Bacon. Deceptively slight, richly atmospheric, utterly modern: this is a novel that will linger long after you've put it down. The Code Book: The Secret History of Codes and Code-Breaking Simon Singh Fourth Estate £7.99, pp402 Buy it at BOL Simon Singh, author of Fermat's Last Theorem, has succeeded in The Code Book in making codes and ciphers intelligible to the layman. The heroes of Singh's absorbing account are code-breakers, 'linguistic alchemists', whose obsessive pursuit of cryptography through the ages has transformed the course of history. Singh uses historical episodes to describe the evolutionary development of codes, from the trap laid for Mary Queen of Scots by the cunning spy-master Walsingham, to the code-breakers at Bletchley Park, the Allies' secret weapon during the Second World War. It concludes with a discussion of why, in the Information Age, cryptography is assuming new significance. For the very ambitious among his readers, Singh has added a Cipher Challenge, with a prize of £10,000. Musing on problems of will, character and fate, Burton moves from one sterilised location to the next, from airport to hospital to morgue, as he tries to come to terms with his son's suicide and his failing marriage. Burton's physical odyssey mirrors his internal quest for some kind of explanation of why his life is falling apart: 'The brighter the light, the more evident it is that revelation is denied. The more clearly one sees, I tell myself, the more inescapable enigma becomes.' Complex and demanding, at bottom humane, Parks's tenth novel is proof (if any were needed) that the serious novel is a genre still both relevant and redemptive. Here he found a transient world in which he felt he belonged; his friendships with artists and radicals such as Aristide Bruant, Felix Fenelon and Oscar Wilde shaped his work, as did his intense sympathy for the prostitutes he used as models. He died in 1901, aged 36, ruined by syphilis and alcoholism, leaving almost a thousand paintings of the underworld by which he was obsessed. Toulouse-Lautrec's painting of his former lover, the artist Suzanne Valadon, riding bareback in a circus ring, was placed at the entrance of the Moulin Rouge when it opened in 1889; it came to encapsulate the fin-de-siècle mood of anarchy and debauchery that David Sweetman describes through Toulouse-Lautrec's fascinating life. webTitle: Classicwatch: Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance

fields.headline: Classicwatch
fields.trailText: An eye-catching new edition of this genuinely 'life-changing' book
fields.body:
Zen and the Art of Motorcycle Maintenance

Robert M. Pirsig

Vintage £7.99, pp451

Buy it at BOL

Pirsig's journey across America and into his own mind is frequently - and accurately - compared to Moby-Dick. Where Ishmael uses whaling to supply the imagery for his parables, Pirsig uses mechanics. Phaedrus's name may not actually mean 'wolf' (Pirsig has finally corrected that error after 25 years), but as a solitary seeker of enlightenment, Pirsig's alter ego is the spiritual heir of Orpheus.

Zen is a travelogue, an autobiography and a treatise on 'Quality' (where Greek and Buddhist philosophy converge), but as literature it's far more than the sum of its parts. The excellent introduction to this eye-catching new edition, which contains interviews, hyperlinks and questions for discussion, points out the similarities to The Turn of the Screw, adding another dimension to the book.

Pirsig uses the analogy of motorcycle construction to explain perception, but it's left to the reader to see that he's also using the novel format to deconstruct 'Time, Identity and Truth'.

This is one of the few books that could genuinely be called life-changing.

webTitle: Paperback of the week: Music and Silence

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: Rose Tremain demonstrates her virtuoso control over historical material once more
fields.body:
Music and Silence
Rose Tremain
Vintage, £6.99
Buy it at BOL

It's 1629 and a young English lutenist called Peter Claire has arrived in Copenhagen to join Christian IV's royal orchestra. In a dark and icy cellar, they play galliards and sarabands while far above, in the Winter Room, the king eats his breakfast to the exquisite sounds transported there by a series of twisting pipes. Elsewhere in the palace of Rosenborg, Christian's consort Kirsten Munk marvels at her violent antipathy to her husband and dreams of the next assignation with her lover. A long way away, in Jutland, a pale and silent girl called Emilia wages war on her overblown stepmother.

The lives - the musical themes - of the king, his queen, the lutenist and the country girl are deftly conducted through solo passages and ensembles by Tremain, who demonstrates again, a decade after Restoration, that she has an alchemist's talent for making history live and breathe. She's in her element here, pulling apart palaces and country households as you might an anthill, so that all the connections become excitingly apparent.

As in all Tremain's best books, there's a fable-like quality. Grotesque and virtuous characters bloom vividly against a backdrop of frozen lakes and springtime forests, hatching plans, falling in love and struggling to find happiness despite much malicious meddling.

There is a victim in all of this: Claire emerges as a little dull viewed next to the livelier grotesques. Honourable mention must be made of Munk and Emilia's stepmother Magdalena, flip sides of a coin: cunning, heartless, destructive. Their wickedness, feckless or deliberate, fuels the novel, stoking it up so the heat comes off it in waves.

webTitle: Observer review: No News at Throat Lake

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText:
Alan Cumming infuses Lawrence Donegan's account of his year in Creeslough, Co Donegal with the warmth of his beautiful scottish voice
Hear an audio clip
fields.body:
No News at Throat Lake

Lawrence Donegan

Read by Alan Cumming

Listening time: 2hr 45min

Penguin Audiobooks £8.99

Hear a clip

I am driving on the North Circular Road in London. A five-mile journey has taken more than 40 minutes. I turn on Lawrence Donegan's autobiographical account of his year in Creeslough, Co Donegal, to make a hideous journey more enjoyable. I smile as he describes his hatred of the roads that have reached gridlock status and his longing for the simple life. His dreams probably echo those of every motorist who is stuck in this interminable traffic jam.

The difference is, Donegan lives it out. He quits his sought-after job as a journalist on The Guardian and his noisy, inner-city flat for Ireland and the peace and quiet of a tiny village in the middle of nowhere. For a man who confesses: 'I've long been one of those confused people who combine a passionate belief that TV turns people into antisocial morons, with an unbroken record of watching Brookside.' He is indeed a brave man to give up the comforts of modern living for a stone cottage with little else than running water and rats.

But what he finds is more than solitude and peace. Begging a job on the local newspaper, he discovers once again the joy and worth of small successes and learns to appreciate the satisfaction of a job well done.

I don't know whom I like more, Alan Cumming and his beautiful, relaxed Scottish voice or the man whose tale he is telling. The two become one in my mind as I listen with growing concern, realising that even Donegan with all his idealism can't last the course in a place that can only boast a village pub for a social life.

webTitle: Observer review: The Forger by Paul Watkins

fields.headline: Portrait of a con-artist
fields.standfirst: Paul Watkins tale of intrigue and derring-do, The Forger, lives up to its atmospheric cover
fields.trailText: Paul Watkins tale of intrigue and derring-do, The Forger, lives up to its atmospheric cover
fields.body:
The Forger
Paul Watkins
Faber £9.99, pp338
Buy it at BOL

It is, of course, no way to judge a book, but the cover of Paul Watkins's seventh novel, The Forger, is gorgeous, a laminated, sepia-toned photograph - Homme de la Nuit, by René Jacques - of a man in a raincoat and trilby hurrying down rainswept stone steps. It has a film noir quality that does justice to a well-written and exciting tale of intrigue and derring-do in occupied Paris during the Second World War.

The novel begins in 1939, when the narrator, David Halifax, a young American artist, comes to Paris at the behest of the mysterious Lavasseur Committee to study under a legendary Russian painter, Pankratov; legendary because every piece he ever created was destroyed in a studio fire in the Twenties, and he has never painted since.

In Pankratov's atelier, David and two other students sketch an aloof and bitter model, Valya, whose link with Pankratov seems inexplicable. David is also charmed by a flamboyant, if shifty, art dealer, Fleury, of whom their landlady says to David: 'You are an artist at making paintings. He is an artist at selling them.' As Pankratov remarks: 'In Paris, everyone is an artist at something or other.'

Including con-artistry. The Lavasseur Committee does not exist. Valya is in bed - literally - with the Nazis. And Fleury, who sells David's sketches of paintings by old masters, has not told him that they are being sold as originals. When, on the eve of war, the cops catch up with the two men, they are offered a stark choice - going to jail or joining the Resistance. They will forge artworks which would otherwise be looted by the Nazis, and trade the fakes for genuine work which would otherwise be burned by the Nazis. They will become the saviours of a culture by appearing to be collaborators; they will protect genuine artworks by creating successful forgeries.

So nothing is as it seems; even the Nazis are cutting deals behind each others' backs. Watkin derives successful tension from the situation - the fear of the footfall on the stairs; the sweat-inducing inspections of the forgeries by expert eyes; the question of whether the men might crack under the pressure and give the game away. There are a number of twists and betrayals. Watkins also lightens the atmosphere with shafts of quick humour.

Pankratov, whose mysterious connection not only with Valya but also with David himself, is slowly revealed, turns out to be an expert at the restoration of old paintings and a dab hand at the finer points of deception. 'We're talking about the illusion of a masterpiece,' he says, talking of 'the great forgers, the proof of whose greatness lies in the fact that we'll never know their names', the opposite of the usual process of validation.

Watkins lightly raises the questions of what and how we value, in art and in life, without that theme becoming dominant or self-conscious. The narrator might have benefited from a little more texture and colour, some restorative touching-up, but that is a minor quibble. The Forger is the real thing.

webTitle: Observer review: Dreaming of Strangers by Matt Thorne

fields.headline: Brief encounter
fields.standfirst: The couple in Matt Thorne's romantic comedy, Dreaming of Strangers, are film buffs. But is there enough drama in the cinema?
fields.trailText: The couple in Matt Thorne's romantic comedy, Dreaming of Strangers, are film buffs. But is there enough drama in the cinema?
fields.body:
Dreaming of Strangers
Matt Thorne
Weidenfeld & Nicholson £9.99, pp243
Buy it at BOL

In Dreaming of Strangers, Matt Thorne makes his pitch: 'Characters in books didn't go [to the cinema], which struck Becca as strange, especially as nineteenth-century novelists had got so much mileage out of characters going to the theatre or the opera in times of turmoil.' Nor had anyone written a novel set in a call centre before Thorne's engaging Eight Minutes Idle, so a romantic comedy for film buffs is an attractive proposition.

Becca, mooching in her fuddy-duddy relationship, becomes intrigued by Chris, who rents her flat. She sneaks in to assess his video shelf, trails him through London into a cinema, engineers a casual meeting. She assures herself she is no stalker, but 'a kooky young heroine', and although initially alarmed to see Chris's collection fluttering with romantic comedies ('Where was the guy stuff?'), she dispels her doubts by constructing their encounters like a compendium of romantic screen moments. Working Girl, You've Got Mail, even Rocky, shape the plot. Happy the couple united by Melanie Griffith and Sylvester Stallone.

Perhaps filmgoing is too casual a practice to allow Thorne the bristling sense of occasion that a set piece demands: once people are slouched in the dark, glutting on popcorn and trailers, promising situations dribble away. Even a fancy-dress all-nighter of teen movies, its gauche absurdity flushed with feeling, is too bashfully employed. Supporting characters lack definition, like the cabbie who pitches a movie about a baby dropped into Vietnam ('It's a cross between Look Who's Talking and Apocalypse Now ').

Becca wonders if Chris's attachment to film, like her own, is 'unusually passionate'. Believe me, passion is not the problem. Becca often associates films with her dodgy ex-boyfriends and Chris with childhood memories, but they are buffs without conviction, without anything compelling to say.

In Geoff Dyer's Paris Trance, crackling sniping about Cassavetes sparks a new relationship; in What a Carve Up! by Jonathan Coe, exposure to guffawing British comedy shapes the hero's psyche. In contrast, Thorne's cast says nothing more taxing than you'd learn from an Empire sidebar. Minnows swimming in the shallows of the movie industry, and you long for an animated, absurd, cinéaste scrap.

Thorne's zippy but reticent style ripples along to a cute ending, but for comic obsession and amorous urgency you'd be better off grabbing your Slush Puppie and heading to a cinema.
