webTitle: First novels: Mr Schnitzel, Welcome to my Planet and The Time of Light

fields.headline: Fantastical family
fields.standfirst: Home isn't necessarily sweet. Especially if you have relatives like these... Maggie O'Farrell on first novels from Stephen Knight, Shannon Olson and Gunnar Kopperud
fields.trailText: Home isn't necessarily sweet. Especially if you have relatives like these... Maggie O'Farrell on first novels from Stephen Knight, Shannon Olson and Gunnar Kopperud
fields.body:
Mr Schnitzel
Stephen Knight
Viking £10.99, pp231
Buy it at BOL

Welcome to my Planet
Shannon Olson
Viking £9.99, pp286
Buy it at BOL

The Time of Light
Gunnar Kopperud
Bloomsbury £15.99, pp247
Buy it at BOL

Don't be put off by the uninspiring title: Mr Schnitzel is not the biography of an unknown German man and it mentions sausages only in passing. Stephen Knight's book is an 'act of retrieval', an account of his Austrian-Welsh family looked at through the filter of fiction. He set out to write down the bedtime stories his father made up for him on their annual holidays in Austria, but instead discovered that the footnotes he felt compelled to include 'began to grow from the bottom of the page, rising up, until they became as important... as the tales themselves.'

Like Nabokov's Pale Fire, Mr Schnitzel is a novel in which the real action occurs off-stage, or at least in the wings. What you get are fantastical, Munchhausenesque fairy stories about the Austrian navy - maidens, sailors, pirates and daring deeds on the high seas - running concurrently with peculiar and oddly touching anecdotes about the family. And what a family it is: a genial, oblivious father, a nearly insane, kleptomaniac mother and numerous unhinged aunts and uncles who endlessly serve up inedible meals.

The footnote links are often surreal and tangential, reflecting the complex and impenetrable currents of connections that any family group can build up: in one story, the word 'sunlight' is footnoted with a recollection of how his comics became faded in the boot of the car, the figures 'bleached to a ghost'. In another, 'sailor's grave' is appended by the observation that 'death is almost as popular as skiing in Austria'.

Reading a book in this way is more of a challenge than it seems. You can't decide whether to interrupt the fairytale to follow the footnote or read it through and then go back. I experimented with both, and the result is much the same - a layered, slightly blurred but curiously satisfying narrative. In revealing the real-life parallels and explanations for the father's tales, it manages to expose that alchemical process of how fact turns into fantasy and then into fiction.

There are more exasperating and mystifying family members in Welcome to my Planet. Try not to be alarmed by the cover here. A virulent pastiche of old Hanna-Barbera cartoons in turquoise, yellow, orange and pink, it's a real car-crash of a book cover. And it doesn't seem to bear any relation to its contents.The author pre-empts any feeble attempts at drawing autobiographical comparisons: Minnesota graduate Shannon Olson's main character is a Minnesota student called Shannon Olson. I got a sinking feeling when, on the first page, she confides: 'I never thought I'd be single at 30.'

But this is not one to file in the single white female fiction section; it's much more acidic and interesting than that. A permanent malcontent, Shannon has lost her way in life. She is doing a non-job in a nebulous branch of software testing, running up credit card bills and wondering why her life isn't more like the soap operas she grew up on. When she splits up with her boyfriend and decides to return to college, she moves back in with her parents.

This is where the real verve and originality lies: this isn't a book about girls and boys, it's about girls and mothers, which is a subject that intrigues at least half of the population. Flo, the mother, does water aerobics, wears lipsticks that match her sweaters, has an unhealthy obsession with the recycling of leftovers and gives gentle but unwanted advice to her daughter such as: 'Maybe that blouse would look nice tucked in.'

Then, suddenly, she is diagnosed with a brain tumour. Olson pulls off a great antithesis of style and content: the narrative is in short, anecdotal chunks like a stand-up routine but the subject matter it tackles is the pain, alienation and confusion inherent in modern life if you don't fit into a prescribed mould. Depression, she decides at one point, is 'the absolutely correct biological response to living in America'. She is also very, very funny, and doesn't pull her punches with the various men who cross her path. Look out for Michael, who metamorphoses from a heaven-sent male into a sinister, smiling detractor who 'always seems surprised when I get an A on something'.

Gunnar Kopperud's The Time of Light is a visceral and often shocking dissection of the effects of war. It is 1994 in the Caucasus and Armenia is preparing for a war with Azerbaijan. An old man, Markus, cannot stop weeping at the sounds and smells of war which reach him through his windows. His neighbours summon a priest and Markus begins to tell him his story, unravelling his life. Markus is a German and fought in the Nazi invasion of Russia in the Second World War. So traumatised and scarred is he by the acts he has committed in the name of his country that he never returns to Germany, preferring instead to make his life in the country he once played a part in trying to destroy.

Like Martin Amis's Time's Arrow, The Time of Light is asking for sympathy for the devil - a Nazi. The prose veers between the factual listing of historical dates and places, unflinching, blow-by-blow accounts of battles Markus and his companions were involved in and some indigestible passages of heavily symbolic magic realism. This is, at times, an impressive book. There is an incredible scene where disbelieving German PoWs are shown a film reel of the Nazi concentration camps: 'This is the truth about the ideology you went to war for,' they are told.

Kopperud's actualities of war work better than his more abstract passages. But the problem is that to return to such well-documented ground you really need to be making a new point, and I'm not sure that Kopperud is.
fields.bodyText: Mr Schnitzel Stephen Knight Viking £10.99, pp231 Buy it at BOL Welcome to my Planet Shannon Olson Viking £9.99, pp286 Buy it at BOL The Time of Light Gunnar Kopperud Bloomsbury £15.99, pp247 Buy it at BOL Don't be put off by the uninspiring title: Mr Schnitzel is not the biography of an unknown German man and it mentions sausages only in passing. Stephen Knight's book is an 'act of retrieval', an account of his Austrian-Welsh family looked at through the filter of fiction. He set out to write down the bedtime stories his father made up for him on their annual holidays in Austria, but instead discovered that the footnotes he felt compelled to include 'began to grow from the bottom of the page, rising up, until they became as important... as the tales themselves.' Like Nabokov's Pale Fire, Mr Schnitzel is a novel in which the real action occurs off-stage, or at least in the wings. What you get are fantastical, Munchhausenesque fairy stories about the Austrian navy - maidens, sailors, pirates and daring deeds on the high seas - running concurrently with peculiar and oddly touching anecdotes about the family. And what a family it is: a genial, oblivious father, a nearly insane, kleptomaniac mother and numerous unhinged aunts and uncles who endlessly serve up inedible meals. The footnote links are often surreal and tangential, reflecting the complex and impenetrable currents of connections that any family group can build up: in one story, the word 'sunlight' is footnoted with a recollection of how his comics became faded in the boot of the car, the figures 'bleached to a ghost'. In another, 'sailor's grave' is appended by the observation that 'death is almost as popular as skiing in Austria'. Reading a book in this way is more of a challenge than it seems. You can't decide whether to interrupt the fairytale to follow the footnote or read it through and then go back. I experimented with both, and the result is much the same - a layered, slightly blurred but curiously satisfying narrative. In revealing the real-life parallels and explanations for the father's tales, it manages to expose that alchemical process of how fact turns into fantasy and then into fiction. There are more exasperating and mystifying family members in Welcome to my Planet. Try not to be alarmed by the cover here. A virulent pastiche of old Hanna-Barbera cartoons in turquoise, yellow, orange and pink, it's a real car-crash of a book cover. And it doesn't seem to bear any relation to its contents.The author pre-empts any feeble attempts at drawing autobiographical comparisons: Minnesota graduate Shannon Olson's main character is a Minnesota student called Shannon Olson. I got a sinking feeling when, on the first page, she confides: 'I never thought I'd be single at 30.' But this is not one to file in the single white female fiction section; it's much more acidic and interesting than that. A permanent malcontent, Shannon has lost her way in life. She is doing a non-job in a nebulous branch of software testing, running up credit card bills and wondering why her life isn't more like the soap operas she grew up on. When she splits up with her boyfriend and decides to return to college, she moves back in with her parents. This is where the real verve and originality lies: this isn't a book about girls and boys, it's about girls and mothers, which is a subject that intrigues at least half of the population. Flo, the mother, does water aerobics, wears lipsticks that match her sweaters, has an unhealthy obsession with the recycling of leftovers and gives gentle but unwanted advice to her daughter such as: 'Maybe that blouse would look nice tucked in.' Then, suddenly, she is diagnosed with a brain tumour. Olson pulls off a great antithesis of style and content: the narrative is in short, anecdotal chunks like a stand-up routine but the subject matter it tackles is the pain, alienation and confusion inherent in modern life if you don't fit into a prescribed mould. Depression, she decides at one point, is 'the absolutely correct biological response to living in America'. She is also very, very funny, and doesn't pull her punches with the various men who cross her path. Look out for Michael, who metamorphoses from a heaven-sent male into a sinister, smiling detractor who 'always seems surprised when I get an A on something'. Gunnar Kopperud's The Time of Light is a visceral and often shocking dissection of the effects of war. It is 1994 in the Caucasus and Armenia is preparing for a war with Azerbaijan. An old man, Markus, cannot stop weeping at the sounds and smells of war which reach him through his windows. His neighbours summon a priest and Markus begins to tell him his story, unravelling his life. Markus is a German and fought in the Nazi invasion of Russia in the Second World War. So traumatised and scarred is he by the acts he has committed in the name of his country that he never returns to Germany, preferring instead to make his life in the country he once played a part in trying to destroy. Like Martin Amis's Time's Arrow, The Time of Light is asking for sympathy for the devil - a Nazi. The prose veers between the factual listing of historical dates and places, unflinching, blow-by-blow accounts of battles Markus and his companions were involved in and some indigestible passages of heavily symbolic magic realism. This is, at times, an impressive book. There is an incredible scene where disbelieving German PoWs are shown a film reel of the Nazi concentration camps: 'This is the truth about the ideology you went to war for,' they are told. Kopperud's actualities of war work better than his more abstract passages. But the problem is that to return to such well-documented ground you really need to be making a new point, and I'm not sure that Kopperud is.

webTitle: Observer review: Love Etc by Julian Barnes

fields.headline: The eternal triangle
fields.standfirst: The three characters from Talking It Over sparkle again in Julian Barnes's new novel, Love Etc
fields.trailText: The three characters from Talking It Over sparkle again in Julian Barnes's new novel, Love Etc
fields.body:
Love Etc
Julian Barnes
Cape £15.99, pp250
Buy it at BOL

When, a decade ago, Julian Barnes wrote Talking It Over, in which a love triangle of self-absorbed characters opened their hearts directly to the reader and told their versions of the fidelities and infidelities that bound them, it seemed like a novel kind of novel. It was also, with hindsight, a prophetic one. In the 10 years since, the Talking It Over-style confessional has become something like our official national rhetoric.

In that time, often by default, we have become used to measuring our own experiences against the savvy solipsisms of wronged, ditched, angry and media-literate thirtysomethings. No north London marriage break-up these days, it seems, comes without a newspaper column, the promise of a hefty publisher's advance and the sniff of a film deal.

Daytime television is entirely based on the notion that an intimate problem shared (with a couple of million people) is, well, an intimate problem shared. Magazines have grown up to peddle true-life stories of the not-so-rich and barely famous, and our popular culture has been in thrall to imports - Sex and the City, Ally McBeal - that offer first-person girls-talk about designer relationships.

The Nineties' push towards recycling was nowhere as successful as with the emotional lives of the confessional classes, which are now routinely sifted and lucratively repackaged for general consumption.

For Love, Etc, Barnes has returned to the characters he introduced in Talking It Over: Oliver, 'the marriage-breaker, wild dog, blood-sucker, snake in the grass, parasite, predator, vulture dingo'; Stuart, the cuckoldee, who described his one-time best friend Oliver as all of the above; and Gillian, now wife to the former, once wife to the latter. But what then seemed a gentle satire on the bed-hopping betrayals of a post-promiscuous generation now looks like a comment on an entire kiss 'n' tell industry. We have always, I suppose, lived by what Oliver here calls 'the voice-over in your own head, the one that comments on your life as you live it', but never before has this voice-over been quite so familiar with the nuance of voice-overs.

Barnes plays these fashionable conventions for all they are worth. His book is by turns a precise, hilarious parody of the mores of self-serving confession, and a very stringent and stylish inquiry into the nature of truth and the compensations offered by love. His characters have moved on, changed, got a little older and a little more bitter (but then so, perhaps, have his readers: 'You probably think you're much the same as you were back then,' announces Oliver, cruelly, on page one. 'Believe me, you aren't.')

All three protagonists are still defence counsels for their own versions of the events that forced them together and apart, slick-talking, misty-eyed lifestyle attorneys appealing to our emotions and plea-bargaining for sympathy and special dispensations: 'Isn't there a statute of limitations for wife-stealing?' Oliver demands at one point, asking Stuart, Gillian - but more important we the jury - to deal with him a little more leniently.

Barnes is the sharpest and most humane observer of the particular frailties of the average middle-class Englishman at the beginning of the twenty-first century. He is also the consummate deconstructor of the lies we all tell ourselves about romance. He attends sharp-eyed to the syntactical shifts wrought by habit: Gillian frets, for example, that familiarity has caused her to drop the 'I' from 'I love you' when she says it to Oliver each day: is the love it describes also losing its subject? Barnes has us quietly wonder throughout in this way - and the 10-year time-lag heightens this sense of temporal decline - whether love is really not time's fool.

This is the question that lies somewhere near the heart of all of Barnes's best work (in books that have always carried the same solitary dedication to his wife Pat Kavanagh), and in some ways Love, Etc is a cynical riposte to the magical half chapter defence of love that underwrote A History of the World in 10 Chapters.

Stuart, who has had his love replaced by betrayal and revenge, and who now carries in his wallet a photograph of his ex-wife, her face bleeding having been hit by Oliver, turns on the reader at one point with a sneer: 'You look surprised. Think about it. Examine your own life. Love leads to happiness? Come off it.'

In some ways, this is the lightest of novels, a little social comedy that you can read in a long afternoon. But within it, and partly because of the format which leaves the reader without authorial compass and unsure where truths lie, there is a much darker book. There was always something claustrophobic about the range of options open to Gillian and Stuart and Oliver, but now their choices seem to have closed in on them still further.

Stuart, who has become wealthy in America, and remarried and redivorced, is protected from the world by his lack of imagination (he says things like: 'I'm suspicious of people comparing things with other things'); Oliver, meanwhile, has always attempted to protect himself from the world with his wild and whirling words and his faith in: 'Love, etc. That has always been my formula, my theory, my wisdom. I knew it at once, as an infant knows its mother's smile.'

This novel deals with the breakdown of Oliver's faith, the realisation that 'The world, being constructed as it is, will not allow [for fantasy]. Realism is our given, our only mode, triste truth as it might be to some.' Oliver is a memorable creation here, Barnes's wannabe Thersites. His list of likes includes 'that moment when you change gear and your passenger's beloved head does not even stir on its spinal column, risotto nero, the third act trio from Rosenkavalier...' but his list of dislikes is much, much longer.

He is the romantic child starved of affection - his mother died when he was a boy, his father took it out on him and his 'wife disgraced him by crying at his funeral'. His version of the world is a seductive one and it can take us almost anywhere with all the vitality of Barnes's most beguiling intelligence.

But despite the intellectual bravado of this voice, there is no triumph here for 'Oliver-speak'; Oliver earns his living pushing junk mail through letter boxes while writing screenplays in his head that will never get written. Gillian, touchingly, marks up the newspaper for him every morning to try to interest him in the world beyond his head: 'But news delights me not, nor features neither.'

All he resolves eventually is that: 'Stuart bores me. Gillian bores me. I bore me.' His sad, comical, little life hinges on the impossibility of one person ever knowing another person's reality. That, it also seems, is the message of Barnes's sparkling little novel, which ends with the question it dramatises, the question we are all stuck with: 'What do you think?'

fields.headline: On the beach with Wills
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the monarchy
fields.trailText: Last week, I tried to join a cult. The members surface together for one week a year in a tiny village in Cornwall, just across the River Camel from Padstow. They collect at 10pm at a pub called the Mariners and then at midnight at a nearby bay.
fields.body:
Last week, I tried to join a cult. The members surface together for one week a year in a tiny village in Cornwall, just across the River Camel from Padstow. They collect at 10pm at a pub called the Mariners and then at midnight at a nearby bay.

All the members are very young, very beautiful and very élite. Prince William is there, hiding under his cap, while Harry bounces around the beach chatting up pretty girls. Tatler boys wander around, kissing girls on the forehead and asking whether they would like to get 'better acquainted', while mini-Sloanes who aren't keen on outdoor living try to keep fires going by contributing bus tickets, cigarette packets and seaweed.

It is possible for someone simply to chance upon these secret meeting places, but most of these cultists are part of the underground chain of information called public-school life. All boarding-school kids seem to know each other, so secret codes and meeting places travel fast. There is only a small stretch of beach where the party happens, only one pub where everybody meets. The only chat up line is: 'I go to Eton/ Harrow/ Ampleforth; where do you go?' The only way to see where you are walking is by the light of Nokia mobiles.

There were three types of people in Cornwall last week: the core boarding- school cult, then there's day-school people like me on the fringe and finally the locals, the 'real' surfers. They turned out to be quite an attraction, but we had to hurry them awaywhen they started calling the Sloanes 'Yahs' and stealing copies of Horse and Hound to burn on the fire.

The Sloanes are like a cabaret to watch. Hundreds of immaculately-dressed teenagers trekked down this perfect Cornwall beach with no visible goal in sight. At midnight low tide, their stage is miles of slightly wet, flat beach. Armed with pastel-coloured pashminas and headscarves, they walked as if they had to be at the King's Road by 9.30. There is a murmur of mellow, stoned, posh voices saying things like, 'Quick ,Tatiana, Arthur's got reception! Let's see which bonfire Raury is at.'Of course, we followed them each night and tried to blend in. We pretended we were boarding-school girls and we just kept 'forgetting' to bring our Sloane accessories. We tried to avoid the question of where we were sleeping. Every time we mentioned our seven-person caravan, where 10 of us were staying, they either keeled over from 'simply bloody hysterical' jokes about the joys of intimate holidays or asked us for detailed instructions on how to get there.

We sat around, sociably chatting to people at their fires. There were CD players and beautiful guitar music. There were police around, but I've never met better natured people in uniform. Sweet-smelling smoke hung in clouds over the beach but when the police came by, they would say things like: 'Do be careful with that bonfire.'

It doesn't matter where people sleep in this cult. If you put on an accent and know somebody who somebody else went to pre-school with or is in the same house as someone at Eton, then you've got a place to sleep. As long as you can pass on some piece of gossip about who has had sex with whom, then you might even get a pillow and duvet.

People sleep in their Mercedes or Daddy's Ferrari. The more adventurous fall asleep on the sand. Nobody wakes up until midday and then the party begins again. William is king of this cult, even though his is a difficult part to play. He tries to blend into the crowd, sitting in a baseball cap surrounded by his friends. Yet all events seem to revolve around him. Harry is everywhere at once, being cheeky and amusing, while his bodyguard shifts neurotically nearby. They both seemed fairly normal.

But then again, I'm slightly confused by what normal is, having spent a week with the best-dressed, thinnest, richest teenagers in England. The princes were, in the context of the the beach, quite normal.

fields.headline: The tale of two Tonys
fields.standfirst:
There are two Blairs - the steadfast leader with his vision of tomorrow and the fickle ditherer rattled by yesterday's headlines
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: There are two Blairs - the steadfast leader with his vision of tomorrow and the fickle ditherer rattled by yesterday's headlines, says Andrew Rawnsley
fields.body:
IT WAS IN July 1994, when Tony Blair became leader and his small group of modernisers set about creating what he would soon christen 'a literally new party', that it was born. Six summers later, New Labour is dying.

This is not a prediction that the Tories will win the next election. I'd still rather place a bet on Elvis landing a UFO on the head of the Loch Ness monster than stake a pound on William Hague moving into Number 10 within the next two years. Nor am I saying that the Government is a great disaster. This is, in so many respects, a remarkably successful administration which continues to enjoy high popularity ratings for the mid-term. What looks terminally green is the unique experiment with the British political system that was labelled New Labour.

The backbench flies buzz down the fetid corridors of Westminster. The media vultures flap over Number 10. The death rattle reverberates across the country. Look at the tears of joy welling from those who have long hoped to jig on the grave. Clare Short, who would have strangled Blair's baby at birth, gloatingly observes that 'the bit which is going wrong is the new bit'. John Prescott is happy to remind anyone who asks that New Labour was never a phrase he used himself; he always knew it would turn out a wrong 'un. Gordon Brown, whose attachment to New Labour has ever been proportionate to its popularity, acts with characteristic comradeliness to distance himself from Tony Blair in whose flailings the Chancellor sniffs an opportunity to advertise his own solidity.

The tocsin sounds most dolefully from within the innermost sanctum of the Blairite tabernacle. Thanks to a cascade of leaked memos we can all share the neurotic alarm at the very centre. Philip Gould, guru of the focus group and mid-wife to 'The Project', reports to the Prime Minister that the 'New Labour brand is badly contaminated'. What was going to bestride the millennium - 'a thousand days for a thousand years,' Blair once boasted - is shrivelling in ridicule and contempt after just half a dozen years. 'Something has gone seriously wrong,' Gould quotes a bewildered Peter Mandelson. 'But what is it?'

To answer his question, begin with the strange circumstances of the birth. New Labour was the creation of a group so small that you can count it on one hand: Blair, Brown, Alastair Campbell, Mandelson, and Gould. That quintet is, essentially, about it. This was never a mass movement; more of a brilliant coup d'etat . The bargain between this power-hungry group and their office-starved party was that they would be given absolute command in return for winning office. Only by ruthlessly concentrating control within such a tight, if volatile, clique was it possible to radically overhaul a four-times losing party and turn into a fantastic vehicle for acquiring power. For that, its principle purpose, New Labour was a sensational triumph. And so it was - or at least appeared to be - for the first half of the Government's life.

Paradoxically, one of the things that has gone wrong for New Labour is its success. It came into life as a negative. It was not the Conservatives, it was not Old Labour, and that was sufficient for the majority of voters who didn't want to return to either. That negative has been more than proved. The most flatulent criticism of Tony Blair was to call him a Tory with dental floss. The minimum wage, the New Deal, devolution: a Conservative Government would have done none of that. Nor would a Tory administration have committed itself to last week's announcement of an unprecedented investment in public services. As there would not have been under an Old Labour Government either, whose every turn in office was shipwrecked in economic calamity by this stage of the parliament.

The first trouble is that the point is long passed when it was enough for New Labour to expect applause simply for not being something else. We've got that, been there, seen the film, acquired the T-shirt. New Labour - as is always the risk with products which market themselves on their novelty - is old news. Now the country asks a different question of Tony Blair, a question that always unnerves him and divides those around the leader. What is he for?

WINNING. THAT is what New Labour has always been for. Towards the end of his first month in power, in May 1997, Tony Blair and Bill Clinton took a press conference in Number 10's ersatz rose garden. I asked Clinton what tips he might have to offer to his British younger cousin. Before the American could reply, Blair leant forward to speak for him: 'He got the most important thing right. He got re-elected.'

There is nothing disreputable about a politician seeking to retain office. The obsession with securing the full second term which eluded every previous Labour government is not of itself a bad thing. Policies without the power to implement them are pointless. It is allowing the pursuit of the popular to consume everything else that is the canker. This has spread the cancerous impression that principle is always expedited into oblivion in the tossing about for populist quick-fixes.

Popularity was elevated to such a pre-eminent place in the New Labourite creed because the modernisers never expected to be loved. It is in the nature of small and secretive groups to be paranoid. fields.headline: The Shrub takes root
fields.standfirst: What did the Republicans do when facing a presidential election without an obvious candidate? They found a bad li'l teen and turned him into a good ol' boy with a multi-million dollar make-over, says Ed Vulliamy
fields.trailText: What did the Republicans do when facing a presidential election without an obvious candidate? They found a bad li'l teen and turned him into a good ol' boy with a multi-million dollar make-over
fields.body:
They call him Shrub, the little Bush. But next week in Philadelphia, the shrub will bloom, a tree in summer, as George W. Bush is crowned by those who have for years awaited this moment. The coronation will be the convention of the Republican Party which planted and nurtured the Shrub as its only hope of reconquering a White House from which it has been exiled eight long years.

Bush heads for the convention with only the narrowest of leads over his rival Al Gore - but that will do nothing to cramp his Presidential style. For if Bush is not inevitable, he is nothing. He has campaigned in a relaxed, tactile, eye-to-eye style that is not visible on television. There is a 'What, me care?' feel to the candidacy.

This is, of course, a deception. Bush's is one of the most carefully planned, packaged and managed campaigns within living political memory, which is fitting enough, for never can there have been an election between two candidates so meticulously groomed for this moment for as long as they have been alive. The main difference between them, as Professor Todd Gitlin, a scrutiniser of American politicians, says is that 'Gore is real trying to be fake, while Bush is fake trying to be real'.

Both are the privileged sons of political heavyweights - a president and a senator. Both are sons of families that straddled the East coast establishment and points West, and both have elected to base their campaigns in the latter - portraying a hoe-down, home-town 'Washington outsider' from Tennessee and Texas respectively. In both cases, this is another monstrous deception. There are barely two men in America so well connected within the DC Beltway and who have used those connections so brazenly.

But here lies the first and crucial difference between Bush and his rival, and the beginning of the curious manufacture of the man they will be calling 'President Bush II' over and over in Philadelphia.

Bush's candidacy is a family drama as well as a political one. Bush is a brand name, and George W. Bush was chosen by both family and party to play an almost Wagnerian role in the history of his dynasty. Once the rebel son, he is now the man who must avenge his father's crushing 1992 defeat to the enemy whom Bush himself resembles in so many ways: Bill Clinton.

Unlike the case of Gore, the campaign to place George W. Bush in the White House did not quite begin when he was in utero . Like Gore, George 'Dubya' Bush was born into political privilege, but unlike Gore, Bush's boyhood in Midland, Texas, was a fairly normal one, getting belted at school for painting a beard on his teacher's face and bicycling in jeans and T-shirt around the streets of a rigidly segregated oil boomtown that was never going to spawn much of a postcard industry.

He was an under-achiever at school, as his grades, published by the New Yorker , revealed to the hilarity of its readers on the Upper West Side but - crucially - to the total indifference of most Americans, who performed even worse. If anyone it was the younger Jeb Bush who was deemed destined for great things in politics, while Dubya famously became the wild child. There may have been US presidential candidates who while at High School dressed up in drag with a wig and shook a leg from beneath a white mini-skirt, but few who did it for the cameras and posterity.

Next came Bush's frat brat years at Harvard, where - according to accusations he has never denied - he was famously a voracious consumer of cocaine and the opposite sex. Fellow alumnae recall that Bush was 'in a different league' when it came to champagne during these binges. But Bush's supposed nemesis, Bill Clinton, has already proved that voting America cares little or nothing for such stories, nor would the Democrats dare to call Bush on them.

It was not Bush's wild years that was the hostage to fortune in Republican politics, but his record over Vietnam. Bush comes from a family of war heroes. His father and grandfather were decorated in combat. The Republican Party defines men of Bush's generation by their service records during Vietnam. Draft-dodging is the ultimate heresy.

But both family and party are about to crown a man who was spared the killing fields of South-East Asia because his father put in a call to get young Bush admitted to the Texas National Guard which would protect him from combat in the paddy fields. George Senior's help and name set the tone for the young Bush's business career too. And Dubya's early start in the oil business, his foray into Wall Street and the urban jungle of investments - even his acquisition of the Texas Rangers baseball team - follow a pattern. It is roughly this: Bush invests a little in an enterprise which either performs with studied mediocrity and is bailed out, or else is pumped full of money by investors anxious to orbit around the son of a prestigious Senator, Vice President and finally President of the USA. 'I was a pit bull on the pant leg of opportunity,' Bush himself once said in one of his more insightful remarks.

Bush pretends that he 'never dreamt about being President' and recalls his joy when communications director Karen Hughes waltzed into his office one day in the summer of 1997 and told him - to his amazement - that he was leading his Republican rivals for the nomination. This was pure guff. The plot to find a pretender to the throne George Bush Snr had lost to Bill Clinton in 1992 began soon after the loss of a second election by Bob Dole the previous year.

Bush's campaign manager Karl Rove arranged for just about every heavyweight bankroller of the Republican Party to visit - together or singly - and come away convinced he was the way back to the White House. The money came flooding in at such a rate that Bush quickly broke all election spending records, spending an average of $1.3 million a day since the campaign was officially opened - an unintended portion of the funds spent on seeing off the challenge of the real war hero Senator John McCain.

At Philadelphia, Bush will perform a delicate balancing act his father also knew well over whether to accommodate or denounce the Republican right wing. He will accomplish it by being two things: presidential, and all things to all people. He will try to retain the Republican Party's conservative base while courting the moderates and their supporters in the political centre that he needs to win the country.

And in doing so, even at this late stage, Bush 'is still a work-in-progress', according to William Niskenan, a former Reagan adviser and now director of the Conservative Cato Institute in Washington. For underneath it all Bush is a devout conservative. His positions on guns, abortion, private school vouchers, taxes (audaciously favourable to the super-rich) and social security (a huge privatisation programme) are well known. But at the same time, Bush has been throwing out other signals that mask his innate conservatism: like spending more on welfare and a passion for education investment. Congress, Bush has said, should not balance the budget 'on the backs of the poor'.

Indeed, ever since he effectively secured the nomination with a brash display of ultra-conservatism in the South Carolina primary, Bush has been prepared to confront the Republican right on Capitol Hill in bursts of what pundits have called 'triangulation' which recall Clinton himself.

He has said he aims to end to take the 'partisan poison' and 'discord' out of business on Capitol Hill - a tale told as part of the honest Texan package. If Bush has shown a weakness it has been in his difficulties in his grasp on foreign policy, famously confusing the Greeks and 'Grecians', Slovenia and Slovakia - but even this is partly contrived: there comes a point at which Americans prefer it that way anyway.

The two remaining questions are for the future: will he get elected? And is Dubya smart enough to carry off the Presidency? His retort to the second was a swift one: 'I'm plenty smart 'nuff.' His retort to the first came in one of his best and most typically adroit lines of late, a reference to Al Gore's many staff reshuffles. 'You can shuffle the deck chairs around much as you like. Fact is that if the ship is called HMS Titanic, you're going down anyway.'

George W. Bush
DoB: 6 July 1946 (New Haven, Connecticut), son of future President George Bush Snr
Married to: Laura Welch Bush (twin 15-year-old girls, Jenna and Barbara)
Studied: BA, history, Yale 1968 MBA, Harvard, 1975
Military F-102 pilot, Texas service: Air National Guard
Religion: Methodist
Current office: Governor of Texas

This was pure guff. The plot to find a pretender to the throne George Bush Snr had lost to Bill Clinton in 1992 began soon after the loss of a second election by Bob Dole the previous year. Bush's campaign manager Karl Rove arranged for just about every heavyweight bankroller of the Republican Party to visit - together or singly - and come away convinced he was the way back to the White House. The money came flooding in at such a rate that Bush quickly broke all election spending records, spending an average of $1.3 million a day since the campaign was officially opened - an unintended portion of the funds spent on seeing off the challenge of the real war hero Senator John McCain. At Philadelphia, Bush will perform a delicate balancing act his father also knew well over whether to accommodate or denounce the Republican right wing. He will accomplish it by being two things: presidential, and all things to all people. He will try to retain the Republican Party's conservative base while courting the moderates and their supporters in the political centre that he needs to win the country. And in doing so, even at this late stage, Bush 'is still a work-in-progress', according to William Niskenan, a former Reagan adviser and now director of the Conservative Cato Institute in Washington. For underneath it all Bush is a devout conservative. His positions on guns, abortion, private school vouchers, taxes (audaciously favourable to the super-rich) and social security (a huge privatisation programme) are well known. But at the same time, Bush has been throwing out other signals that mask his innate conservatism: like spending more on welfare and a passion for education investment. Congress, Bush has said, should not balance the budget 'on the backs of the poor'. Indeed, ever since he effectively secured the nomination with a brash display of ultra-conservatism in the South Carolina primary, Bush has been prepared to confront the Republican right on Capitol Hill in bursts of what pundits have called 'triangulation' which recall Clinton himself. He has said he aims to end to take the 'partisan poison' and 'discord' out of business on Capitol Hill - a tale told as part of the honest Texan package. If Bush has shown a weakness it has been in his difficulties in his grasp on foreign policy, famously confusing the Greeks and 'Grecians', Slovenia and Slovakia - but even this is partly contrived: there comes a point at which Americans prefer it that way anyway. The two remaining questions are for the future: will he get elected? And is Dubya smart enough to carry off the Presidency? His retort to the second was a swift one: 'I'm plenty smart 'nuff.' His retort to the first came in one of his best and most typically adroit lines of late, a reference to Al Gore's many staff reshuffles. 'You can shuffle the deck chairs around much as you like. Fact is that if the ship is called HMS Titanic, you're going down anyway.' George W. Bush DoB: 6 July 1946 (New Haven, Connecticut), son of future President George Bush Snr Married to: Laura Welch Bush (twin 15-year-old girls, Jenna and Barbara) Studied: BA, history, Yale 1968 MBA, Harvard, 1975 Military F-102 pilot, Texas service: Air National Guard Religion: Methodist Current office: Governor of Texas

fields.headline: Finding common purpose
fields.standfirst:
Landmark decisions in the Shipman and Shayler cases reveal new attitude to free speech
Special report: David Shayler
Special report: the Shipman trial
fields.trailText: British judges  have traditionally undervalued freedom of the press and of speech. That is why cases like Thalidomide (contempt of court), Spycatcher (breach of confidence), Harriet Harman (contempt of court), Tolstoy (libel damages), and Goodwin (journalist's refusal to disclose confidential source) were taken successfully to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg.
fields.body:
British judges have traditionally undervalued freedom of the press and of speech. That is why cases like Thalidomide (contempt of court), Spycatcher (breach of confidence), Harriet Harman (contempt of court), Tolstoy (libel damages), and Goodwin (journalist's refusal to disclose confidential source) were taken successfully to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg. Until recently, only a tiny minority of British judges took free speech seriously. Today, the position is changing dramatically. Our courts, influenced by the European Court of Human Rights, are giving judgments based on a strong commitment to human rights.

Last week's landmark rulings in the Shipman and Shayler cases show how senior judges are protecting free speech more strongly on the eve of the coming into force of the Human Rights Act 1998 on 2 October. Their decisions mean that the Strasbourg Court will probably be less burdened with future British cases fettering freedom of information and public discussion.

In Shipman, the Divisional Court upheld a challenge by families of the victims, supported by the media, to the Secretary of State for Health's decision requiring an inquiry into the issues raised by Dr Harold Shipman's murder of 15 patients to be held in private. Lord Justice Kennedy found that the decision to sit in private was legally irrational and contravened the guarantee of free expression in Article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights because it constituted unjustified government interference with the free communication of information. He quoted from the Strasbourg Court's classic statement of principle that freedom of expression protects information and ideas that 'offend, shock or disturb'; that the exceptions to free expression 'must be narrowly interpreted and the necessity for any restrictions must be convincingly established'; and that it is incumbent on the press, in its vital role as public watchdog, to impart information and ideas on matters of public interest.

The Court treated the right to free expression, anchored in the European Convention, as also being a fundamental principle of the English common law. It ruled that there is a presumption that a public inquiry will proceed in public 'unless there are persuasive reasons for taking some other course'. Because the Minister, Alan Milburn, had failed to give persuasive reasons for excluding the press and the public, he had exceeded his lawful powers.

Judicial recognition of a positive right to free expression rooted in the common law was first made by the Law Lords in 1993 in the Derbyshire libel case. They decided that a government body cannot invoke libel law to vindicate its so-called 'governing reputation'. To allow public authorities to take up the sword of libel law to protect themselves against public criticism would have a 'chilling effect' on free speech. They emphasised that 'it is of the highest public importance that a government body should be open to uninhibited public criticism'. Their decision wove the Convention right into the fabric of English law, and recognised the fundamental importance of a free press in a democratic society.

This major shift in British judicial attitudes was influenced by the European Court's findings that the Law Lords had unnecessarily interfered with free expression by giving excessive weight to other competing rights and interests. European human rights law has had a tonic effect in prompting our courts to discover hitherto hidden potential in the common law.

Last year, in Reynolds' case (an alleged libel on the political reputation of Ireland's former Taoiseach), the Law Lords extended the common law protection of qualified privilege to media reporting of matters of public interest. English libel law has notoriously draconian features reflecting its origins in the seventeenth-century Court of Star Chamber. It puts the burden on the publisher to prove the truth of his allegations. The state of mind and conduct of the publisher are irrelevant unless he is able to claim that the publication was made on an occasion of privilege. In Reynolds, the Law Lords looked at this harsh law in the context of a constitutional or common-law right to free expression. They recognised that the media should be entitled to publish inaccurate information on matters of public interest, provided that they act fairly and reasonably in accordance with proper professional standards. The reasoning in Reynolds has been developed further in a brilliant judgment of the Court of Appeal of New Zealand given last month in Lange.

Again last year, in Simms, the Law Lords ruled that a blanket ban by the Home Office on interviews of prisoners by journalists was unlawful because it deprived prisoners of their basic and fundamental right free expression to gain access to justice through press reporting. They refused to follow the restrictive rulings of the American Supreme Court, Lord Steyn observing that the Supreme Court's approach of 'judicial deference to the view of prison authorities... does not accord with the approach under English law. It is at variance with the principle that only a pressing social need can defeat freedom of expression'. That is a striking observation. A decade ago the American Supreme Court's decisions on the First Amendment's guarantee of free speech were treated as too liberal to influence our law; today, in the area of prisoners' rights American constitutional law is treated as being too restrictive to meet more liberal British legal standards.

Last Thursday's judgment of the Court of Appeal in Shayler is a further example of the enlightened approach that will surely inform our courts' use of the Human Rights Act to protect basic civil rights and freedoms. The Observer and the Guardian are right to claim the judgment as a famous victory. In particular, the leading judgment of Lord Justice Judge is charmingly English, purporting to find the principles of the European Convention 'bred in the bone of the common law', and a part of 'the folk understanding of the community as a whole'. References to Dicey, Voltaire and the great eighteenth-century case of Entick v Carrington are invoked by Lord Justice Judge to lament the pitiful condition of the French under the Bourbons for their inferior status, without benefit of the glorious English constitution in King George III's reign. Vive l'Angleterre!

It also contains some well-deserved shafts of irony at the expense the luckless detective sergeant who expressed the belief that there had been a breach of the Official Secrets Act while knowing virtually nothing about the case.

What is really important about the Shayler judgment is the effective protection it gives to 'fundamental principles' and its emphasis on the need for the judge to be alert to the need to safeguard basic human rights and freedoms against inordinate and excessive claims by the state and its agents. The judgment identifies the risks of self-incrimination and of stifling newspaper investigation of the Shayler story as out- weighing the competing benefit of disclosure to the security services. In Lord Justice Judge's magisterial language: 'Inconvenient or embarrassing revelations, whether for the security services, or for public authorities, should not be suppressed. Legal proceedings directed towards the seizure of the working papers of an individual journalist or the premises of the newspaper or television programme publishing his or her reports, or the threat of such proceedings, tends to inhibit discussion. When a genuine investigation into possible corrupt or reprehensible activities by a public authority is being investigated by the media, compelling evidence would normally be needed to demonstrate that the public interest would be served by such proceedings. Otherwise, to the public disadvantage, legitimate enquiry and discussion and the safety valve of investigative journalism... would be discouraged perhaps stifled.'

British senior judges really are, in Jack Straw's phrase, 'Bringing Rights Home'. What a pity that the Home Secretary does not share their democratic values. His flawed measures, unnecessarily restricting public access to official information, and authorising the interception, surveillance and disclosure of journalistic material without a judicial warrant, will make it necessary for the judges to come to the rescue of British rights and freedoms.

 Lord Lester of Herne Hill QC is a human rights lawyer at Blackstone Chambers who has argued several of the free speech cases to which he refers in English courts and the European Court of Human Rights.

webTitle: Gordon's given you the ammo, Tony

fields.headline: Gordon's given you the ammo, Tony
fields.standfirst:
To counter growing criticism, the Prime Minister's message to the nation should be 'New Labour, new clarity'
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: To counter growing criticism, the Prime Minister's message to the nation should be 'New Labour, new clarity', says Will Hutton
fields.body:
The former vice-chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff leaned forward intently. 'Some people now talk of the state as a legacy activity,' he declared. 'That is not my view. There remains a legitimate role for the Government in supporting business.' Thanks a lot. Doubtless, Bill Owens meant well, but his less than comprehensive defence of the state as an activity relevant now and in the future spoke volumes. # # We live in a civilisation which celebrates the private sector and is sceptical about government as never before. We used to mock the notion that the state could be privatised and that the role of elected politicians would be no more than drawing up contracts with private companies for minimal public provision, but that is overtly the conservative agenda, especially in the US. Watch out. It is American values that now colonise our political and intellectual establishment. In this world view, government activity is justified only in if it does not obstruct the onward march of business. If it has to spend, it must do so only in those areas where it is proven that there is no private alternative. British Tories know they can advance this agenda cautiously, but it is the vision that informs their politics.

It is in this context that last week's Comprehensive Spending Review should be judged. The statistical annexe of the document shows that over the last five years public expenditure has shrunk by 5 per cent of GDP or some £50 billion, a fifth of the decline represented by a calamitous fall in public investment. Stripped of the hyperbole, all that New Labour is now proposing is a partial and cautious reversal of that trend financed by the tax increases it levied in 1997 and 1998 and lower debt interest and social security spending. By 2003, public investment will nearly be as high as in 1993.

Health expenditure will have grown nearly as fast as during the last Labour government, while education expenditure will have edged slightly higher as a proportion of GDP than John Major spent. So tight has the control on public spending been during the last two years of the Tories and the first three years of New Labour that some recovery to where it might have been had it been allowed to grow in line with economic growth is hailed as a major triumph for social democratic politics.

The trouble is that our political discourse has now moved so far to the Right and so dominant is the anti-state consensus that New Labour is partly justified in making that claim. The growth rate in departmental spending, albeit from a desperately depressed level, in education, health, Home Office and transport spending is impressive. But it needs to be. We have the lowest number of doctors in Europe per head apart from Turkey; the most congested roads; the lowest spending per head on secondary school and university students. If the spending is sustained, as it should be because Gordon Brown has made certain the plans are almost bomb-proof, then Britain will have climbed towards, but still fall short of the European average in most areas of public provision. Extraordinarily, shadow Chancellor Michael Portillo is not laughed out of the TV and radio studios when he talks of spending £17bn less more wisely to produce better results.

Where, pray, are the cuts to come from? Eighty per cent of the increased spending is going to transport, education, health, the Home Office and defence. Little or none is directed at social security recipients. Public-sector pay is assumed to rise no faster than inflation. There is absolutely no give in the numbers. If we want a moderately funded health and education system along with some attempt to halt the growth in traffic congestion, New Labour has done the minimum necessary - and even that may be insufficient. For on one issue, the critics and Government agree.

The question now is delivery. Brown has tried to meet the critique through an array of public-service agreements in which spending departments commit to achieve a range of improved outcomes with the extra cash; in the autumn, he plans to go a level deeper by publishing service delivery agreements in which departments specify precisely how they are to achieve the targets to which they are committed. This does represent a reinforcement of centralised Treasury power, but a mechanism is needed to ensure that cash translates into better outcomes.

This is the decisive roll of the dice. If within two or three years there is no significant improvement in public services despite the trumpeted increase in public spending, then the 'state-as-legacy' anti-public-sector mood will be reinforced and the case for tax-funded public- service provision will be seriously damaged. On this, New Labour must make its stand or it is lost. But has it already hampered its own cause, both substantively and in terms of its message?

You can't improve public services without motivated people. Yet recruitment to the public sector is becoming increasingly difficult, not only because of indifferent pay, but because public-sector workers correctly see them selves, and the notion of public service, as having no champion. Teachers and doctors are attacked; managers and administrators are excoriated. Who would enter public service?

This is the more serious criticism of the Number 10 'spinning' operation. In its pursuit of winning the headlines, it has lost sight of the Government's strategic mission. The tragic element of the leaked memo on touchstone issues is less Mr Blair's preoccupation with a good press, more his concern with presenting himself as being wholly in sympathy with the Right-of-centre Zeitgeist that he needs to challenge and change. In his leaked paper, Philip Gould notes that Clinton in government gathered momentum while the Government is losing it. But Clinton knew what he was trying to do.

Blair is facing in two directions at once - courting the Right while trying to relegitimise government - hence the public rubbishing of a public sector whose morale and sense of purpose he needs to reignite if the Government's programme is to succeed. New Labour needs a new clarity urgently. It needs simple, muscular messages about the importance of improved public services - and it needs to back them with substantive actions within a powerful political narrative. If Blair is serious, he will organise himself and his advisers to deliver just this. The Chancellor has given him the opportunity - it is now up to him to seize it.

webTitle: The Maze slams shut at last

fields.headline: The Maze slams shut at last
fields.standfirst:
John O'Farrell on the history of the jail which closes next week and had talismanic status for all factions
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Next friday one of the most remarkable buildings in Britain will close for business. Her Majesty's Prison Maze, or Long Kesh to its current and former inhabitants, will be emptied of its 96 remaining prisoners. Sixteen will go to Magaberry Prison, while 80 will be freed under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement.
fields.body:
Next friday one of the most remarkable buildings in Britain will close for business. Her Majesty's Prison Maze, or Long Kesh to its current and former inhabitants, will be emptied of its 96 remaining prisoners. Sixteen will go to Magaberry Prison, while 80 will be freed under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement.

The releases will be staggered over the course of the day. If all 80 were to be 'sprung' simultaneously, there would be a possibility of violence amid the jubilation of the hundreds who are expected to crowd the car park of the Maze.

As well as the families of the prisoners, there will be supporters of the paramilitary groups in whose name the men went inside. The Provisional IRA, Irish National Liberation Army, the Loyalist Volunteer Force, the Ulster Volunteer Force and the Ulster Freedom Fighters may have found common cause in prison, but outside the walls remain bitter enemies.

The political wings of the paramilitary groups made the early release of prisoners a common 'bottom line' during the talks that led to the Good Friday Agreement. The talks teams from Sinn Fein, the Progressive Unionist Party and the Ulster Democratic Party felt they owed 'their' prisoners that much. Also, many of the key players in the talks had 'done their wack' - served long prison sentences in the H-Blocks - and many of the same ex-prisoners are now sitting in the Northern Ireland Assembly or in local government.

The recently elected Mayor of Derry, Cathal Crumley, took part in the 'dirty protest' in the late Seventies and early Eighties. Gerry Kelly, SF MLA for North Belfast, took part in the biggest mass breakout in British prison history when 38 IRA prisoners burst out in 1983, an escape that resulted in the death of a prison warder. The two PUP MLAs, Billy Hutchinson and David Ervine, served long sentences, as did the UDP's prison spokesman, John White.

Gerry Adams was interned in the 'compounds', the Nissen huts that stand abandoned beside the 12ft walls of the Maze, and spent seven months in the H-Blocks as a remand prisoner in 1977.

Months before the agreement was signed, Mo Mowlam became the first Secretary of State to meet prisoners in the H-Blocks, when she secured the retention of the UFF ceasefire by meeting its prisoners. The UFF had taken part in at least three murders 'in retaliation' for another incident in the Maze, the shooting dead by INLA inmates of the LVF leader Billy Wright.

Earlier in the same month of December 1997, Liam Averill, an IRA prisoner, escaped dressed as a woman after a Christmas party for inmates' families.

Furious unionists demanded explanations and rolling heads. Reports filtered out of raves in the H-Blocks with drugs galore; of mobile phones directing operations outside; of a cell full of dirt remaining undetected for weeks as the IRA built an escape tunnel complete with electric lights; of UFF leader Johnny Adair attempting to smuggle a puppy on to his wing.

By the late Nineties, cells were open 24 hours a day, with the 'screws' locked into the 'circle' - the bar in the 'H' shape of the blocks - while prisoners controlled the four wings of each block. Internal control of the wings came from an appointed representative of the prisoners, who in turn would report to the 'Officer Commanding' the prisoners for that particular faction.

On one occasion, he left to address the SF special conference in favour of accepting the Good Friday deal. He is now believed to be involved as an interlocutor with the Decommissioning Commission.

The first convicted IRA man to be handed a prison uniform was Kieran Nugent, who died at 42 two months ago. He refused, saying he was not a common criminal. Instead, he wrapped himself in the coarse prison issue blanket in his cell. Thus began a struggle between authorities and prisoners which escalated into violence, degradation and death. Prisoners lost all privileges, such as visits, education and exercise for years at a time.

Furniture was smashed and removed, leaving two men per cell with a mattress, a blanket, a chamber pot and a Bible. They would be moved to different cells every 10 days. Beatings and rough searches were commonplace, escalated in turn by the IRA's shooting of prison officials (24 were killed, including the governor of the Maze). When the 'screws' refused to empty the overflowing chamber pots, their contents were smeared over the walls of the cells. Nevertheless, the 'smell could be stomach-churning', recalls O Mhuaidh, not to mention the 'disgusting' food and the regular sight of maggots. They emptied the urine from their chamber pots through their doors onto the landing and built bread dams across the bottom of the doors to stop the contents flowing back into their cells. Eventually, under the leadership of Brendan Hughes, IRA prisoners wore uniforms in order to meet visitors. 'Comms', letters in tiny writing on toilet paper, were smuggled out, usually transferred by a kiss. The seats of the uniforms were torn so that other items could be smuggled inside. Biro refills, letters, tiny crystal radios in test tubes, were carried anally, or swallowed.

On the way to and from visits, prisoners would be held down and forced to squat over a mirror, or be probed by prison officers wearing surgical gloves. If caught smuggling, visits would be banned for three months.

Even education continued, with daily classes in Irish being shouted from one cell during lunch. O Mhuaidh, who now runs an Irish language group in Belfast, learnt the language in those conditions. He would clean an area of cell wall, and scratch notes of the day's lesson with a holy medal or a tube of toothpaste. Then things escalated to the point of last resort; hunger strike. The IRA outside was opposed to this option, arguing that it 'deflected resources from the war', but, according to Tommy McKearney, 'it was prisoner-led'.

'There was no other way out for us,' says O Mhuaidh. 'If we didn't see it through until the end, the long-term effect on the republican movement would have been disastrous'. The prisoners' argument was that, if the battle in the H-Blocks was lost, it would have been tantamount to an admission that the IRA was a criminal organisation. As a ballad of the time put it; 'I'll wear no prison uniform, Nor meekly serve my time, And let England reduce Ireland's fight, To 800 years of crime.'

'Compromise was not possible,' remembers Tommy McKearney, 'it would have had the effect of dissolving the ideology of the movement.'

Thus, McKearney and six others went on hunger strike in late 1980, demanding the right to wear their own clothes, not to do prison work, for segregation into their own wings, for lost privileges and 'creature comforts' such as education and visits. By day 53, he was on the verge of a coma when the strike was called off by Brendan Hughes, who thought the Thatcher Government had conceded. As the weeks passed, it became clear that the Lady had not turned. McKearney felt 'desperately despondent'.

Others started another hunger strike. Bobby Sands went first. In the course of his fast, he won a by-election for the Westminster seat of Fermanagh-South Tyrone, showing world opinion that the IRA prisoners had public support and allowing SF leaders such as Adams to argue to the 'militarists' in the republican movement that elections were a viable complement to (and eventually, alternative to) 'armed struggle'.

Nine more men would die before an uncertain ending. But by the mid-Eighties, the 'five demands' were 'won by stealth by the prisoners themselves', according to O Mhuaidh.

What should be done with the H-Blocks? The Prison Service plans to close the prison by the end of the year, and talks of 'mothballing' it in the eventuality of a future civil breakdown. Others in government would like to see it 'razed'. Ex-prisoners contacted by The Observer were unanimous. At least one block should be kept, as a museum for future generations.

fields.headline: A family affair
fields.standfirst:
Making black seem white is small beer for this trio of Government-advising fraternal siblings: More focus-pocus from New Labour
Special report: Labour in power
fields.trailText: Making black seem white is small beer for this trio of Government-advising fraternal siblings :  More focus-pocus from New Labour
fields.body:
The continuity between Old Tory and New Labour has been made flesh in the permanent government of Britain by the Powell family. Sir Charles Powell (who insisted his name must be pronounced 'Pole' because it sounded classier) was Margaret Thatcher's foreign policy adviser. On May Day 1997, the waste and squalor of 18 years of Tory misrule was smashed by Tony Blair's charge to power. One of the fresh leader's first acts on that new dawn was to take Jonathan Powell from our Washington embassy and make him chief of staff and foreign policy adviser. Unlike his brother, Jonathan had the social confidence to pronounce Powell 'Powell', as did a third brother, Chris, who organised the advertising of the New Labour 'brand'.

Siblings can be rivals but few have been able to spot the differences between Pole and Powell. Carla Pole, wife of Charles, befriended Peter Mandelson and protested about the pain her confidante suffered when he was briefly disgraced for forgetting to declare an enormous loan from Geoffrey Robinson, a man Mandelson's department was investigating for alleged breaches of company law. Jonathan added to the air of bipartisan conviviality by fighting to uphold the standards of the party of the family under a Labour government.

Robin Cook thought he might break from the past. From now on, there would be an 'ethical dimension' to foreign policy, the Foreign Secretary said in June 1997. Powell was having none of it. Government advisers told me he stomped through Downing Street chanting: 'An ethical foreign policy is bollocks, an ethical foreign policy is bollocks.' I refuse to believe that a mandarin who can boast blood ties to a Pole could be that vulgar, but Blair's circle, the Department for Trade and Industry and BAe executives close to the Prime Minister nevertheless overruled Cook's attempts to stop the public purse subsidising arms sales to some of the worst and most insolvent governments on Earth.

Cynics say you can't squeeze a wafer between the old and new regimes. Yet there is a distinction which the muddled arguments about spin grope towards. Unlike the Tories, New Labour covers reactionary politics with a bright, warm gloss.

For three years, the Foreign Office has produced an annual report on its support for human rights. The first was a shameless piece of puffery which, without a wince or a blush, featured a photo of Cook and General Suharto, the mass-murdering Indonesian dictator, locked in a manly handshake. In an early manifestation of the marketing ethos which has defiled the Government, the report ignored the theocratic dictatorship of the House of Saud or massacres of the Algerian government for fear of disillusioning the reader about the source of our oil and gas imports

The style and, to be fair, the content has improved since then. The third audit, released last week, shows a Foreign Office willing to condemn the death penalty or the oppression of women with a robustness the Conservatives would never match. Although everyone in Whitehall shudders at the mention of the words 'ethical dimension', Cook appears to be a goodish man fallen into bad company.

His condemnations only go so far, however. He has divided the world into two spheres. There are unpleasant countries, such as Iraq and Serbia, with which Britain has no business interests. These are denounced without reserve and must suffer sanctions and war. Then there are unpleasant countries, such as Russia and Saudi Arabia, in which Britain has many business interests. These are denounced in the mildest tones and must suffer 'constructive engagement'.

'Shorn of its colourful episodes, Yeltsin's Presidency will be respected for burying the Cold War,' intones Cook. The colourful episodes in question are the turning of Chechnya into a desert, the rise of gangster capitalism and the reduction of the bulk of the Russian population to such misery that male life expectancy has fallen by 10 years since the break-up of the Soviet Union. The Saudi Arabian monarchy is acknowledged to be a dictatorship, which is an advance, I suppose. But millions of pounds in bribes have been paid to persuade the Saudi royals to buy British arms, so criticism can be levelled only in 'frank but discreet exchanges'.

Despite the effort to display a modicum of honesty, there is a chapter on one nation in which the PR is outrageous and the attempts to cover up iniquity are so blatant a child of three could see through them. That country is Britain, a small archipelago of islands off the north-west coast of Europe, which, we are told, has a government which has placed 'full respect of human rights' as a 'central objective' of domestic as well as foreign pol icy. The Foreign Office supports this bold claim by telling the world that an Immigration and Asylum Act has come into force which will ensure 'respect for the human rights' of refugees from oppression and 'create new support arrangements for asylum-seekers'.

Cook is too embarrassed to mention that his colleagues have made it impossible for any refugee, however genuine, to reach Britain legally. Those who are here will have to support themselves with food vouchers worth £35 a week and see the supermarkets pocket the change when they exchange the tokens for scanty rations. The Freedom of Information Bill is cited as evidence that the islands have modern, democratic rulers. The Act's sweet title hides sweeping provisions which will turn pretty much anything Ministers want to hide into official secrets, which the report can't find the space to discuss.

Speaking of which, the Foreign Office has missed the prosecution of former MI5 agent David Shayler and journalists such as Tony Geraghty and my colleagues on the Guardian and The Observer for telling the truth about the operations of the security services. It is not only leftie columnists who get agitated about such matters. Last week, as the human rights report was being released, a UN report on human rights said the persecution of the legitimate inquiry in Britain and the Official Secrets Act were 'incompatible with media freedom'.

Put this together and we have an official culture which believes the tricks of advertising will allow it to get away with a 'freedom of information' Bill that promotes secrecy and an Asylum Bill which denies asylum. A name should be found for an ideology which dictates that government can present itself as caring and cuddly while carrying on with old abuses. I propose Powellism, but would accept Poleism.

More focus-pocus from New labour
If you read The Unfinished Revolution by Philip Gould - you don't have to, incidentally; the editor pays me an inadequate salary to endure that trauma on your behalf - you come across a telling scene which foreshadows the wasted radical opportunity of the past three years.

In 1996, as the death rattle of the Conservative government became deafening, Gould describes attending 'a vast polling meeting, stuffed with academic experts'. In Gould's mind, these were neutral scientists who dissected public opinion and purveyed incontrovertible findings to politicians. They spoke as one. All the evidence was that New Labour could 'safely put taxes up'.

You might have expected Gould to have been relieved. Hospitals and schools were sinking into slums and there was no point in having a Labour government unless it provided immediate remedies. Instead of being happy, he was disgusted. In one of the few scenes of genuine passion in the dreary book, he glowers at the audience in amazement. 'I couldn't stand it and left,' he says. 'I couldn't bear to watch.'

Surely he must have believed his colleagues were on to something? If he did not, he must admit the trade of pollstering, to which he had dedicated his life, is a pseudo-science. That he slighted his 'profession' and stormed out of the meeting suggests the rage which comes when deep prejudices are affronted.

The memo to Blair leaked last week shows that the commitment to conservatism still burns bright. None of the measures in Gordon Brown's spending review - the first Labour spending review in 21 years, which may yet win the next election - was commended. Instead, Gould insisted his objective experiments on focus groupies proved that Blair must veer ever further rightwards.

He must be tougher on crime, even though he has assailed civil liberties with vigour and incarcerated a record number of citizens. He must be more patriotic, even though he has fought two wars. (Does Gould want him to start another one? If so, against whom?)

Gould says that New Labour should emulate Bill Clinton who 'started badly but got a grip and developed eventually an easy, comfortable rhythm of government'. No one except a giddy Pollyanna can believe that a Clinton administration awash with corruption was a triumph. In Gould's debased accountancy of electoral success, Clinton's watch saw the Democrats lose control of Congress and head to the probable loss of the Presidency later this year.

Others may look at the way Clinton tore up Roosevelt's New Deal and merrily grovelled and triangulated to the most reactionary interests. Gould admires the old fraud none the less. As he made clear years ago, it is only policies which might help the poor he can't stand and propel him to the exit.
