Unlike his brother, Jonathan had the social confidence to pronounce Powell 'Powell', as did a third brother, Chris, who organised the advertising of the New Labour 'brand'. Siblings can be rivals but few have been able to spot the differences between Pole and Powell. Carla Pole, wife of Charles, befriended Peter Mandelson and protested about the pain her confidante suffered when he was briefly disgraced for forgetting to declare an enormous loan from Geoffrey Robinson, a man Mandelson's department was investigating for alleged breaches of company law. Jonathan added to the air of bipartisan conviviality by fighting to uphold the standards of the party of the family under a Labour government. Robin Cook thought he might break from the past. From now on, there would be an 'ethical dimension' to foreign policy, the Foreign Secretary said in June 1997. Powell was having none of it. Government advisers told me he stomped through Downing Street chanting: 'An ethical foreign policy is bollocks, an ethical foreign policy is bollocks.' I refuse to believe that a mandarin who can boast blood ties to a Pole could be that vulgar, but Blair's circle, the Department for Trade and Industry and BAe executives close to the Prime Minister nevertheless overruled Cook's attempts to stop the public purse subsidising arms sales to some of the worst and most insolvent governments on Earth. Cynics say you can't squeeze a wafer between the old and new regimes. Yet there is a distinction which the muddled arguments about spin grope towards. Unlike the Tories, New Labour covers reactionary politics with a bright, warm gloss. For three years, the Foreign Office has produced an annual report on its support for human rights. The first was a shameless piece of puffery which, without a wince or a blush, featured a photo of Cook and General Suharto, the mass-murdering Indonesian dictator, locked in a manly handshake. In an early manifestation of the marketing ethos which has defiled the Government, the report ignored the theocratic dictatorship of the House of Saud or massacres of the Algerian government for fear of disillusioning the reader about the source of our oil and gas imports The style and, to be fair, the content has improved since then. The third audit, released last week, shows a Foreign Office willing to condemn the death penalty or the oppression of women with a robustness the Conservatives would never match. Although everyone in Whitehall shudders at the mention of the words 'ethical dimension', Cook appears to be a goodish man fallen into bad company. His condemnations only go so far, however. He has divided the world into two spheres. There are unpleasant countries, such as Iraq and Serbia, with which Britain has no business interests. These are denounced without reserve and must suffer sanctions and war. Then there are unpleasant countries, such as Russia and Saudi Arabia, in which Britain has many business interests. These are denounced in the mildest tones and must suffer 'constructive engagement'. 'Shorn of its colourful episodes, Yeltsin's Presidency will be respected for burying the Cold War,' intones Cook. The colourful episodes in question are the turning of Chechnya into a desert, the rise of gangster capitalism and the reduction of the bulk of the Russian population to such misery that male life expectancy has fallen by 10 years since the break-up of the Soviet Union. The Saudi Arabian monarchy is acknowledged to be a dictatorship, which is an advance, I suppose. But millions of pounds in bribes have been paid to persuade the Saudi royals to buy British arms, so criticism can be levelled only in 'frank but discreet exchanges'. Despite the effort to display a modicum of honesty, there is a chapter on one nation in which the PR is outrageous and the attempts to cover up iniquity are so blatant a child of three could see through them. That country is Britain, a small archipelago of islands off the north-west coast of Europe, which, we are told, has a government which has placed 'full respect of human rights' as a 'central objective' of domestic as well as foreign pol icy. The Foreign Office supports this bold claim by telling the world that an Immigration and Asylum Act has come into force which will ensure 'respect for the human rights' of refugees from oppression and 'create new support arrangements for asylum-seekers'. Cook is too embarrassed to mention that his colleagues have made it impossible for any refugee, however genuine, to reach Britain legally. Those who are here will have to support themselves with food vouchers worth £35 a week and see the supermarkets pocket the change when they exchange the tokens for scanty rations. The Freedom of Information Bill is cited as evidence that the islands have modern, democratic rulers. The Act's sweet title hides sweeping provisions which will turn pretty much anything Ministers want to hide into official secrets, which the report can't find the space to discuss. Speaking of which, the Foreign Office has missed the prosecution of former MI5 agent David Shayler and journalists such as Tony Geraghty and my colleagues on the Guardian and The Observer for telling the truth about the operations of the security services. It is not only leftie columnists who get agitated about such matters. Last week, as the human rights report was being released, a UN report on human rights said the persecution of the legitimate inquiry in Britain and the Official Secrets Act were 'incompatible with media freedom'. Put this together and we have an official culture which believes the tricks of advertising will allow it to get away with a 'freedom of information' Bill that promotes secrecy and an Asylum Bill which denies asylum. A name should be found for an ideology which dictates that government can present itself as caring and cuddly while carrying on with old abuses. I propose Powellism, but would accept Poleism. More focus-pocus from New labour If you read The Unfinished Revolution by Philip Gould - you don't have to, incidentally; the editor pays me an inadequate salary to endure that trauma on your behalf - you come across a telling scene which foreshadows the wasted radical opportunity of the past three years. In 1996, as the death rattle of the Conservative government became deafening, Gould describes attending 'a vast polling meeting, stuffed with academic experts'. In Gould's mind, these were neutral scientists who dissected public opinion and purveyed incontrovertible findings to politicians. They spoke as one. All the evidence was that New Labour could 'safely put taxes up'. You might have expected Gould to have been relieved. Hospitals and schools were sinking into slums and there was no point in having a Labour government unless it provided immediate remedies. Instead of being happy, he was disgusted. In one of the few scenes of genuine passion in the dreary book, he glowers at the audience in amazement. 'I couldn't stand it and left,' he says. 'I couldn't bear to watch.' Surely he must have believed his colleagues were on to something? If he did not, he must admit the trade of pollstering, to which he had dedicated his life, is a pseudo-science. That he slighted his 'profession' and stormed out of the meeting suggests the rage which comes when deep prejudices are affronted. The memo to Blair leaked last week shows that the commitment to conservatism still burns bright. None of the measures in Gordon Brown's spending review - the first Labour spending review in 21 years, which may yet win the next election - was commended. Instead, Gould insisted his objective experiments on focus groupies proved that Blair must veer ever further rightwards. He must be tougher on crime, even though he has assailed civil liberties with vigour and incarcerated a record number of citizens. He must be more patriotic, even though he has fought two wars. (Does Gould want him to start another one? If so, against whom?) Gould says that New Labour should emulate Bill Clinton who 'started badly but got a grip and developed eventually an easy, comfortable rhythm of government'. No one except a giddy Pollyanna can believe that a Clinton administration awash with corruption was a triumph. In Gould's debased accountancy of electoral success, Clinton's watch saw the Democrats lose control of Congress and head to the probable loss of the Presidency later this year. Others may look at the way Clinton tore up Roosevelt's New Deal and merrily grovelled and triangulated to the most reactionary interests. Gould admires the old fraud none the less. As he made clear years ago, it is only policies which might help the poor he can't stand and propel him to the exit.

fields.headline: Patients' champion for every hospital
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Every hospital will get a 'patients' champion' to tackle rundown wards and end the neglect of basic needs, under a fundamental reform of the National Health Service to be unveiled this week.
fields.body:
Every hospital will get a 'patients' champion' to tackle rundown wards and end the neglect of basic needs, under a fundamental reform of the National Health Service to be unveiled this week.

The champion, or advocate, will have the authority to demand action and handle complaints from patients and their relatives on everything from dirty wards and inedible food to disputes with doctors and fears that the elderly are being denied care.

Health Secretary Alan Milburn intends the scheme to put patients' needs at the centre of the service, turn back the rising tide of official complaints and reduce the £2.8 billion NHS bill for medical negligence by detecting problems before they spiral out of control. However, critics are expected to claim the scheme is a gimmick that is unlikely to have real impact.

The move reflects growing public calls to 'bring back matron'. Surveys show widespread frustration that there is no obvious authority figure who can sort out problems and stop standards sliding.

The patients' champions will come from all walks of life, including the customer services departments of industry. They will have direct access to hospital chief executives and ward sisters. The champions will operate in teams to help as many patients as possible.

This is part of the National Plan, the wide-ranging reform which the Government insists will be the most radical since the NHS was founded in 1948.

'Although staff are working tremendously hard, they are having to fight the system to get the patients the care they need,' Milburn told The Observer. 'There are a host of very basic things wrong. There are just too many stories about people not getting their food, or the treatment they need. What is lacking in a lot of hospitals is that sort of fast access for patients, that kind of figure of authority.'

A damning report by consultants from the Virgin group last week highlighted squalid conditions, nurses reading newspapers at ward stations and the 'dead hand of bureaucracy' stifling staff who had lost pride in their jobs. Milburn said: 'The NHS has got to start thinking like a modern service sector industry where the interests of patients always come first.'

The National Plan will promise an expansion of the hospital building programme, and a £400 million scheme to improve GP services by revamping crumbling surgeries and building a network of 'one-stop' centres in deprived neighbourhoods.

The Department of Health has had great difficulties in getting GPs to work in poor areas, where the need for them is greatest. There will be financial incentives to attract and retain doctors.

The plan will include a nine-month maximum waiting time for surgery, as revealed in The Observer last week, and the number of cancelled operations will be cut by sending patients to private hospitals. The elderly are expected to be given free nursing in residential homes, but continue to pay 'bed and board' charges.

The central theme will be to put patients - rather than professionals - at the centre of the service. The patients' advocate scheme will be introduced first in major hospitals, then nationally, at a cost of more than £10 million.

The other main aim is to reduce inequalities, reflecting government concern that the poor have far worse access to the NHS than the affluent.

In many deprived areas, there are so few GPs that it can take up to a week to get an appointment. A network of 'one stop' centres will provide GPs, social services, opticians, chemists and, in some cases, minor operations.

webTitle: Whitehall braced for reform of the Official Secrets Act

fields.headline: Whitehall braced for reform of the Official Secrets Act
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Senior civil servants in the Home Office, Ministry of Defence and Cabinet Office are preparing to reform the Official Secrets Act to make it compatible with European law - or even repeal it altogether.
fields.body:
Senior civil servants in the Home Office, Ministry of Defence and Cabinet Office are preparing to reform the Official Secrets Act to make it compatible with European law - or even repeal it altogether.

The intelligence community is reeling after last week's successful challenges by The Observer and Guardian to demands by the police to hand over documents relating to former MI5 officer David Shayler. Most whistleblowers come to the press, and it is difficult to see where police will find evidence of breaches of the Act if journalists no longer have to hand over notes.

Officials are also concerned about the introduction of the European Convention on Human Rights into English law on 2 October. Lawyers acting for Shayler believe they can challenge the Official Secrets Act under Article 10 of the convention, which guarantees freedom of expression.

One senior MoD source with special responsibility for official secrets told The Observer: 'We know there are real challenges to the Official Secrets Act coming up with the return and possible trial of David Shayler and the introduction of the Human Rights Act.' But he said reform was unlikely to come from inside the Home Office. Instead, those in favour of reform are hoping a high-profile secrets trial will directly challenge the legislation. Senior civil servants are split between hardliners who believe the law should be tougher, with automatic fines for breaches in cases where whistleblowers have made money from revelations, and liberals who believe in reform and, in some cases, abolition.

The news comes as the intelligence services win new budgets reaching nearly £1bn following an unprecedented increase in funding in last week's Comprehensive Spending Review. New Labour has reversed the downward trend in intelligence funding since the Cold War. From 1997 to the end of the current spending review in 2003 funding for spies and surveillance is planned to increase 34 per cent, or by £248 million. It follows five years of cuts under the Major government.

The bulk of the money is believed to be earmarked for the new Government Communications Headquarters in Cheltenham. The building will be the focus of controversial moves to intercept email under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers RIP bill. Government figures released earlier this month revealed that bugging, phone-tapping and letter-opening by the police and security services have risen by 60 per cent since Labour came to power.

fields.headline: Princess the Palace hides away
fields.standfirst:
She's 99 this year... but Princess Alice is the forgotten royal missing from the Court Circular
Special report: the future of the monarchy
Special report: The Queen Mother at 100
fields.trailText: The beatific countenance of Britain's last Queen-Empress - described by her chaplain as heavenly - did not waver last week. But as a calendar of commemorative family events is staged, one figure will not be by her side.
fields.body:
The beatific countenance of Britain's last Queen-Empress - described by her chaplain as heavenly - did not waver last week. But as a calendar of commemorative family events is staged, one figure will not be by her side.

As the Queen Mother celebrates her hundredth birthday, Princess Alice approaches her ninety-ninth. But the Dowager Duchess of Gloucester will spend the next month - as she has spent the past five years - hidden in Kensington Palace, the west London residence monickered the 'Aunt Heap' by Edward VII.

The Princess, mother of the Duke of Gloucester, is the Queen's aunt and sister-in-law of the Queen Mother. When Lady Alice Montagu-Douglas-Scott married Prince Henry of Gloucester in 1935, he was fourth in line to the throne. If the Luftwaffe had killed George VI and his immediate family when it bombed Buckingham Palace, Alice, not Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon, would have become Britain's Queen and last Empress of India.

What is as sad as the Princess's decline is the wall of silence that surrounds it. A senior Palace official describes her as 'with us some of the time, but not at others'. It is the closest any intimate has come to acknowledging that the princess's frailty is more than just physical.

A charity with which she has had a lengthy connection, respecting the omertà the Windsors demand of their circle, would say only that meetings with Her Royal Highness 'have not taken place for some time'. A family friend said loyally: 'She did remember me the last time I spoke to her.' That was three years ago.

The princess's early life was the stuff of a Waugh novel. From an even more lustrous background than the Queen Mother, she once recalled that during the Season there were 68 staff in residence at the London home of her father, the Duke of Buccleuch.

She recalled: 'Looking back, I was somewhat starved in my affections. I prayed every night for my teddy bear to come to life.'

She spent much of her twenties in Kenya, close to the Happy Valley set which became notorious for promiscuity and drug-taking. She went on to India and gold-prospecting. When her family refused to finance any more foreign trips, she sold watercolours at a Bond Street gallery, netting 190 guineas.

After her marriage, Alice became an assiduous member of the royal 'firm', supporting her husband and acquiring many of the Windsors' odder prejudices. 'One always seemed to be giving places [countries] away,' she observed blithely in a memoir. 'They have been at war since, in most cases.'

In 1995, the Duke of Gloucester let out the family's castellated home at Barnwell Manor, in Northamptonshire, where Princess Alice, then 93, had spent almost all of her married life. He claimed the property was too expensive to keep and moved her into Kensington Palace, where he now lives rent-free.

He was pilloried by tabloid newspapers for removing an elderly lady from her lifelong home - a recognised cause of disorientation for old people. He did not respond.

Since 1995, references to the princess's predicament have disappeared from the Court Circular, issued daily by Buckingham Palace as an update on the activities and wellbeing of the royal family. At one time, reports of her state of health - flu, a bad leg, the removal of varicose veins - featured regularly. Now there is silence.

The royal family's refusal to acknowledge any human frailty is not new. Prince John, who would have become brother-in-law to both the Queen Mother and Princess Alice had he lived, was born in 1905.

His life was transformed when he was four and had his first epileptic fit. His health-obsessed parents, later George V and Queen Mary, were appalled.

He was excluded from official family photographs. He was not allowed to be present at his father's coronation in 1911.

Early in 1917, John was removed from any risk of public discovery forever. He was consigned - with a nanny and two robust male attendants to hold him down whenever he had fits - to Wood Farm, on a corner of the Sandringham estate. He was never to see his parents again.

Two years later John died in his sleep. The King and Queen drove the three miles from the main house at Sandringham to view his body.

Little appears to have changed since. In 1987, it emerged that Katherine and Nerissa Bowes-Lyon had been incarcerated in the Royal Earlswood Mental Hospital in Surrey for 46 years. The two women, nieces of the Queen Mother, had never been visited by a member of the royal family.

Burke's Peerage, the guidebook to aristocratic lineage, recorded the sisters as having died in 1940 and 1961.

'If that is what members of the family told us, then we would have included it,' said Harold Brooks-Baker, the editor at the time. 'It is not normal to doubt the word of members of the royal family.'

The Queen Mother herself, patron of Mencap, claimed that news about the women had come as a surprise in the early Eighties. Royal correspondents were briefed that she had sent a cheque 'to pay for sweets'.

When Nerissa Bowes-Lyon died in 1986, she was buried in Redhill cemetery. Her grave was marked with a plastic tag bearing a serial number and her name.

Yesterday an official at Kensington Palace admitted: 'Princess Alice does not attend any events now. It would be too much for her. It's a health thing. She is different from the Queen Mother.'

A spokeswoman for the Dementia Relief Trust said: 'All too often with older people there is an unwillingness among families to acknowledge what is happening. One in four people over 85 has some dementia. It's just something that happens. Sometimes it's best to seek diagnosis. They're not mad.'

fields.headline: CPS drops McAliskey investigation
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Crown Prosecution Service has abandoned a secret investigation into Roisin McAliskey, bringing to an end one of the most controversial terrorism inquiries of the past decade.
fields.body:
The Crown Prosecution Service has abandoned a secret investigation into Roisin McAliskey, bringing to an end one of the most controversial terrorism inquiries of the past decade.

The CPS said there was no reasonable chance of securing a conviction of McAliskey, who was accused of being involved in the IRA bombing of a British army base in Osnabruck, Germany, in June 1996.

Her solicitor, Gareth Peirce, said she was surprised when she received a fax from the CPS last Wednesday telling her of the decision.

In a statement laid before Parliament last week with no publicity, the Solicitor General, Ross Cranston, said no further action would be taken against McAliskey, whose case became a cause célèbre during the 1990s.

'Further to the statement of the Home Secretary on 10 March 1998 that he would not order the extradition of Roisin McAliskey to Germany, the Crown Prosecution Service... has considered whether to prosecute Roisin McAliskey in this country. [It] has concluded that there is not a realistic prospect of convicting Miss McAliskey for any offence arising out of the Osnabruk bombing.'

The statement was slipped out on the same day Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, was making his announcement on the Comprehensive Spending Review.

'From the first morning Roisin McAliskey appeared in court you did not need to be a lawyer to know that she was innocent,' Peirce said. 'The evidence was puny.

'That it has taken [the CPS] so long seems to be something of a waste of public authority time and money.'

McAliskey's case became the subject of heated debate in the 1990s when she was kept in prison for months on a German extradition charge despite being pregnant. She was forced to have her daughter, Loinnir, in prison.

Her supporters, including her mother, Bernadette McAliskey, former Nationalist MP for Mid-Ulster, said that she suffered from brittle bone disease after being kept without daylight for days on end, had suffered psychological problems and had been strip searched 75 times.

She was arrested in November 1996 after the German authorities said that her fingerprints had been found on cellophane wrapping near the scene of the mortar bomb attack, in which no one was injured. An eye witness also said she had been seen at a holiday home rented by an IRA active service unit.

The evidence was fatally undermined when it was revealed that the cellophane wrapping could have been moved to Germany from Britain and the eyewitness later retracted his statement.

Other witnesses said that at the time she was alleged to have been planning the attack, the 28-year-old politics graduate was at home in Coalisland, County Tyrone, and at work in Dungannon.

The Home Secretary, Jack Straw, finally refused extradition on health grounds.

The CPS said there was no reasonable chance of securing a conviction of McAliskey, who was accused of being involved in the IRA bombing of a British army base in Osnabruck, Germany, in June 1996. Her solicitor, Gareth Peirce, said she was surprised when she received a fax from the CPS last Wednesday telling her of the decision. In a statement laid before Parliament last week with no publicity, the Solicitor General, Ross Cranston, said no further action would be taken against McAliskey, whose case became a cause célèbre during the 1990s. 'Further to the statement of the Home Secretary on 10 March 1998 that he would not order the extradition of Roisin McAliskey to Germany, the Crown Prosecution Service... has considered whether to prosecute Roisin McAliskey in this country. [It] has concluded that there is not a realistic prospect of convicting Miss McAliskey for any offence arising out of the Osnabruk bombing.' The statement was slipped out on the same day Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, was making his announcement on the Comprehensive Spending Review. 'From the first morning Roisin McAliskey appeared in court you did not need to be a lawyer to know that she was innocent,' Peirce said. 'The evidence was puny. 'That it has taken [the CPS] so long seems to be something of a waste of public authority time and money.' McAliskey's case became the subject of heated debate in the 1990s when she was kept in prison for months on a German extradition charge despite being pregnant. She was forced to have her daughter, Loinnir, in prison. Her supporters, including her mother, Bernadette McAliskey, former Nationalist MP for Mid-Ulster, said that she suffered from brittle bone disease after being kept without daylight for days on end, had suffered psychological problems and had been strip searched 75 times. She was arrested in November 1996 after the German authorities said that her fingerprints had been found on cellophane wrapping near the scene of the mortar bomb attack, in which no one was injured. An eye witness also said she had been seen at a holiday home rented by an IRA active service unit. The evidence was fatally undermined when it was revealed that the cellophane wrapping could have been moved to Germany from Britain and the eyewitness later retracted his statement. Other witnesses said that at the time she was alleged to have been planning the attack, the 28-year-old politics graduate was at home in Coalisland, County Tyrone, and at work in Dungannon. The Home Secretary, Jack Straw, finally refused extradition on health grounds.

webTitle: Millions of lab animals to die in Euro tests

fields.headline: Millions of lab animals to die in Euro tests
fields.standfirst: Special report: the European Commission
fields.trailText: Ten million laboratory animals will be slaughtered under plans being drawn up by the European Commission for a massive chemical testing programme on a wide range of household products, animal welfare groups and the chemical industry have warned.
fields.body:
Ten million laboratory animals will be slaughtered under plans being drawn up by the European Commission for a massive chemical testing programme on a wide range of household products, animal welfare groups and the chemical industry have warned.

Internal reports and briefing notes obtained by the British Union for the Abolition of Vivisection show that up to 70,000 substances found in everything from everyday foods to pots of paint are under review.

Brussels' environment division is drawing up proposals to test chemicals manufactured before 1993, when current EU rules on testing were introduced. They are due for publication in early September.

'This proposal is alarming,' said Michelle Thew, chief executive of BUAV. 'There is no real logical basis to it. Even the chemical industry does not want it. It will be a massive waste of millions of animals' lives and it flies directly in the face of the European Commission's commitment to reduce animal testing.

'The BUAV will be fighting this proposal every step of the way. We will be co-ordinating a mass mobilisation of the public and of animal groups across Europe to ensure that this sickening and needless exploitation of animals does not take place.'

American animal welfare groups, such as the Doris Day Animal League, told The Observer they are shocked that Europe is preparing such wide-ranging testing. Last year they successfully mobilised a continent-wide campaign against Vice-President Al Gore when he backed a similar plan.

Sara Admundson, of the Doris Day Animal League, said: 'I cannot fathom why the usually progressive regulators in Europe are making the same mistake as the US federal regulators made last year.'

A report from the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions shows that British officials are supporting Brussels bureaucrats.

'We need a better understanding of the fate and effects of chemicals in the environment...'

The report expresses concern that relatively few chemicals on the market and in the food chain have been subjected to the testing regime introduced in 1993. It says the programme to test existing chemicals is expensive and slow.

But BUAV argues that these chemicals have been used for decades and there are plenty of alternative routes to testing their safety and impact on the environment without subjecting animals to toxicity tests. Rabbits, dogs, monkeys, birds, rats and mice would undergo the tests, whose purpose is to find what level of poisoning an animal can bear before it dies.

None of the products would be removed from the market during the 10 years it would take to complete the Brussels plan. This throws doubt on how serious officials really believe the threat from these chemicals is.

The DETR report estimates that there are 20,000 chemicals on the market which fit its criteria for testing. It puts the cost of basic testing for a single chemical at between £100,000 and £500,000.

But the industry itself views the proposals - outlined by an environment official from Brussels to a meeting of the European Chemical Industry Council, CEFIC, in May - with alarm. CEFIC says the Brussels plan is 'unworkable'.

webTitle: Hope just glimmers in light of Jerusalem's golden dome

fields.headline: Hope just glimmers in light of Jerusalem's golden dome
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A step beyond the stone portal that lies beneath Adnan Husseini's office, the Dome of the Rock explodes into view, a dazzling golden vision in the bright morning sun: the heart of Muslim Jerusalem, and of the epic struggle for the holy city.
fields.body:
A step beyond the stone portal that lies beneath Adnan Husseini's office, the Dome of the Rock explodes into view, a dazzling golden vision in the bright morning sun: the heart of Muslim Jerusalem, and of the epic struggle for the holy city.

A world away from Husseini's office in the Council for Waqf and Islamic Affairs (the custodian of Muslim holy places), President Bill Clinton was making his way back to Camp David yesterday, ending his visit to Okinawa to pick up the reins on the thirteenth day of the Middle East peace talks.

The schedule change has created a tiny bubble of optimism. But Clinton now needs a miracle. If he fails to reconcile Israelis and Palestinians on the most divisive issue between them - the status of Jerusalem - the whole show could crash down.

After seven years of talks, crowned by the marathon sessions of the last days at Camp David, it all comes down to this patch of land one kilometre square: the ancient walled city, which houses the most sacred relic of the Jews at the Wailing Wall, the burial place of Jesus at the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, and al-Aqsa mosque, the third holiest shrine in Islam after Mecca and Medina.

The yearning for a deal to end 52 years of conflict is great, and many observers were cheered on Friday when Rabbi Michael Melchior, an Israeli Minister, said that the Jewish state was willing to foresake its divine mantra of Jerusalem as its 'undivided and eternal capital', and to contemplate the sharing of sovereignty.

Palestinian leaders, however, were unmoved, arguing that control of municipal services in parts of East Jerusalem stopped far short of their demand for the return of all parts of the city taken by Israel in the 1967 war.

While Israel may be willing to bend on northern Palestinian neighbourhoods, it insists it will never yield on the old city. 'This is the heart of Jerusalem and you can't compromise on the heart,' Melchior told a prayer session at the Wailing Wall, soon after offering his compromise to the Palestinians.

Husseini's heart is in the same place, and he is just as uncompromising. He says the Israeli and American formulas for limited Palestinian rule are sheer illusion. Without a full-fledged Palestinian capital in Arab East Jerusalem, and control of al-Aqsa and the Muslim quarters of the old city, there is no chance that Yasser Arafat could accept the compromise proposals.

'Jerusalem is not only for Palestine,' he says. 'The Palestinian people will suffer the condemnation of the Islamic and Arab countries forever if they agree to a solution that only gives us East Jerusalem.'

The US-Israeli proposal to satisfy Muslim aspirations by allowing Palestinians safe passage to al-Aqsa via an underground tunnel from the Mount of Olives is an additional indignity.

Husseini's family has produced the muftis and mayors of Jerusalem for hundreds of years. In his 31 years at the Waqf board, Husseini has been at the front line of Palestinian efforts to hold their own in the walled city against Israeli expansion. Some 29,500 Palestinians live in the old city, cramped into a warren of dirty lanes.

Hundreds were robbed of their homes in 1967 when bulldozers levelled the land for a Jewish quarter. Some 2,500 Jews now live where those houses stood, spread out in landscaped condominiums. A stroll towards the serenity of al-Aqsa from the hubbub of Damascus Gate provides evidence of the potential for combustibility within its gates.

The route, past the Palestinian women in long embroidered dresses selling bunches of mint, the shops selling jokey T-shirts and other souvenir tat is intersected by the Via Dolorosa, and crocodiles of Christian pilgrims.

It is also scored by a scattering of Jewish houses and synagogues, the outposts of the most militant Jewish settlers. Husseini argues that these outposts are proof that the Jewish state has failed to protect the rights of Palestinians living under its occupation for the last 33 years.

Yesterday there was trepidation among Palestinians that Arafat would come under intolerable pressure from Clinton and Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak, to swallow compromise proposals, or be cast as the summit wrecker.

webTitle: Bosnia's holy warriors ready to fight evictions

fields.headline: Bosnia's holy warriors ready to fight evictions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Bosnian police are preparing to take on one of the strangest and most difficult legacies of the war - the Mujahideen who have settled in the former Serb villages in central Bosnia.
fields.body:
Bosnian police are preparing to take on one of the strangest and most difficult legacies of the war - the Mujahideen who have settled in the former Serb villages in central Bosnia.

Although a programme of deportation is not due to begin until tomorrow, tensions are high and police have made arrests.

The Mujahideen originally came from Iran, Afghanistan and other Islamic countries, offering their services as freelance freedom fighters alongside the Muslim-dominated Bosnian government army. Most of Bosnia's Muslims have little truck with the strict form of Islam practised by the Mujahideen. Nevertheless, in the depths of the war, with a United Nations arms embargo blocking most sources of weapons, the government army asked no questions of anyone volunteering to help.

By rights, the Mujahideen should have gone home four years ago. The Dayton peace accord, which was signed in December 1995, ordered all foreign forces to leave the country within a month. However, many of the Mujahideen now have Bosnian citizenship.

After the war the former holy warriors settled in the villages around Maglaj, in central Bosnia. The area was Serb-dominated before the war, but by 1996 the local Serbs had fled or been killed, victims of ethnic cleansing. Many of the Mujahideen married Bosnians and lived undisturbed with their new families in other people's houses.

But with a sudden increase in the number of refugee returns, that's about to change. This year the logjam has broken, and people are returning to their homes in greater numbers than ever before. Between January and May of this year, more than 15,000 refugees went back to their homes. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) is struggling to keep up with the demand for assistance.

At the same time the international community is renewing its efforts to get Bosnia's property laws implemented. This means getting local authorities to evict illegal occupants, thus freeing houses for their rightful owners to return.

Among those wanting to return are the displaced Serbs of Bocinja, near Maglaj, one of the main centres of the Mujahideen. The displaced Serbs are ready to go back for good.

The UNHCR spokeswoman in Sarajevo, Barbara Smith, described Bocinja as a 'difficult area for returns'. As of the end of May, only 57 people had gone back this year. The scene is set for a confrontation between local police and Mujahideen.

Last week local media reports that evictions were due to begin led people around Bocinja to set up two roadblocks. The International Police Task Force (IPTF), which has been monitoring the situation, reported 40 to 50 people on the roadblocks. In fact, evictions are not due to begin until tomorrow. Nevertheless, it took the local police three days to move in and dismantle the barricades. Nineteen people were arrested, including several described as 'foreigners or Mujahideen'.

The first people to be evicted will be displaced Serbs and Muslims who are also living around Bocinja. They will be taken out of their houses, along with their belongings, and moved to temporary accommodation elsewhere. But the Mujahideen know they are also on the list, and it is that which is likely to lead to further disturbances.

No one knows exactly how many Mujahideen there are, but most estimates put their numbers at 60 to 70 families. Their presence hasn't always been trouble-free. Last year police in Turkey arrested a man travelling on a Bosnian passport who was said to be a member of the terrorist organisation run by the exiled Saudi fundamentalist Osama bin Laden.

The International Crisis Group, a think tank which produces regular reports on Bosnia, says the Mujahideen are a 'source of potential political and ethnic instability in central Bosnia'. In 1994 a British aid worker was killed around Zenica, allegedly by Mujahideen. And in early 1996, French S-For troops raided a camp in the hills outside Fojnica, where they found explosives and booby-traps. The director of the ICG, James Lyon, said the base 'bore all the signs of a terrorist training camp'.

The new moves to get rid of the Mujahideen mark a shift in tactics. They're no longer being dealt with as illegal foreign forces; instead, they're considered as squatters. The IPTF said last week's roadblocks appeared to be 'a co-ordinated attempt to halt the evictions process in Bocinja'.

Oleg Milisic, spokesman for the Office of the High Representative, which oversees the implementation of the Dayton accord, said: 'This is not a political issue. It is an issue of the law and citizens' rights to their property. Property rights must be respected as part of the returns process now under way across the whole of Bosnia and Herzegovina.'

fields.headline: Battle to save Bevan's dream
fields.standfirst:
Health Secretary burns midnight oil to deliver ambitious NHS plan
Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: When MPs glance across the river from the House of Commons, the first thing they see is the sprawling expanse of St Thomas's hospital. It happens to have one of the better cancer wards in Britain, but as he wanders his department Dr Adrian Timothy, director of cancer services, keeps uttering the word 'crisis'.
fields.body:
When MPs glance across the river from the House of Commons, the first thing they see is the sprawling expanse of St Thomas's hospital. It happens to have one of the better cancer wards in Britain, but as he wanders his department Dr Adrian Timothy, director of cancer services, keeps uttering the word 'crisis'.

Consultants who are meant to see 350 new patients a year are treating over 500: people are waiting more than 10 weeks for treatment. Timothy has just decommissioned a radiotherapy machine that was 35 years old, and the two they have left are out-dated. He has a third fewer radiology therapists than he needs.

'You can't overestimate the crisis - we have been underfunded for so long,' he says. 'Patients get less time, there are delays in treatment, and some of the delays are very significant. You can't give as much treatment as you would like. It's a constant frustration.'

New Labour has been seeking radical answers to such uncomfortable dilemmas for years. In opposition they seriously considered pledging to scrap waiting for surgery altogether before discarding that as impractical. But even cutting 100,000 off the lists took Herculean effort.

So is Alan Milburn giving a hostage to fortune by promising this week to ensure no-one waits more than nine months for an operation?

Or has the decision to involve over 120 nurses, doctors, managers and patients in producing a National Plan for the NHS finally produced a workable cure for all its ills?

The stakes are certainly high. Milburn deliberately describes it as a 'heartland' issue, the word modernisers hardly ever use: everyone knows the core vote will not tolerate failure here.

'Labour and the NHS have a common history and a set of common values,' says Milburn. 'It is absolute core, heartland policy territory, and by heartland I mean it is core to what the Government means.'

He admits there have been decades of under-investment, but insists the problem, now that Gordon Brown has unleashed £13 billion for health, is not cash but reform. 'Our conclusion is that the principles of the NHS are absolutely right and even more valid today then they ever have been,' he says. 'But its practices all too often are wrong.'

If he were listening, the Labour folk hero whose legacy Milburn now wrestles with might smile wryly. Launching his brainchild of a free National Health Service for all on 5 July 1948, Nye Bevan warned: 'Nor will there be overnight any miraculous removal of our more serious shortages of nurses and others and of modern, replanned buildings and equipment. But the sooner we start, the sooner we can try together to see to these things and to secure the improvements we all want.'

His words could easily have been spoken 52 years later to the day, when a select band of medical experts gathered in the unlikely surroundings of the London Arena, a glitzy Docklands concert venue, two weeks ago.

The venue was chosen because Milburn was there dishing out awards in Bevan's name: the guests came from six teams of experts invited to work on the Plan back in March so that nobody could say politicians were forcing half-baked ideas on a profession that knew better. Nick Harvey, the Liberal Democrat health spokesman and friend of Milburn's, was also invited.

The main pieces of the National Plan jigsaw were clear by then - faster treatment, building new hospitals, thousands more doctors, extra cash for best performers, new ways to conquer heart disease and cancer. Their task was to fit it together, and their conclusions form the basis of the report Milburn has been hammering out on his computer ever since.

The polished oval table in his Whitehall office is now a sea of half-empty coffee mugs, laptops and papers among which Milburn, plus special advisers Simon Stevens and Darren Murphy, have laboured until the early hours most nights. They are flanked by three huge whiteboards covered in multi-coloured scribbles of the key points. The boards have been rubbed out and rewritten so often they are turning grey.

The Health Secretary has allowed himself only one break this weekend - rushing home to the North-East for his son's ninth birthday party last night and returning on the early morning flight.

He is spending the weekend chewing over last-minute questions with trusted expert team members like Christine Hancock, the no-nonsense general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, and Professor Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians. Neither has spared the Government criticism in the past.

Copies of the plan have been tightly restricted in Whitehall. The key players outside Milburn's circle have been Treasury chief secretary Andrew Smith, Number 10 policy wonk Robert Hill and, above all, Tony Blair himself. The secure - or so they hoped - fax line in the Prime Minister's hotel suite in Okinawa, Japan, began spewing forth paper at midday on Friday.

It was Milburn's latest draft, delivered just before 2am British time as he headed home to bed. After too few hours' sleep he was back in the office for some good news: Blair rang from Japan to say he was happy with it.

Over the last few months Blair has held around 100 meetings on the plan. Even on paternity leave he pored over papers at Chequers. And it will be Blair who announces the plan in parliament this Thursday. His personal involvement is meant to signal how seriously the Government takes health.

To prevent grumbles that ministerial spin is part of the problem for the NHS there will be no glitzy launch. One rally organised to consult London staff on the plan brought warnings that policy 'too often appears to be media-led' and that politicians 'should not raise unrealistic expectations'.

So the talk this week will be of an extra £1,000 in health spending for every household, not vast billions. And the plan's first chapter will be a frank analysis of the NHS's failings. Chief among which, as Timothy points out, is the most basic and obvious of all: too few doctors and nurses.

The British Medical Association says the nation needs another 6,000 consultants. Milburn plans another 1,000 medical school places, plus a recruitment drive abroad to fill the gaps. But staff take years to train. 'The big constraint for us is no longer cash, it's people,' Milburn warns.

He says the plan will not shirk the big questions left unanswered by Bevan's vision. 'There are issues no government has had the guts or conviction to address. And yes, there are some difficult issues for us: health and social care, the relations between the NHS and the private sector, the way that doctors are employed. This is the moment when those nettles have to be grasped. Politics is not without risk.'

However the Government believes the answers are all out there somewhere. 'Bevan said we had got to take the best in the NHS and make it nationwide, and that crucially is the problem the NHS still has today,' says one government aide. 'Every day, every problem, there is a solution being worked out somewhere in the NHS - but not yet everywhere.'

Time will tell if the answer to Dr Timothy's crisis is out there too.

It happens to have one of the better cancer wards in Britain, but as he wanders his department Dr Adrian Timothy, director of cancer services, keeps uttering the word 'crisis'. Consultants who are meant to see 350 new patients a year are treating over 500: people are waiting more than 10 weeks for treatment. Timothy has just decommissioned a radiotherapy machine that was 35 years old, and the two they have left are out-dated. He has a third fewer radiology therapists than he needs. 'You can't overestimate the crisis - we have been underfunded for so long,' he says. 'Patients get less time, there are delays in treatment, and some of the delays are very significant. You can't give as much treatment as you would like. It's a constant frustration.' New Labour has been seeking radical answers to such uncomfortable dilemmas for years. In opposition they seriously considered pledging to scrap waiting for surgery altogether before discarding that as impractical. But even cutting 100,000 off the lists took Herculean effort. So is Alan Milburn giving a hostage to fortune by promising this week to ensure no-one waits more than nine months for an operation? Or has the decision to involve over 120 nurses, doctors, managers and patients in producing a National Plan for the NHS finally produced a workable cure for all its ills? The stakes are certainly high. Milburn deliberately describes it as a 'heartland' issue, the word modernisers hardly ever use: everyone knows the core vote will not tolerate failure here. 'Labour and the NHS have a common history and a set of common values,' says Milburn. 'It is absolute core, heartland policy territory, and by heartland I mean it is core to what the Government means.' He admits there have been decades of under-investment, but insists the problem, now that Gordon Brown has unleashed £13 billion for health, is not cash but reform. 'Our conclusion is that the principles of the NHS are absolutely right and even more valid today then they ever have been,' he says. 'But its practices all too often are wrong.' If he were listening, the Labour folk hero whose legacy Milburn now wrestles with might smile wryly. Launching his brainchild of a free National Health Service for all on 5 July 1948, Nye Bevan warned: 'Nor will there be overnight any miraculous removal of our more serious shortages of nurses and others and of modern, replanned buildings and equipment. But the sooner we start, the sooner we can try together to see to these things and to secure the improvements we all want.' His words could easily have been spoken 52 years later to the day, when a select band of medical experts gathered in the unlikely surroundings of the London Arena, a glitzy Docklands concert venue, two weeks ago. The venue was chosen because Milburn was there dishing out awards in Bevan's name: the guests came from six teams of experts invited to work on the Plan back in March so that nobody could say politicians were forcing half-baked ideas on a profession that knew better. Nick Harvey, the Liberal Democrat health spokesman and friend of Milburn's, was also invited. The main pieces of the National Plan jigsaw were clear by then - faster treatment, building new hospitals, thousands more doctors, extra cash for best performers, new ways to conquer heart disease and cancer. Their task was to fit it together, and their conclusions form the basis of the report Milburn has been hammering out on his computer ever since. The polished oval table in his Whitehall office is now a sea of half-empty coffee mugs, laptops and papers among which Milburn, plus special advisers Simon Stevens and Darren Murphy, have laboured until the early hours most nights. They are flanked by three huge whiteboards covered in multi-coloured scribbles of the key points. The boards have been rubbed out and rewritten so often they are turning grey. The Health Secretary has allowed himself only one break this weekend - rushing home to the North-East for his son's ninth birthday party last night and returning on the early morning flight. He is spending the weekend chewing over last-minute questions with trusted expert team members like Christine Hancock, the no-nonsense general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, and Professor Sir George Alberti, president of the Royal College of Physicians. Neither has spared the Government criticism in the past. Copies of the plan have been tightly restricted in Whitehall. The key players outside Milburn's circle have been Treasury chief secretary Andrew Smith, Number 10 policy wonk Robert Hill and, above all, Tony Blair himself. The secure - or so they hoped - fax line in the Prime Minister's hotel suite in Okinawa, Japan, began spewing forth paper at midday on Friday. It was Milburn's latest draft, delivered just before 2am British time as he headed home to bed. After too few hours' sleep he was back in the office for some good news: Blair rang from Japan to say he was happy with it. Over the last few months Blair has held around 100 meetings on the plan. Even on paternity leave he pored over papers at Chequers. And it will be Blair who announces the plan in parliament this Thursday. His personal involvement is meant to signal how seriously the Government takes health. To prevent grumbles that ministerial spin is part of the problem for the NHS there will be no glitzy launch. One rally organised to consult London staff on the plan brought warnings that policy 'too often appears to be media-led' and that politicians 'should not raise unrealistic expectations'. So the talk this week will be of an extra £1,000 in health spending for every household, not vast billions. And the plan's first chapter will be a frank analysis of the NHS's failings. Chief among which, as Timothy points out, is the most basic and obvious of all: too few doctors and nurses. The British Medical Association says the nation needs another 6,000 consultants. Milburn plans another 1,000 medical school places, plus a recruitment drive abroad to fill the gaps. But staff take years to train. 'The big constraint for us is no longer cash, it's people,' Milburn warns. He says the plan will not shirk the big questions left unanswered by Bevan's vision. 'There are issues no government has had the guts or conviction to address. And yes, there are some difficult issues for us: health and social care, the relations between the NHS and the private sector, the way that doctors are employed. This is the moment when those nettles have to be grasped. Politics is not without risk.' However the Government believes the answers are all out there somewhere. 'Bevan said we had got to take the best in the NHS and make it nationwide, and that crucially is the problem the NHS still has today,' says one government aide. 'Every day, every problem, there is a solution being worked out somewhere in the NHS - but not yet everywhere.' Time will tell if the answer to Dr Timothy's crisis is out there too.

fields.headline: Drip... drip... drip...
fields.standfirst:
Amid the glitz of Okinawa, Tony Blair is enduring his own private torture after a steady leak of memos. He knows somebody is out to get him - but who? Kamal Ahmed reports
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: It must all have seemed a long way from the fear and loathing stalking the corridors of Downing Street. Last night, in the sumptuous surroundings of Shurijo Castle, a fifteenth-century palace near the Busena Terrace beach resort, Tony Blair tucked into a five-course dinner to mark the end of the G8 summit in Okinawa, Japan.
fields.body:
It must all have seemed a long way from the fear and loathing stalking the corridors of Downing Street. Last night, in the sumptuous surroundings of Shurijo Castle, a fifteenth-century palace near the Busena Terrace beach resort, Tony Blair tucked into a five-course dinner to mark the end of the G8 summit in Okinawa, Japan.

Lobster, duck, crab and caviar were followed by dried sea cucumber fried in rice, carp and red potatoes in lightly fried tempura. The evening was rounded off with a palate-cleansing melon and papaya dessert. Chablis Grand Cru, 1995 Vaudesir and 1996 Opus One accompanied the meal.

Blair's mind must have flickered to what awaited him on his return to Britain. No 10 is gripped by one subject: who is the source of the plethora of memos tumbling out of the centre of government, revealing deep-seated worries at the heart of Blair's administration? Who is the disloyal one?

There are two sides now to Blair; the authorised version and the unauthorised version. The public, suddenly, has been given a glimpse of the latter.

In the authorised version, Blair is unconcerned by the fury of critics who say he is weak on crime, on asylum seekers, on the family. The authorised Blair wants to concentrate on education, jobs, the economy. His principles are deep-set and he will continue on course because he understands what is right.

But Blair unauthorised is a different matter. His memo leaked earlier this week, and a linked memo from his close adviser, Philip Gould, betray a mind seized by doubts, a Prime Minister desperately casting around for new ideas, intensely worried about losing his political way, a man who has been told that the New Labour brand has been 'contaminated'.

'There are a clutch of issues that are in fact linked,' the Prime Minister wrote in the memo entitled Touchstone Issues. 'They range from: the family where partly due to MCA [married couple's allowance] and gay issues we are perceived as weak; asylum and crime, where we are perceived as soft; and asserting the nation's interests where, because of the unpopularity of Europe, a constant barrage of small stories beginning to add up on defence and even issues like Zimbabwe, we are seen as insufficiently assertive.

'All these things add up to a sense that the Government - and this even applies to me - are somehow out of touch with gut British instincts.' He called for 'eye-catching initiatives 'that should be 'personally associated' with the Prime Minister. He suggested 'locking up muggers' as a sign of strength. A few weeks after he wrote the memo came Blair's ill-judged plan for on-the-spot fines for criminals. Left-wing MPs have been shocked by the tone of Blair's words, one describing them as 'knee-jerkism gone mad'.

Backbenchers and senior party and government figures told The Observer last week that the memo had achieved three things. It has strengthened the position of Gordon Brown, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, a man seen by backbenchers as principled. He made it clear in an interview with the Today programme that he hadn't read the memo from Gould, who is disliked by many on the left of the party. 'That was a nice touch,' said one backbench MP.

Second, and for similar reasons, it has strengthened John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, and David Blunkett, the education sec retary, who have distanced themselves from Gould's comments. They are now pressing for an end to the New Labour lexicon of soundbites. 'We have to get back to language that people actually understand,' said one Labour source. 'Get away from automaton talk.'

Thirdly, it has damaged Blair in the minds of many within the Labour Party who were shocked that he was able to write a memo which seemed so closely to reflect the views of the Daily Mail. Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, insists that out there, among the general public, they care about jobs and education, not about leaked memos. So why, Blair's critics ask, did he write such a stinging attack on his government's methods?

The first rumbles started on Friday afternoon, nine days ago. The phone rang in the office of Andrew Pierce, the assistant editor of the Times. On the end of the line was someone with some interesting information. It was the Blair memo.

Pierce cancelled his weekend plans and the next day met his contact at a secret location away from Westminster and was handed a brown paper envelope. Inside was Blair's tightly typed missive. Pierce did not even look at it. He took the envelope home and read it. It was dynamite.

On the same day a telephone call was made to Trevor Kavanagh, political editor of the Sun, asking if he would he be interested in a memo from Blair? The question didn't need asking. Never before has a Prime Minister's personal correspondence been leaked. Someone, somewhere, was attempting to destabilise the heart of Government.

As Pierce made his way across London to the Times, Kavanagh set off for the press gallery at the House of Commons. Neither man knew what the other had got. Pierce spoke to Phil Webster, the political editor of the Times who was also at Westminster, along the corridor from Kavanagh.

Kavanagh was told that the Times had the same story and he and Webster agreed to make one call to Campbell. Webster picked up the phone at 3.30pm, Kavanagh standing next to him. Webster gave the details. Campbell listened and said he would need to check. The line went dead. Later that afternoon, Webster's phone rang. It was Campbell. Yes, the memo was from the Prime Minister, he said flatly. The Times and the Sun started making their front pages. The Government's carefully laid plans to announce the comprehensive spending review in a blaze of positive publicity were about to be derailed.

'This has been destabilising, no doubt,' said a senior backbencher. 'It was supposed to be our good news week, but all those issues have been clouded.'

The devastating insight into the thinking of Blair has sparked a round of furious activity at Downing Street. Only four people were on the 'to see' list at the top of the memo: Blair, Campbell, Peter Mandelson and Gordon Brown. Sir Richard Wilson, the permanent secretary to the Cabinet, was asked to undertake a leak inquiry.

Special Branch officers were called in and are expected to start trawling the telephone calls and emails of advisers and officials who may have had access to the memo.

Just as Downing Street was trying to come to terms with the near paralysis caused by a mole at the heart of government, the Gould document appeared. Again, it went to Kavanagh and Pierce. Again, it was written during the late April/early May period when the Government was struggling against poor local election results and the damaging battle for the mayor of London.

Downing Street officials began speculating that News International, which owns both papers, had been handed a job lot of memos which would slowly drip out over the succeeding weeks. The feeling of panic was rising. An NI executive described the theory as 'bollocks'.

Deri Jones, one of the Government's top advisers on electronic security, believes that someone may have hacked into the Government's supposedly secure internet and email system, which connects not only Downing Street and Whitehall but also has links to the homes and offices of Campbell, Gould and members of the Cabinet. A security survey by Jones's company on the state of government anti-hacking measures on the web revealed shocking weaknesses. Some Labour officials are convinced that the documents were passed to the Conservative Party who then handed them out to friendly newspapers. The Tories have refused to be drawn.

Some senior Downing Street figures believe the source of the leak will never be found; some that Gould should take a back seat or use more temperate language. Others feel Greg Cook, the party's highly respected pollster at Millbank, should be given a more central role, or that Gould should be ditched in favour of Bob Worcester, the trusted head of Mori.

Gould has been warned about overblown language before. In 1995 his report The Unfinished Revolution was leaked to the Guardian. In it Gould said that Labour was 'unfit to govern'. It caused a row of such ferocity that Gould thought it could derail the whole New Labour project. Blair rang him and, although supportive of the direction of the memo, said the 'unfit to govern' phrase had been damaging. Could he please calm down a bit? Gould does not seem to have learned his lesson. Critics say he seems too keen on spooking Blair. It seems to have worked.

 AC, DA and GB: How to decode a Labour memo

The latest leaks of memos from the heart of Government are sprinkled with initials which are baffling to the outside world. Here, we give you the cut-out-and-keep-guide to New Labour memo speak and reveal who is really who in Blair's inner circle.

TB: Tony Blair, the Prime Minister.

PM: Peter Mandelson, the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland and head, with GB, of the team planning the general election campaign.

GB: Gordon Brown, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

AC: Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, otherwise known as the second most powerful man in Britain.

DA: Douglas Alexander, the MP for Paisley South and key campaign organiser. Firm ally of Brown.

PH: Peter Hyman, Dowing Street special adviser admired for his ability to inject punchy phrases into speeches. Target of good-natured sarcasm from AC for his inability to get into Downing Street very early. Inventor of the New Labour pledge card. Agrees with PG (see below) that New Labour's brand is damaged. Arsenal supporter.

PG: Philip Gould, memo writer and New Labour worrier. One of the archiects of the Blair project. Trusted adviser leant on heavily by TB. Disliked by Labour rank and file, distrusted by GB.

DM: Dick Morris, former adviser to President Bill Clinton. PG loves DM's books, particularly the New Prince, which says that politicians have to 'win elections every day' not just once a week with big policy announcements.

MCA: Married couple's allowance, tax break repealed by TB, who now thinks it makes him look anti-family.

CF: Charlie Falconer, old friend of TB and his wife Cherie. Seen as the real Cabinet enforcer who has influence across all government departments. TB asks for his advice regularly.

fields.headline: 'Vengeful' military jail Sharif
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pakistan
fields.trailText: Pakistan's  deposed Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, was sentenced to 14 years of 'rigorous imprisonment' yesterday when he was convicted in the first of several corruption trials.
fields.byline: Rory McCarthy in Attock Fort, Pakistan
fields.body:
Pakistan's deposed Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, was sentenced to 14 years of 'rigorous imprisonment' yesterday when he was convicted in the first of several corruption trials.

Sharif, who was overthrown in a coup in October, was also banned from holding public office for 21 years and fined 20 million rupees (£250,000). He is already serving two life terms for hijacking and terrorism in connection with the military takeover, and he condemned the verdict as a personal vendetta led by the military.

Accountability Court judge Farrukh Latif acquitted Saifur Rehman, Sharif's own former anti-corruption chief. Rehman was also acquitted in the hijacking trial earlier this year, but faces other corruption charges.

'There is only one target in this country and that is Nawaz Sharif,' the former Prime Minister said after the brief court hearing in Attock Fort, a military compound.

He was found guilty of failing to pay tax on a £600,000 Russian Mi-8 helicopter which he leased and then bought in October 1993 and used for electioneering.

Sharif already enjoys 'A' class privileges in jail and the balding 50-year-old is likely to be able to avoid hard labour, despite the sentence.

Lawyers for the former Prime Minister boycotted the trial but, after the hearing, Sharif claimed the helicopter had crashed before his tax returns were due and so its cost was not included.

'There was no corruption, no kickbacks, no public funds misappropriated, no embezzlement,' he said. 'But I was expecting this verdict. It has been announced by the judge but of course on behalf of somebody else. There is noth ing worth the name "independent" in this country.'

Sharif has claimed Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, has singled him and his family out for punishment since the coup. Musharraf seized power shortly after Sharif sacked him as army chief.

Farouk Adam Khan, the chief prosecutor, insisted the case had been fair. 'This was a free and fair trial,' he said.

Sharif is already appealing against the two life terms imposed by an anti-terrorism court earlier this year, but the government is also appealing against the sentence, arguing Sharif should face the death penalty instead.

Pakistan's new military regime has pledged to tackle the country's pervasive corruption, with Sharif and his family the main target.

A team from the FBI will arrive in Islamabad next month to help to train the newly established National Accountability Bureau in investigating white-collar crime.

The National Accountability Bureau has broad powers of investigation and arrest and under law is allowed to hold a suspect for 90 days without charge.

The former Prime Minister faces several more corruption cases based on allegations that he stole hundreds of mil lions of pounds during his two terms in power.

Despite being one of Pakistan's richest men, Sharif paid no income tax in the year 1994-9'5, the accountability court heard, because he claimed all his income was from agriculture, which until now has never been taxed in Pakistan.

Last week prosecutors charged him with tax evasion for failing to declare income used to buy and develop his lavish £2.9 million, 100-acre family estate in Raiwind, near Lahore.

The estate was purchased under the name of his mother, Shamim Akther, who together with Sharif's powerful father, Mian Mohammed Sharif, is also named in the charges.

Sharif has also been charged with defaulting on bank loans given to two of his companies. He has been questioned over how he was able to buy four Park Lane apartments, which are registered to two offshore companies in the British Virgin Islands.

Sharif has denied the allegations and insists he is being victimised by the military regime. But he is losing friends fast. Many in his Pakistan Muslim League party and now even his brother Shahbaz, who faces his own corruption cases, say they would rather accommodate with the army than risk confronting it.

The trial was the first civilian case to be heard in the 16th-century Attock Fort, which has been used for at least three military courts- martial for attempted coups.

Khan, the accountability prosecutor-general who led the case against Sharif, was jailed here for 13 months in 1973 for his part in a failed military takeover.

Now the fort, which stands between Islamabad and Peshawar, is the base of the army's elite commando unit, the Special Services Group.

A team from the FBI will arrive in Islamabad next month to help to train the newly established National Accountability Bureau in investigating white-collar crime. The National Accountability Bureau has broad powers of investigation and arrest and under law is allowed to hold a suspect for 90 days without charge. The former Prime Minister faces several more corruption cases based on allegations that he stole hundreds of mil lions of pounds during his two terms in power. Despite being one of Pakistan's richest men, Sharif paid no income tax in the year 1994-9'5, the accountability court heard, because he claimed all his income was from agriculture, which until now has never been taxed in Pakistan. Last week prosecutors charged him with tax evasion for failing to declare income used to buy and develop his lavish £2.9 million, 100-acre family estate in Raiwind, near Lahore. The estate was purchased under the name of his mother, Shamim Akther, who together with Sharif's powerful father, Mian Mohammed Sharif, is also named in the charges. Sharif has also been charged with defaulting on bank loans given to two of his companies. He has been questioned over how he was able to buy four Park Lane apartments, which are registered to two offshore companies in the British Virgin Islands. Sharif has denied the allegations and insists he is being victimised by the military regime. But he is losing friends fast. Many in his Pakistan Muslim League party and now even his brother Shahbaz, who faces his own corruption cases, say they would rather accommodate with the army than risk confronting it. The trial was the first civilian case to be heard in the 16th-century Attock Fort, which has been used for at least three military courts- martial for attempted coups. Khan, the accountability prosecutor-general who led the case against Sharif, was jailed here for 13 months in 1973 for his part in a failed military takeover. Now the fort, which stands between Islamabad and Peshawar, is the base of the army's elite commando unit, the Special Services Group.
fields.bylineHtml: Rory McCarthy in Attock Fort, Pakistan

webTitle: Why everyone wants to be a lesbian

fields.headline: Why everyone wants to be a lesbian
fields.trailText: 'More and more over the past 12 months, I've been finding myself listening to drunk women tell me they're 'so sick' of guys, they're 'seriously considering' becoming lesbians.'
fields.body:
More and more over the past 12 months, I've been finding myself bearing witness to lesbian comings out. Or should I say, listening to drunk women tell me they're 'so sick' of guys, they're 'seriously considering' becoming lesbians.

'Why not? Why not, I ask you?' the latest one cried the other evening. I pointed out that, for one thing, she was straighter than Grandma Walton. My friend sloshed some wine into her glass and glared at me as if to say: 'What's that got to do with it?' This woman is an attractive, intelligent professional in her late thirties. I would wager that, as recently as a couple of years ago, she would no sooner have contemplated a switch to lesbianism than she would have proposed invading Poland. However, there she sat, considering 'Sapphism: The Lifestyle Option' as casually as if she was leafing through a holiday brochure. Sipping her wine, she mused: 'Seriously, what have I got to lose?' Not for the first time, I couldn't help wondering whether she was asking a question or trying to talk herself into it.

Opportunistic lesbianism seems to be on the female brain these days. Crazed by bad relationships, the decision seems to have been taken that men are 'the problem' so it stands to reason that women must be 'the answer'. Just as desperate characters throughout history have come to the end of their rope, so does millennial British womankind seem to be coming to the end of its heterosexuality. We even had our first lesbian sitcom, Rhonda , start last week, though the writer/star Rhonda Cameron, was keen to point out that it is more 'a sitcom featuring a lesbian'.

The self-styled quasi-bi aspirant probably wouldn't notice the difference. To her, lesbianity seems to be less about sexuality than it is about quality control. As in: 'Why keep letting creepy men into my life when I could be with fabulous women?' The rather idealised assumption being that, while straight relationships are a trip to hell and back with dinner thrown in, the lesbian liaison is a stress-free breeze.

Absolute rubbish, of course. I know lesbians who've been horribly hurt by their partners, but straight women don't want to hear that. In fact, they don't seem to want to hear much about the realities of lesbianism. With the opportunistic lesbian, it doesn't seem to be so much about desiring women per se as it is to do with turning away from men. Where sexual orientation is concerned, women seem to have become the floating-voter gender. After all, straight men with broken hearts don't tend to sensationally announce their imminent gayness. In the past, they would join the Foreign Legion; now, if anything, they become even more aggressively heterosexual. It's women who blithely consider swapping teams. 'There is an Ellen Degeneres out there for us all,' the unspoken mantra seems to run.

The Degeneres effect is significant, For all her high-profile lesbianity, Degeneres still manages to come across as the non-threatening sort. If she spent all her time luridly groping Anne Heche's breasts in public, her lesbianity might not be deemed quite so 'heart-warming'. The bottom line is that lesbians are all right, so long as they don't actually have sex. The obvious exception being in porn, where 'lesbians' soaping each other in bathtubs is viewed by most men as being a welcome step forward towards a more civilised and tolerant society (or something). But back in the real world, those straight women who fancy bolting into the dyke enclave generally seem slow to realise that actual fornication is involved.

It's as if these aspirant bisexuals view lesbianism as a platonic, pastel-hued Disney ride, where all they have to do to qualify is hold hands, be 'empathetic' and snarl about men. It reminds you of those Soviet ballerinas from the 70s who defected to the West, not because they loved it, but because they were sick to death of privation behind the Iron Curtain. Bearing this in mind, the obvious losers are proper lesbians. Straight women seem to take it for granted that they'd be welcomed with open arms, but does the lesbian community really need an influx of disaffected heterosexuals who've run screaming from sex and spend the whole time whingeing about ex-boyfriends?

To me, that's as odd as a gay guy propositioning a straight woman with the line: 'Hampstead Heath's not the same any more - how about it?' Just as lesbianity isn't a sexy sideshow dreamt up for men's benefit, nor is it some kind of safety net for straight women when hetero-romance goes awry. While it is good that shows such as Ellen and Rhonda establish that gay people have lives beyond their sexuality, it shouldn't be forgotten that sexuality exists. Nor should us straights give up on ourselves so easily. Men and women might constantly disappoint each other and women might occasionally daydream that there's something to be gained from changing teams, but there isn't, really. In heterosexuality, as in homosexuality, you can run but you can't hide.
