fields.headline: Making an entrance
fields.trailText: 'My wife is off to the dentist's to have herself measured up for new gums with the money I've scraped together for my tax bill.'
fields.body:
My wife is off to the dentist's to have herself measured up for new gums with the money I've scraped together for my tax bill, and God knows I'm not one to begrudge a close relative by marriage the full panoply of emergency orthodontic treatment that could have waited until perhaps next year, but I can't help thinking that if we are to reprioritise our finances in so highhanded a fashion perhaps I might reintroduce the notion of investing in a decent widescreen TV in time for the Olympics? As I remind her, the long jump isn't getting any shorter.

'Bye,' she says, driving off and leaving me with nothing but the three-year-old and a pile of ironing to amuse myself with. So I put the little chap in front of a double bill of Teletubbies and The Tweenies, but I've barely had a cup of tea and done the crossword and worked out how to erect the ironing board than he's hugging me round the legs and wanting his red car from the shed. Anything to stop him frothing at the mouth. But we're having so much fun, me pushing him up the hill for days on end, that by the time my wife gets home holding her jaw, it's not just the laughing gas talking when she marvels at how much progress I haven't made and wonders whether she must do everything herself!

Do everything herself? I suppose it was the good fairy yesterday who shut the windows when it started raining and she was out gallivanting at a parents' evening?

Still, not to be churlish and in the spirit of being a fully functioning perfect husband I volunteer to drive up to the salvage reclamation yard near Cambridge to look for something woody and characterful to replace our hideous double-glazed front entrance, which makes the house look like a bedsit-letting agency to such an extent that a woman walked in unannounced last week and deposited two suitcases in the hall. ('Er... can I help you?' asked my wife, who is hospitality personified but draws the line at allowing people to move in with us.) It all turned out to be a silly misunderstanding. The woman merely thought we were the guest cloakroom for the house next door. How we laughed!

Anyway, it takes me ages to find this place, which is like one of those mirages that you can see from the M11 but when you get there it's turned into a pig farm.

But at last I notice the big sign telling me what a fool I am, and sure enough just around the corner is a huge compound full of statues, which looks like a graveyard except that instead of angels with harps they've got Greek-buttocked discus throwers and goddesses of fertility discovering how difficult it is to carry a water urn and keep your breasts inside your nightie at the same time. Fantastic.

There's a six-ton rhinoceros and a lifesize Apache on a horse in bronze that would look rather grand in the hall providing we removed the ceiling and front bedrooms and made the children sleep outside, though no doubt we'd then have parties of guests wandering in from next door assuming we were the Centre for Native American Studies (East Herts branch).

Still, plenty of old railings, chimney pots, railway sleepers. Cow trough for the garden, sir? Nice millstone? Got one, thanks. (Unworthy joke.) I must admit I am tempted by a scary Medusa's head that you can hang on your bedroom door with a view to having a sex life that doesn't involve the children watching.

But what about doors? Well, they do have some nice ones but I'm not sure stained-glass ex-cathedral jobs are entirely architecturally consonant with a 50s semi, and where would we put the doorbell?

My wife is still cross when I finally get home via the instructions of a succession of petrol station managers who send me zigzagging between two counties in search of a motorway, but luckily this is because she has just got back from her weekly appointment with the Halifax Timewasting Society, which didn't get to be the biggest bank in the world by knowing how to set up a savings account without the involvement of someone who has got stuck in the traffic or how to transfer urgent teeth funds when the computer doesn't recognise our address even though they own the bloody house. 'They're so stupid ,' she says.

'Soothing anaesthetic?' I suggest.

She sighs. 'You pour.'

webTitle: Suburban cigarette gang raised cash for Hizbollah

fields.headline: Suburban cigarette gang raised cash for Hizbollah
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Early  on Friday morning, George Levkulich of Charlotte, North Carolina was woken by shouting and the slamming of car doors.
fields.body:
Early on Friday morning, George Levkulich of Charlotte, North Carolina was woken by shouting and the slamming of car doors.

Looking out on to the broad, suburban street, he was then astonished to see more than 200 federal agents surrounding the home of his neighbour, a Lebanese painter and decorator called Mohammed Darwishe.

Darwishe was, the FBI told him, a leader of a fund-raising cell for Hizbollah, one of the most feared terrorist organisations in the world. Law enforcement agencies eventually arrested a total of 18 people in the sleepy southern American town.

It is alleged that all were involved in a multi-million dollar cigarette smuggling ring. Funds either went direct to Lebanon-based Hizbollah, or were used to buy hi-tech equipment, such as global positioning systems, night vision equipment and digital cameras, which were then sent to the Middle East.

US security sources say that the Charlotte cell was founded as a benign, if pro-Hizbollah, discussion group. However, it soon developed into a far more threatening active unit.

The cell met every week to plan their operations - usually in the house of de facto leader Muhammad Youssef Hammoud and meetings involved a reading from the speeches of Ayatollah Khomeini which Hammoud downloaded from hardline Islamic websites on the Internet.

Almost all those arrested are from the south Lebanon area and some charges relate to the false marriages which the group allegedly used to get into the US.

None of the suspects has been charged with any terrorist activities, though Hammoud is said to have received military training from Hizbollah.

According to the FBI, an informant had said that Hammoud 'would not hesitate' to carry out a terrorist act if ordered to do so. Another man has been charged with helping to purchase technical equipment for Hizbollah.

Others face trial for aiding a terrorist organisation, and for immigration fraud, money laundering and racketeering. Information on the suspects appears to have come from five informers who infiltrated the cell during a three-year FBI operation, codenamed 'Smokescreen'.

First, Hammoud and his colleagues set up a series of tobacco businesses. They used these as fronts for smuggling large quantities of cigarettes from North Carolina, where the tax is 5 cents a pack, to the northern state of Michigan, where it is 75 cents a pack. The difference in price, officials said, could result in a profit of $3,000 (£2,000) on every truckload.

A surveillance operation was launched after West Virginia State Police stopped Hammoud for speeding and found $46,000 (£30,000) in his vehicle. Two months later, he was spotted unloading large quantities of cigarettes from a lorry. It took three years to gather enough evidence to launch last week's raids.

According to law enforcement experts, cigarette smuggling - a major problem in the USA - is a favourite of Russian and Asian organised crime groups.

Aside from the tobacco business, the Charlotte group is alleged to have invested much of the proceeds in a Lebanese restaurant and delicatessen. Darwishe, who the FBI said was the brother of a 'well-known Hizbollah fighter' in Lebanon, was in charge of sending any money raised to the organisation.

Hizbollah (the Party of God) is backed by Syria and Iran and was a thorn in the side of Israeli forces in southern Lebanon, being largely responsible for forcing their withdrawal after 18 years earlier this summer.

The US designated Hizbollah a 'terrorist organisation' after linking it to the bombing that killed 241 US marines in Beirut in 1983 and the kidnapping of Western hostages in Lebanon.

Israel has long urged the US to crack down on cells that it says are funnelling money to the organisation.

But supporters of Hizbollah say that, like many Islamic organisations, its funds are used for social welfare projects and do not fund terrorism.

The FBI's primary target is Osama bin Laden, the shadowy Saudi dissident based in Afghanistan, who is thought to have been behind the bombings of two American embassies in east Africa in 1998 and other attacks.

But US authorities have been accused of exaggerating the threat posed by hardline groups. Last year officials warned of massive bombs planned for the dawn of the millennium. In the event there were none.

For many in Charlotte this weekend, the idea that their neighbours were highly-motivated terrorist sympathisers dedicated to Holy War is a little hard to believe.

'He was a nice guy, a regular guy,' Levkulich said of his neighbour. 'He helped me with a water pipe once.'

fields.headline: Defying the conventions
fields.standfirst:
American television networks are bored with the presidential hoopla, reports Felicity Spector
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: American television networks are bored with the presidential hoopla, reports Felicity Spector
fields.body:
Hoopla, excitement, passion and intrigue - packed into a few days every four years. In the old days, when America's Democrats and Republicans gathered at their conventions to vote on their platform and choose their presidential nominee, tens of millions of viewers were glued to their television sets.

'There are not many things we do together as a nation besides choosing a president,' says Maxine Isaacs, who ran Walter Mondale's campaign back in 1984. 'It is a vital shared experience.'

In fact, the national political organisations barely exist outside these carnival-like occasions: 'They are the virtual party, made flesh and blood,' says Michael Waldman, who served as Bill Clinton's chief speechwriter for five years.

Traditionally, the conventions are one of the few peaks in America's seemingly endless presidential campaigns, when millions of voters sit up and take notice for the first time. They provide a chance to find out what the parties are all about, who the candidates are and what they have to say. By this stage in the calendar, barely a third of people have already made up their minds which way to vote. This is why the candidates always used to view their set-piece speeches as a vital chance to communicate directly with party activists and the public at large.

TV networks also made their reputations at these events, sending rising stars to hobnob with the rich and powerful. Channels competed to provide the biggest on-site studio, called a skybox, complete with giant neon logos.

But if voters try searching for serious coverage of this year's political jamborees, they'll be lucky to catch more than a few edited highlights. The US media has fallen deeply out of love with politics in general, claiming that it has degenerated into a series of choreographed events devoid of any real substance. The conventions are now simply giant photo-opportunities, with delegates dressed in silly hats and waving homemade signs for the cameras.

Anything controversial runs at an anti-social hour when no one will be tuned in. Serious speeches have been replaced by Hollywood-style films about the candidates' lives, and vapid gushing by film stars and assorted celebs.

Indeed, last time round, in 1996, one of America's most famous TV anchors, Ted Koppel, declared himself so bored by the Republicans' event that he simply walked out half way through, muttering: 'Nothing surprising has happened, nothing surprising is expected.'

All the press wants is a bit of old fashioned drama and conflict - which of course is anathema to party spin doctors desperate to present a perfect picture of unity and strength.

So this is why, in 2000, despite years of planning at a cost of millions of dollars, the networks are barely bothering to turn up. Now, even keynote speeches take second place to football games in the battle for ratings, and the parties must fight for precious minutes of prime time.

To political insiders, the media's attitude is arrogance in the extreme: 'Given how little coverage of politics and issues there is, it's surely not the end of the world for the parties to get some airtime for four days every four years,' says Waldman. 'The networks have an obligation to the public,' insists Isaacs. 'They should do their civic duty and stop complaining.'

The answer may lie in new technology and the media of the future. The networks no longer have a monopoly over the viewing habits of the US: indeed, what with cable, satellite and, now, online interactive channels, the ratings of the Big Four are deep in the doldrums. News coverage is largely confined to real-life crime and entertainment reportage, and, in the era of the 'shrinking sound-bite', politicians get an average of six seconds to say their piece.

So all-news stations such as CNN, are rushing in to fill the gap. 'We are determined to be the network of record for Campaign 2000' is CNN's proud claim: it plans to send 35 senior reporters and presenters to the conventions, hiring skyboxes galore at each event.

fields.headline: Flying fortresses under fire
fields.standfirst:
As the civil and military aviation giants gather at Farnborough, the stakes have never been higher. Joanna Walters and Oliver Morgan report
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: As the civil and military aviation giants gather at Farnborough, the stakes have never been higher. Joanna Walters and Oliver Morgan report
fields.body:
The staged row that traditionally breaks out at airshows between Boeing and Airbus about whose planes are better and who sells more of them will have a keener edge than usual this year.

There is nothing like a new invention to add some sizzle to the proceedings. The invention in question is the A3XX 'superjumbo' under development by Europe's Airbus. At its most packed, with sardine-style economy seating throughout, this giant of the skies will be able to carry 900 people. Even carrying the average number of travellers, 550 in various classes, the aircraft leapfrogs Boeing's 400-seat 747, which has ruled the world for 30 years.

Airbus forecasts that demand from the world's airlines will be in the order of 1,200 such aircraft in the two decades following its expected launch, in 2005. Observers estimate that at a development cost of £8 billion and a price tag for airlines of £132 million per plane, Airbus will have to sell at least 350 of these leviathans. Anything less will spell financial disaster for the plane-maker.

Ian Wild, airline analyst with stockbroker Societe Generale, said: 'Will you find enough airlines stupid enough to go and buy a thing like that?' He believes the answer is yes. If the world's airlines keep up their long record of ordering too many planes, especially too many large ones, and then slashing prices to fill them, they will queue up for the A3XX.

This is great news for consumers, because this sort of behaviour helps bring air travel to the mass market at affordable prices, and keeps world passenger numbers growing at 5 per cent a year. But Wild says it may not be the answer for airlines' profit margins as they try to woo lucrative business travellers. Busy executives want, and are prepared to pay higher fares, for smaller jets that load and unload quickly and fly more frequently, not a behemoth leaving once a day.

Yet if the A3XX takes off, it could be Airbus's ticket to global market leadership in civil aerospace in the future - a crushing victory for European over American ingenu ity. Airbus took 55 per cent of the orders placed last year by the world's airlines, but measured in value and in terms of total aircraft in service worldwide, Boeing has always been way ahead.

The A3XX has been talked about for years as anything from a drawing board joke to Airbus's future golden goose. Now the consortium has finally decided to build it and is likely this week to unveil some 'launch customer' airlines which have signed up to buy it, giving the project a vital credibility boost. Airlines showing an initial interest include Middle Eastern carrier Emirates, Singapore Airlines, Qantas of Australia, the UK's Virgin and US leasing giant ILFC.

Boeing's mission at Farnborough will be to scoff as loudly as possible at A3XX and claim it will be a flying white elephant that will squash Airbus flat when, commercially, the project falls out of the sky. It will also repeat and amplify its customary threat to sue Airbus for allegedly breaking international trade laws by taking preferential loans from partner governments to help develop the new aircraft.

The mighty double-deck A3XX project is expected to cost between £8bn and £10bn, depending on how many versions Airbus builds. The UK has already pledged £500m of repayable launch aid to BAE Systems, which owns 20 per cent of Airbus and makes the wings for the aircraft. France, Germany and Spain, whose champion aerospace companies last year formed the European Aeronautic Defence and Space company (EADS) which now makes up the rest of the consortium, are also expected to stump up a total state loan package of around £2.6bn.

Chris Paxton, senior aerospace consultant with A T Kearney, says the world took a leap of faith in the late Sixties when Boeing unveiled the 747. Many thought it would be a failure but it has feathered Boeing's nest for 30 years. Now a similar extension of the imagination is required for the A3XX. And Paxton thinks Boeing, for all its bluff, probably has a new giant aircraft of its own up its sleeve. Once it has let the A3XX test the market, it will unveil it in a late bid to get back on top.

Boeing is planning a 'stretch' version of the 747, but many observers believe that it also has a whole new A3XX-beater in a secret design bureau somewhere in its Seattle headquarters. 'Boeing will want to stay on top, but will let Airbus take the early risks,' says Paxton.

The tension between the US and European defence and aerospace industries is not limited to civil aviation. Although the A3XX is likely to dominate the headlines at Farnborough, defence will raise equally fraught questions behind the scenes.

The overdue consolidation of European aerospace and defence, which took its first step with the formation of EADS , has huge ramifications on both sides of the Atlantic. At the centre stands BAE, whose head John Weston is having to tread with exceeding care in Washington and in European capitals.

At Farnborough last year Europe's consolidation was only half played out. At that stage the then British Aerospace had recently jilted its assumed German partner DaimlerChrysler Aerospace (DASA) by merging instead with GEC Marconi.

In doing so BAE combined its airframe building expertise with electronics operations to create a £12bn aerospace-defence colossus.

DASA was not amused - its head, Jurgen Schrempp, was livid with Weston. His counter stroke came several months later with the formation of the £9.6 bn EADS. At a stroke this created a combine with a turnover of 22.5bn euros, leapfrogging BAE to third spot behind US giants Boeing and Lockheed Martin.

The game, however, was not over. The key for BAE was to capitalise on its tricky position at the crossroads of US and European defence procurement. The US wants to forge transatlantic links.

BAE has several advantages. First, and most important, it is British. Historically close Anglo-American relations were strengthened in February when Defence Secretary Geoff Hoon and his US opposite number William Cohen signed a co-operation agreement.

EADS is less likely to gain access to the vast $48bn US defence procurement budget and benefit from development projects coming from the $44bn spent on R&D (the rest of Nato spends $8.9 bn). US-French relations are not close.

Second, in acquiring Marconi, BAE gained the US Tracor avionics business, and Marconi North America, giving it a $2.5bn turnover toehold from which to start.

BAE launched itself into the major league earlier this month by completing a £1.1bn acquisition of the Lockheed Martin aerospace electronics business Sanders, making it the largest defence contractor in the world - ahead of US giants Lockheed, Boeing and Raytheon. Weston said the US now represented 25 per cent of the group's turnover and gave it the lead in 'information dominance', adding that BAE's success in the Sanders deal was 'an expression of confidence that the UK is a US ally'.

Salomon Smith Barney analyst Nick Cunningham says: 'I am surprised that BAE was allowed to buy this - although regulators still have to approve the deal. It gives a very strong role in the US to BAE, but it shows that the US is as good as its word when it talks of transatlantic defence co-operation.'

The question, in Cunningham's mind, however, is whether the move will allow BAE to become a US prime contractor.

Andrew Brookes of the International Institute for Strategic Studies is doubtful. For example, the US government is currently deciding between Boeing and Lockheed Martin on the Joint Strike Aircraft - a navy/airforce plane. He says future projects such as the F22 fighter will be similar, although BAE will be involved at second-tier level.

Importantly, its business will focus on the higher value elements of manufacture, but it will never be rolling planes off production lines in the US, he says.

While looking to the US, BAE has to keep one eye on Europe, EADS and Airbus. In doing so, it has had to fight ferociously with the US to win European orders.

The latest example was the duel with Raytheon over a £1bn RAF contract for a Beyond Visual Range Air to Air Missile (BVRAAM), which it won as part of the European Meteor Consortium, comprising the Anglo-French-Italian Matra BAE Dynamics.

At the same time Airbus's A400 transport aircraft beat Boeing's C17 - although C17s will be leased until A400s are built.

Raytheon, and the US government, were less than pleased - Bill Clinton himself wrote at least three times to Tony Blair in an attempt to secure the order for the US.

But the decision helped with a Blair priority - using defence policy as a means of putting the UK at the heart of Europe.

Interestingly, Raytheon says the BVRAAM bidding is likely to increase transatlantic co-operation. Raytheon director Andy Head says: 'We are moving away from fortress Europe and Fortress US. We made it clear to an unprecedented extent during the bidding process that we were willing to co-operate if we won the deal. And the UK could be the stepping stone.'

Nevertheless, analysts say BAE is unlikely to win missile orders in the US because of the French role in the European Matra BAE Dynamics missile consortium behind Meteor - despite protestations that impenetrable Chinese walls can be constructed.

BAE's expertise is likely to make sure it remains an integral part of the European defence scene; EADS centres on civil activities.

But there is a coda. French assets, including family-owned Dassault, in which EADS has a 46 per cent interest, and Thompson CSF - partly state owned, partly held by Alcatel and partly floated - have been missed in the grand consolidation. BAE is unlikely to get them, but if EADS does, the European pattern will change yet again.

webTitle: Not time yet to go back into Japan

fields.headline: Not time yet to go back into Japan
fields.trailText: It was Japan's biggest-ever corporate bankruptcy. Sogo, the department store chain, collapsed earlier this month with debts of almost £12.4bn. So why were Japanese shoppers and investors both cheering?
fields.body:
It was Japan's biggest-ever corporate bankruptcy - and it would have broken a few records here, too. Sogo, the department store chain, collapsed earlier this month with debts of almost ¥2,000 billion (£12.4bn). So why were Japanese shoppers and investors both cheering?

They were happy because, after much deliberation, the government had allowed Sogo to fail. That pleased the Japanese, who have seen the government waste too much money propping up crippled businesses. And it gave another jolt to the agonisingly slow process of corporate restructuring. That pleased investors, who were worried that paternalism and protectionism could be making a real comeback.

The news is not unequivocally good, however. Sogo's collapse may accelerate the pace of restructuring in other parts of Japan's stricken economy; another large company, hotel group Seiyo, collapsed last week. And, while Sogo may survive without too many job losses - other parts of Japanese industry may be less lucky. The construction industry, for example, is burdened by huge debts and over-capacity. Failures there could have a domino effect and significantly increase unemployment.

But the restructuring is desperately needed. Many Japanese companies are still laden with debts from the 1980s, limiting their scope to invest and expand. They are being kept afloat by hope and zero interest rates, introduced as an emergency measure almost 18 months ago. But the government is giving clear warnings that rates will go up next month.

Analysts are divided about whether that is a good thing. Some warn that it could ruin hundreds of small and medium-sized companies and have a devastating effect on confidence.

Others, however, say a rates rise could boost confidence by suggesting that recovery is on the way. Certainly, the zero interest-rate policy has not succeeded in persuading the Japanese to spend. They might, however, be persuaded to part with a little bit of interest on their savings.

Alistair Way, from the Japanese desk of fund managers Baillie Gifford, errs on the optimistic side, saying higher interest rates could accelerate restructuring, for the medium-term benefit of the economy. The markets remain unconvinced. A recovery at the start of the year petered out as foreign investors started selling - partly because of US selling of technology stocks. Bulls, like Peter Oppenheimer, global strategist at HSBC, think that is now slowing and that there are signs of strong growth in corporate earnings. He thinks the Japanese market could rise 15 per cent in the rest of this year.

Others, like Baillie Gifford, are waiting for signs of stronger leadership. Cautious investors should heed this warning and stay out of the market until there are clear signs of an upward trend.

fields.headline: Private affluence, public money
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's Comprehensive Spending Review (CSR) is, superficially, something of an anti-climax. Its main contents - the vast increases in spending on health and education - were conceived and leaked in panic at the time of the Budget in March. Since then a government that has no skilled plumbers left has leaked, leaked and leaked again the fact that it was planning to spend an extra £40 billion a year on public services, transport and assorted other items of public expenditure.

Gordon Brown's Comprehensive Spending Review (CSR) is, superficially, something of an anti-climax. Its main contents - the vast increases in spending on health and education - were conceived and leaked in panic at the time of the Budget in March. Since then a government that has no skilled plumbers left has leaked, leaked and leaked again the fact that it was planning to spend an extra £40 billion a year on public services, transport and assorted other items of public expenditure.

True there has been the usual infighting in Whitehall over marginal extra allocations of expenditure. True, also, there have been further budgetary improvements since March in revenues from higher oil prices and lower-than-expected unemployment. Thus, in later outpourings from the Government's non-plumbing department, the leaks became £43bn.

But the big figures seem to have produced a big yawn in a public fed up with leaks and talk - a public that would quite like results.

Yet the Comprehensive Spending Review is a fascinating event. In macro-economic terms it is both pre-Keynesian and (I confess I normally have an aversion to 'post' phrases) post-Keynesian.

It is pre-Keynesian because, almost like an inter-war chancellor under the iron grip of Montagu Norman (only in this instance it was his own personal grip) Brown felt the money had to be earned before it could be spent. The credit and borrowing mechanism may lie at the heart of the modern capitalist economy, but for Honest Gordon it was to be Prudence first and Purpose later.

True, the Government made a dog's breakfast of welfare reform, so the way in which it was prudent had to be adapted as it went along. It then turned to means-testing in a big way - something that sounded alarm bells in Old Labour England and, when it comes to things like widows' pensions, may yet worry Middle England - or, more to the point perhaps, Lower Middle England.

But the principal reason for the Treasury's finances continuing to improve (because, let's face it: the improvement began under Norman Lamont and continued under Kenneth Clarke's admirable growth policies) has been the buoyancy of the economy. Some serious long-term 'structural' reforms may or may not have taken place - one never quite knows until years later, as Lord Lawson will testify - but the economic cycle has performed wonders for the Budgetary position.

So the Chancellor can happily boast that unemployment, social security and debt interest now account collectively for 17 per cent of public spending, as opposed to 42 per cent a few years ago. A government that said it did not believe in 'tax and spend' has raised the revenue in various ways, and is now happily embarking on the 'spend'.

Which brings us to the post-Keynesian nature of the Comprehensive Spending Review. As was clear in the Financial Statement that accompanied the Budget, the Chancellor was planning to raise public spending by a cumulative £40bn a year over three years. Extra revenues made this £43bn. The indispensably independent Insti tute for Fiscal Studies estimates that public spending will in fact be £50bn a year higher at the end of the period.

These are truly amazing figures. It is the biggest 'Keynesian' injection into a European economy since the reunification of Germany after 1989, and possibly since the Marshall Plan of the late Forties.

A Treasury that says it no longer believes in short-term demand management - ex cept via the Bank of England's alterations in the interest rate - is planning to inject up to the equivalent of 5 per cent of gross domestic product a year into the economy over the medium term.

It is obvious that such an ambitious strategy is needed to redress the extraordinary imbalance in this country between those old Galbraithian friends, private affluence and public squalor.

But when you also think of the strategic need for the pound to come down to save large sectors of manufacturing from bankruptcy, and therefore the need to divert resources into exports, the implications for consumers - for which read electors - ought to be clear: consumption cannot continue apace in an economy which, until very recently, the Monetary Policy Committee feared was overheating.

Of course, the real spending does not get under way until next year - widely assumed to be election year. There is quite a debate going on inside the MPC about the likely course of the economy and of interest rates between now and then. But we may find that this sequence of pre- and post-Keynesianism pro duces some interesting results. I have no doubt that, having - unnecessarily, in my opinion - been seriously frugal with the nation's finances until now, the Chancellor would be dourly happy to see the MPC impose a period of austerity on the consumer, in order to do something about public squalor - but not until after the election.

The fundamental problem is that British economic policy continues to be prone to dogmatic lurches: lean years for the public sector are to be followed by fat years, and a lot of damage has been inflicted on the way.

Indeed, public spending has been so depressed that, even with the planned spree, it will be nothing like as high a proportion of gross national product as it was under past Conservative governments, let alone in most Continental countries. It will nevertheless be quite a lurch - and quite a spree.

In effect, last week's public spending announcement constitutes some 75 per cent of Labour's next manifesto. Amazingly, it is a whole Parliament later than was expected when this strange animal called New Labour was elected in 1997.

webTitle: Keep taking our tablets (no one else's)

fields.headline: Keep taking our tablets (no one else's)
fields.standfirst: The WTO's response to Africa's Aids crisis is a chilling reminder of where power lies in the global economy
fields.trailText: The WTO's response to Africa's Aids crisis is a chilling reminder of where power lies in the global economy
fields.body:
It would give me great pleasure to report, as did the New York Times this week, that Bill Clinton has saved Africa. That big-hearted lug will lend African nations $1billion a year for Aids drugs which - more joy! - the pharmaceutical companies have agreed to just give away at 75 per cent off list price. But just when I thought I could announce Christmas in July, The Observer came into possession of a 12-page document from Argentina.

It appears to have originated in the Office of the United States Trade Representative in Geneva (which does not deny the document's authenticity). The official missive threatens Argentina for opening its borders to the drugs trade - not the fun stuff, but sales of legal, licensed medicines. If Argentina does not end its commitment to free cross-border trade in pharmaceuticals, said the Trade Rep, America would keep the nation on the Section 301 Watch List - a kind of Death Row for trading partners.

If you read the gospels of globalisation apostles Paul Krugman or Thomas Friedman, you could get the impression that the World Trade Organisation is all about ending tariffs and trade barriers. Only in your dreams.

In the real world, the WTO is the mechanism for privatising the tariff system. Once, countries protected their workers and local industry behind taxes at national borders. In the New World Trade Order, global corpora tions may demand levies against nations that sell or buy products outside the zones they have marked out by brand names and market segments. The WTO's penal system for prohibited importing and exporting goes under the psychedelic title Trips (for Trade-related Intellectual Property Rights).

Trip-ping, Argentina and Africa - it all fits together. The story begins with this un-fun fact: one in four people in black Africa is going to die of Aids unless medicine arrives now. Luckily, Brazil, India and, most aggressively, Argentina, can make the drugs dirt-cheap and ship them to the dying. But US, British and Swiss pharmaceuticals giants howled out loud about the proposed cross-shipments.

The US trade cops, led by Vice-President Al Gore, backed Big Pharma and halted the life-saving plan - Nelson Mandela's pleas, Nobel Prize and flowered shirts notwithstanding.

Unfortunately for Gore the presidential candidate, his let-them-eat-aspirin policies resulted in his every campaign stop attracting packs of enraged homosexuals who hollered about his killing more Africans than Michael Caine in Zulu. This did not make for good TV for Al. So his good buddy President Bill found a few billion to quell the restless natives.

However, the billions come with strings attached or, more accurately, chains and manacles. South Africa must buy 100 per cent of the medicine from the USA and pay back all the cash at 'commercial interest rates'.

The US Trade Rep's billet-doux to Argentina is the supply side of this scheme to stop South Africa breaking the de facto embargo on free trade in pharmaceuticals. South Africa hoped to use a loophole in Trips that permits the import of patent drugs in extreme emergencies, even without the patent-holder's approval.

Initially, the US retaliated against South Africa by taxing some of its imports to the US - until the anti-Gore demos. The Trade Rep document suggests that the Clinton Administration will re-aim the sanctions missiles at Argentina, thereby avoiding the impolitic Mandela imagery while cutting off South Africa's supply at source.

After an expected WTO show trial, Argentina's economy will be hung from a pole in Geneva as an example for India and Brazil, other potential exporters.

Maybe I'm not being fair. After all, Trips seeks to protect and compensate manufacturers for their risky investments and inventiveness in creating medicines such as AZT, Glaxo-Wellcome's anti-Aids drug.

Glaxo was inventive, all right, but not in discovering AZT. A Professor Jerome Horowitz synthesised the drug in 1964, under a grant from the US government's National Institutes of Health (NIH). A Glaxo unit bought the formula to use on pet cats.

In 1984, an NIH lab discovered the HIV virus. The government lab urgently asked drugmakers to send samples of every anti-retrovirus drug on their shelves. NIH spent millions inventing a method to test these compounds. When the tests showed AZT killed the virus, the government asked Glaxo, as the compound's owner, to conduct lab tests.

Glaxo refused. You can't blame it. HIV could contaminate labs, even kill researchers. So NIH's Dr Hiroaki Mitsuya, combining brilliance, bravery and loads of public cash, performed the difficult proofs on live virus. In February 1985, NIH told Glaxo the good news and asked the company to conduct human trials.

Glaxo refused again. Here's where Glaxo got inventive. Within days of the notice, the company filed a patent in Britain for its 'discovery'. Glaxo failed to mention the US government work.

But Glaxo has a heart. The Anglo-American behemoth announced it would sell South Africa an AZT-based drug for only $2 a day per patient, more than 75 per cent off the price charged in the America and Europe. I called Glaxo USA to say thanks but, after a few questions, it became clear that the $2 price merely matched the Brazilian/Argentine prices.

Think about that. If $2 is the free-market price, Europeans and Americans pay 400 per cent over the odds, price discrimination explicitly protected by Trips.

That's the funny thing about the WTO's expansion of so-called intellectual property rights. It is sold in the West on the slick line that those people, the dark, unindustrious tribes of the southern hemisphere, are trying to steal our inventions.

In fact, says expert Jamie Love of the Consumer Project on Technology in Washington, patients in the West have as much to lose as Africans under the new regime of thought ownership.

This came to Love graphically when Maude Jones, a 30-year-old London woman, called him begging help to obtain Taxol. The drug could have controlled her breast cancer, but her NHS region did not prescribe it because of its stratospheric cost.

There is no patent on Taxol. The US government discovered it. But Bristol-Myers Squibb, because it performed minor work calculating dosage levels, holds the intellectual property rights on dose-related data, even though the data was originally collected by govern ment. Under Britain's data protection laws this gave Bristol-Myers Squibb lock-up control on Taxol in the UK for 10 years even without a patent.

Bristol-Myers Squibb takes no chances with its cancer monopoly. Taxol comes from the yew tree. While Western drug companies have long argued that rainforest trees and plants are theirs for the taking without paying royalties, Bristol-Myers Squibb obtained from Congress the exclusive right to harvest yew trees on US government lands, about the only place it grows on the planet. For these public assets the company paid nothing.

But Ms Jones paid. Ultimately, the company was shamed into offering her the medicine for free, if she moved to America. However, doctors concluded the offer was probably too late. As her family already faced bankruptcy, Maude (not her real name) phoned Love to say she had chosen to die.

From her death, Love hoped South Africans, Americans and Europeans would discover 'a helpful solidarity'. In Aids and breast cancer, the stricken North and South share a horrific commonality as the new landless peasantry in the apartheid of intellectual property rights.

webTitle: BA will back open skies on KLM deal

fields.headline: BA will back open skies on KLM deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: British Airways is expected to support an open-skies deal between the UK and the US if its takeover of Dutch carrier KLM goes ahead this summer.
fields.body:
British Airways is expected to support an open-skies deal between the UK and the US if its takeover of Dutch carrier KLM goes ahead this summer.

The US government last week demanded open skies as a condition of any such takeover. This would allow unlimited access to London's Heathrow Airport for American airlines, and give UK carriers access to any US city.

Sources close to BA hinted to The Observer this weekend that if it decides in the next fortnight to extend its initial discussions with KLM to fullblown takeover talks, it will tell Whitehall officials it is in favour of signing up to open skies.

City observers believe that opinion is currently divided within BA about KLM. Some senior executives close to the negotiations think a deal should be tied up quickly because the airline missed an opportunity when it failed to merge with the Dutch carrier in the early Nineties.

Others think that BA risks jeopardising its business by acquiring KLM's loss-making European services and its bloated workforce, and also that a deal would face potentially prohibitive regulatory hurdles.

'KLM is very keen and talking up the deal. But there is genuinely an open mind at the top of BA, and this could go either way,' one analyst said this weekend.

BA is likely to decide in early August whether to walk away or continue talking. If it presses on with negotiations, senior executives are likely to indicate to Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott that it will not object if the Government concedes open skies to the Americans.

A source close to the airline said: 'We can conceive of it. It would be quite a relief in many ways - it has gone on for so long. It has to happen some time, and it would be nice to clear it out of the way and get on with the business of facing the competition.'

The UK and US are closer than they have been for 10 years to signing a deal to liberalise the heavily restricted transatlantic market. Prescott and US transport secretary Rodney Slater are keen to sign a deal before the Clinton administration comes to an end this November. Talks between the two sides resume in September.

webTitle: Any fool can create their own e-commerce site. Many do so

fields.headline: Any fool can create their own e-commerce site. Many do so
fields.trailText: Scenes from e-commercial life: One: my teenage son needs a new watch. He has set his heart on something called a Casio G-shock, a hideous contraption the size of a three-pin plug. I send him downtown to check the price. It's about £80. 'Too much,' I protest, 'far too much.' We reach a deal: if he can find a G-shock timepiece significantly cheaper on the Web, I'll buy it.
fields.body:
Scenes from e-commercial life: One: my teenage son needs a new watch. He has set his heart on something called a Casio G-shock, a hideous contraption the size of a three-pin plug. I send him downtown to check the price. It's about £80. 'Too much,' I protest, 'far too much.' We reach a deal: if he can find a G-shock timepiece significantly cheaper on the Web, I'll buy it.

After a few minutes' research he suggests www.letsbuyit.com a reverse auction site which enables buyers to band together to get group discounts. In the end, we buy the watch for something like £44. Delivery is promised within 10 days. I am sceptical, but on the tenth day the parcel arrives and my son berates me for my lack of faith in technology.

Two days later another G-shock watch arrives. My credit card account, however, has not been debited for it. I send an email to letsbuyit.com but receive no reply. Eventually I get a phone call from an embarrassed young woman who arranges for a courier to pick up the surplus timepiece. I spend some time calculating how much her employer has lost on this transaction.

Scene two: I want to buy a pre-pay mobile phone as a present for someone. The queues at the local Carphone Warehouse go round the block. Not having the time to hang about, I order the phone from the Virgin website. The transaction form seems well designed and even offers me the facility to choose the date on which the phone will be delivered.

Agreeably surprised by this, I choose the following Saturday. But when I look at the form, re-presented for my click-through approval, I find the delivery date is set for 'next day' and that this is impossible to change. In other words, the approval form has not picked up my delivery preference. After several fruitless attempts to remedy this, I notice that the site offers a link enabling one to track one's order online, and so click to approve the deal.

But guess what? The tracking link doesn't work, providing only the useless information that 'Your order has a status of Dispatched. Delivery status is Unknown'. Eventually I ring the 0845 number and speak to a human being. 'Your software doesn't work,' I say. He murmurs the resigned platitudes of someone who has heard this before, and tells me that the phone will be delivered on Friday.

I could fill this entire page with similar e-commerce horror stories culled from my own and readers' experiences. What they illustrate is an attitude towards e-commerce and customer service on the part of many companies which borders on criminal negligence. They see the Web as a way to make money without incurring the costs of a bricks-and-mortar operation. And because any fool can create an e-commerce website, many fools do.

Taking orders is easy; but fulfilling them - delivering the stuff to your door - is difficult and expensive, requiring as it does old-economy disciplines like adequate staffing, infrastructure, stock control and logistics. The only e-commerce vendor I have used extensively which has never faltered in this respect is Amazon - a fact which has led me to conclude that Amazon is really just a good customer-service organisation which happens to be on the web.

There is a corporate governance issue here. Directors of public companies such as Powergen (whose website recently breached the credit card security of many of its customers) ought to take a closer interest in what is being done on the web in their name. Many of the most flagrant examples of incompetent e-commercial software would never have got past a vigilant, internet-savvy manager. Evidently such managers are rare in Britain. I wonder why.

john.naughton@observer.co.uk

Delivery is promised within 10 days. I am sceptical, but on the tenth day the parcel arrives and my son berates me for my lack of faith in technology. Two days later another G-shock watch arrives. My credit card account, however, has not been debited for it. I send an email to letsbuyit.com but receive no reply. Eventually I get a phone call from an embarrassed young woman who arranges for a courier to pick up the surplus timepiece. I spend some time calculating how much her employer has lost on this transaction. Scene two: I want to buy a pre-pay mobile phone as a present for someone. The queues at the local Carphone Warehouse go round the block. Not having the time to hang about, I order the phone from the Virgin website. The transaction form seems well designed and even offers me the facility to choose the date on which the phone will be delivered. Agreeably surprised by this, I choose the following Saturday. But when I look at the form, re-presented for my click-through approval, I find the delivery date is set for 'next day' and that this is impossible to change. In other words, the approval form has not picked up my delivery preference. After several fruitless attempts to remedy this, I notice that the site offers a link enabling one to track one's order online, and so click to approve the deal. But guess what? The tracking link doesn't work, providing only the useless information that 'Your order has a status of Dispatched. Delivery status is Unknown'. Eventually I ring the 0845 number and speak to a human being. 'Your software doesn't work,' I say. He murmurs the resigned platitudes of someone who has heard this before, and tells me that the phone will be delivered on Friday. I could fill this entire page with similar e-commerce horror stories culled from my own and readers' experiences. What they illustrate is an attitude towards e-commerce and customer service on the part of many companies which borders on criminal negligence. They see the Web as a way to make money without incurring the costs of a bricks-and-mortar operation. And because any fool can create an e-commerce website, many fools do. Taking orders is easy; but fulfilling them - delivering the stuff to your door - is difficult and expensive, requiring as it does old-economy disciplines like adequate staffing, infrastructure, stock control and logistics. The only e-commerce vendor I have used extensively which has never faltered in this respect is Amazon - a fact which has led me to conclude that Amazon is really just a good customer-service organisation which happens to be on the web. There is a corporate governance issue here. Directors of public companies such as Powergen (whose website recently breached the credit card security of many of its customers) ought to take a closer interest in what is being done on the web in their name. Many of the most flagrant examples of incompetent e-commercial software would never have got past a vigilant, internet-savvy manager. Evidently such managers are rare in Britain. I wonder why. john.naughton@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: I'm frustrated, says 'Colditz' inmate
fields.standfirst: Wilson talks of frustrations
fields.trailText: It was the London base of the Scottish Office for almost a century. Now Dover House in Whitehall has become the Colditz of British politics and its inmates must dream of escape.
fields.body:
It was the London base of the Scottish Office for almost a century. Now Dover House in Whitehall has become the Colditz of British politics and its inmates must dream of escape.

Brian Wilson, Minister of State at what is now called the Scotland Office, admits his role there has frustrations. But he dismisses suggestions that now the Scottish Parliament and Executive are in place, it should be abolished.

'For the foreseeable future, until something better or equivalent is put in place, Scotland would be very much disadvantaged if there wasn't a presence in government in Whitehall,' he says.

Dover House was once the home of Lady Caroline Lamb. Indeed, it is said she seduced her lover Lord Byron there. The Scottish civil servants' were naturally a greyer lot but their diplomacy over many years is one reason Scotland has a favourable share of UK public expenditure. They were pervasive, sitting on almost every important Whitehall committee.

Wilson says: 'It always has to be remembered that half the public expenditure in Scotland comes directly from Whitehall departments. The other half - as we were reminded last week by the Comprehensive Spending review - is determined by decisions in the Treasury.

'It's entirely proper that the distribution of this money is done in Scotland, but the money has to be there in the first place. In all of that the Scotland Office has a really significant role.'

Wilson must have taken the job with mixed feelings. He must have hoped that his boss, John Reid, would take over at as Defence Secretary when George Robertson went to lead Nato, and that he would succeed Reid. Instead, the defence job went to Geoff Hoon, perhaps because it was thought there were too many Scots in the Cabinet.

Now Reid and Wilson are stuck in Dover House at least until after the election. And although Wilson soldiers loyally on - Tony Blair sweetened the job by adding to it the chairmanship of a Cabinet committee on trade policy - a sense of loss is inescapable.

After all, he was a spending Minister at the Scottish Office, with responsibility for education and industry, and then made it into a major UK department as Minister for Trade. Now he says: 'I see at first hand the difficulties of a department which doesn't have a spending programme or legislative powers of its own. So I don't underestimate the anomaly that the Scotland Act represents.'

He accepts that the future of the Cabinet post of Scottish Secretary may be in doubt. There have been suggestions - and a firm proposal from the Tories - that one Minister should represent Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

'It's inevitable that we should think about the future,' says Wilson. But he sees difficulties in lumping three departments into one. 'They would still face the same lack of spending and legislative power that the Scotland Office faces.'

It would not be in Scotland's interests to abolish it and 'pretend that the Scottish Executive can exercise the same influence in relation to Whitehall. The physical presence is very important.'

Sitting on a wide range of policy committees John Reid and he 'make our influence felt. There is a significant difference between that relationship and people coming down from the Executive. They are bound to be peripheral to the daily workings of government.'

There is 'real potential' in the joint committees set up between Whitehall and Holyrood. 'These could quickly develop links as strong as those at present'. But he insists: 'As things stand, the Scotland Office has a very important role.'

Attracting top politicians to such a department in future will be 'a problem. But it is the reality: the way devolution was framed.'

He acknowledges: 'It is frustrating that there isn't even a small amount of money to oil the wheels of initiatives beneficial to Scotland. So we have to work by persuasion and negotiation. In the longer term it's a difficult concept to sustain.'

Another frustration is that Wilson is held at arm's length from issues with which he is identified, such as land reform. 'Given that I've ended up back in Scottish politics, it would be silly to say there aren't things I would like to have a direct input on.'

But there are 'many avenues' for involvement in such issues. For example, 'I was able to achieve the investigation' into the ownership of the Cuillins, 'even if one does not like the outcome'. [Last week the Crown Estate said no legal challenge could be made to clan chief John MacLeod of MacLeod's title to the lands. He wants to sell them for £10 million or, failing that, have public funds to fix his roof.]

Wilson believes devolution will have a profound effect on Scottish politics. Over the past 30 years, he says, they have been 'distorted' by the self-inflicted failure of the Scottish Conservative Party.

'I grew up in Argyll, and the idea that there are 10 or 12 per cent of Tories in Scotland is an absurdity. There are 25 to 25 per cent. The triumph of the Thatcher-Forsyth years was to estrange a high proportion of these people.'

Now, he says, 'that vacuum has to be filled'. It is the SNP, not the Labour Party which is the home of these 'natural Tories. For all Alex Salmond's craving to make headway in Labour territory, the only place the SNP holds seats is in Tory heartlands'.

He says of Salmond's decision to quit the SNP leadership: 'I suspect that after days of soundbites after the Scottish elections claiming a great victory, he woke up and realised he had actually lost and he was facing another four years, or even 12 years, of opposition politics. And that is not a cheerful outlook.'

Wilson has been MP for Cunninghame North since 1987. Publisher and founding editor of the West Highland Free Press, he has kept his hand in at journalism. It is an alternative career option. And one senses a certain fellow feeling when he says of Salmond's decision: 'I don't blame him. I wouldn't point the finger and say it's wrong for any individual to say they've done their bit and it's time to move on.'

He leaves to return to Dover House before catching the sleeper home to Glasgow and his family. He is not yet organising an escape committee, but I wouldn't be surprised if he did.

webTitle: Blair launches G8 war against world drugs trade

fields.headline: Blair launches G8 war against world drugs trade
fields.trailText: Tony Blair won international backing yesterday for a new war on the $400 billion drug industry which now makes more money than generated by the textile and motor sectors.
fields.body:
Tony Blair won international backing yesterday for a new war on the $400 billion drug industry which now makes more money than generated by the textile and motor sectors.

World leaders agreed to stage a conference in Britain next February to gather intelligence on the markets of the drugs gangs, which operate like multi-national corporations. The information will be used to devise ways of putting them out of business, for example by passing new laws on confiscation of assets.

'These gangs work through perverting the financial system. There's a growing sense that we need to take clear, hard action,' Blair said.

His plan was put forward at the G8 summit in Okinawa, Japan, where he also cemented his relationship with new Russian premier Vladimir Putin by winning agreement to stage a conference together on tackling the trade in 'conflict diamonds'. Russia has a large, legitmate market in the gems and Putin is anxious to protect it, while at the same time eliminating an important source of funding for wars in Africa.

The Prime Minister's spokesman said Blair had formed a 'very strong, favourable impression' of Putin, making his debut at the summit.

Among the British successes was expected to be an agreement to set firm targets to reduce preventable diseases over the next 10 years. Blair wants to half deaths from malaria and TB over the next 10 years and cut Aids deaths by 25 per cent. 'It's not just a moral imperative. It's in our best economic interest because Africa is a potentially important and massive market for the future,' said Blair's spokesman.

The annual turnover of the drugs trafficking business, estimated at up to $400bn by the United Nations, represents 8 per cent of world trade. By comparison, textiles represent 7.5 per cent, motor vehicles 5.3 per cent and iron and steel 2.8 per cent The drugs trade is almost as big as oil and gas, which represents 8.6 per cent of world trade.

'The aim of all this is to get better analysis, better information, and then use that to remove the financial incentives and the lifeblood from crime,' said the Prime Minister's spokesman.

Some of the questions to be studied will be the price-setting mechanisms, the supply chains, whether there are many or just a few participants in each market, whether gangs concentrate on one drug or several and the barriers to entering and leaving markets.

The new way of thinking about the international drug cartels has already been discussed by Home Secretary Jack Straw and Janet Reno, the US attorney-general.

Influenced by the ideas of British drug tsar Keith Hellawell, the plan is expected to inform the design of legislation and work in tandem with the Prime Minister's domestic agenda on drugs, which is expected to be highlighted by a new Bill on the subject in the Queen's Speech.

webTitle: Cancer peril of animal organ transplants

fields.headline: Cancer peril of animal organ transplants
fields.trailText: Transplanting animal organs into humans could trigger a global pandemic of a deadly new disease. A new study by British scientists has found that cancer-causing retroviruses are spread relatively easily between different creatures in the wild.
fields.body:
Transplanting animal organs into humans could trigger a global pandemic of a deadly new disease. A new study by British scientists has found that cancer-causing retroviruses are spread relatively easily between different creatures in the wild.

The discovery, outlined last week by the Natural Environment Research Council, will reinforce concerns raised by experiments which recently revealed that pig hearts and kidneys carry potentially deadly animal retroviruses, dashing hopes that animals could one day supply spare parts for human surgery.

As a result of these initial experiments, Western health authorities imposed a moratorium on all xenotransplant surgery, although biotechnology companies are known to be continuing with research. Human organs are desperately scarce, as are supplies of brain tissue for treating stroke victims and Parkinson's sufferers. It was hoped specially-reared animals, mainly pigs, would provide tissue and organs for tens of thousands of operations a year.

The dangers of this plan are underlined in the study by biologists Michael Tristem and Joanne Martin of Imperial College, London, which focused on murine leukaemia viruses, close relatives of the cancer retroviruses that are known to infect pigs. Traces of virus DNA were found in a range of mammalian species in the wild, suggesting that pig retroviruses are capable of infecting other animals - including humans - with relative ease.

'There are two ways to demonstrate that animal retroviruses pose risks,' said Tristem. 'You can show they can be grown in human cells in the laboratory. Scientists have done that. Or you can show such viruses jump easily between species in the wild. Our study now proves this also happens - that cancer viruses will jump species in the real world, not just in artificial laboratory settings.'

Finding leukaemia virus DNA mixed up with the genes of different animals does not prove these creatures were all made ill by their infection, Tristem admitted. 'However, when viruses jump species they usually acquire pathogenic properties, just as HIV did when it leapt from monkeys to humans. There is a real, but small risk that pig organ transplants could trigger a new disease epidemic.'

Virologist Professor Robin Weiss, who first demonstrated that pig viruses could infect human cells, agreed. 'Xenotransplants do not seem to pose a big risk. But then BSE or HIV were not thought to pose big risks when they were first discovered. We obviously have to be very careful.'

Professor George Griffen, a member of the UK Xenotransplantation Interim Regulatory Authority, said: 'There is always going to be a chance that a viral stowaway could be transplanted into a human along with a pig heart or kidney. It could then spread through his or her body, and then to other individuals, triggering a new epidemic.

'However, if the risk of this happening is found to be very, very small, would it be right to block xenotransplants, given that they could help treat so many serious illnesses? And don't forget that none of the hundreds of pre-moratorium xenotransplant recipients have yet to show reactions to retroviruses.'

Sceptics point out that transferred viruses could take decades to take effect, and these transplant patients could still develop retroviral illnesses in 20 years. They also argue that stem cell surgery, in which the patients' own cells are used to grow new organs, could soon obviate the need to use animal hearts or livers. 'I think it is now touch and go whether xenotransplants will ever be given the go-ahead in the West,' said Griffen.

Even if they were approved, operations would only be permitted under the most stringent conditions. Patients would have to be monitored and tested for the rest of their lives, as would their sexual partners and children.

What worries some researchers is the prospect that these costly lifetime safeguards may drive an unscrupulous surgeon or biotech company to carry out transplants in 'xeno-havens', developing nations that do not impose regulations.

fields.headline: 'I'd have welcomed the death penalty'
fields.standfirst: Drug smuggler Sandra Gregory can't believe she's home after surprise pardon by King of Thailand
fields.trailText: Drug smuggler Sandra Gregory said yesterday that if she had been given the choice she would have chosen to be executed for her crime. Speaking on her first day of freedom, the 35-year-old said: 'I think that people should be allowed the option.'
fields.body:
Drug smuggler Sandra Gregory said yesterday that if she had been given the choice she would have chosen to be executed for her crime. Speaking on her first day of freedom, the 35-year-old said: 'I think that people should be allowed the option.'

She admitted that during her seven years in prison she would have been happy to take 'the easy way out' of a death penalty.

Gregory was freed on Friday after receiving an unexpected pardon from the King of Thailand. But she said that she hoped her early release did not send out any wrong signals to others. 'When I heard I was to be set free, I thought I just didn't deserve it,' she said.'I know how incredibly lucky I have been because I got myself into this situation and there is no one else to blame.'

A Thai court sentenced her to 25 years imprisonment in February 1993 after she was found guilty of trying to smuggle 86.9 grammes (3oz) of heroin through Bangkok airport.

Gregory had accepted £1,000 for a flight home in return for carrying the drugs inside her body when, sick with fever, she was desperate to return after 18 months abroad.

The British authorities are believed to have tipped off Thai customs that the man she was travelling with, Robert Lock, was a suspected trafficker. He was freed but later jailed in the UK for other drugs offences.

Yesterday Gregory, a former teacher, was at her parents' home in Aberdeenshire for the first time in nearly nine years. Her mother had been waiting for her at the prison gates and the pair arrived at Aberdeen station yesterday morning for an emotional reunion with her 66-year-old father Stan.

Gregory said she was experiencing a 'flurry of emotions' and had spent her first night sitting up, too frightened to sleep. 'I was scared to sleep in case I woke up in a prison cell again.

'I haven't eaten or slept. Life is just too great at the moment to waste time on those things,' she said, sporting the same smile she has worn since her parents telephoned her at Cookham Wood prison in Kent on Thursday to tell her she was to be freed.

Gregory was moved to a UK jail in 1997 under a prisoner transfer scheme after four and a half years in Thailand's 'Bangkok Hilton' women's jail, notorious for appalling conditions and brutality. Her sentence made her Britain's longest-serving female prisoner after Myra Hindley and Rose West.

Yesterday she hinted at the depths of despair she had reached in a prison system she once described as 'being kept alive to suffer slowly - killed from the inside out.

'I never imagined I would get a full pardon. I hoped for a reduction in my sentence but never this,' she said. 'To be honest, when mum and dad started their campaign to free me, I thought it wouldn't do any good at all.'

But it was undoubtedly the diplomacy and the dignified efforts of her parents that saw their daughter released. Stan and Doreen Gregory, a softly-spoken couple, have never tried to deny their daughter's guilt nor justify her action. 'The issue was not that she was being punished, it was what was a fair punishment. The court's decision of 25 years imprisonment was clearly not.'

The couple's constituency MP, Malcolm Bruce, brought the case to Parliament ensuring a flow of private letters from ministers, MPs and peers were reaching the Thai authorities.

Even Foreign Office officials tested the boundaries of Government policy by ensuring the Thais were aware of the strength of support the Gregorys were getting from the public.

Bound by policy which prevents the British Government making clemency appeals for a national unless there are compelling compassionate grounds, Foreign Office minister Peter Hain this year expressed clear disquiet at the length of sentence.

In reply to Malcolm Bruce's adjournment debate speech in January, Hain stressed that while the government could not make a formal plea to the Thais, behind-the-scene representations were being made. The transcript of the debate was later sent to Thailand by the foreign office.

Yesterday it was to the King of Thailand that the Gregory family were directing their thanks.

Gregory was moved to a UK jail in 1997 under a prisoner transfer scheme after four and a half years in Thailand's 'Bangkok Hilton' women's jail, notorious for appalling conditions and brutality. Her sentence made her Britain's longest-serving female prisoner after Myra Hindley and Rose West. Yesterday she hinted at the depths of despair she had reached in a prison system she once described as 'being kept alive to suffer slowly - killed from the inside out. 'I never imagined I would get a full pardon. I hoped for a reduction in my sentence but never this,' she said. 'To be honest, when mum and dad started their campaign to free me, I thought it wouldn't do any good at all.' But it was undoubtedly the diplomacy and the dignified efforts of her parents that saw their daughter released. Stan and Doreen Gregory, a softly-spoken couple, have never tried to deny their daughter's guilt nor justify her action. 'The issue was not that she was being punished, it was what was a fair punishment. The court's decision of 25 years imprisonment was clearly not.' The couple's constituency MP, Malcolm Bruce, brought the case to Parliament ensuring a flow of private letters from ministers, MPs and peers were reaching the Thai authorities. Even Foreign Office officials tested the boundaries of Government policy by ensuring the Thais were aware of the strength of support the Gregorys were getting from the public. Bound by policy which prevents the British Government making clemency appeals for a national unless there are compelling compassionate grounds, Foreign Office minister Peter Hain this year expressed clear disquiet at the length of sentence. In reply to Malcolm Bruce's adjournment debate speech in January, Hain stressed that while the government could not make a formal plea to the Thais, behind-the-scene representations were being made. The transcript of the debate was later sent to Thailand by the foreign office. Yesterday it was to the King of Thailand that the Gregory family were directing their thanks.

fields.headline: Sarah's death
fields.standfirst: What lessons can we learn?
fields.trailText: The tragic death of Sarah Payne has saddened the entire nation. Although we do not know the identity of her murderer, it seems likely that it was a man with sexual disorders, possibly but not certainly a paedophile.
fields.body:
The tragic death of Sarah Payne has saddened the entire nation. Although we do not know the identity of her murderer, it seems likely that it was a man with sexual disorders, possibly but not certainly a paedophile.

Sarah's death has reopened a debate about what the appropriate policy is towards those with a known predisposition to paedophilia, sexual deviancy or who have served sentences for committing sexual offences ranging from rape to paedophilia.

The problem is that the recidivist rate among sex offenders is very high. Paedophilia, with the current state of medical knowledge, is almost untreatable. Many of its sufferers have themselves been the objects of sexual attacks in their childhood and hate their own irresistible proclivities. They know that they need to be saved from themselves.

One option now being considered in Scotland is the electronic tagging of paedophiles, so that if the wearer of the tag approached a banned area - a school, for example - an alarm would be set off. In Arizona, a similar scheme allows the tag to be tracked by satellite so that there is a permanent record of the movements of the sex offender.

The objection is that the number of paedophile murders is relatively small - fewer than eight a year - and a precedent, it might be argued, would be set in British law justifying the constraint of the free movement of individuals. But it was John Stuart Mill who argued that no liberty is absolute.

If tagging proved beyond doubt that there would be a significant and measurable reduction in a terrible crime, and thus a promotion of the liberty of children, then its introduction would be justified, as long as there was a proper right of appeal.

We urge the Scottish Executive to accelerate its investigation and publish the results. This could be a trailblazing initiative with national implications.

webTitle: Farmer drops £10,000 claim for crop damage in Sarah search

fields.headline: Farmer drops £10,000 claim for crop damage in Sarah search
fields.standfirst: More about the Sarah Payne case
fields.trailText: The millionaire owner of a field who had planned to claim £10,000 compensation from police for damage caused during the search for murdered eight-year-old Sarah Payne last night dropped his claim.
fields.body:
The millionaire owner of a field who had planned to claim £10,000 compensation from police for damage caused during the search for murdered eight-year-old Sarah Payne last night dropped his claim.

Paul Langmead, who runs a Pick-Your-Own farm business between Worthing and Littlehampton, alleged his crops were destroyed as officers searched his field near East Preston, West Sussex. But yesterday he issued a statement saying: 'Owing to the great unhappiness this has caused my farm staff and family, we are withdrawing any claim for damages caused to our crops.'

As well as being vilified by the press, the farmer's original claim was condemned by the Payne family, who said they were 'appalled'. Police said they were left 'open-mouthed'. Langmead had claimed that any money would be donated to the Sarah Payne fund, but despite this the National Farmers Union said it would not back his claim under the present circumstances. Earlier Langmead had issued a statement, which read: 'I am very upset that someone with Sussex police has seen fit to publicise the fact that I notified the police of damage to crops on my farm in the course of the search for Sarah Payne. I and my farm staff have been deeply distressed by the tragic disappearance and murder of Sarah.

'However, we cannot afford to ignore the fact that, through no fault of the police, many thousands of pounds of damage has been done to our crops during the course of searches for Sarah...'

News of the farmer's retreat came as detectives investigating the murder began to examine the possibility that the killer may have discarded items of Sarah's clothing over a wide area in a bid to confuse or taunt police. They have so far failed to find more clothing or other forensic evidence.

Sarah's naked body was found in a field close to Pul borough. It was believed to have been hidden in the early hours of 2 July but was not discovered until 17 July. Her shoe was found on 20 July.

Detectives believe that, after snatching Sarah from a lane close to the coast at Kingston, near Littlehampton, her killer travelled north, most likely using the A24 before turning west along the A272 to Coolham before heading south again on the A29. Her body was found beside this road. Or he could have travelled in the opposite direction.

All the lanes below the A272 and between the A29 and A24 were being subjected to intense searches when her shoe was found by a member of the public near Coolham. Motorists are being questioned at roadblocks by police hoping to garner clues from day-trippers returning to the area.

Police were also to continue inquiries near a property in Crawley, West Sussex, where a Littlehampton man arrested in connection with the inquiry was staying after he was released on police bail until August.
