fields.headline: Letters to the editor
fields.standfirst: The big issue :  Anger and delight at criticism of the Queen Mother
fields.trailText: How despicable is Anthony Holden's article (Review, last week) about the Queen Mother! Such malevolence would be justified if we were discussing General Pinochet's centenary. But we are celebrating the 100th birthday of a woman born of the sun who has brightened our lives with her delight in living, warmth of character and grace in performing her duties and responsibilities.
fields.body:
How despicable is Anthony Holden's article (Review, last week) about the Queen Mother! Such malevolence would be justified if we were discussing General Pinochet's centenary. But we are celebrating the 100th birthday of a woman born of the sun who has brightened our lives with her delight in living, warmth of character and grace in performing her duties and responsibilities.

Glenys Jones, Llanfrothen, Gwynedd

I was distressed to read the article about the Queen Mother. She was and is loved by the older generation because, during the war, she and King George VI worked at pulling the country together by being seen all over London; by raising the morale of the public; by refusing to send their daughters to Canada to escape the bombs. The Queen Mother's treatment of Wallis Simpson was in keeping with the feeling of most of the populace at the time. She still remains a figurehead to many of us. it seems out of keeping to celebrate her 100th birthday with such an article.

Ralph Baer, Amersham, Bucks

Our thanks to Anthony Holden for his heartwarming, hilarious homily on 'The Enforcer', that little old lady whose long and lazy lifespan has epitomised the inequality in our society which makes our nation the laughing stock of our more enlightened Euro neighbours. We were both blessed with beloved parents who were born around the same time as the Queen Mother, but whose lives were shortened by the privations of poverty and constant toil.

Unfortunately, Mr Holden's wise words will only reach the converted and not those hapless hordes who line the streets to look at her and the rest of her farcical 'first family'.

We were among those in the East End who could not care whether they ever looked us in the face, so it would be nice to believe that at least some of the 'millions who love royalty for reasons they themselves cannot quite articulate or understand' may have given this reply to their children when asked 'Mummy, why is that tiny lady always smiling at us?' - 'No dear, she's not smiling - she's laughing at us.'

Diane and Ken Taylor, Brighton

In his article on the Queen Mother Anthony Holden quotes, seemingly with approval, 'a courtier' that 'she wouldn't know where the East End was'. She did know, as long ago as in the early 1930s, when as Duchess of York she presented the prizes at the Central Foundation School in Spitalfields, very much in east London. My sister was a pupil and I sat in the balcony overlooking the platform and admiring the Duchess's beauty and the informal and happy note she brought to this normally boring chore.

The Queen Mother, her husband and her elder daughter have 'done the State some service': in her last years we should not begrudge her the G&Ts, the horses and the retinue she has always enjoyed.

W.A. Stubbles, Harwich, Essex

It is worth pointing out that six countries within the EU are monarchies. In Spain it was the restoration of the monarchy which ensured that the country moved from fascist dictatorship under Franco to become the stable and prosperous democracy we see today.

Jenny Banks Bryer, Birmingham

So many grades of metric failure

Your editorial (Leader comment, last week) fails to mention one field where the metric system even failed to get adopted anywhere outside France or its colonies. French revolutionaries planned to have 100 'grades' in a right-angle instead of 90 degrees. Only after this decimalisation (or rather centesimalisation) was conceived did the metre get defined as one ten-millionth of the surface distance between the Equator and the North Pole. The idea was to emulate the Nautical Mile derived from one arc-second of latitude from the Earth's centre to its surface. In the metric equivalent a kilometre would be the distance similarly subtended, by a ten thousandth of a right-angle, ie one-hundredth of a grade.

Richard Gosnell, Wootton Bassett, Wilts

Hemingway slur

It seems picky, I know, but it has to be said that Amelia Hill is wrong to use Hemingway's hero of A Farewell to Arms as an example of emotional fuckwittage, as compared to Tony Parson's New Father in Man and Boy. (Focus, last week). Quoting Lieutenant Henry - one of the most tear-jerking figures of cinema history - saying 'I felt no feelings of fatherhood' in a cut-up extract from Hemingway's novel is not fair to Papa at all. For a start, the baby is dead. Its mother, who is the love of our hero's life, is dying next door. Naturally, he doesn't know what to think. He's a man of few words. He does cry when his wife dies, however. Tony Parsons would do the same doubtless. You could do a lot worse, boys, than to feel like Hemingway wrote it.

Sheena Joughin, London EC1

Aids argument

John Cairns asks if my argument that Aids may have been caused by medical error is not undermined by the 'presumption' that male circumcision reduces the risk of contracting HIV during sex (Letters, last week). The spread of the virus was facilitated by many factors, including the fact that the foreskin affords HIV a safe haven. That male circumcision radically reduces the chances of African men acquiring HIV sexually has been demonstrated by many published studies, notably those by Frank Plummer's team in Nairobi.

Ed Hooper, Bridgwater, Somerset

Australian guilt

Much has been made of the inaccurate portrayal of British atrocities in Mel Gibson's new film, The Patriot . Congratulations to Philip French (Review, last week) for managing not to over-emphasise these in his review of the film. After all, Gibson is making a career of playing the underdog who fights back. I look forward to his movie portraying the wrongs perpetrated upon his country's native aboriginals by his ancestors.

Simon Birnstingl, Upper Beeding, West Sussex

Danger in apathy

Barry Cox appears to believe that political disengagement is nothing to worry about (Comment, last week), and that apathy is a 'fact of life' which we should just accept. I believe that to do this would be dangerous and threatening to democracy in this country if this was to happen. Only last week the BNP came second in a council by-election in south-east London. For Cox to claim that liberal democracy would be 'self-correcting' in the event of extremists gaining power is flippant, and does not give enough gravity to the very real threat that the far right poses in many areas of the UK.

Sarah Albert, Redhill, Surrey

Flying lessons

The Luftwaffe pilots of 1940 still think Hitler was right (News, last week) and that the Battle of Britain was of no significance. How little they learned from their Second World War experiences. The fact is that Admiral Raeder informed Hitler that he could not take an army across the Channel without control of the air by the Luftwaffe. If an invasion had been launched the Royal Navy would have been hard put to stop it. The day of the battleship was over. No major battle of the war was won by a general who did not have substantial control of the air.

PE Perry, London E17

webTitle: Champ cars to crash the F1 party

fields.headline: Champ cars to crash the F1 party
fields.trailText: It's enough to make Michael Schumacher and David Coulthard choke on their winners' champagne. Formula 1 has a new rival. The American sport of champ cars - which resembles Roman chariot races colliding with fairground dodgems at 250mph - is about to cross the Atlantic.
fields.body:
It's enough to make Michael Schumacher and David Coulthard choke on their winners' champagne. Formula 1 has a new rival. The American sport of champ cars - which resembles Roman chariot races colliding with fairground dodgems at 250mph - is about to cross the Atlantic.

With F1 under fire for being too predictable, a sport which began on dirt tracks across America is aiming to win over British motorsport enthusiasts with its dramatic mix of scarily high speeds, spectacular crashes and cars turning into heaps of crumpled metal.

Thousands of fans are queuing up to buy tickets for the champ cars' British debut next year, even though the venue has not yet been built. The oval circuit will be the country's biggest sporting arena, capable of holding up to 130,000 cheering 'petrolheads'.

Staging the event will put the Rockingham course, being constructed on a 300-acre site outside the former steel town of Corby, Northants, on the world motorsport map. Many expect it eventually to prise the British Grand Prix away from its existing home at Silverstone, a few miles away. F1 fans have turned against Silverstone since rain ruined the British Grand Prix last Easter. Car parks became swamps and 30,000 of the expected 80,000-strong crowd could not reach the track.

Champ cars attracts speed freaks, turned on by the high-speed jousting, and racing purists who believe F1's technological wizardry has ousted the heroic skills demanded of men handling a car at over 200mph.

'Champ car racing is unique; British fans won't have seen anything like it. It is a very dangerous sport,' said Damien Smith of Autosport magazine. 'If a driver spins off the track or misjudges a corner, there are only concrete walls to crash into, not gravel traps and banks of tyres to protect you like in F1.'

Four drivers and several spectators have been killed in the past few years. Gonzalo Rodríguez, an Uruguayan rookie, died last September when his car hit a wall at 160mph during practice. Six weeks later Canadian Greg Moore died when his car spun out of control, hit the inside wall and broke in two. The fate of both men was shown live on American television.

The sport's governing body, the Championship Auto Racing Team, is discussing whether to make both cars and courses safer to prevent further fatalities. Unlike the bends, chicanes, twists and turns of F1 circuits, the shape of champ cars circuits and widespread use of banking mean competitors must be able to drive continuously at speeds of up to 250mph.

Rob Yarham of the Cart Official Yearbook says: 'Champ car is pure speed racing. Fans like it because it's much more open than F1, which is dominated by the two richest teams, Ferrari and McLaren, whereas the guy that starts seventeenth on the grid in champ cars can win.'

How they compare

Champ car
Races: 20 (five countries; three continents)

Total spectators: 2.5 million

Biggest stars: Juan Montoya (Chile) and Dario Franchitti (Scotland)

Stars' earnings: Montoya - $5 million; Franchitti - $3m

TV audience: 29 million in America, and a few in Britain

Crashes: Fairly frequent, and often involve multiple pile-ups. Spate of fatalities in the 1990s including two last year

Money: $69m income in America. Likely to rise with sport now expanding internationally

Formula one
 Races: 17 (17 countries; four continents)

 Total spectators: 1.4 million per season, including new record high 200,000 at Monaco Grand Prix last month

 Biggest stars: Michael Schumacher (Germany) and Mika Hakkinen (Finland)

 Stars' earnings: Schumacher - £30.6m; Hakkinen - £20m

 TV audience: Five billion people watch worldwide

 Crashes: Much less frequent since Ayrton Senna died

 Money: Huge global business worth multi-billions in income from TV and big-name sponsors

denis.campbell@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: 'I'm back from the Stone Age'
fields.standfirst: Finally freed after being jailed with two other black men for the M25 murder and robberies, Michael Davis talks of his 10 lost years in jail to Tony Thompson
fields.trailText: Just hours after being freed after 10 years of a life sentence for a murder and armed robberies he did not commit, Michael Davis was walking down a south London road with friends when his mobile phone - a coming-out present - burst into life.
fields.body:
Just hours after being freed after 10 years of a life sentence for a murder and armed robberies he did not commit, Michael Davis was walking down a south London road with friends when his mobile phone - a coming-out present - burst into life.

Davis stopped and stared at the flashing gadget in his palm. Then he stared at his friends. 'I'd never seen a mobile close up before, let alone held one. I had absolutely no idea what to do with it. Everyone thought it was really funny but when I went to prison, these things just didn't really exist.

'It's not just technology that's moved on. I talk to people and can't follow what they're talking about. The names of cars, the cultural references they make, they might just as well be speaking a foreign language.'

Davis said: 'When you're in prison, everything is backward, it's like being in the Stone Age. Although we hear about things, it's not part of your world so you dismiss it, you don't really pay attention. Your only concern is what you're going to do the next day, and that's usually exactly the same as whatever you did the day before.

'Now I feel like a kid at Christmas. Everything is new. Everything is exciting. That first night, I went out for a walk in the dark. It was amazing. I haven't walked in the dark for nearly 12 years. And I haven't walked anywhere without a screw looking over my shoulder. It's a good feeling.'

The events that led to Davis spending almost all his adult life behind bars began in the early hours of Friday 16 December 1988. A gang of three masked men, one armed with a gun, another with a knife, set off on what would later be called an 'orgy of violence'.

First they attacked and robbed a gay couple making love in a car in Surrey. The pair were beaten and had petrol poured over them. One, Peter Hurburgh, was so terrified that he suffered a fatal heart attack during the ordeal. Their attackers then drove 10 miles on the M25 to Oxted and broke into a house, stealing rings and stabbing a male occupant. After returning to the M25 for a further 20 miles, the trio robbed and attacked another couple. The traumatised victims had no idea of the identity of the assailants but agreed on one thing - two of the attackers were white, one was black.

At the time, Davis was a self-confessed petty criminal with convictions for cannabis possession, handling stolen goods and failing to attend court. He had drifted into crime, having left school with no qualifications, unable even to read or write. Living in a probation hostel along with Raphael Rowe following a theft charge, Davis became friendly with Randolph Johnson who suggested the two of them carry out a burglary. When the police raided the house a few days after the M25 raid, Davis assumed it was in connection with that.

'I thought they were going to be talking about handling stolen goods. When they said murder, I said I don't think so, you've got the wrong bloke, but they seemed hell bent on it, trying to convince me I was guilty. They asked me where I was at the time of the murder and I told them. They called me a liar. I said hang on, you haven't even checked yet. Go and check then tell me if you believe me.

'As far as I was concerned, that was going to be the end of it. But they came back and called me a liar, even though my alibi checked out. There were nine people, some of whom didn't even know me, who said they had seen me somehwere else at the time of the murders. They had arrested 12 people at the house, some white, some black, and put us all in the same police station. As people were getting interviewed, they'd come back and discuss what was going on. It was obvious the police were looking for two white guys and a black guy so I started to relax. But then they charged me and my world fell apart. I couldn't believe it was happening, it didn't make any sense.'

Davis assumed the charges against himself, Rowe and Johnson would be dropped, especially when he heard the forensic evidence did not match any of them. But as the weeks passed it became obvious the trial would go ahead. 'That still didn't worry me,' he says. 'I thought the judge would take one look at it all and rule there was no case to answer. It seemed obvious.'

But the police produced a man who claimed to have stolen a car used in the robbery and passed it to Rowe. He also claimed he heard Rowe and the others discussing their plans for the night of violence. The three were found guilty and it took nearly eight years before they discovered the man whose evidence had convicted them had originally been charged with the murder and become a police informer to get himself off the hook.

'We lodged an appeal straight away. I thought an appeal was about correcting errors, rectifying any mistakes that had been made. That wasn't the case. Because the evidence that two of the suspects were white had already been heard by the jury, we weren't able to use it as grounds for an appeal. The most glaring bit of evidence in our favour was no good. The only way to be free was to find new evidence.'

While in prison, Davis decided to get an education. 'Once you're in a cell, the only way you can communicate with people is by writing. I spent the first year with nothing. No books, no magazines. Just me in my cell. That was the incentive.' His studies floundered until he was found to be dyslexic. 'It had never been identified before and that was the cause of all my troubles. Once that was taken in account, I was able to learn to read and write.'

Davis now has more than a dozen literary and science qualifications. He also plays the clarinet up to grade 5 level and has become an accomplished painter. Two of his works have been commended by the Koestler Foundation.

He now hopes to work towards a career in the music business but also to find the two children, aged 12 and 17, with whom he has lost touch.

'People talk about compenstation but what I want is justice. Not just for myself but for the victims of the crime. They have been treated just as badly. The campaign goes on. The targets now are the people responsible for taking away our liberty. Only when they are punished can the case be closed.'

webTitle: Clutter to be swept off streets

fields.headline: Clutter to be swept off streets
fields.standfirst: Blueprint for city centres applies principles of feng shui to the muddle of urban life
fields.trailText: A million lampposts may soon rust in peace. A government-backed blueprint for town centres has delighted fans of feng shui who say it will apply the principles of the ancient Chinese art to Britains's 5,000 high streets.
fields.body:
A million lampposts may soon rust in peace. A government-backed blueprint for town centres has delighted fans of feng shui who say it will apply the principles of the ancient Chinese art to Britains's 5,000 high streets.

Thousands of items of street clutter should be removed, calming uniform colours should be used on all remaining fixtures and 'line and art' should replace 'confusion and sloppiness' in urban spaces, says the report to be published next week by English Partnerships.

The influential experts, who advise both Whitehall and local authorities and are involved in the regeneration of city centres across the country, will also demand an end to the age-old division between pedestrian, cycle and vehicles on our roads. Reduced traffic flow with a 20mph limit would mean cycles and cars could live together, they will insist.

'We now need to strike an appropriate balance between traffic and other uses,' said EP chief executive Paula Hay-Plumb. 'If you design in a way that requires cars, people will use cars. If you want people to use public transport and walk, you have to make it appealing for them to do so.'

On the design blacklist alongside lampposts are 'ugly and sloppily applied white and yellow paint' on roads and the 'so-called street furniture' which litters Britain's streets. Grit bins, bollards, railings, signposts, CCTV cameras, utility substations, cycle stands and phone boxes should all also be done away with or sited and designed more sympathetically, says the report, to be launched by New Labour architect Lord Richard Rogers.

In future, streetlights should be attached to the sides of buildings and more use should be made of bollards which can light streets as well as guide traffic. Uplighters placed in pavements and illumination from shop windows could be deployed instead of traditional lampposts.

The report will also call for thousands more statues, sculptures and murals in public places. It recommends a 5 per cent levy on the value of new private developments towards the cost of funding such public art.

Security fences or grilles should be designed as sculptures too, and staggered road crossings with 'sheep pens' in the middle should be replaced so that pedestrians have a simple and straightforward path across major roads.

Feng shui is a Far Eastern practice of organising your environment in order to live more harmoniously with the perceived energy fields around it. Originally used as a way of divining where to site graves, the credo was later applied to the arrangement of homes.

Colin Binns, a leading British feng shui practitioner, welcomed the report: 'I'm delighted that these principles are now to be used in public spaces. There are lots of lessons that can be learned. Look at any high street.'

Christian Kyriacou, another feng shui expert, said: 'The whole layout of a town can affect the happiness of the people who live there. If you harness energy centres in the right way, you can create harmony for its residents.'

In the last decade feng shui has been adopted by a string of fashionable figures to improve their domestic harmony. Madonna and George Michael are known converts to the claimed beneficial effects of removing clutter and realigning furniture.

In Radio 4's long-running The Archers, feng shui convert Linda Snell has recently caused consternation at her workplace, Grey Gables, after rearranging flower pots and removing wastepaper baskets in a unilateral bid to improve the happiness of the hotel's guests.

'Detail matters enormously in town centres too,' said Hay-Plumb. 'It's not just a question of major works. Small amounts of money spent on improving the quality of the environment can produce huge social returns.'

The problem...

1 The space is dominated by Yang Wood energy (strong upward shapes of buildings columns and bollards) at the expense of the street

2 Long - straight tarmac streets channel Chi energy too fiercely, to the detriment of pedestrians

3 Bollards in the foreground fragment flow of Chi for pedestrians

4 Corner of building and news stand is too hard and dominant

And how

ve it...

1 Sculpture to counter energy of major buildings

2 Rounded tree shapes balance building energy and slow down Chi flow in street 'corridor'

3 Textured surfaces and flowing paths improve the Chi flow

4 New bollards allow energy to be balanced by Yin metal shapes

5 A rounded news stand gives improved Chi flow

ben.summerskill@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Young Stalins make art a family affair

fields.headline: Young Stalins make art a family affair
fields.trailText: Their great-grandfather was the arch-persecutor of artists inside the Soviet Union, but now Stalin's descendants are winning international acclaim as painters and filmmakers.
fields.body:
Their great-grandfather was the arch-persecutor of artists inside the Soviet Union, but now Stalin's descendants are winning international acclaim as painters and filmmakers.

While one great-grandson carves out a career in German cinema, his younger brother, Jacob Dzhugashvili, is in London this week exhibiting a collection of oils in a London gallery.

Dzhugashvili the painter tries to keep his political heritage to himself, but he accepts that some of those who buy his work are probably more interested in the surname at the bottom of the canvas than the paintings themselves. His great-grandfather was born Joseph Dzhugashvili, but changed his name to Stalin, which means 'steel-like'.

'If that is what they want, then fine,' said the 28-year-old. 'This family is something I have been given by God and I have to deal with it. I am not afraid. I was born with it.'

Dzhugashvili admits that he had to cope with a lot of attention from a young age: 'My name meant that I grew up quite early. And it is, of course, interesting that several of us have gone into the world of art.'

As well as Vissarion, his 35-year-old older brother whose short film The Stone has been praised by German critics, Dzhugashvili also has a cousin making films in Georgia. 'Lela is 33 years old and very talented. She is my uncle's daughter,' he said.

The family is still mourning the sudden death of another cousin who had established himself on the Georgian arts scene. Dzhugashvili's 49-year-old cousin Levan was a poet. 'He died of a heart attack while he was reciting his poetry.

'I guess with our history all of us have something to say. There's a lot of stuff that we have to share with others.'

The Dzhugashvilis have been saddled with one of the most difficult legacies of the modern age. Within Georgia they are infamous for the violent way that great-grandfather Stalin imposed communism. As General Secretary of the Communist Party from 1922 to 1953, he repressed all art he considered subversive - frequently organising the murder of the perpetrators.

In the late Fifties and the Sixties the Dzhugashvilis themselves were persecuted. In 1956, three years after Stalin's death, Khrushchev denounced him and in 1961 his body was removed from the Lenin Mausoleum in Moscow. Stalin's grandson and Jacob's father, Yevgeny, left Moscow for Georgia where the family name was less reviled.

The family stayed in Georgia until 1971, when Khrushchev died, before returning to Moscow. At school, Jacob and his brother were not spared criticism of their great-grandfather. 'The history books we used had pictures of him and assessments of his role.' Ten years ago the family went back to Georgia and Dzhugashvili won a place at the Academy of Fine Art in Georgia.

He later attended the Glasgow School of Art with an unexpected £6,000 grant from the Georgian authorities. He kept his identity to himself. 'At college I was always just Georgian Jacob and, in fact, by the end of my studies, I was Scottish Georgian Jacob.'

webTitle: Perfect eyesight may be just a sleep away

fields.headline: Perfect eyesight may be just a sleep away
fields.trailText: Throw out the glasses and flush away the contact lenses. A radical new treatment that cures short-sightedness while people sleep is set to give them perfect vision during the day.
fields.body:
Throw out the glasses and flush away the contact lenses. A radical new treatment that cures short-sightedness while people sleep is set to give them perfect vision during the day.

The technique requires people to wear special lenses overnight. These are harder than normal contact lenses, and work by temporarily reshaping the eye, restoring normal vision. For some people, wearing the lenses only once every two or three nights may be enough to correct their vision the rest of the time.

The technique, known as 'orthokeratology' is undergoing safety trials but the lenses are expected to go on general sale within a few years.

Joseph Barr, professor of optometry at Ohio State University, who ran a recent two-month trial of the lenses, said: 'Wearing these lenses overnight is an effective way to temporarily reduce myopia,' he said.

At the moment, the only option for people needing eyesight correction is to undergo refractive surgery. This uses either a laser or a knife to permanently reshape the cornea but it is usually unavailable on the NHS, and can cost up to £1,000 per eye.

Surgery is also irreversible, and in a small percentage of cases the operation is unsuccessful and more major, corrective surgery is needed.

Professor Barr said: 'When the participants took the lenses out, their corneas were shaped like they had undergone refractive surgery. If a patient discontinues wearing these lenses, their vision will regress to what it was.'

But the lenses may not work for everyone. So far they have mainly been tested on people with moderate short-sightedness and without astigmatism.

fields.headline: International news in brief
fields.body:
Indian pardons raise hopes of jailed Briton

India's decision to pardon five aircrew from Russia and Latvia has kindled hope that their co-accused, former British Army officer Peter Bleach, will be freed. The six were sentenced to life imprisonment in February for their role in an arms drop over eastern India in 1995.

Kohl faces modest fine

German prosecutors investigating former Chancellor Helmut Kohl for his role in a party financing scandal will fine him £30,000, according to Der Spiegel . They say any breach of trust has been offset by his attempts to set things right.

Broke Burundi shuts embassies

A severe shortage of money has forced Burundi, in crisis because of civil war and economic sanctions, to close its embassies in Kenya, Uganda, Sweden, Britain and Italy.

Waco deaths blamed on cult

The blame for the catastrophe at Waco that killed 80 people in 1993 rests solely with Branch Davidian cult leader David Koresh, US special counsel John Danforth has concluded after a 10-month investigation.

Haider met by protests on mission to Venice

Noisy protests greeted Austrian far-right leader Jörg Haider when he arrived in Venice to promote tourism in the state of Carinthia, where he is governor. About 150 police guarded the building.

Bomb at Bangladesh rally

A large bomb was found hidden yards from where the Bangladesh Prime Minister, Sheikh Hasina, was due to address a rally in her home town of Tungipara. It was made safe and three people were arrested.

Foxy thief with shoe fetish

Playful fox cubs top the list of suspects in the mysterious disappearance of some 50 shoes in the Swiss village of Zeglingen, west of Zurich.

More Disney

A third Disney theme park in California is to be built next to the 45-year-old Disneyland.

Search ends

The search ended for bodies in the ruins of a clothing factory that caught fire in Alexandria. Twenty-one people died.

Tourist decline

Due to crises in Fiji and the Solomon Islands, tourism is declining, say operators in 13 South Pacific islands.

Titanic jewels sinking fast

Divers searching the wreck of the Titanic for diamonds said they were racing against time because it is rapidly deteriorating. Their priority is first class registered mail.

Olympic scam

Tom Welch, 55, and David Johnson, 41, of Salt Lake City have been indicted by a Grand Jury for allegedly carrying out an enormous cash-for-votes campaign to lure the 2002 Winter Olympic Games to Utah.

India in control

India, home to a billion people, is to set up a fund to promote family planning programmes aimed at stabilising its population in two decades.

They say any breach of trust has been offset by his attempts to set things right. Broke Burundi shuts embassies A severe shortage of money has forced Burundi, in crisis because of civil war and economic sanctions, to close its embassies in Kenya, Uganda, Sweden, Britain and Italy. Waco deaths blamed on cult The blame for the catastrophe at Waco that killed 80 people in 1993 rests solely with Branch Davidian cult leader David Koresh, US special counsel John Danforth has concluded after a 10-month investigation. About 150 police guarded the building. It was made safe and three people were arrested. Search ends The search ended for bodies in the ruins of a clothing factory that caught fire in Alexandria. Twenty-one people died. Their priority is first class registered mail. India in control India, home to a billion people, is to set up a fund to promote family planning programmes aimed at stabilising its population in two decades.

fields.headline: French farce at super hospital
fields.trailText: It has been called the hospital of the future. Not only the biggest, shiniest 827-bed model of its kind, but - this being France - a new concept in health care. There's just one problem: there are no patients.
fields.byline: David Hearst in Paris and Amy Lodge
fields.body:
It has been called the hospital of the future. Not only the biggest, shiniest 827-bed model of its kind, but - this being France - a new concept in health care. There's just one problem: there are no patients.

The problems of transferring patients from three feeder hospitals and merging more than 5,000 medical staff into one integrated team have so far proved too much.

The theory is superb. Services are clustered in groups so that the specialist comes to the patient, rather than the other way round. You can arrive at any one of 22 different reception points and be met by a personal hostess, who will guide you to your private room, where the computer is at the bottom of the bed, case notes exist in cyberspace and robots carry out operations. It has swimming pools, health clubs and cafes.

The director of the European Hospital Georges Pompidou (HEGP) calls what is taking place in South-west Paris nothing less than a revolution. Equally modestly, the architect calls it 'a place of light and transparency'. Palm trees sway in the internal breeze created by a 220-yard stretch of glass-topped, marble-lined galleria. Escalators lead to the patients' rooms, arrows point to the operating theatres.

Two years late, 20 years in the gestation and consuming a budget of £130 million every 18 months even with no patients, the HEGP has had a painful birth. Opened earlier this month after many delays, the first in-patient does not arrive until tomorrow. It will be the middle of next year before it functions fully.

Three big hospitals and 5,000 staff serving a region of 570,000 people have to be merged into one. More than 1,350 of the employees will be switched to other hospitals in Paris, and 412 beds will be cut. A transfer on this scale has never before been achieved in Europe.

With a drill gnawing away somewhere beneath his feet, Louis Omnès, the hospital director, said: 'A delay like this is normal. We are leaving behind the entire world of medicine as it is practised in Paris, where the consultant was the diva, and we are bearing witness to a revolution.' As he speaks of his computer problems, you can feel his ambitions receding.

Back in the worn but friendly corridors of Boucicault hospital, one of the three facing closure, Professor Clement of the radiology department was caught midway in the giant patient transfer. The sister hospital Broussais, with whom his department has had to share equipment, has moved into the HEGP, although only for out-patients, but Boucicault still awaits the furniture vans.

Clement says: 'With one hospital moved and two waiting to go, it has become a bit crazy. Our staff have had to put off non-urgent patients, so we've had an overall deceleration of activity.'

There is no doubt that the HEGP is a grand gesture. Omnès wants to create a genuinely decentralised super hospital where multidisciplinary teams move around the patient rather than the other way round. The idea is to create a hospital where the beds have real room service.

But critics of the delay and the cost claim he is aiming too high. The name Pompidou bears unfortunate associations with other grand presidential gestures - like the gleaming tubular arts centre near Les Halles, reopened last year following complete refurbishment only 22 years after it opened.

And not everyone agrees that the attempt to reorganise a century of medical practice will work. The surgeons wanted more room than their neighbours, and not every team wanted to merge.

'The cardios of Broussais, those who did spectacular crafts, managed to protect their territory. So they will be the kings of the new unit,' said a surgeon at Laennec, the third of the three hospitals to be closed.

As doctors and administrators finish their lunch and disappear to their patient-free consulting rooms, the galleria empties. A group of workers wolf-whistle a passing girl. A nurse complains: 'I don't even have a chair to sit on.'

But why hurry? It may be some time before she sees a patient.

fields.headline: A nation fed by monkey and 'roadkill'
fields.standfirst: Children in the street sell run-over groundhogs to Liberia's desperately hungry poor. But the wheeler-dealers live in style, writes Jason Burke in Monrovia
fields.trailText: It was about two feet long and hairy, with two sharp incisors protruding from its mouth and a tail like a rubber cable. Luckily, a large proportion of its brains lay spread over the road a few feet away. Not that Moses - who is holding it up by its hind legs for the scrutiny of oncoming traffic - was particularly bothered. At least the blood congealing on the tarmac proved that his groundhog was freshly killed. And that makes a big difference when you are selling roadkill.
fields.body:
It was about two feet long and hairy, with two sharp incisors protruding from its mouth and a tail like a rubber cable. Luckily, a large proportion of its brains lay spread over the road a few feet away. Not that Moses - who is holding it up by its hind legs for the scrutiny of oncoming traffic - was particularly bothered. At least the blood congealing on the tarmac proved that his groundhog was freshly killed. And that makes a big difference when you are selling roadkill.

Liberia is not a wealthy place. Neighbouring Sierra Leone is supposed to be the poorest place in the world, but Liberia must run it close. When there's a thriving market for run-over rodent, you know a country is in trouble.

Liberia has been in trouble for a long time. The brutal civil war that tore it apart in the Nineties is over, but the legacy of nearly 200 years of misrule is apparent. The markets are full of shoddy goods and wizened vegetables - which no one buys; the hotels are full of whores, arms dealers and diamond traders - whom no one regulates; the corridors of power are full of ex-killers and conmen - whom no one is likely to depose soon. Along with roadkill, monkey is a common source of meat. Most livestock was eaten long ago.

But there's no shortage at the Mambo Point Hotel. The shady wheeler-dealers, the United Nations consultants and, indeed, the visiting journalists who pay their $110 a night for air-conditioning and hot water, expect a decent club sandwich and steak and chips. But the hotel's location makes up for the company. If you can see past the leather stetsons of the American diamond dealers and the pot-bellies of the South African 'freelance military advisers', then you'll make out a wonderful view: the long, steady swell of the Atlantic, as grey as the North Sea under a sky thick with rain. Sweeping round the bay lies the battered, shell-pocked city of Monrovia which, in the early morning, emerges from the mist like an old boxer coming down to breakfast after a night's drinking.

Next to the hotel is an old colonial mansion, set back on a rise above the rubbish-strewn beach. The faces of the two stone lions that flank the 30-step staircase leading to the main entrance have been worn smooth by 150 years of storms and spray. The house was built by one of Liberia's first grandees - the descendants of slaves freed from their plantations in America and shipped to West Africa by philanthropists in 1822.

Unfortunately, the do-gooders forgot that plenty of people already lived along the 'slave coast'. When the freed slaves landed, they enthusiastically started replicating the lifestyle of their erstwhile masters. They built houses like those of the plantation owners they once worked for. They developed women's fashions - long dresses with ruffles and frills - based on that of the Southern gentry. And, most ironic of all, they set about enslaving the indigenous population.

The house next to the Mambo Point Hotel - it is known as the Webah Hospital locally, as it once housed Monrovia's terminally ill - is home to around 200 people. At the foot of the steps is a shack made of bamboo and planks of wood. It's here that the men gather to drink beer, if they can afford it, and smoke fabulously potent local ganja, when they can't.

The school holidays are on, so a horde of ragged children in oversized flip-flops runs up and down the steps, playing football and shrieking.

Jakey David stands watching the children play. His own family - seven strong - live in a single room in the house. For that he pays 700 Liberian dollars - around £15 - a month. 'It's an injustice,' he says. 'It keeps the rain out, but there is nothing else. There are always tribulations.' Jakey makes his living washing the bright, white, luxury Landcruisers that the diplomats and the aid workers drive. But now it is the rainy season there is little demand for his services.

Inside the house it is very dark and there is a smell of unwashed bodies and old fat. Water comes from a nearby stream and is boiled up on charcoal braziers by women wrapped in colourful if faded lengths of printed cotton.

Tony is a sharp 17-year-old. But for his mournful eyes he would be the classic teenage hustler. He brought us up to the house, past the faceless lions and a ferocious dog, and guided us through its labyrinthine floors. He wants to earn money to go back to school, so we give him a fistful of Liberian dollars and ask him about his plans. His brown eyes grow deeper, wider and sadder than ever. 'Just keep moving,' he says. 'Just keep moving.'

fields.headline: General on mass murder charge
fields.standfirst: Sri Lankan trial to establish responsibility for torture and killing of left-wing rebels
fields.trailText: One of the  dirtiest chapters in Sri Lanka's brutal recent history is to be revisited this week when a retired general appears in court charged with running death squads and torture chambers used against thousands of left-wing rebels.
fields.body:
One of the dirtiest chapters in Sri Lanka's brutal recent history is to be revisited this week when a retired general appears in court charged with running death squads and torture chambers used against thousands of left-wing rebels.

Major General Ananada Weerasekera faces trial for murder, abduction and unlawful detention, amid accusations that his prosecution is a plot to discredit him by a paranoid government three months before elections.

The charges, which he denies, relate to the late Eighties, when Sri Lanka was convulsed by a Marxist uprising in the South led by the Janatha Vimukthi Peramuna (JVP), or People's Liberation Party. A terrified regime gave army officers carte blanche to use any methods to crush the insurrection. Between 30,000 and 100,000 people were killed or disappeared in a bloody campaign of state-approved terror. Mutilated bodies were dumped in streets and rivers.

Weerasekera, then a brigadier, was in charge of Sri Lanka's north-east province, with his headquarters at the ancient city of Anuradhapura. One of his alleged crimes was to oversee a torture chamber and illegal detention camp close to the city's 2,000-year-old sacred Bo-tree, which is revered by Sri Lanka's Buddhist Sinhalese majority. The tree came from a sapling of the original tree under which the Buddha sat to gain enlightenment.

His supporters reject the accusations as a slur. They say the general has been singled out because of his oppo sition to President Chandrika Kumaratunga and her ruling People's Alliance party.

Weerasekera is known as a hard-line Sinhalese activist, associated with a new political group, the Sihala Urumaya, which threatens Kumaratunga in October's elections and may emerge holding the balance of power.

'The trial seems to be politically motivated. And it is difficult to prove charges against high-ranking army officers,' Jehan Pereira, of the National Peace Council said. 'Many of them are involved in the fight against the LTTE [Tamil Tigers], which makes it hard to prosecute them without demoralising the army.

'During the JVP rebellion there was an atmosphere of licence. There was no accountability. Human rights abuses were widespread.'

Weerasekera was arrested last Wednesday. Two of his subordinates, Sergeants Nimal Nugawela and Loku Gunasekera, also face trial and are due to appear in court on 31 July.

The trial was ordered by Sri Lanka's attorney general after a state-appointed commission of inquiry had uncovered evidence linking the general - and many others - to the deaths and disappearances of JVP members.

'He certainly doesn't look like a killer,' one senior military source said last night. 'He is not a gung-ho type. He is very charming.'

During the JVP's first 1971 attempt to topple the government, 10,000 of its supporters were killed or disappeared. The party, which has since rejoined mainstream politics, estimates 60,000 of its members died during the 1987-89 revolt, which also saw the JVP kill hundreds of political opponents and government officials. In Jaffna, which the army retook from the Tamil Tigers in 1996, 600 Tamils suddenly vanished. A mass grave containing 16 bodies was exhumed last year.

Amnesty International last night welcomed the general's arrest. 'Those against whom there is sufficient evidence of their involvement in human rights violations should be tried,' a spokesman said. 'Sri Lanka is at a crucial juncture in dealing with its experience of "disappearances" and putting an end to this pernicious and persistent violation that has for so long wrecked the lives of so many people.'

webTitle: America in jaws of fear as rattlesnakes get more bite

fields.headline: America in jaws of fear as rattlesnakes get more bite
fields.standfirst: Deaths rise as venom of previously 'harmless' types turns potent
fields.trailText: It was meant to reveal the strength of the young minister's fundamental beliefs. But when the Alabama cleric picked up the timber rattlesnake in front of the congregation of his baptist sect, the reptile promptly bit him. Within 10 minutes the man was dead.
fields.body:
It was meant to reveal the strength of the young minister's fundamental beliefs. But when the Alabama cleric picked up the timber rattlesnake in front of the congregation of his baptist sect, the reptile promptly bit him. Within 10 minutes the man was dead.

The minister's demise, in 1998, may not seem surprising, or particularly undeserved. Nevertheless doctors were startled, for the timber rattlesnake does not normally kill.

Despite its fearsome reputation, rattlesnakes - of which there are 70 subspecies in the United States - rarely deliver fatal bites: on average only one in 500 of their human victims has died in the past. People have lost toes or fingers, but few perished, particularly after the development of anti-venom made from horse serum.

But now that comforting picture is changing - for something strange is hap pening to America's rattler population. The ability to deliver life-threatening bites, once restricted to only a few subspecies like the deadly Mojave rattler, has been spreading rapidly.

Like the opening scenes of a cheap horror movie, bizarre deaths and near-fatal encounters with rattlesnakes - which normally only bite when hunting rodents or in self-defence - have been occurring with increasing frequency. For example, in Hesperia, California, an 18-year-old collector was bitten last year as he tried to grab a local southern Pacific rattler, another relatively harmless member of the species. Within minutes, he was paralysed, unable to breathe or swallow properly. It took 35 vials of anti-venom to save his life.

At around the same time, in Florida, an army ranger stopped breathing only 13 minutes after being bitten by a timber rattlesnake. He was resuscitated and survived, although it required 40 vials of anti-venom - four times the usual dose - to save him. The American rattler is behaving very strangely, in other words. Its bite is not what it used to be.

'Doctors must now use much more anti-venom to treat bites,' states Steve Grenard, of Staten Island University Hospital, in the latest issue of Natural History . 'Whereas five to 10 vials used to suffice, patients today don't seem to improve until they have been injected with between 30 and 70.'

But why? Some scientists argue that America is simply witnessing the rapid molecular evolution of the rattlesnake. Hybrids of two species are being created at the borders of their separate ranges, and the ability to deliver powerful neurotoxin bites is being passed from the more deadly species to the formerly less harmful one, in a manner analagous to the spread of antibiotic resistance among bacteria. In this way, increased venom toxicity is spreading west from Arizona, and east to Texas and Florida.

Not every researcher agrees, however. Scientists at the University of California, Davis, point to a very different agent: the ground squirrel, one of the rattlesnake's traditional meals. Recent studies of this creature have shown that it has evolved an enzyme defence system which can break down rattler venom in its blood.

Studies of rattlers' other rodent prey have shown they, too, have evolved anti-venom defences - thus triggering an arms race. To overcome their prey evolving more and more effective anti-venom defences, rattlers have simply developed more and more deadly venom.

But again, other scientists disagree. Squirrels and other rodents still get eaten in large numbers by rattlers, they say. Instead, this group of researchers point to a very different cause: human beings.

Younger and smaller snakes are known to have more toxic bites than mature rattlers - because they simply cannot inject as much venom as their elders, and so have to make less go further. At the same time, rattler round-ups, like those held every year in Sweetwater, Texas, are depleting populations of mature reptiles. Thousands of large, adult rattlesnakes are killed, leaving smaller, younger snakes - the ones with the more toxic venom - to take over the wild where they can then bite the hands of those that persecute them.

Some scientists argue that America is simply witnessing the rapid molecular evolution of the rattlesnake. Hybrids of two species are being created at the borders of their separate ranges, and the ability to deliver powerful neurotoxin bites is being passed from the more deadly species to the formerly less harmful one, in a manner analagous to the spread of antibiotic resistance among bacteria. In this way, increased venom toxicity is spreading west from Arizona, and east to Texas and Florida. Not every researcher agrees, however. Scientists at the University of California, Davis, point to a very different agent: the ground squirrel, one of the rattlesnake's traditional meals. Recent studies of this creature have shown that it has evolved an enzyme defence system which can break down rattler venom in its blood. Studies of rattlers' other rodent prey have shown they, too, have evolved anti-venom defences - thus triggering an arms race. To overcome their prey evolving more and more effective anti-venom defences, rattlers have simply developed more and more deadly venom. But again, other scientists disagree. Squirrels and other rodents still get eaten in large numbers by rattlers, they say. Instead, this group of researchers point to a very different cause: human beings. Younger and smaller snakes are known to have more toxic bites than mature rattlers - because they simply cannot inject as much venom as their elders, and so have to make less go further. At the same time, rattler round-ups, like those held every year in Sweetwater, Texas, are depleting populations of mature reptiles. Thousands of large, adult rattlesnakes are killed, leaving smaller, younger snakes - the ones with the more toxic venom - to take over the wild where they can then bite the hands of those that persecute them.

webTitle: SAS founder was a Nazi sympathiser

fields.headline: SAS founder was a Nazi sympathiser
fields.standfirst: New book reveals how a great patriotic hero was seduced by pre-war Germany
fields.trailText: He was one of Britain's bravest wartime heroes and co-founded the lethally effective SAS. Without Lieutenant Jock Lewes, history would have been very different. But shocking revelations in a new book could change for ever the way he is remembered.
fields.body:
He was one of Britain's bravest wartime heroes and co-founded the lethally effective SAS. Without Lieutenant Jock Lewes, history would have been very different. But shocking revelations in a new book could change for ever the way he is remembered.

The discovery of more than 450 letters, written by Lewes to his parents between 1924 and 1941 and left forgotten in a garage for more than half a century, has revealed that Lewes visited Berlin regularly in the years leading up to the Second World War and developed strong sympathies with the National Socialists.

The letters, which are contemptuous of British politicians, reveal that Lewes almost married a member of the Nazi party and was vehemently opposed to Britain's pre-war antipathy to Germany, arguing that the British should have backed Germany in the First World War.

The content of the letters is so at odds with Lewes's patriotic wartime persona that some military historians have suggested his early behaviour may have been a front and that Lewes may have been a government agent.

Other experts have speculated that his pro-Nazi past explains why Lewes, unlike David Stirling, commanding officer of the early SAS, was never properly feted for his contributions to the war effort, despite Stirling's admission that 'Jock Lewes could far more genuinely claim to be the founder of the SAS than I'.

John Lewes, the soldier's nephew and author of Jock Lewes, Co-founder of the SAS, to be published this week, discovered the letters in his aunt's outhouse. 'The revelations in those letters came as a complete surprise,' he said. 'Jock's pro-Nazi and anti-British convictions were so firmly held and passionately expressed that at one point I was concerned my uncle had been an out-and-out Nazi.'

Lewes first visited Germany in the summer of 1935, on a cycling trip. He was 22, dissatisfied with his studies at Oxford and having doubts about his planned military career. He was impressed by German students and their arguments against the Versailles Treaty, and wrote to his parents detailing the restrictions it placed on the lives of his new friends. 'England is no democracy and Germany far from being a totalitarian state,' he wrote.

His nephew said: 'Jock very quickly began to despair of Britain and France's attitude towards Germany. He disagreed with the democratic powers that enabled them to openly criticise the Nazis whom he saw working to improve the lives of his friends.'

When Lewes returned to England two months later, he brought with him a Hitler Youth knife. The following year he organised a visit with his rowing fraternity to the Berlin Olympic Games. He wrote letters home singing the praises of Germany and refused to back his rowing group's anti-Nazi activities.

'My uncle fell for the grandeur, the permanency and respectability of the new regime and failed to notice or criticise the encroaching anti-Semitic tendencies of the era,' said his nephew.

'Jock was absolutely besotted by his Nazi girlfriend and was flirting with the Socialist way. He was aware that there was propaganda around intended to dazzle him but he was seriously taken with the ideas of the Nazi party too.'

In 1938 Jock Lewes attended a ball attended by Hitler and Goebbels. 'My uncle shook hands with Nazis who almost certainly had blood under their fingernails, and he did so before the blood was dry,' said his nephew.

He wrote to his parents that England had 'backed the wrong horse in the First World War' and criticised England's politicians, calling them 'braying parliamentarians'. His loyalty to Germany continued until November 1938, when Kristallnacht forced him to realise the real objectives of the Nazi party.

'I have been struggling to believe or rather retain my belief in German sincerity but only a fanatic faith could withstand the evidence they choose of their own free will to put before us,' he wrote to his parents. 'I have great faith in Britain and I swear I will not live to see the day when Britain hauls down the colours of her beliefs before totalitarian aggression.'

Lewes's disillusionment with Germany turned to bitterness. He broke off all contact with his fiancée. 'I shall willingly take up arms against Germany, almost gladly,' he wrote.

In 1940, Jock travelled to the Middle East and, along with Stirling, Paddy Mayne and Georges Bergé, founded the SAS. He died in Libya at the end of 1941 following a daring operation.

Former SAS sergeant and author Andy McNab admitted he had never heard about Lewes's flirtation with Nazi Germany. 'This is going to be a bit of a shock for a lot of people,' he said.

webTitle: Speaker's exit fuels battle for new Blair Babes

fields.headline: Speaker's exit fuels battle for new Blair Babes
fields.trailText: Betty Boothroyd's decision to step down as an MP and as Speaker of the Commons has prompted a bitter struggle for her seat, pitting Blair's Babes against the male-dominated Labour bureaucracy.
fields.body:
Betty Boothroyd's decision to step down as an MP and as Speaker of the Commons has prompted a bitter struggle for her seat, pitting Blair's Babes against the male-dominated Labour bureaucracy.

Women MPs are determined that a female should inherit her plum seat as a signal of Labour's seriousness about feminising Parliament. Valerie Vaz, sister of the Foreign Office Minister, Keith, is the leading female contender to emerge so far for the West Bromwich West seat, and Labour's Millbank headquarters is seeking others.

But Vaz will face a stiff challenge from the unions' 'favoured son', Tom Watson, the well-liked political officer of the AEEU, who is close to several New Labour movers and shakers.

The battle for Boothroyd's successor is heightened not only because it will be a high-profile by-election, but because fewer than one in six of those new Labour candidates so far selected for the next general election is a woman, the same figure as for the Tories, once decried by the Left as sexist.

One Labour Party source said: 'Given the difficulties we are having getting women for Labour seats, here is a chance for the NEC to put their money where their mouth is.

'The normal run of constituency selections are not turning up women. This would be a very good way of sending a signal - Betty is one of the most celebrated women in British politics, and a worthy successor might well be another woman.'

Harriet Harman, the ex-Minister who recently produced a pamphlet on women voters, said: 'The evidence we have found is overwhelmingly that women voters don't think it is fair if only men are in Parliament. They want more women MPs.

'Clearly there is discrimination going on, as nobody can say that the women don't want to be selected or are not as good. At the moment it is not a meritocracy, and we have to redress that.'

The mass influx of 101 'Blair Babes' in 1997 was fuelled by all-women shortlists forcing constituencies to pick females, but these were then ruled unlawful on sex discrimination grounds.

This time round, out of 104 new selections - seats where the MP is standing down or there is no sitting Labour MP - only 16 are women, while the Tories have picked 44 women out of 280. Not all seats have selected.

Although the Tories could still boast only a handful of female MPs, even if all their best female contenders got in, Harman believes it is not enough for Labour to compare itself to their historically-poor record.

Meanwhile, according to calculations made by women MPs and passed on to Sally Morgan, the Prime Minister's political secretary, heavy losses in the next election would sway gender balance back towards men.

If Labour's majority is cut by fewer than 80 seats, proportionally more men would disappear than women.

But if up to 120 seats were lost, it could end up with a ratio of one woman MP to every four men, compared with the current one woman to every three.

Boothroyd, who will this week make her farewell speech to the Commons, is stepping down in October.

fields.headline: Juggernauts take over 'by stealth'
fields.standfirst: The hidden threat in Prescott's road plans
fields.trailText: Designer Christine Shine's garden is as large and flat as a croquet lawn and should be a haven of tranquillity in her picturesque Cotswolds village with its Norman church, leafy lanes and wild deer.
fields.body:
Designer Christine Shine's garden is as large and flat as a croquet lawn and should be a haven of tranquillity in her picturesque Cotswolds village with its Norman church, leafy lanes and wild deer.

But every few seconds the view is spoilt by yet another high-sided juggernaut thundering down the nearby dual carriageway. The noise drowns out the birdsong and drives her complaining indoors, even in sunshine.

Shine is a victim of road-building by stealth. What was once a single carriageway through the heart of the Cotswolds has been turned surreptitiously in less than a decade - via a series of bypasses and 'safety measures' - into a virtual motorway carrying nine million vehicles a year.

There are now widespread fears that last week's government announcement of £59 billion to be spent on roads over the next decade amounts to a covert plan for new traffic arteries spreading tar over miles of countryside in the name of 'road improvements'.

Shine, 52 said, 'They don't talk about road-building now. They talk about a bypass here, a hotspot or safety measure there, all in little packages to get past the planners and avoid the protesters.

'But before you know it, these innocent-sounding "improvements" have linked up and you have a virtual motorway passing your door. That is what happened here.'

When Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott admitted last week that Britain's transport system is in crisis and announced total spending of £180bn, there were huge windfalls for trains, buses and trams to cut congestion and pollution by 2010.

But there was also news to placate the motoring lobby. Prescott promised no new roads, apart from the controversial Birmingham Northern Relief toll road scheme, but he pledged cash to build 100 more bypasses and widen 360 miles of motorway.

The lobby group Transport 2000 agrees some local schemes will provide genuine relief for towns and villages marred by heavy traffic.

But widening schemes for the M6, M1 and M62 in the North, the M42 in the Midlands and the M25 around London, along with the revival of plans to bypass Salisbury, Hastings and Hereford, are highly controversial.

And those who masterminded the 'eco war' that brought Swampy to fame in the Nineties protests against road schemes warn that some of the innocuous-sounding bypass proposals amount to roadbuilding by stealth.

Shine's village, Elkstone, is five minutes from the A417 and A419 that link Gloucester with Cirencester and Swindon through an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty. In 12 years a staccato of plans labelled as village bypasses, inter-urban links and safety improvements have turned this normal A-road into a roaring 25-mile freight freeway and commuter short cut.

From as far as Belfast and Barcelona lorries use the road as a link between the M5 and M4 on their way to and from the Channel ports. A widening in 1997 attracted thousands of extra commuters who can now get from Swindon to Birmingham in an hour. They 'rat-run' through tiny villages to get to the dual carriageway.

Giant, motorway-style signs have been erected on the skyline; the Little Chef has been redesignated 'Services'. Pedestrians, buses and bicycles have almost gone, leaving lorries, vans and cars.

'Village life has been completely blighted. People cannot ride their horses without getting honked at, villagers cannot stop in the street for a chat or let their children ride their bikes in the lanes anymore,' said Shine.

Yet the scale of this major traffic artery was never put to a public inquiry. The fear now is that this is what the Government intends by talking of 'road improvements', as opposed to road-building.

Prescott announced the money, but the bypasses need approval under local transport plans and 'multi-modal' studies, under which Labour has promised to consult. It is also pledged to ban road schemes where better public transport would do the job.

So why, ask campaigners, has he already promised the money and pledged to cut the roads planning process from an average of 10 years to six?

Tony Bosworth, of Friends of the Earth, said: 'We are worried Prescott will adopt the Tories' devious methods of expanding the road network.'

One group which disbanded after the last election, thinking its mission was accomplished, unofficially re-formed a fortnight ago. Alarm UK mobilised community groups nationally in the Nineties and allied them with the forces of non-violent direct action to create an unprecedented show of force against road-building.

John Stewart, its former chairman, told The Observer this weekend that the group is ready for Prescott's new schemes. 'The direct action people tell us that this time they will attack the construction firms and the banks that back these schemes. They will target their HQs and shareholders, occupy the chairman's office and sit-in.'

Shine is not the sit-in type, but she said: 'John Prescott has the right ideas about reducing traffic and boosting public transport, I just hope he has the guts to stick by them. Otherwise this Government's transport policy is on a road to nowhere.'

The routes to protest

The plans most likely to bring Swampy out of retirement are:

 Bypasses for Salisbury, Hastings and Hereford.

 'Improvements', such as widening, inter-urban linking, safety measures and bypasses that link to form new traffic arteries for:

 The South Coast, from the Channel Tunnel to Devon, via Portsmouth (involving the A259, the A27 and A35).

 A South-west link to Bristol (M4 and M5) from Southampton/ Weymouth (A36, A37).

 A South-east to South-west artery across Salisbury Plain (A303).

 A link in East Anglia from Norwich to the M11 near Cambridge (A11).

 Penrith to Scotch Corner on the A1 (A66).

 Yorkshire Dales, Aire Valley, Leeds to the Lake District (A65).

webTitle: Doctors move to employ maggots in NHS

fields.headline: Doctors move to employ maggots in NHS
fields.trailText: Placing up to 150 live maggots in an open wound and leaving them to feed for three days may not be most patients' first choice of medical care. But a study to be published tomorrow will reveal that larval therapy is the most efficient and cost-effective method of wound treatment available.
fields.body:
Placing up to 150 live maggots in an open wound and leaving them to feed for three days may not be most patients' first choice of medical care. But a study to be published tomorrow will reveal that larval therapy is the most efficient and cost-effective method of wound treatment available.

The study is the first to compare larval therapy with modern treatments and its findings are so conclusive it has been hailed as an important milestone in the struggle to get the technique accepted.

Specialists at the West Cumberland Hospital found that 100 per cent of the infected and festering ulcers treated with larval therapy were clean and healthy after a single application of maggots. By contrast, two-thirds of the patients given more conventional therapy were still in hospital for treatment one month after the initial application.

The study also found that hydrogel therapy using conventional antiseptics was almost twice as expensive as larval therapy. The average cost of larval treatment was £78.64, compared with £136.23 for the hydrogel therapy.

'This was a very small study, but the results were so amazingly conclusive that we're preparing to use it as the first piece of concrete evidence in the fight to get larval therapy approved in mainstream medicine,' said Michael Walker, a consultant surgeon at the hospital.

'One of the problems is that the medical profession is a deeply conservative group unwilling to try new things, but this study can help us shout about the efficiency of this treatment,' he said.

Maggots were commonly used to clean infected wounds during the American Civil War, but the practice ended after antibiotics were discovered in the Forties.

The insidious advance of potentially fatal, antibiotic-resistant superbugs, such as methicillin-resistant staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), and the flesh-eating bug that causes necrotising fasciitis, has led scientists to look elsewhere for treatments.

'These results demonstrate that the application of sterile maggots can remove dead and festering tissue more effectively than conventional medicines, enabling the wounds to heal safely while eliminating MRSA from wounds that have failed to respond to other treatments,' said Stephen Thomas, director of the biosurgical research unit at the Surgical Materials Testing Laboratory at the Princess of Wales Hospital in Bridgend, Wales, the only commercial facility producing sterile fly larvae in Britain.

'Maggots eat pus, infections, bacteria and rotting flesh while avoiding healthy flesh altogether,' he said. But because larval therapy is not on the list of drugs and treatments which GPs can prescribe, it is not available to patients in the community.

The therapy could save the NHS up to £2 million a year.

www.smtl.co.uk For the Surgical Materials Testing Laboratory.

'These results demonstrate that the application of sterile maggots can remove dead and festering tissue more effectively than conventional medicines, enabling the wounds to heal safely while eliminating MRSA from wounds that have failed to respond to other treatments,' said Stephen Thomas, director of the biosurgical research unit at the Surgical Materials Testing Laboratory at the Princess of Wales Hospital in Bridgend, Wales, the only commercial facility producing sterile fly larvae in Britain. 'Maggots eat pus, infections, bacteria and rotting flesh while avoiding healthy flesh altogether,' he said. But because larval therapy is not on the list of drugs and treatments which GPs can prescribe, it is not available to patients in the community. The therapy could save the NHS up to £2 million a year. Links www.tvs.org.uk For the Tissue Viability Society's website. www.smtl.co.uk For the Surgical Materials Testing Laboratory.

webTitle: Clintons unite in denial of racism

fields.headline: Clintons unite in denial of racism
fields.trailText: Sources  at the White House and on Hillary Clinton's staff have told  The Observer that claims the First Lady made an anti-Semitic comment are part of a 'dirty war' run by Rupert Murdoch's empire.
fields.body:
Sources at the White House and on Hillary Clinton's staff have told The Observer that claims the First Lady made an anti-Semitic comment are part of a 'dirty war' run by Rupert Murdoch's empire.

The allegation surfaced in three Murdoch-related sources, and seemed to appear just in time to hurt both Mrs Clinton's campaign for the New York State Senate seat and the Middle East Peace process.

The First Lady has denied that she called campaign volunteer Paul Fray a 'Jew bastard' in 1974, after her husband's unsuccessful Congressional run. The allegation will appear in a book by Jerry Oppenheimer, well-known author of scurrilous works.

In the book, published by Murdoch's Harper Collins, he describes the Clinton marriage as 'a power-hungry, unholy alliance'.

Earlier David Brock, a former hardline right-winger who wrote initial accounts of the Paula Jones scandal, conducted 'lengthy interviews' with Fray for a book about Hillary. But, he says Fray made no mention of the anti-Semitic slur.

The allegation appeared on the website of Matt Drudge, a former Murdoch employee who also broke the Lewinsky scandal.

The story then ran in Murdoch's New York Post , which has been opposed to Hillary's political aspirations.

The remark was also denied by Bill Clinton himself in the Post's rival, the New York Daily News, sparking an issue war between the titles.

Fray wrote to Mrs Clinton three years ago, asking for forgiveness, saying he had acted 'without thinking, without foundation and without rhyme or remedy unless it furthered my own agenda'.

Fray suffered a cerebral haemorrhage some years ago which, his wife now admits, has affected his memory.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst:
When Jeremiah Mulumba announced he was HIV-positive on Zambian TV, his community disowned him. Six years later, with the
   VSO's Kate Greenaway, he is still fighting the ignorance that surrounds the disease
fields.trailText:
When Jeremiah Mulumba announced he was HIV-positive on Zambian TV, his community disowned him. Six years later, with the
   VSO's Kate Greenaway, he is still fighting the ignorance that surrounds the disease.
fields.body:
Jeremiah Mulumba
I went to be tested for HIV when I was 29 and wasn't shocked when it came back positive. I used to spend a lot of time in discos and shared ladies with my friends, many of whom had since contracted the disease. When I got the result, my first reaction was to blame myself for not using condoms. I stopped my job selling fish and two months later, while I was doing some courses in public speaking and counselling, I knew I had to tell people I was HIV-positive.

My family wanted me to keep quiet because of the embarrassment it would cause them. But I announced it anyway on a national television programme called Tell the Nation . The reaction was very negative. My family disowned me and I felt very isolated from the community. People would not come near me - they wouldn't even shake my hand. But I was determined to teach people about HIV and joined KARA, the counselling service I work for now.

Although Kate and I lead very different lives - she lives in the posh area of Lusaka and I live in a shantytown - we share the cause of HIV. I visit different communities to warn them about HIV and to share my personal experiences with them. I met Kate three years ago at a VSO orientation session, and now we often meet to exchange ideas and go to functions. I am the Lusaka representative for the Network of Zambian People with HIV and Aids, so I keep Kate up to date with the communities. She also has problems going into the shantytowns because she is white, so I collect information and provide her with contacts.

VSO has a big job to do and Kate is a very strong person. If more people were like her I think the face of HIV in Zambia would change. She helps me when I get frustrated and scared. I am just recovering from malaria and although I don't fear death I am afraid of what I will suffer before that. When I see lots of people dying, I often want to escape back to my village, but Kate stops me and tells me I am saving lives. Whenever I meet Kate I feel relieved - her advice is very practical.

We are making some progress here because more Zambians are going to be tested for HIV. We encourage people to assume they are HIV-positive before they are proved negative, and we want friends to go for a test together to help remove the stigma. We must prevent Zambia from following in the footsteps of Uganda, where Aids wiped the entire generation aged between 21 and 49. HIV is not a war you can fight on your own, but attitudes are starting to change.

Kate Greenaway
I didn't really appreciate the scale of Zambia's HIV problem until I had lived there for a few months. I arrived in Lusaka from Canada with my husband and son in 1997 to manage the volunteer programme run by VSO. I place British, Canadian and Dutch volunteers with Zambian employers and they work towards strengthening non-governmental organisations, improving education and agriculture and increasing awareness of HIV and Aids.

I met Jeremiah in 1997 when I attended my first induction course for incoming volunteers. Jeremiah was one of the first people in Zambia to declare publicly that he is HIV-positive, which was incredibly brave. Even though one in five Zambians have contracted HIV, there is a massive stigma attached to it and the illness is draining the country of its human resources. Women are compromised by Zambia's poverty and cultural gender divides, usually unable to say no to sex and often with nothing to sell but their bodies. And for the 80 per cent of Zambians who live in townships with no running water or electricity, sex is practically the only free entertainment they can get after dark. In the past 10 years 700,000 people have died.

After hearing Jeremiah speak that first time, I extended his session from 45 minutes to four and a half hours. The volunteers will read about HIV and Aids at home but Jeremiah is usually the first sufferer they will meet. He's an incredibly candid speaker and is willing to expose every aspect of his life to help convey the issues. He strings out these great stories to explain how Zambians get into trouble without safe sex, which leaves us with tears streaming down our faces. What I find so special about Jeremiah is his ability to laugh at himself - even at his illness.

When he found out he had TB last year, he found he couldn't tell anybody because it's often a quintessential sign of full-blown Aids. He came to see me and said, 'I can't believe what I've just done. I can tell the whole world I am HIV-positive but I can't tell them I've got TB'. And he stood there and he laughed. And then he went right out and started telling everybody the truth.

Jeremiah was diagnosed with HIV six years ago and it's hard to know whether he has Aids or not. He has survived longer than most sufferers because he works hard at staying healthy and is trying to develop himself as a role model. I try to keep him in good spirits although I know his death will be really hard for me, and I panic when I think of what our cause will lose.
