fields.headline: Taming toddlers
fields.standfirst: Liberal childcare is all the rage, but if you want a decent night's sleep, your baby needs routine and more routine.
fields.trailText: Liberal childcare is all the rage, but if you want a decent night's sleep, your baby needs routine and more routine.
fields.body:
For nine months, I'd occupied my mind with mere diversions - giving up whisky, avoiding goat's cheese, writing a birth plan (which basically read 'PLEASEGIMMEACAESAREAN'). Then one sunny day in April 1999, I was discharged from hospital (bent double by the scar) with a sleeping newborn in my arms. As we sped towards home in the back of a minicab, I realised with horror that I knew nothing about babies. I loved my nieces and nephews, of course, but not enough to change their nappies. I knew a few other mothers - but we'd never discussed the details of their days. For how long and how often should Ruby feed? When and where should she sleep? What happens if she wants to nap through the day and party the night away?

The advice from my health worker was reassuringly simple: 'Whatever.' The latest books from the Baby Gurus (Miriam Stoppard, Penelope Leach, the NCT) followed the same line. Whatever your baby wants. Feed on demand is the current vogue. Three in a bed is the in thing. Sleep when your baby does. Throw out the clock. Go with the flow... and don't even think about routine.

This is largely a backlash against the bad old days of baby care when mothers were instructed to put their babies on a rota. Feeds were every four hours regardless of hunger, babies slept alone in cots, and there was no harm in leaving the pram at the bottom of the garden if you wanted a few hours' peace. Today, this is tantamount to child abuse. Fitting your baby to a schedule, withholding food, forcing sleep in a darkened nursery will teach terror and isolation. Babies are not clockwork toys; they are quirky little people whose needs change hour to hour, day to day, night to night, whim by whim. So for the first year at least, it's goodbye to order, goodbye to unbroken sleep and goodbye to your life.

But does it have to be this way? Absolutely not, says Gina Ford, one of the world's top maternity nurses, who's waging a one-woman war against current thinking. Recently set in a ferocious head-to-head with the sweet Dr Miriam Stoppard on the Today programme, followed by hot debates in the press, Gina is currently making headlines as a hard-hearted, no-nonsense baby bully who believes that all little ones should be 'left to cry'.

This really misses the point. In fact, the opposite is the case. If you follow her advice, she claims, your baby will hardly cry at all. Having built a career tending to more than 300 newborns of the very rich and often famous (royalty, rock stars, actors), Gina has never failed to get her babies sleeping through the night within weeks of the birth - without a fight. None has ever had colic. They hardly ever cry. They eat well and sleep deeply.

Gina believes the reason for this is simple, and it all boils down to one - forbidden - word: routine. Last summer, her formula was set out in astonishing detail (with precise times for waking, napping, playing, feeding, adjusted every few weeks) and published by Vermilion ( The Contented Little Baby Book , £7.99). With little publicity and no promotion, her timetables have walked off the shelves and now divide mothers across the land. The internet hosts some of the debate where comments range from 'Nothing short of miraculous' and 'Brilliant'. 'For a happy baby that sleeps like a dream' to 'Put quite simply, this book encourages damaging, abusive behaviour towards babies'.

Shortly to be published in America by Penguin, Gina is now finishing off her second, a trouble-shooting book from birth to three years (for the mothers who failed to heed her advice first time round and now have toddlers who are fretful, milkaholic insomniacs). There is also a website and a TV series on the way, Gina's Babies , featuring Gina working her magic on troubled households across the country (a kind of Barbara Woodhouse meets Ground Force on babies).

Despite her recent run-in with Miriam, Gina believes that times are changing. 'Ten years ago, it was like working for the Secret Service,' says Gina, a large, laughing middle-aged lady from the Scottish borders who fell into the baby business while nannying as a student. 'All these desperate mothers were asking me to sort out their baby's sleep problems. What they meant was "could I get their baby into a routine", but we never used that word. It's only in the last few years that I've felt able to stand up and say, "I believe in routines." Because I've seen the consequences of not having one.'

Which isn't to say Gina supports the old four-hourly regime, either. 'I noticed a long time ago that it didn't suit babies' natural rhythms,' she says. So Gina started recording when her babies were tired, when they were hungry, when they were wide awake. 'It's been a gradual progression, but I'd say it's only in the last eight years that my routines have become perfect,' she says. 'For example, all young babies get sleepy within two hours of being awake - so they must be able to nap regularly. But if they are then allowed to sleep all day, they won't want to be put down and left at night. It's common sense.'

Feed times should be equally structured, says Gina, who believes 'colic' - that mystery curse which causes some babies to scream through the evening - is simply a result of feeding too often, and not leaving time to digest. Breastfed babies given constant 'top ups' will take lots of foremilk feeds (the watery stuff that comes first and whizzes through the system) and not enough hind-milk (which comes after a good long suck and is five time fattier and more filling).

This all sounded sensible enough, when I first read Gina's book (as Ruby suckled away at my breast for the 10th time in two hours). But back then, my girl was just eight weeks old, and I felt violently opposed to Gina's central premise that my special angel, who had good days and bad days, sleepy days and play days, was actually a clockwork toy who ran to the same rhythms as all the other babies on this planet. (How could she, when she was far more alert/ advanced/intelligent than any other?).

So I ditched the book and towed the lovable, liberal line. If Ruby cried, down came the bra. When she slept through the afternoon, we tiptoed round the house. If she was wide awake at 1am, my husband and I did shifts.

Two months later, we were all bleary-eyed basket cases. I can't recall when I decided to change tack. Perhaps it was the night Ruby woke me five times for a quick slurp. Or when I woke up myself, and practically choked trying to suppress a cough because I didn't want to disturb the sleeping princess slumped across my stomach.

In any case, at some point, I wanted a baby who didn't seem hungry all the time, who wasn't either over-tired or not nearly tired enough, and who (most importantly) slept through the night in her own room.

Back came the book, and slowly, gingerly, we tried easing Ruby in a more Gina-ly direction. By the time she was five months old, I had become (and remain) a routine freak, a tyrannical clockwatcher, a woman obsessed, a Gina Junky.

Other mothers look puzzled when I rush home for Ruby's lunchtime nap, and can't understand why I don't take her to dinner parties. (In the days when supermodels take their babies to premières, it's not very 21st century to leave yours at home with the sitter.) But the rewards are obvious. Ruby is happy and bright, she naps twice a day, sleeps through the night and wakes in the morning singing. She is capable of making my least broody friends re-evaluate.

'Why is Ruby so sweet? Do you think it's nature or nurture?' one asked recently. Actually, I think it's because rather than letting a tiny baby dictate an ever-changing pattern, I set one for her. In other words, it's down to a seven-letter word beginning with 'r' - or a four letter word beginning with 'g'. But of course, I didn't tell my friend that. 'Nature or nurture? A bit of both,' I replied, looking smug.

fields.headline: Watchdog to police Chinese cures
fields.trailText: They have become some of Britain's most successful treatments for chronic illness, generating an industry worth more than £100 million a year.
fields.body:
They have become some of Britain's most successful treatments for chronic illness, generating an industry worth more than £100 million a year.

Chinese herbal medicines - first used 3,000 years ago - are now big business and used to treat everything from eczema to rheumatoid arthritis. Last year more than a million prescriptions were issued to British people. Treatments typically involve taking a few mouthfuls of concocted brews - a simple, harmless business, according to practitioners.

But this cosy image has recently been destroyed by doctors uncovering cases of near-fatal incidents in which patients were given incorrect drugs. In one case, two women suffered serious kidney damage when they took the herbal preparation Aristolochia instead of the harmless drug Stephania.

Similar confusion led to an outbreak - involving more than 70 people - of kidney failures in Belgium. As a result, Aristolochia is now banned in Britain and many other countries.

In another study, researchers in London uncovered more than a dozen cases of liver disease triggered by traditional Chinese prescriptions for eczema.

Many experts fear that increasing numbers of people could be given incorrect, sometimes dangerous, doses as the use of Chinese herbal medicines soars, and as numbers of practitioners - of whom there are now more than 4,000 in the UK - continue to rise. The problem, they stress, is not one of malpractice, but of an inability to identify herbs accurately.

This alarming scenario has had unexpected consequences: the establishment of a unique scientific collaboration between Oriental doctors and Western scientists. Together they have set up an authentication centre at Kew Gardens for pinpointing Chinese medicinal herbs.

The scheme - backed by medical herb importers and by the Chinese government - is aimed at preventing future poisoning outbreaks.

'There are more than 500 herbs, used by traditional Chinese doctors, and these are being imported in increasing amounts to Britain,' said Dr Christine Leon, head of Kew's Chinese Medicinal Plants Authentication Centre.

More than 10,000 tonnes of Chinese herbs were imported into Britain last year, although estimates suggest a quarter of this traffic is still incorrectly labelled.

For example, one drug, picked at random from Leon's collection, was labelled heartwood of Aquilaria. Chinese doctors claim its resin has powerful, anti-indigestion properties.

'Unfortunately, the sample I have here indicates it has been coated with black paint at some time, and that is unlikely to be conducive to good digestion,' she added. webTitle: Family of dead soldier to sue MoD

fields.headline: Family of dead soldier to sue MoD
fields.trailText: The family of a young soldier accidentally shot dead in training are to sue the Ministry of Defence in a final attempt to find out why their son died.
fields.body:
The family of a young soldier accidentally shot dead in training are to sue the Ministry of Defence in a final attempt to find out why their son died. Although they could get a substantial compensation package from the Government, Richard King's relatives accuse the MoD of withholding information about the fatal incident. Their legal action will be launched next week.

'My brother died more than two years ago and we can't put him to rest until we know how he was killed,' Liz Bull, the dead soldier's older sister, said. 'They have been keeping us in the dark. It's destroying us.'

King, 22, a Grenadier Guardsman, died when a fellow soldier fired five live rounds into a trench during a night-time 'escape and evasion' exercise at the Army's Sennybridge training ground in South Wales. The rounds shattered a blank-firing device attached to the soldier's SA80 personal weapon. One bullet hit King in the chest, splintering his spine and causing internal injuries. He died in a military ambulance on the way to hospital.

An inquest recorded a verdict of 'accidental death' and a subsequent investigation by Dyfed- Powys police led to no charges being brought against any of the individuals involved. However, testimony at the inquest revealed that live and blank rounds had got mixed up during the exercise, possibly because some soldiers had, contrary to regulations, held on to some live bullets from a separate exercise two days before the accident.

An investigation by the Military Police's Special Investigation Branch (SIB) is continuing. King's family say there are still many unanswered questions about his death and are angry that no one has been called to account.

The family, from Sheppey, Kent, hope their legal action will force the Army to give them access to SIB files. They say they still do not know how the bullets were mixed up, how they were loaded without anyone noticing or why nobody realised for several minutes King had been shot. They also claim that the Army has failed to keep them informed of the progress of the inquiry.

They also accuse senior officers of being complacent. Although the Army made a number of changes in its safety procedures after King's death, another young soldier was killed in similar circumstances in March. Wayne Richards, a teenage Royal Marine recruit, died when an instructor opened fire with a weapon that was thought to be loaded with blanks during an exercise at the Commando Training Centre at Lympstone, Devon.

'The MoD say all the right things and make all the right promises, but then it happens again,' Liz Bull said. 'If we really knew how my brother had been killed then these lads would be a lot safer.'

A spokesman for the MoD said that they had every sympathy with the bereaved family and appreciated their frustration. 'We are doing as much as we can not to delay the matter further,' he said.

Five soldiers have been killed during military exercises in the past two years. Two died of heart attacks while on endurance tests and a third, a 16-year-old recruit, while wading through a pool.

Politicians back the King family's campaign. 'Delays of this length are quite unacceptable,' said Menzies Campbell, the senior Liberal Democrat MP. 'The longer investigations go on the more suspicious the public is likely to be.'

'To say we are bitter doesn't begin to describe it,' said Bull last weekend. 'You just take for granted that your baby brother is going to be with you forever. He loved two things in life: his family and the Army... and in the end what he loved killed him.'

fields.headline: Barefoot Doctor
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: how to quell anxiety, combat lower-back pain and alleviate allergies
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: how to quell anxiety, combat lower-back pain and alleviate allergies
fields.body:
You've got a deadline to meet. You're being squeezed in a cash-flow crunch. Your partner's threatening to run off with another unless you suddenly get more sexy. The deal you've been slaving over might not come off. The promotion you've been counting on may never come your way. Your children are acting up at school and show signs of delinquency. The exchange rate may rocket against you before you have time to buy your second home in France. And, yes, you may die before fulfilling your life's dream.

Anxiety has overtaken you. Your breathing is shallow. You can't or won't focus on the very job at hand that could pull you out of this chicane, which is compounding your anxiety.

So you have a drink, smoke a cigarette, spend money you haven't got on frivolous whims or regress to vegetable state, further compounding the anxiety. And it has to stop.

Anxiety is endemic. We have grown accustomed to going through our daily paces in a state of low-grade anxiety, as if it is the natural state.

Originally, anxiety is a chosen or learned response, a bogus coping mechanism usually adopted in infancy from an anxious parent. The anxiety response soon embeds itself in your psyche as a pattern, whereupon it assumes the status of an a priori truth: of course I get anxious - I've got deadlines to meet, bills to pay, etc. Sounds plausible, quite grown up, in fact.

But as any martial artist, flying trapeze artist or commercial airline pilot will tell you, your mind and body perform to optimum levels only when you're relaxed.

Anxiety causes the area surrounding your kidneys and adrenal glands to contract, thus impairing their functions. This leads to symptoms including lower-back ache, cystitis, headaches, tinnitus, nervous stomach, poor digestion, significant drop in sexual interest or performance, and more anxiety.

Now you could run to your GP and attempt to stuff the feeling down with various chemicals, or you could take the self-help option: slow the tempo of your breathing down to half-time. This means relaxing your belly so your diaphragm can pull the lungs down efficiently.

Breathe in fully. Breathe out fully. If so inclined, tell yourself you're exhaling the anxiety and inhaling calm and clarity.

Using your fists, massage in circular motion the soft area of your lower and middle back until you feel it soften.

Drink small amounts of valerian tea.

Take Bach Flower Remedy of Mimulus.

Eschew coffee and other adrenalin stimulators.

Long-term, take up chi gong or t'ai chi, as these work intensively on strengthening the kidneys and adrenals.

If you are suffering from extreme anxiety, visit an acupuncturist one week, a homeopath the next and a shiatsu specialist the next, repeated in rotation over a six-week period. It'll be worth the investment.

Finally, remain mindful of your body, at work, rest and play. Whenever you find yourself in a state of unnecessary muscular gripping, get a grip with your mind instead and ask, 'Don't I deserve to feel better than this?'

Your letters

Hello Doctor, over the past week, I've developed an ache in my upper back on the left side. It feels muscular but I get a sharp pain when I breathe in. Might this be serious? I've just finished a long relationship. Could it be just stress-related?
Jan, Harpenden

Jan, the stress of loss and grief always affects the lungs, making you more susceptible to respiratory problems at times like this. In this instance, it sounds like a lung infection of some kind, possibly pneumonia, and should be first examined by a GP in case you need antibiotics. If so, an alternative treatment is to try propolis tincture, golden seal and echinacea, which will act as a natural antibiotic, and drink mullein tea to open up the air passages. Additionally, visit a shiatsu specialist to have a go at manually moving the blockage.

Dear Barefoot, I've suffered with lower-back pain for 18 years. I've been to osteopaths, physiotherapists and acupuncturists but they only make it worse. When I tried remedial yoga, the teacher said I was too flexible and it would damage me. What can you suggest?
Mrs F Loppy

Mrs F Loppy?! You're suffering from hypermobility of the joints. Take up Pilates to strengthen the core muscles. After a few months, visit a cranio-sacral therapist to align your spine and maybe an acupuncturist to tighten the surface muscles. Avoid physiotherapy and osteopathy - the last thing you need is to move the too-mobile joints around. On an emotional level, this indicates weakness of will- spinelessness, in other words. Consider meditation as a tool for strengthening your will, and possibly a name change by deed poll to Mrs I Ronwill.

Dear Doc, I've visited an allergy specialist and changed my diet many times, but my allergies just get worse. What can I do?
Jon Icanteatthat, Fortis Green

Dear Jon, allergies arise because the deepest part of your mind is forgetting to tell your body to resist invasion by negative exogenous factors. Apply your mind and energy to building up your inner resistance - your immune system - with vigorous exercise (running, weight-training, etc) to both build stamina and mental power and, by homeopathy and or acupuncture, to trigger the immune system. Tell yourself that you welcome all input from the outside world as your friend - your mind can be powerful in combating allergens.

 If you have any problems you'd like answers to, please write to Barefoot Doctor c/o Life Magazine, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER

fields.headline: Six of the best...
fields.standfirst: ... places to savour savoury tarts.
fields.trailText: ... places to savour savoury tarts.
fields.body:
It's funny how too much hobnobbing with foodies and reading recipe books can cause you to speak a different language from other people. There I was with friends in a venerable old restaurant near Kensington Gardens, when I saw 'savoury tart of the day' written on a blackboard among the starters. So I ordered it, thinking of something small crisp and delicious, only to be presented with a wedge of eggy, spinach quiche.

Serves me right, really. Even those excellent French patissiers, Maison Blanc, which has branches in Oxford, Chichester and other county towns as well as London (call 020 8838 0848 for details) only makes egg-based tartlets (£1.55 each), albeit with good shortcrust pastry and tasty fillings such as broccoli, mushroom and bacon, leeks and so on. Ask the French assistants for that Niçoise speciality, pissaladière, and you'll draw a blank - they've never heard of it, and the name makes them giggle.

At least Tom Ilic, chef at the newly acclaimed New End restaurant (102 Heath Street, London NW3; 020 7431 4423) is man who knows what I mean by a savoury tart. He makes caramelised shallot and tomato tatin to go with roast loin of lamb and caramelised endive, and cep tart with truffle vinaigrette especially to please the vegetarian faction of Hampstead intellectuals. His secret is to counteract the sweetness of the caramelised vegetables with an aged vinegar to create a perfect balance in flavour. He also confits the tomatoes first to take out the moisture, then he 'fills in the gaps' with puréed shallots. 'I hate using creams or making quiches,' he says. 'It's only there to hold the stuff together.'

Ilic only uses his own really thin puff pastry, but thinks home cooks should buy it and concentrate on making the fillings delicious instead. Unsurprisingly, many of the best products are imported from France. Les Trois Toques produces ready-to-fill puff pastry tartlets (nine individual size, £1.55; 16 cocktail size, £1.35), which can be found in House of Fraser stores around the country, as well as in Northallerton's answer to Fortnum & Mason, Lewis & Cooper (92 High Street, Northallerton, North Yorkshire; 01609 772 880). Celebrating its centenary this year, behind the same smallish shop front, it stretches back, Tardis-like, to cover 3,000 sq ft of home-cured meats, regional cheeses, famous puddings and fine teas. The store is also a conscientious supplier of hampers as required by picnickers attending 'proms in the park' at Ormsby Hall; tarts featuring asparagus and Parmesan are hot favourites this year.

The only problem with much ready-made pastry (including Les Trois Toques, which uses vegetable shortening and Evernat, a ready-to-roll organic product which uses palm oil) is they don't contain butter.

Susan Cunningham, a sometime futures trader who left the City to become a chef, also subscribes to the all-butter school because 'it gives a superior flavour'. Now co-owner (with her husband David) of her own restaurant in Kent, West House (28 High Street, Biddenden; 01580 291 341), Susan delights in making galettes of gorgonzola and pear or even hot oak-smoked salmon. 'The worst thing about tarts is that people are often so mean with the filling,' she contends. 'Our salmon comes from a one-man smokery down the road and people absolutely love the tart.'

It sounds fantastic. But before we get too carried away, not all worthwhile tarts are strictly gourmet. Mary Contini (of Edinburgh's Valvona & Crolla, 19 Elm Row; 0131 556 6066) includes a tomato, basil and cheddar tart in her children's recipe book Easy Peasy (co-written by Pru Irvine, Ebury Press, £12.99). Any five-year-old can do it.

fields.headline: Cress fallen
fields.standfirst: Today's bland sprouts are a far cry from the mustardy zest of the Victorian's cress. Sybil Kapoor spots the green shoots of recovery
fields.trailText: Today's bland sprouts are a far cry from the mustardy zest of the Victorian's cress. Sybil Kapoor spots the green shoots of recovery.
fields.body:
I was flicking through Jamie Oliver's The Return of the Naked Chef (£20, Michael Joseph) recently when a salad of boiled potatoes, avocado and cress caught my eye. 'I had to do this salad, even though cress must be one of the tackiest things in the world,' the young Mr Oliver had written. 'For some reason I'm absolutely addicted to it and love it to bits.' Delicious, peppery mustard and cress, tacky? Does the man know what he writes?

Perhaps he does not realise that it has one of the most ancient of culinary pedigrees. Never mind the Greeks' and Romans' penchant for these addictive sprouts, even the Anglo-Saxons, not renowned for their cooking, used to grow tun-cerse, or garden cress, Lepidium sativum , with a few white mustard seedlings, Sinapis alba , mixed in. By the 16th century, British cooks were smitten by the fashion for intricate salads. The exquisite heat of a tiny mustard shoot, counterbalanced by cooler garden cress, worked wonders with their hard-boiled eggs, cucumbers and finely pared lemons.

From then on, winter and summer, mustard and cress were sprinkled on to our salads. The Victorians decided that it was the equivalent of ginseng and urged respectable matrons to serve it for breakfast with sliced radishes and salt. It reached its zenith with the invention of the egg and cress sandwich, then the ultimate in tea-time refinement.

Disaster struck in the 20th century when a cress-growing entrepreneur replaced the customary 75 per cent garden cress, 25 per cent mustard, with 85 per cent rape seed, 15 per cent garden cress. Salad cress was created, and blandness became the order of the day. Of the supermarkets, only Sainsbury's adds a hint of mustard seedlings to this dull creation. You can still buy traditional mustard and cress, but according to Sarah Hesford, Sainsbury's fresh-herb buyer, salad cress accounts for 75 per cent of their cress sales, despite the fact that both are sold for 29p a punnet.

All is not quite lost. Pret A Manger uses mustard and cress for both its Egg Mayo and All Day Breakfast sandwiches. 'It complements the other ingredients and looks good,' explains Emma Blackmore, their development chef. Even more comforting is the fact that Egg Mayo is its number-one seller (30,829 consumed each week). Perhaps master Oliver should revise his opinion and declare mustard and cress to be 'pukka'. It may then return to its rightful place in our affections and oust the pernicious salad cress.
fields.bodyText: I was flicking through Jamie Oliver's The Return of the Naked Chef (£20, Michael Joseph) recently when a salad of boiled potatoes, avocado and cress caught my eye. 'I had to do this salad, even though cress must be one of the tackiest things in the world,' the young Mr Oliver had written. 'For some reason I'm absolutely addicted to it and love it to bits.' Delicious, peppery mustard and cress, tacky? Does the man know what he writes? Perhaps he does not realise that it has one of the most ancient of culinary pedigrees. Never mind the Greeks' and Romans' penchant for these addictive sprouts, even the Anglo-Saxons, not renowned for their cooking, used to grow tun-cerse, or garden cress, Lepidium sativum , with a few white mustard seedlings, Sinapis alba , mixed in. By the 16th century, British cooks were smitten by the fashion for intricate salads. The exquisite heat of a tiny mustard shoot, counterbalanced by cooler garden cress, worked wonders with their hard-boiled eggs, cucumbers and finely pared lemons. From then on, winter and summer, mustard and cress were sprinkled on to our salads. The Victorians decided that it was the equivalent of ginseng and urged respectable matrons to serve it for breakfast with sliced radishes and salt. It reached its zenith with the invention of the egg and cress sandwich, then the ultimate in tea-time refinement. Disaster struck in the 20th century when a cress-growing entrepreneur replaced the customary 75 per cent garden cress, 25 per cent mustard, with 85 per cent rape seed, 15 per cent garden cress. Salad cress was created, and blandness became the order of the day. Of the supermarkets, only Sainsbury's adds a hint of mustard seedlings to this dull creation. You can still buy traditional mustard and cress, but according to Sarah Hesford, Sainsbury's fresh-herb buyer, salad cress accounts for 75 per cent of their cress sales, despite the fact that both are sold for 29p a punnet. All is not quite lost. Pret A Manger uses mustard and cress for both its Egg Mayo and All Day Breakfast sandwiches. 'It complements the other ingredients and looks good,' explains Emma Blackmore, their development chef. Even more comforting is the fact that Egg Mayo is its number-one seller (30,829 consumed each week). Perhaps master Oliver should revise his opinion and declare mustard and cress to be 'pukka'. It may then return to its rightful place in our affections and oust the pernicious salad cress.

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: ...The Cambridge Folk Festival
fields.trailText: ...The Cambridge Folk Festival
fields.body:
Joan Baez returns to the leafy grounds of Cherry Hinton Hall for her third Cambridge Folk Festival next weekend, heading another exemplary line-up of British, Irish and American roots music. (The festival began in 1964, when newcomer Paul Simon was a late addition to the bill.) Baez toured Britain last year to rave reviews, with a young band in tow and her small guitar worn high, Mexican-style. She's a silver-haired beauty now, and the beads and bandana have been replaced by not-so-folk trouser suits, but that defining voice of the 60s protest movement is still oddly potent.

Much of Baez's material is new, though; she covers songs by up-and-coming artists such as Dar Williams and Sinéad Lohan, and appears to have taken 24-year-old English folk firebrand Eliza Carthy under her wing as an honorary band member and her support act of choice, clearly recognising in Carthy another gutsy, pioneering spirit. Baez appears on Saturday only. Eliza will be on stage Friday and Saturday (no doubt shocking traditionalists with songs from her imminent debut pop album).

Other highlights include Juan De Marcos's (17-strong) Afro-Cuban All Stars, last seen throwing their maracas around Ronnie Scott's; the ever-independent Ani DiFranco; tender, angry Scot Dick Gaughan; legendary American singer Odetta; Priory of Brion, featuring Robert Plant; and an eagerly awaited showcase on Saturday by singer-songwriter Kathryn Williams, who has been compared to Nick Drake, Joni Mitchell and Carole King, no less.

The pick of this year's workshops are led by Martin Carthy 'and colleagues' (the subject: stage skills) and the wonderful Shetland fiddle player Catriona Macdonald - if anyone can bring a tentful of amateur violinists to order, here's your woman.

The festival, as usual, is sponsored by Bedford-based beer company Charles Wells, so the place will be pleasantly awash with Bombardier English Bitter. But this is 21st-century folk, so there's a 24-hour internet café, too.

The Cambridge Folk Festival runs from 27 to 30 July and is selling out fast. For tickets, call 01223 357 851; email: boxoffice@cambridge.gov.uk; information on www.cam-folkfest.co.uk. If you can't get tickets this year, book early for 2001.

fields.headline: The perfect...
fields.standfirst: ... nightclub
fields.trailText: ... nightclub
fields.body:
The perfect nightclub is underground, in the sense that it is in a dark basement in an unsavoury area, and in the sense that it is publicised by word of mouth only. You're not sure if it really exists, or if you'll get in if it does, but then one night you see a friend who says she's become a regular there. She takes you down a shadowy alley, through the little crowd of hopefuls huddled around the unlit door, past the forbidding-looking security staff with just a nod, and down the hole into wonderland.

It's hot in there. Murky, hard to see. Dark corners seem to be harbouring furtive deals and unimaginable transgressions. A famous face drifts past, doing something so outrageously indiscreet that it's hard to believe your eyes. It's kind of scary. You should be shocked. But instead you feel instantly that you belong. And then there's the music. Music like you've never heard before. A bassline you can feel throbbing through your ribcage, a rhythm that winds into your brain. You start to dance, moving without thinking. You let the music take control. Time freezes. Everything else is forgotten as you merge with the crowd and the music, becoming part of something bigger than yourself, something you know will be talked about for years to come. Moments like this don't come often. Moments like this change lives.

A good nightclub is a haven. It is sleazy, pushing at the edges of legality. A place to shed old inhibitions and try on new identities, to experiment with new drugs, new sexualities, new social mixtures. As everyone is there for the same thing, you can do all this in relative safety.

The perfect club ends before you want it to. Eyes shining, you say it was the best night of your life. But there's always someone wanting to start the next thing. 'You should have been here last month,' he says. 'It was so much better before people like you came along.'

fields.headline: No more nine to five
fields.standfirst:
Long hours, low pay and a crushing lack of job
security... In Britain, it seems, we love to whinge
about work. But as Richard Reeves of the Industrial Society reports, most of us have never
had it so good
fields.trailText:
Long hours, low pay and a crushing lack of job
security... In Britain, it seems, we love to whinge
about work. But as Richard Reeves of the Industrial Society reports, most of us have never
had it so good.
fields.body:
Stress, sleeplessness, depression, heart disease, shortness of temper, memory loss, irritable bowel syndrome, anxiety, marital breakdown, child delinquency, impotence, the decline of local neighbourhoods, cancer, RSI, rudeness, suicide, Tins couples (Two Incomes, No Sex) - a mere shortlist of some of the symptoms of the postmodern malaise.

The cause of all our woes? Enter, stage right, the prime suspect - work. Wicked, wicked work. An avalanche of surveys, polls and expert commentaries show that we all work too long, too hard, that our bosses are beastly, that we are insecure and afraid. You know all this stuff. We seem to be workers on the verge of a nervous breakdown.

A council housing officer wins £67,000 from her employers for workplace stress; a young, gifted surgeon works 220 hours in 10 days, then breaks into a stranger's bungalow, strips naked and bites anyone who tries to help him; a financial services company enrols its overworked staff on to a dating agency's books; Businesswoman of the Year Nikki Beckett says she keeps her weekends clear for her children - but puts in 70 hours a week for her company NSB Retail Systems; Longbridge lives, but Dagenham dies.

So far, so bad. But there's plenty of good news about work, too - even if it is not always shared with the same enthusiasm as the 'Work Sucks' stories. The average wage has increased 57 per cent in the past decade. The proportion of firms offering maternity leave in excess of the statutory minimum has quintupled over the same time period. A third of firms now offer sabbaticals; two-thirds allow staff to work from home some of the time. Four out of 10 UK workers declare themselves 'very satisfied' with their jobs [see box page 23], more than in France, Germany, Italy or Spain.

An infant-school dinner lady wins the Lottery but - like many of her fellow winners - keeps working. 'I love my job because I enjoy talking to the children and parents,' she said. 'It is a very responsible job.' A young woman is crowned Miss Northern Ireland and refuses to give up her admin job in a doctor's surgery. 'I love my job,' she explained. Unemployment plumbs record lows - and may even drop below the symbolic 1 million mark before long. We seem to have never had it so good.

Consider the space devoted by magazines and newspapers to workplace issues; the sprouting advertising billboards for recruitment agencies; the exploding number of books and websites on work and work-related issues. Browse the dozens of websites containing jokes about work; peruse the humour shelves of your local bookshop - almost certainly filled with Dilbert-style laughs about our labour. Listen for just a moment to the rhetoric of the Labour government, living up to its name, pouring money into the New Deal programme to get people into work.

Work has become our national obsession. Whether we are damning the impact of work on our health, our families, our time, or celebrating its new-found flexibility, rewards and opportunities, we are talking, writing and thinking about work like never before.

'There is no question that work is moving up the agenda,' says Michael Willmott, co-director of the Future Foundation, a think-tank on social trends. 'Private conversations and public debate are dominated by work, and what work means.'

As with so many obsessive relationships, the one with work is a love-hate one. Confusion reigns. Mixed messages are everywhere - on the one hand, the government bangs on and on about the importance of paid work, and then cautions about the impact of too much paid work on families. Women celebrate the economic independence work brings, then are made to feel guilty about their children. Salaries go up, but few of us feel richer. We get to a point where we feel OK about our work; and then along comes Martha Lane Fox and we think we've missed the dotcom boat. We find a job we love and so work long hours at it, and then feel that we are failing to get our 'work/life' balance right.

Why is work under the microscope? Why all the angst? Perhaps because our work simply occupies a more important place in our lives than it did. Maybe we care, and worry, more about work for the same reason we care and worry so much about our children or our health - because it is important to us. Men and (for the first time in centuries) women are placing work closer to the centre of their lives. And maybe that's no bad thing. The 'leisure society' - remember that? - would probably have been a boring place in any case.

Our work fixation springs from a series of profound changes in the nature of employment, all of which push work more deeply into our individual lives, our families and our communities. Work has become a more important element of our personal identity; we have greater control and choice over the shape of our working lives; women have entered and transformed the workplace; the nine-to-five has become more sociable; more of us want or need the financial independence that a wage offers; and the economic rewards of working have increased - work pays.

Work has become a more important personal identity tag, supplanting the three traditional indicators of our uniqueness - place, faith and blood. As geographical roots have weakened, religious affiliations have diminished and the extended family has dispersed, how we spend our labouring hours has become a more important window into our souls.

'I am sure that work is becoming more important,' says Willmott. 'People are getting at least as much sense of who they are from their work as from their family and friends.' Work is getting personal. That is why our first question at parties is not 'where do you live?' or 'do you have children?' or 'what do you believe in?' but 'what do you do?' Our work is a shorthand for ourselves.

This trend reflects and reinforces a desire for work which brings personal fulfilment, for work we are proud of. If work means not just income but identity, then the choice of job becomes critical. This is why tobacco companies find it so hard to hire people - to work for them would be to taint your own identity.

Ed Mayo, director of the New Economics Foundation, a lobbying group for a progressive workplace and environment, believes there is a growing thirst for work which is meaningful to the worker. 'Our surveys on quality of life show,' he says, 'that the number-one concern now is people's desire for fulfilling work.' In William Gibson's Neuromancer , Razorgirl says: 'If you love what you do, that's what you are, right?'

Michael Willmott says that younger people are becoming more discerning about what they do - and that employment choices are being made in the context of a greater desire for freedom, fulfilment and individuality. The number of twenty- and thirtysomethings saying they 'feel a strong need for new experiences' has doubled in the same period. We want our work to demonstrate our individuality, not box us into a stereotype.

Many column inches have been dedicated to the 'death of the career' as if that were necessarily a backwards development. It is worth remembering that the word 'career' is derived from the word for a single straight pathway; now we are starting to meander off, following our own course, seeking out new routes. John Knell, of the Industrial Society, will argue in a report published this week that a new breed of 'hyper-opportunist' worker has been born, and that work will never be the same again.

The ability - or requirement - to create our own working life, rather than having it laid out for us by a corporate parent-replacement is another reason for our renewed interest in work. We have to think about it because no one is doing the thinking for us. There are fewer predictable corporate ladders to climb. We have to make our own.

The fact that in a lightly regulated labour market there is no promise that a job today is a job tomorrow has altered the definition of security at work. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development estimates that one in 10 jobs cease to exist each decade.

Andy Westwood, head of research and development at the Employment Policy Institute, says that while security was once based on one employer, or at least one set of skills, security now comes from an ability to move with the times. The transition is not an easy one. 'I think some of the difficulties of the past few years have been the birth pangs of a different kind of working life, with different kinds of security,' he says.

The young are in the vanguard of the DIY career-makers. Younger workers are often seen as problematic for employers: disloyal, undecided, easily bored and individualistic. In the US, the average 32-year-old has had nine jobs. In the UK, one in four youngsters want to work for themselves. But Generation X is simply reacting to the new world. They have seen for themselves that no one can guarantee a job for life. They have learned that a clever and skilful employee can call the shots. It is exhausting - but it can be liberating, too.

While the young have reinvented their expectations of work, another even more significant change has taken place: the Entry of Woman. Women will shortly outnumber men in the UK labour force, and have been flooding into work for the past few decades. This seismic social and economic shift has prompted cries of 'What about the children' and 'What about the jobs for men', and the sexist inventions of 'Superwoman' and 'The woman who has it all'.

The real impact of women's sometimes forced entry into the workplace has been to increase the importance of work in all our lives. When work was ghettoised by gender it was up to men to worry about breadwinning and up to women to worry about bread. The female half of the population was, by and large, excluded from conversations about work - that was 'men's talk'. Now women - with an unemployment rate half that for men - talk and care about work as much as men.

It is not just the fact of women working that has pushed work up the agenda but the nature of their work. In 1911, 39 per cent of Britain's working women were domestic servants, now they are knocking at the boardroom door. There are more women than men studying to be doctors and lawyers. Cosmopolitan magazine reports that women undergoing plastic surgery frequently say it is to help them at work, not help them snag a man.

Conservative notions that women are being forced into work against their will, in breach of natural laws dictating that they should be rearing and caring, not earning and commanding, are bunkum. In a recent survey by Mintel, a higher proportion of women full-time workers than men said they enjoyed their job.

The long-overdue partial feminisation of the workplace has put work at the heart of modern relationships. Dates between young men and women have to be fitted around their work schedules; if they do get together, their candlelit dinners are likely to feature a two-way discussion about work projects; if one of them is offered a job in another city, the other has to see if it is somewhere they might be able to work.

In the past, when men worked and women cared and cleaned, mixed socialising and mating had to take place in non-work settings. Now the office has lost its gender. Of course, this means that issues such as sexual harassment and discrimination become more important - but it also makes work a place of greater opportunity.

Indeed, more and more of us meet our lovers and life partners through work. In her book Sex and Business , Shere Hite estimates that 62 per cent of women and 71 per cent of men have had a love affair with a colleague.

The increase in the numbers of women at work has also changed the atmosphere of the workplace and helped to create a more natural and sociable environment than the testosterone-filled offices and factories of the past. The arrival of women has coincided with an increase in the lev els of personal interaction at work; a recent survey suggests we spend more time talking to each other at work than ever before. This reflects not only the influence of women, but also a profound change in the nature of work, away from manufacturing and towards services - increasingly services that need a human touch. Hi-tech jobs are being replaced by 'high touch' jobs. Within 10 years, half of us will be in a managerial, administrative, professional or technical job.

And while the working day is not filled with enjoyable interaction for everyone, there is no questioning the fact that for most people, most of the time, work is better now - which inevitably makes it more valuable.

'One of the reasons work is becoming more important is that more jobs are allowing room for personal interaction,' says Willmott. 'There are fewer people in mind-numbing jobs. There's concern about people in call centres - but at least they are talking to people, at least there is some engagement.'

Of course, the notion of work as a place for friends, lovers, chatter and socialising is not completely new. Sinclair Lewis - one of the century's most perceptive writers on working life and author of Babbitt , a kind of 1920s Dilbert - once noted the similarities between the office and the village. 'Not surprisingly,' says Jeremy Lewis, editor of The Vintage Book of Office Life , 'given the amount of time we spend in these curious places, the friendships and gossip and the intrigues and even passions of office life may well loom larger than those of domestic life.' Now that few of us live in a real village, or indeed a community that we can honestly call our own, the social role of work has increased.

Of course, no matter how convivial our vocation, the prime reason for work is - as it has always been - to pay the bills. Today, though, a bigger slice of the population - particularly women - want or need the financial independence that comes from earning their own way. Forecaster Professor Richard Scase says: 'A growing percentage of women now have the earning capacity to live independent lifestyles.' More of us are choosing to live alone - by 2010, singletons will be the most common household type. This independence requires income, and as work is the only way to generate income, work becomes even more important, more precious.

Fortunately, work is repaying our efforts. While there are pockets of low pay - and while women continue to lag behind men in pay - our pay packets are getting consistently fatter. At the same time, tax rates have declined so that we keep more of what we earn. Highly skilled workers in particular have seen their wages rise rapidly in the last two decades. Small wonder that they are the ones putting in the hours and obsessing most about work.

But even for those at the bottom end of the pay scale, the rewards of working are improving. The Labour government has poured billions of pounds into tax credits to top up lower pay and put in place a minimum wage - which many employers are bettering. 'There are good reasons to be optimistic about work, and not just at the top,' says Westwood. 'Wages towards the bottom of the labour market are moving upwards quite strongly.' Work is becoming more important to us, in part at least, because it is becoming more profitable for us.

But the new salience of work has come with a price; fewer people are able to feel secure; the need to keep pace with change is tiring and stressful; white-collar workers are putting in longer hours to try and keep a toehold - with potentially damaging consequences for the children; and the reification of work threatens to push those who are outside the paid workforce further towards the margins of society.

The previous twins of security - corporate career paths and powerful trade unions - have each declined. While for some highly skilled workers the job-hopping mobility of the new labour market is exhilarating, for others simply staying in the race is unnerving; a quarter of us say we are 'highly stressed' at work. The stakes have got higher.

Willmott says that while the new world offers more freedom, there are downsides. 'People who grew up with downsizing are certainly wanting and getting more control over their own destiny,' he says. 'But it means you can never let up, you have to be constantly competing, improving, reskilling. There's no fallow period.'

Trade unions have been unable, with few exceptions, to counteract the effects of the more competitive workplace, and their memberships have declined. Fewer than one in three of us are in a union and less than one in five twentysomething workers have bothered to sign up.

Relying on your own skills and effort for security increases the incentive to work longer hours. British men - a third of whom clock in more than 50 hours a week - work the longest hours in Europe. A US-style workaholic culture threatens us, with a 'presenteeism' attitude in the office.

The story of working hours is actually a little more subtle than the hysterical headlines suggest. Working hours in the UK are actually declining slightly, because of the growing number of people working part-time. We work the longest hours in Europe, but we work the shortest, too. Working hours also divide along class lines - with higher-paid, more senior workers putting in much more time than junior staff.

Of those who do work long hours, a significant proportion do so simply because they want to. Some do not see it as work; Confucius said that if you find a job you love, you'll never work another day in your life. But even if long hours are a labour of love, rather than an indication of insecurity, there are still legitimate fears for the family. If parents both work long hours, what about the children? But two-thirds of full-time working women say there is no negative impact on their family or social life outside work.

The current vogue is to strive for greater work/life balance. But there are signs that balance may not be all it is cracked up to be. At a recent conference in San Francisco, sociologist April Gilbert presented the findings of some in-depth research with working couples - and exploded a few myths in the process. First, she found that only a minority of those interviewed were genuinely seeking 'balance' in their lives. Even more dramatically, she discovered that women who had achieved an 'enviable' balance between work and home reported low levels of job satisfaction.

'The complaints centred around one theme,' she says. 'Balancing one's life by limiting one's work involvement results in work being less interesting, exciting and involving.' This is not to say that having parents, both of whom work all the hours God sends, is the ideal family arrangement - simply that the view of home as a delightful idyll and of work as wearying toil is too simplistic.

A world in which work is king (or queen) is, however, a harsh one for those who are outside the labour force because of unemployment, disability, caring responsibilities - or simply because their age has disqualified them. One of the darkest sides of the new workworld is the tossing of older workers on to the scrapheap. A third of men between 50 and 65 are deemed 'economically inactive', and only 37 per cent of 64-year-olds are working, compared to 57 per cent 20 years ago.

This would not matter so much if work did not matter so much. Not just in terms of income, but in terms of identity. When work becomes more than simply a passport to a pay cheque, when it opens the door to friends, purpose, satisfaction and a place in the world, its absence is more keenly felt. Once we admit the centrality of work to our lives, it might be harder to kid ourselves that we are doing older employees a favour by 'letting them go'.

But we are screwed up about work. We dare not admit its importance to us. We like to moan about it, preferably with work colleagues just after work. One publisher says: 'I love my job, but I feel embarrassed even saying that. My parents think it is sad that the only friends I've got are through work - but I don't see the problem. Funnily enough, we've got lots in common!' The love of your job is now the only one that dare not speak its name. But even the French, in the privacy of an anonymous poll, say that they valued work more highly than love or sex.

Blame religion for turning work into a penance, or blame economists who insist we only work to buy 'leisure' time, or blame trade unionists whose only mission in life is to win less work for their members, or blame competitiveness, or as a last resort blame the global economy. Or blame yourself for liking your job more than you like to admit. The idea of work as intrinsically bad has poisoned us for too long. The poet and mystic Kahlil Gibran said that work was 'love made visible'. Wouldn't it be great if we could capture a bit of that spirit, even if just for a while?

 Richard Reeves is director of the Futures division at the Industrial Society which launches on Tuesday. You can contact him on rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.
