An infant-school dinner lady wins the Lottery but - like many of her fellow winners - keeps working. 'I love my job because I enjoy talking to the children and parents,' she said. 'It is a very responsible job.' A young woman is crowned Miss Northern Ireland and refuses to give up her admin job in a doctor's surgery. 'I love my job,' she explained. Unemployment plumbs record lows - and may even drop below the symbolic 1 million mark before long. We seem to have never had it so good. Consider the space devoted by magazines and newspapers to workplace issues; the sprouting advertising billboards for recruitment agencies; the exploding number of books and websites on work and work-related issues. Browse the dozens of websites containing jokes about work; peruse the humour shelves of your local bookshop - almost certainly filled with Dilbert-style laughs about our labour. Listen for just a moment to the rhetoric of the Labour government, living up to its name, pouring money into the New Deal programme to get people into work. Work has become our national obsession. Whether we are damning the impact of work on our health, our families, our time, or celebrating its new-found flexibility, rewards and opportunities, we are talking, writing and thinking about work like never before. 'There is no question that work is moving up the agenda,' says Michael Willmott, co-director of the Future Foundation, a think-tank on social trends. 'Private conversations and public debate are dominated by work, and what work means.' As with so many obsessive relationships, the one with work is a love-hate one. Confusion reigns. Mixed messages are everywhere - on the one hand, the government bangs on and on about the importance of paid work, and then cautions about the impact of too much paid work on families. Women celebrate the economic independence work brings, then are made to feel guilty about their children. Salaries go up, but few of us feel richer. We get to a point where we feel OK about our work; and then along comes Martha Lane Fox and we think we've missed the dotcom boat. We find a job we love and so work long hours at it, and then feel that we are failing to get our 'work/life' balance right. Why is work under the microscope? Why all the angst? Perhaps because our work simply occupies a more important place in our lives than it did. Maybe we care, and worry, more about work for the same reason we care and worry so much about our children or our health - because it is important to us. Men and (for the first time in centuries) women are placing work closer to the centre of their lives. And maybe that's no bad thing. The 'leisure society' - remember that? - would probably have been a boring place in any case. Our work fixation springs from a series of profound changes in the nature of employment, all of which push work more deeply into our individual lives, our families and our communities. Work has become a more important element of our personal identity; we have greater control and choice over the shape of our working lives; women have entered and transformed the workplace; the nine-to-five has become more sociable; more of us want or need the financial independence that a wage offers; and the economic rewards of working have increased - work pays. Work has become a more important personal identity tag, supplanting the three traditional indicators of our uniqueness - place, faith and blood. As geographical roots have weakened, religious affiliations have diminished and the extended family has dispersed, how we spend our labouring hours has become a more important window into our souls. 'I am sure that work is becoming more important,' says Willmott. 'People are getting at least as much sense of who they are from their work as from their family and friends.' Work is getting personal. That is why our first question at parties is not 'where do you live?' or 'do you have children?' or 'what do you believe in?' but 'what do you do?' Our work is a shorthand for ourselves. This trend reflects and reinforces a desire for work which brings personal fulfilment, for work we are proud of. If work means not just income but identity, then the choice of job becomes critical. This is why tobacco companies find it so hard to hire people - to work for them would be to taint your own identity. Ed Mayo, director of the New Economics Foundation, a lobbying group for a progressive workplace and environment, believes there is a growing thirst for work which is meaningful to the worker. 'Our surveys on quality of life show,' he says, 'that the number-one concern now is people's desire for fulfilling work.' In William Gibson's Neuromancer , Razorgirl says: 'If you love what you do, that's what you are, right?' Michael Willmott says that younger people are becoming more discerning about what they do - and that employment choices are being made in the context of a greater desire for freedom, fulfilment and individuality. The number of twenty- and thirtysomethings saying they 'feel a strong need for new experiences' has doubled in the same period. We want our work to demonstrate our individuality, not box us into a stereotype. Many column inches have been dedicated to the 'death of the career' as if that were necessarily a backwards development. It is worth remembering that the word 'career' is derived from the word for a single straight pathway; now we are starting to meander off, following our own course, seeking out new routes. John Knell, of the Industrial Society, will argue in a report published this week that a new breed of 'hyper-opportunist' worker has been born, and that work will never be the same again. The ability - or requirement - to create our own working life, rather than having it laid out for us by a corporate parent-replacement is another reason for our renewed interest in work. We have to think about it because no one is doing the thinking for us. There are fewer predictable corporate ladders to climb. We have to make our own. The fact that in a lightly regulated labour market there is no promise that a job today is a job tomorrow has altered the definition of security at work. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development estimates that one in 10 jobs cease to exist each decade. Andy Westwood, head of research and development at the Employment Policy Institute, says that while security was once based on one employer, or at least one set of skills, security now comes from an ability to move with the times. The transition is not an easy one. 'I think some of the difficulties of the past few years have been the birth pangs of a different kind of working life, with different kinds of security,' he says. The young are in the vanguard of the DIY career-makers. Younger workers are often seen as problematic for employers: disloyal, undecided, easily bored and individualistic. In the US, the average 32-year-old has had nine jobs. In the UK, one in four youngsters want to work for themselves. But Generation X is simply reacting to the new world. They have seen for themselves that no one can guarantee a job for life. They have learned that a clever and skilful employee can call the shots. It is exhausting - but it can be liberating, too. While the young have reinvented their expectations of work, another even more significant change has taken place: the Entry of Woman. Women will shortly outnumber men in the UK labour force, and have been flooding into work for the past few decades. This seismic social and economic shift has prompted cries of 'What about the children' and 'What about the jobs for men', and the sexist inventions of 'Superwoman' and 'The woman who has it all'. The real impact of women's sometimes forced entry into the workplace has been to increase the importance of work in all our lives. When work was ghettoised by gender it was up to men to worry about breadwinning and up to women to worry about bread. The female half of the population was, by and large, excluded from conversations about work - that was 'men's talk'. Now women - with an unemployment rate half that for men - talk and care about work as much as men. It is not just the fact of women working that has pushed work up the agenda but the nature of their work. In 1911, 39 per cent of Britain's working women were domestic servants, now they are knocking at the boardroom door. There are more women than men studying to be doctors and lawyers. Cosmopolitan magazine reports that women undergoing plastic surgery frequently say it is to help them at work, not help them snag a man. Conservative notions that women are being forced into work against their will, in breach of natural laws dictating that they should be rearing and caring, not earning and commanding, are bunkum. In a recent survey by Mintel, a higher proportion of women full-time workers than men said they enjoyed their job. The long-overdue partial feminisation of the workplace has put work at the heart of modern relationships. Dates between young men and women have to be fitted around their work schedules; if they do get together, their candlelit dinners are likely to feature a two-way discussion about work projects; if one of them is offered a job in another city, the other has to see if it is somewhere they might be able to work. In the past, when men worked and women cared and cleaned, mixed socialising and mating had to take place in non-work settings. Now the office has lost its gender. Of course, this means that issues such as sexual harassment and discrimination become more important - but it also makes work a place of greater opportunity. Indeed, more and more of us meet our lovers and life partners through work. In her book Sex and Business , Shere Hite estimates that 62 per cent of women and 71 per cent of men have had a love affair with a colleague. The increase in the numbers of women at work has also changed the atmosphere of the workplace and helped to create a more natural and sociable environment than the testosterone-filled offices and factories of the past. The arrival of women has coincided with an increase in the lev els of personal interaction at work; a recent survey suggests we spend more time talking to each other at work than ever before. This reflects not only the influence of women, but also a profound change in the nature of work, away from manufacturing and towards services - increasingly services that need a human touch. Hi-tech jobs are being replaced by 'high touch' jobs. Within 10 years, half of us will be in a managerial, administrative, professional or technical job. And while the working day is not filled with enjoyable interaction for everyone, there is no questioning the fact that for most people, most of the time, work is better now - which inevitably makes it more valuable. 'One of the reasons work is becoming more important is that more jobs are allowing room for personal interaction,' says Willmott. 'There are fewer people in mind-numbing jobs. There's concern about people in call centres - but at least they are talking to people, at least there is some engagement.' Of course, the notion of work as a place for friends, lovers, chatter and socialising is not completely new. Sinclair Lewis - one of the century's most perceptive writers on working life and author of Babbitt , a kind of 1920s Dilbert - once noted the similarities between the office and the village. 'Not surprisingly,' says Jeremy Lewis, editor of The Vintage Book of Office Life , 'given the amount of time we spend in these curious places, the friendships and gossip and the intrigues and even passions of office life may well loom larger than those of domestic life.' Now that few of us live in a real village, or indeed a community that we can honestly call our own, the social role of work has increased. Of course, no matter how convivial our vocation, the prime reason for work is - as it has always been - to pay the bills. Today, though, a bigger slice of the population - particularly women - want or need the financial independence that comes from earning their own way. Forecaster Professor Richard Scase says: 'A growing percentage of women now have the earning capacity to live independent lifestyles.' More of us are choosing to live alone - by 2010, singletons will be the most common household type. This independence requires income, and as work is the only way to generate income, work becomes even more important, more precious. Fortunately, work is repaying our efforts. While there are pockets of low pay - and while women continue to lag behind men in pay - our pay packets are getting consistently fatter. At the same time, tax rates have declined so that we keep more of what we earn. Highly skilled workers in particular have seen their wages rise rapidly in the last two decades. Small wonder that they are the ones putting in the hours and obsessing most about work. But even for those at the bottom end of the pay scale, the rewards of working are improving. The Labour government has poured billions of pounds into tax credits to top up lower pay and put in place a minimum wage - which many employers are bettering. 'There are good reasons to be optimistic about work, and not just at the top,' says Westwood. 'Wages towards the bottom of the labour market are moving upwards quite strongly.' Work is becoming more important to us, in part at least, because it is becoming more profitable for us. But the new salience of work has come with a price; fewer people are able to feel secure; the need to keep pace with change is tiring and stressful; white-collar workers are putting in longer hours to try and keep a toehold - with potentially damaging consequences for the children; and the reification of work threatens to push those who are outside the paid workforce further towards the margins of society. The previous twins of security - corporate career paths and powerful trade unions - have each declined. While for some highly skilled workers the job-hopping mobility of the new labour market is exhilarating, for others simply staying in the race is unnerving; a quarter of us say we are 'highly stressed' at work. The stakes have got higher. Willmott says that while the new world offers more freedom, there are downsides. 'People who grew up with downsizing are certainly wanting and getting more control over their own destiny,' he says. 'But it means you can never let up, you have to be constantly competing, improving, reskilling. There's no fallow period.' Trade unions have been unable, with few exceptions, to counteract the effects of the more competitive workplace, and their memberships have declined. Fewer than one in three of us are in a union and less than one in five twentysomething workers have bothered to sign up. Relying on your own skills and effort for security increases the incentive to work longer hours. British men - a third of whom clock in more than 50 hours a week - work the longest hours in Europe. A US-style workaholic culture threatens us, with a 'presenteeism' attitude in the office. The story of working hours is actually a little more subtle than the hysterical headlines suggest. Working hours in the UK are actually declining slightly, because of the growing number of people working part-time. We work the longest hours in Europe, but we work the shortest, too. Working hours also divide along class lines - with higher-paid, more senior workers putting in much more time than junior staff. Of those who do work long hours, a significant proportion do so simply because they want to. Some do not see it as work; Confucius said that if you find a job you love, you'll never work another day in your life. But even if long hours are a labour of love, rather than an indication of insecurity, there are still legitimate fears for the family. If parents both work long hours, what about the children? But two-thirds of full-time working women say there is no negative impact on their family or social life outside work. The current vogue is to strive for greater work/life balance. But there are signs that balance may not be all it is cracked up to be. At a recent conference in San Francisco, sociologist April Gilbert presented the findings of some in-depth research with working couples - and exploded a few myths in the process. First, she found that only a minority of those interviewed were genuinely seeking 'balance' in their lives. Even more dramatically, she discovered that women who had achieved an 'enviable' balance between work and home reported low levels of job satisfaction. 'The complaints centred around one theme,' she says. 'Balancing one's life by limiting one's work involvement results in work being less interesting, exciting and involving.' This is not to say that having parents, both of whom work all the hours God sends, is the ideal family arrangement - simply that the view of home as a delightful idyll and of work as wearying toil is too simplistic. A world in which work is king (or queen) is, however, a harsh one for those who are outside the labour force because of unemployment, disability, caring responsibilities - or simply because their age has disqualified them. One of the darkest sides of the new workworld is the tossing of older workers on to the scrapheap. A third of men between 50 and 65 are deemed 'economically inactive', and only 37 per cent of 64-year-olds are working, compared to 57 per cent 20 years ago. This would not matter so much if work did not matter so much. Not just in terms of income, but in terms of identity. When work becomes more than simply a passport to a pay cheque, when it opens the door to friends, purpose, satisfaction and a place in the world, its absence is more keenly felt. Once we admit the centrality of work to our lives, it might be harder to kid ourselves that we are doing older employees a favour by 'letting them go'. But we are screwed up about work. We dare not admit its importance to us. We like to moan about it, preferably with work colleagues just after work. One publisher says: 'I love my job, but I feel embarrassed even saying that. My parents think it is sad that the only friends I've got are through work - but I don't see the problem. Funnily enough, we've got lots in common!' The love of your job is now the only one that dare not speak its name. But even the French, in the privacy of an anonymous poll, say that they valued work more highly than love or sex. Blame religion for turning work into a penance, or blame economists who insist we only work to buy 'leisure' time, or blame trade unionists whose only mission in life is to win less work for their members, or blame competitiveness, or as a last resort blame the global economy. Or blame yourself for liking your job more than you like to admit. The idea of work as intrinsically bad has poisoned us for too long. The poet and mystic Kahlil Gibran said that work was 'love made visible'. Wouldn't it be great if we could capture a bit of that spirit, even if just for a while?  Richard Reeves is director of the Futures division at the Industrial Society which launches on Tuesday. You can contact him on rreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

webTitle: The further trials of Patty Hearst

fields.headline: The further trials of Patty Hearst
fields.standfirst: Patricia Hearst hadn't seen or heard of Kathy Soliah since they both robbed banks with the Symbionese Liberation Army 25 years ago. Then, a doctor's wife was arrested in Minnesota and the nightmare started all over again
fields.trailText: Patricia Hearst hadn't seen or heard of Kathy Soliah since they both robbed banks with the Symbionese Liberation Army 25 years ago. Then, a doctor's wife was arrested in Minnesota and the nightmare started all over again.
fields.body:
It was early last summer that Patricia Hearst began to hear the Kathleen Soliah rumours. Soliah had been a sometime member of the Symbionese Liberation Army that had kidnapped Hearst a quarter of a century before. She had gone underground shortly after Hearst's arrest and hadn't been heard of since. The rumours were that Soliah was hoping to re-surface, but wanted to cut a deal that ruled out jail time. Hearst had no strong feelings about this.

Then in mid-June, a photo of Soliah popped up on the TV show, America's Most Wanted ; a special to mark the 25th anniversary of the shoot-out in Los Angeles in which six of the SLA had died. A few days later, Sara Jane Olson, doctor's wife and community activist, was arrested in St Paul, Minnesota. Olson, as Soliah now called herself, was charged with the failed bombings of a couple of police cars to avenge the shoot-out. She had been arrested en route to a class she was teaching at the Center for Victims of Torture.

Hearst still felt detached. 'I just ignored it. Because what she was going to get charged with didn't concern me,' she says. We are speaking in a flat on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Hearst is more strapping than when she was a wraith on magazine covers, but she remains wholly recognisable, with big bright eyes and wavy hair the complicated colour of tarnished bronze. She speaks with the sort of American blue-blood cadences that sound like heels creaking into fresh snow, and she has an oddly old-fashioned repertoire of 'ughs!' and meaningful sighs.

This January, Judge James Ideman of the Los Angeles Superior Court ruled that the Soliah prosecution could examine all of the crimes of the SLA - the most baleful being the gunning down of a woman during a robbery in a California bank. Kathy Soliah had been part of the hold-up posse, and Hearst had been a lookout outside. The killing had never been prosecuted. Now, Hearst was to be a reluctant star witness against Kathy Soliah.

It happens that there have been certain resemblances in the vectors of Hearst's and Soliah's later lives. Both have adolescent daughters - Hearst two and Soliah three. Both act - Soliah in community theatre, Hearst in small movie roles, most especially in the films of John Waters - she plays a terrorist's mother in his forthcoming Cecil B DeMented . Both have survived.

The differences have been greater, though. Soliah hid in plain sight, in the very heart of the middle-middle-class Midwest. Hearst is married to Bernard Shaw, one of her former bodyguards, and lives in Connecticut, the most patrician of the New England states. When her name appears in print - on the invitation to a benefit, say, it is always as Patricia. It is as Patricia Hearst that she appears in movie credits. Now, she is Patty Hearst again.

On 1 July this year, Judge Ideman lifted a gag order he had imposed, ineffectually, on all parties (the trial is set for 8 January 2001). The Sarah Olson Defense Fund Committee had been raising funds by selling T-shirts and a cookbook, Serving Time: America's Most Wanted Recipes, by Sara Jane Olson, her Family and Friends . A cover picture shows Olson holding a waffle iron in one hand, handcuffs dangling from the other. At a benefit, she spoke in defence of her actions of a quarter of a century before, saying she had only been one of 'perhaps tens of thousands of people who felt the same way, acted the same way'. She added, 'I never underwent any kind of redemption. I never really changed. I just got older.'

Hitherto Patty Hearst had borne Kathy Soliah no particular ill will. Soliah had not been one of her kidnappers. Plunge back into that time. When Hearst was kidnapped on 4 February 1974, the West was waking up from the hippy dream. The Oz magazine obscenity trial had been about as extreme as things got here - but the Hearst kidnapping was a template for what was to come in the dour shapes of the kidnap-happy Red Brigades and the Baader-Meinhof Gruppe.

Hearst is the daughter of media magnate Randolph Hearst, the grand-daughter of WR Hearst, who was savaged in Citizen Kane . Her kidnapping at the age of 19 from the flat she shared with her fiancé Steven Weed on the Berkeley campus made her the most famous woman in the world - a fact of which she was at first wholly unaware. Stuck in a cupboard for 57 days, she tape-recorded demands that her father come up with what would have amounted to a ransom of $25m worth of food for the poor.

She met the eight SLA members, including Nancy Perry, Angela Attwood, Bill and Emily Harris, and their leader, the black ex-con, Donald de Freeze aka Field Marshal Cinque. Hearst submitted to sex because it was the 'comradely' thing to do. She recorded an announcement that she joined the group as 'Tania'. Soon she was absorbing Cinque's gruelling programming, which involved relentless exercise, weapons training, propaganda, self criticism, under-nourishment and unutterable fatigue, all in an interminable drizzle of weepiness. Tania was photographed holding a gun in front of the SLA symbol, a seven-headed cobra. She was photographed again, by automatic bank cameras, in the act of robbing the Hibernia Bank on 15 April 1974 - which was owned by the father of her best friend, Trish Tobin.

Hearst and the Harrises were operating as an independent unit when Cinque and the remaining SLA members perished in a shoot-out with several hundred feds - a scene that creaks with symbolic overload when you learn that the Harrises and Hearst were watching this shoot-out on the TV in a motel in view of Disneyland. But the threesome were located and hidden by a radical sportswriter, Jack Scott.

Kathy Soliah had joined the depleted cell after the shoot out because Angela Attwood had been her best friend. Kathy's brother Steven and her younger sister Josephine had also been recruited, though their roles were marginal.

But Hearst and the Harrises were nabbed by the FBI on 19 September 1975. Hearst was the only person tried for the Hibernia job. She was found guilty, and sentenced to seven years. Two years later, her sentence was commuted by President Carter on the grounds that had she not been kidnapped, she'd never have been involved in any crimes. Two years after Hearst's conviction, the Harrises pleaded guilty to her kidnapping. They served eight years. Kathy Soliah, meanwhile, had got clean away. Until now.

How determined a revolutionary had she seemed when Hearst first met her, I asked?

'There seemed to be a number of radicals and would-be revolutionaries who managed to live out their revolutionary beliefs vicariously through groups like the SLA. I think she was one of those,' says Hearst.

You found it easier to talk with Steve?

'Yeah, because he and Josephine just weren't as into it. It seemed they were more or less following their older sister. She was definitely the more committed one.'

During the last days of the SLA, the Soliahs had financed the revolution by petty theft. 'They would go to health clubs and steal people's wallets. Then they would go and write bad checks,' Hearst says. 'And shoplifting. They were all proud of that.'

Hearst took a walk with Kathy Soliah immediately before the bank job that turned deadly. She remembers Soliah had been peppy before, leaden during the getaway. 'I just remember that it was clear that something wasn't right when they got into the car. There was a problem. But everything gets further away. Now it's just impressions of what were impressions back then.'

Last October, Jack Scott, who had throat cancer, gave a 'deathbed confession' to Kathy Soliah's then attorney, Susan Jordan, and to the FBI. Scott claimed that when he offered to free Hearst, she 'told them to take her where they were supposed to, or they would all be dead'. Also, that she had her own private hit list, and that Jane Fonda was on it.

Most remarkably, Scott claimed that Patty Hearst had organised her own kidnapping with one of the SLA members 'who was Hearst's supplier of marijuana in Berkeley'. The FBI interview quotes Scott as saying 'Perry told Cinque, leader of the SLA, about the plan and he thought kidnapping Hearst would be great publicity. The other members of the SLA were not told about it.' So - in this version - those in the know died in the shoot out and the innocent Harrises went to the slammer. Two days after his confession, Jack Scott died, his claims unexamined.

I met Patricia Hearst in an ever-so-slightly fancy restaurant on Madison Avenue. What has it been like being plunged into all this again, I asked. 'I have basically spent my life trying to forget these people,' she says. 'My entire adult life has been post-kidnapping. I was 19 when I was kidnapped. I have no way of determining what I would be like without that. Because there was nothing before.'

Scott's most serious claim is that you planned your own kidnapping. In your book, Every Secret Thing , you mention that rumours you organised the kidnapping yourself sprang up right away. Why? 'Everybody believed in conspiracies at that time. Something peculiar was going on! Some people were sure that de Freeze was a government agent, that this was all a plot, that everyone worked for the CIA.'

Didn't the FBI have the SLA hit list with your name before the kidnapping? 'Oh, yeah! The FBI admitted they knew about it. What they told my mother was they had them on the run and would catch them quickly. After I was kidnapped, the FBI did inform other people. Gerald Ford's daughter, Susan, and these girls I went to school with, the Bechtels. They told me their security was massive.'

What about the hit list that Scott said you kept personally? 'Oh, that's just ridiculous. On the drive across the country? Now the SLA did keep a file of people. And we were all expected to go through the newspapers and clip out people. Like, well, what about this person?'

Jane Fonda? 'No. They were never interested in movie stars. Because in one of the books they had there was a thing about how you don't kidnap or murder soccer stars or movie stars or any of these popular icons because that just infuriates the people. You have to pick targets they understand, like generals and the police. Which leads you to wonder: why the hell did they kidnap me?'

What was Jack Scott's original motive? 'He did nothing but try to get money. He wanted money when he took the SLA across country. He wanted to write a book. He had the plans all set up to open up a bank account in Liechtenstein, and a dummy corporation, and filter money to the SLA. He had gone to my parents, even, to try to get money after he'd lost contact with the group. He was so drunk he fell down the stairs.'

Patty Hearst has been sucked back into it all - back into the time of the closet. 'Emily Harris showed me this magazine cover. It was a split cover with me on one side and Solzhenitsyn on the other. And that sticks in my mind as the most bizarre part of the whole deal. A 19-year-old kidnapped co-ed and Alexander Solzhenitsyn was a bizarre juxtaposition.'

She gives a breathy, disbelieving laugh. 'Looking back, it's symbolic of what makes people famous today. Which is nothing! Being in the wrong place at the wrong time turns you into an international cultural icon.'

No sooner had Patricia become Patty Hearst, of course, than she metamorphosed again, this time into 'Tania' the revolutionary. Powerful images defined her. The photograph of her posing with a gun in front of the seven-headed SLA cobra was art-directed by Cinque. 'That picture was lifted off a Jimmy Cliff reggae album. I think it was from the film The Harder They Come ,' Hearst says.

Even more notorious are the Hibernia Bank shots. 'I'm just so grateful that there weren't video cameras available then,' she says. 'You have no idea. If those had been available at the time, widely available, we'd still be seeing the stuff. A tape recording and photographs are not quite so effective.' Effective enough, though. Kathy Soliah was undone by her mug shot on TV.

Nervously, I produce a batch of Time and Newsweek covers, including the one in which her face is stamped with huge crude letters reading GUILTY. She looks, without flinching. 'I actually got invited to the Time magazine party,' she said. This had been the shindig celebrating the magazine's 75th birthday, at which scores of cover subjects had been present. 'I turned it down. They called four times, faxed three times. And the letter was so hilarious. At first, I thought it was a hoax. I would like to know: did Tim McVeigh get this same letter? OJ? Finally I said we were going to be out of town. And then I saw pictures of people like Mary Tyler Moore posing next to their covers. And I thought how odd would that have been.'

Field Marshal Cinque once told Tania she could never be free of the SLA. This has turned out to be a paranoid's sound sense. There was the sheer intensity of scrutiny. 'For a while, I didn't want to go out. It was hard. I mean, the traffic stopped. You would see people turn around and be walking backwards.' Hearst says. 'So many people know about the case or think they know about the case or are confused about the case. Everything he said seemed to come true.'

President Carter's decision to commute Hearst's sentence had come after reviewing the evidence and taking into consideration the numerous cases that the government was unable to make because they had put Hearst on trial. Hearst duly set the wheels in motion to apply for a presidential pardon. Eighteen months ago, her 'pardon package' reached the Justice Department.

Two weeks later, a United Parcel Service van delivered a cardboard box to the Connecticut house. It wasn't correctly addressed and she didn't recognise the name of the sender, Brad O'Husky. The UPS driver struck her as strangely insistent that she take the box indoors, but her days with the SLA - whose members frequently discussed such creative ways of death-dealing as mail bombs - have left her super-sensitive.

She refused. A few minutes later, the agents from the Drug Enforcement Administration were all over her. The box contained $40,000 worth of drugs. The UPS driver had been a DEA agent. In Connecticut, this is embarrassing - like being busted in full view of the neighbours in, say, Eaton Square.

'When those drugs came to my house, I called both children's schools,' Hearst says. 'If somebody comes with a badge showing that they're federal agents, you do not let those children go anywhere with them. You call the local police immediately. First of all, I don't believe they're federal agents. And, second, if they are, I don't want my children anywhere near them.'

The identity of the sender of the drugs remains a mystery.

'The DEA likes to think that it's an embittered old radical,' Hearst says, adding, after a fretful pause: 'I just happen to think that the timing two weeks after President Carter had talked to President Clinton about me - that to me is so suspicious! You know, I can't shake that at all.' Rightly or wrongly, she suspects some federal hand, equally embittered by so many foul ups, so long ago.

The pardon is somewhat symbolic at this juncture. 'Legally, I can vote, but I can't go to the polls because people try to stop me,' Hearst says. 'They recognise me. They just make a scene. fields.bodyText: It was early last summer that Patricia Hearst began to hear the Kathleen Soliah rumours. Soliah had been a sometime member of the Symbionese Liberation Army that had kidnapped Hearst a quarter of a century before. She had gone underground shortly after Hearst's arrest and hadn't been heard of since. The rumours were that Soliah was hoping to re-surface, but wanted to cut a deal that ruled out jail time. Hearst had no strong feelings about this. Then in mid-June, a photo of Soliah popped up on the TV show, America's Most Wanted ; a special to mark the 25th anniversary of the shoot-out in Los Angeles in which six of the SLA had died. A few days later, Sara Jane Olson, doctor's wife and community activist, was arrested in St Paul, Minnesota. Olson, as Soliah now called herself, was charged with the failed bombings of a couple of police cars to avenge the shoot-out. She had been arrested en route to a class she was teaching at the Center for Victims of Torture. Hearst still felt detached. 'I just ignored it. Because what she was going to get charged with didn't concern me,' she says. We are speaking in a flat on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Hearst is more strapping than when she was a wraith on magazine covers, but she remains wholly recognisable, with big bright eyes and wavy hair the complicated colour of tarnished bronze. She speaks with the sort of American blue-blood cadences that sound like heels creaking into fresh snow, and she has an oddly old-fashioned repertoire of 'ughs!' and meaningful sighs. This January, Judge James Ideman of the Los Angeles Superior Court ruled that the Soliah prosecution could examine all of the crimes of the SLA - the most baleful being the gunning down of a woman during a robbery in a California bank. Kathy Soliah had been part of the hold-up posse, and Hearst had been a lookout outside. The killing had never been prosecuted. Now, Hearst was to be a reluctant star witness against Kathy Soliah. It happens that there have been certain resemblances in the vectors of Hearst's and Soliah's later lives. Both have adolescent daughters - Hearst two and Soliah three. Both act - Soliah in community theatre, Hearst in small movie roles, most especially in the films of John Waters - she plays a terrorist's mother in his forthcoming Cecil B DeMented . Both have survived. The differences have been greater, though. Soliah hid in plain sight, in the very heart of the middle-middle-class Midwest. Hearst is married to Bernard Shaw, one of her former bodyguards, and lives in Connecticut, the most patrician of the New England states. When her name appears in print - on the invitation to a benefit, say, it is always as Patricia. It is as Patricia Hearst that she appears in movie credits. Now, she is Patty Hearst again. On 1 July this year, Judge Ideman lifted a gag order he had imposed, ineffectually, on all parties (the trial is set for 8 January 2001). The Sarah Olson Defense Fund Committee had been raising funds by selling T-shirts and a cookbook, Serving Time: America's Most Wanted Recipes, by Sara Jane Olson, her Family and Friends . A cover picture shows Olson holding a waffle iron in one hand, handcuffs dangling from the other. At a benefit, she spoke in defence of her actions of a quarter of a century before, saying she had only been one of 'perhaps tens of thousands of people who felt the same way, acted the same way'. She added, 'I never underwent any kind of redemption. I never really changed. I just got older.' Hitherto Patty Hearst had borne Kathy Soliah no particular ill will. Soliah had not been one of her kidnappers. Plunge back into that time. When Hearst was kidnapped on 4 February 1974, the West was waking up from the hippy dream. The Oz magazine obscenity trial had been about as extreme as things got here - but the Hearst kidnapping was a template for what was to come in the dour shapes of the kidnap-happy Red Brigades and the Baader-Meinhof Gruppe. Hearst is the daughter of media magnate Randolph Hearst, the grand-daughter of WR Hearst, who was savaged in Citizen Kane . Her kidnapping at the age of 19 from the flat she shared with her fiancé Steven Weed on the Berkeley campus made her the most famous woman in the world - a fact of which she was at first wholly unaware. Stuck in a cupboard for 57 days, she tape-recorded demands that her father come up with what would have amounted to a ransom of $25m worth of food for the poor. She met the eight SLA members, including Nancy Perry, Angela Attwood, Bill and Emily Harris, and their leader, the black ex-con, Donald de Freeze aka Field Marshal Cinque. Hearst submitted to sex because it was the 'comradely' thing to do. She recorded an announcement that she joined the group as 'Tania'. Soon she was absorbing Cinque's gruelling programming, which involved relentless exercise, weapons training, propaganda, self criticism, under-nourishment and unutterable fatigue, all in an interminable drizzle of weepiness. Tania was photographed holding a gun in front of the SLA symbol, a seven-headed cobra. She was photographed again, by automatic bank cameras, in the act of robbing the Hibernia Bank on 15 April 1974 - which was owned by the father of her best friend, Trish Tobin. Hearst and the Harrises were operating as an independent unit when Cinque and the remaining SLA members perished in a shoot-out with several hundred feds - a scene that creaks with symbolic overload when you learn that the Harrises and Hearst were watching this shoot-out on the TV in a motel in view of Disneyland. But the threesome were located and hidden by a radical sportswriter, Jack Scott. Kathy Soliah had joined the depleted cell after the shoot out because Angela Attwood had been her best friend. Kathy's brother Steven and her younger sister Josephine had also been recruited, though their roles were marginal. But Hearst and the Harrises were nabbed by the FBI on 19 September 1975. Hearst was the only person tried for the Hibernia job. She was found guilty, and sentenced to seven years. Two years later, her sentence was commuted by President Carter on the grounds that had she not been kidnapped, she'd never have been involved in any crimes. Two years after Hearst's conviction, the Harrises pleaded guilty to her kidnapping. They served eight years. Kathy Soliah, meanwhile, had got clean away. Until now. How determined a revolutionary had she seemed when Hearst first met her, I asked? Two days after his confession, Jack Scott died, his claims unexamined. I met Patricia Hearst in an ever-so-slightly fancy restaurant on Madison Avenue. Didn't the FBI have the SLA hit list with your name before the kidnapping? 'Oh, yeah! The FBI admitted they knew about it. What they told my mother was they had them on the run and would catch them quickly. After I was kidnapped, the FBI did inform other people. Gerald Ford's daughter, Susan, and these girls I went to school with, the Bechtels. They told me their security was massive.' What about the hit list that Scott said you kept personally? 'Oh, that's just ridiculous. On the drive across the country? Now the SLA did keep a file of people. And we were all expected to go through the newspapers and clip out people. Like, well, what about this person?' Jane Fonda? 'No. They were never interested in movie stars. Because in one of the books they had there was a thing about how you don't kidnap or murder soccer stars or movie stars or any of these popular icons because that just infuriates the people. You have to pick targets they understand, like generals and the police. Which leads you to wonder: why the hell did they kidnap me?' What was Jack Scott's original motive? 'He did nothing but try to get money. He wanted money when he took the SLA across country. He wanted to write a book. He had the plans all set up to open up a bank account in Liechtenstein, and a dummy corporation, and filter money to the SLA. He had gone to my parents, even, to try to get money after he'd lost contact with the group. He was so drunk he fell down the stairs.' Patty Hearst has been sucked back into it all - back into the time of the closet. 'Emily Harris showed me this magazine cover. It was a split cover with me on one side and Solzhenitsyn on the other. And that sticks in my mind as the most bizarre part of the whole deal. A 19-year-old kidnapped co-ed and Alexander Solzhenitsyn was a bizarre juxtaposition.' She gives a breathy, disbelieving laugh. 'Looking back, it's symbolic of what makes people famous today. Which is nothing! Being in the wrong place at the wrong time turns you into an international cultural icon.' No sooner had Patricia become Patty Hearst, of course, than she metamorphosed again, this time into 'Tania' the revolutionary. Powerful images defined her. The photograph of her posing with a gun in front of the seven-headed SLA cobra was art-directed by Cinque. 'That picture was lifted off a Jimmy Cliff reggae album. I think it was from the film The Harder They Come ,' Hearst says. Even more notorious are the Hibernia Bank shots. 'I'm just so grateful that there weren't video cameras available then,' she says. 'You have no idea. If those had been available at the time, widely available, we'd still be seeing the stuff. A tape recording and photographs are not quite so effective.' Effective enough, though. Kathy Soliah was undone by her mug shot on TV. Nervously, I produce a batch of Time and Newsweek covers, including the one in which her face is stamped with huge crude letters reading GUILTY. She looks, without flinching. 'I actually got invited to the Time magazine party,' she said. This had been the shindig celebrating the magazine's 75th birthday, at which scores of cover subjects had been present. 'I turned it down. They called four times, faxed three times. And the letter was so hilarious. At first, I thought it was a hoax. I would like to know: did Tim McVeigh get this same letter? OJ? Finally I said we were going to be out of town. And then I saw pictures of people like Mary Tyler Moore posing next to their covers. And I thought how odd would that have been.' Field Marshal Cinque once told Tania she could never be free of the SLA. This has turned out to be a paranoid's sound sense. There was the sheer intensity of scrutiny. 'For a while, I didn't want to go out. It was hard. I mean, the traffic stopped. You would see people turn around and be walking backwards.' Hearst says. 'So many people know about the case or think they know about the case or are confused about the case. Everything he said seemed to come true.' President Carter's decision to commute Hearst's sentence had come after reviewing the evidence and taking into consideration the numerous cases that the government was unable to make because they had put Hearst on trial. Hearst duly set the wheels in motion to apply for a presidential pardon. Eighteen months ago, her 'pardon package' reached the Justice Department. Two weeks later, a United Parcel Service van delivered a cardboard box to the Connecticut house. It wasn't correctly addressed and she didn't recognise the name of the sender, Brad O'Husky. The UPS driver struck her as strangely insistent that she take the box indoors, but her days with the SLA - whose members frequently discussed such creative ways of death-dealing as mail bombs - have left her super-sensitive. She refused. A few minutes later, the agents from the Drug Enforcement Administration were all over her. The box contained $40,000 worth of drugs. The UPS driver had been a DEA agent. In Connecticut, this is embarrassing - like being busted in full view of the neighbours in, say, Eaton Square. 'When those drugs came to my house, I called both children's schools,' Hearst says. 'If somebody comes with a badge showing that they're federal agents, you do not let those children go anywhere with them. You call the local police immediately. First of all, I don't believe they're federal agents. And, second, if they are, I don't want my children anywhere near them.' The identity of the sender of the drugs remains a mystery. fields.headline: Peel unplugged
fields.standfirst: Phil Hogan drops in for a day at 'Peel Acres' for some home truths on football, family life and that one-night stand with Germaine Greer
fields.trailText: Phil Hogan drops in for a day at 'Peel Acres' for some home truths on football, family life and that one-night stand with Germaine Greer.
fields.body:
As someone best known for doggedly cutting the same groove for most of his life, it's odd that John Peel seems to have been tainted with a reputation in recent years for being less or more than he seems. Why - some people demand to know - does he insist on pretending to be so modest and ordinary when everyone can see he's a famous celebrity and a national treasure with an OBE and a houseful of awards for his radio shows. And didn't the BBC commemorate his 60th birthday last year by devoting an evening's viewing to his genius and longevity? They even advertise his Radio 4 programme Home Truths on telly for goodness sake! So what is his problem? Why did he change his name? Why did he change his accent? He's not actually from Liverpool you know - somewhere much posher. And what's he doing interviewing people with terminal illnesses on Radio 4 anyway? Why can't he stick to what he's good at, playing that dreadful racket on Radio 1?

And then there was the diatribe by Julie Burchill, who practically accused him of being a racist and a paedophile. You can't fool her with all that stuff about being champion of the musically downtrodden and a family man with a yardful of chickens.

Peel is bewildered and hurt by stuff like this, though he says he is reluctant to protest his innocence to the point where it starts to look like guilt. He is particularly indignant at the idea that he has operated a whites-only music policy on his Radio 1 show, pointing out his long-standing passion for reggae and African music and gospel and deep soul and numerous other categories of non-whites-only music I am unfamiliar with. As for being interested in schoolgirls, well it is true that about a hundred years ago he once married a 15-year-old by accident, but, come on, that could have happened to anyone - especially in the 60s.

'A lot of the things Julie Burchill writes I kind of agree with,' he says gloomily. 'But then she goes off on one, and it kind of undervalues all the other stuff she's written. I hate being misrepresented.' He feels the same way about those who seek to expose the 'sham' of his ordinariness. 'I was enraged once when someone wrote that I lived in a grand country house and drove a fast foreign sports car. Well, yes, this house is in the country and it's nice but it's hardly grand. And I was driving a Volkswagen Scirocco at the time..' I can vouch for the house. We're sitting in his kitchen at what he likes to call 'Peel Acres', a rambling thatched farmhouse in Suffolk. Nice bit of land attached. Bernard the dog sniffs about. Peel's wife Sheila flits backwards and forwards, dispensing drinks, tossing salad for lunch, Peel is slobbing about in a 'King of the Surf Guitar' T-shirt, jeans and faded orange socks that you couldn't fake if you wanted to. Two of the kids are upstairs with hangovers. The football (Italy v Turkey) starts in half an hour. A perfect Sunday.

So far, so ordinary. But then in the middle of our cheese and hummus someone from The Guardian rings and wants to know about Peel having sex with Germaine Greer in the days of black-and-white television. Sheila rolls her eyes. 'I wouldn't mind, but he was supposed to be going out with me at the time,' she complains, though only in the way you might complain about someone walking mud into the kitchen.

'Well it was the era of free love and all that,' says Peel after taking the call. 'Besides, Germaine Greer was sleeping with everyone famous. It just happened to be my night after George Best.' He goes on to recall, with Sheila's passing help, an occasion aeons ago during his programme at Broadcasting House when the two of them nipped off for a swift shag between records, only to appear in the Daily Something-or-other 25 years later. 'The trouble is the tabloids dredge up these stories and write them up as if it happened yesterday,' says Sheila. 'Another beer?'

You could construe Peel's willingness to volunteer information and answer questions that haven't quite been asked as either ingenuousness or calculation, though it strikes me that his candour is part of his determination to be ordinary, or at least not grand. We could be just gossiping down the pub. Of course, in this, I am being invited to be ordinary, too, though I am rather spoiling the effect by ungraciously scribbling into a notebook. Peel doesn't seem to mind. He is now too busy telling me that about his passion for tikka masala curry paste, which you're supposed to cook with, but which he smears on everything. 'Except cereal, obviously,' he says. 'That would be an affectation.'

He is funny. We pass seamlessly on to Sheila's brain haemorrhage four years ago, which turned Peel's world upside down, not least, it seems, because she is his personal organiser. 'I was terrified we'd lose her knowledge of phone numbers,' he says in that deadpan way he has of reducing every utterance to the same comic denominator, a device I've noticed he uses when he's interviewing victims of unspeakable tragedy on Home Truths. 'I find that if you can introduce a moment of tasteless levity, people are extraordinarily grateful. Sometimes I think, have I gone too far? But I don't think I have done yet.'

But saying what he thinks without wondering what might happen next landed Peel in domestic strife during last year's birthday celebrations, when in the middle of a TV interview he talked with unusual intensity about the problem of his struggle to persuade his eldest son William to tidy his pigsty of a bedroom. When the show was eventually broadcast, William didn't take it well ('You fucking bastard!') and a contrite Peel was moved to publicly apologise on air. I remember that his original comments struck me as a touching attempt to reach his son when everything else had failed - the equivalent of leaving your diary open for someone to see. But Peel says it started as an innocent conversation between himself and the director. 'I knew the camera was running,' he says, 'but once they'd edited his bit out, it turned into this 20-minute hymn of hate.' He still feels bad about it.

But that's where ordinariness gets you.

We've just got time to take a stroll round his patch of England before kick-off. It's very peaceful. They bought the house for £10,250 in the early 70s and expanded gradually as their four children came along (all now strapping young adults aged 18 to 24), knocking through into the cottage next door, buying a field off a neighbouring farmer. Peel had a tennis court put in from the money he made as 'the voice of Andrex' and there's a swimming pool, too (no, not Olympic size), Sheila's vegetable plot and, yes, chickens. He admits he suffers 'middle-class guilt' at being able to take the dog for a walk without leaving the garden, though I can't help thinking it's not something most people would beat themselves up about. And he does work from here, too, sifting through a huge daily mailbag of tapes and CDs, broadcasting live on Thursdays from a room at the back. And half the house is crammed with his records and clutter.

It's not a point of dispute, though, that Peel is a class traitor of the socially downward kind. Brought up by nannies, he didn't meet his father until he was six. He was sent away at seven to boarding school and later to Shrewsbury public school. There wasn't much quality time involved. There wasn't much love. So he was attracted by affection wherever he found it. 'I suppose I was aspirant working class in a way. The kind of working class I knew seemed to be warmer, more considerate. My parents and their friends were part of a culture and society in which being rather brittle and amusing and destructive was seen as all there was. The clever put-down was very much a part of it. My dad would always introduce me like [assumes Captain Mainwaring voice], "Ah, this is John - John's the family idiot". I don't think he meant it unkindly, but of course you come to believe it. I was envious of the relationship Sheila had with her dad - they were very playful, obviously fond of each other and teased each other. And I just thought God that's great...'

Sheila (née Gilhooly) comes from a close-knit Catholic family in Yorkshire. In fact she comes from the same small town as me. Peel loves it there. It seems that while I was busy fleeing to London in the 70s, he was busy discovering its ordinariness and warmth, or at least the ordinariness and warmth of Sheila's relatives.

He looks at his watch. 'Shall we, er...'

We head inside for the footie. I risk another beer and Peel pours a glass of red wine and tells an anecdote about some terrible cheapskate Radio 1 football competition during which he was trapped in a Gothenberg hotel with a flatulent prizewinner with whom he had to share a room, and a gang of English hooligans who ate all the goldfish from the tank in the breakfast lounge. Sheila berates the referee. Italy win 2-1. I have to ring home to say I'm running slightly late due to being looked after too well. By the time I put the phone down, Peel is asleep in the chair.

Sheila sighs as if he's such an embarrassment, and takes me out to see his old white Chevrolet hidden away in the garage - a ridiculously huge thing with a boot the size of nearby Ipswich - followed by an inspection of his seven-inch singles, which he started keeping in the stable after the horse died. Eventually, Peel comes out bleary-eyed.

' John...' says Sheila reproachfully.

'What? I only had one-and-a-half glasses,' he says, pleading tiredness after driving back from a wedding yesterday.

We sit out in the open air for a while talking about children. (For the record, I've edited mine out.) As you might expect, Peel is as laid-back a father as a teenager could wish to not get on with, with mellow views on education ('I always told them that passing exams and going to university was a good way of getting out of Stowmarket') and drugs ('You have to have a practical attitude. You're not going to stop them doing teenage things unless you're fantastically severe and brutal. The only thing I'd tell them is there's no quality control, so the one time you try drug X could be the time that it really messes you up'). In view of his slightly non-interventionist childcare policy, I'm surprised he gave his eldest so much grief about his room - especially when you see the state of Peel's own working environment. Ah, yes, well. He points out that he can't possibly keep pace with all the boxes of tapes and CDs that flood in. Even so, I remember seeing Andy Kershaw in a TV interview telling how a woman from the BBC's premises department once came storming in complaining that Peel's studio contravened the Health and Safety at Work Act.

But back to bedrooms. 'The thing is,' he says, 'I suppose I used to go to a lot of trouble to find things for the children that I thought they would like and be interested in or amused by - CDs or whatever. You'd give them these things and you'd find them just stirred into the soup on the floor. It's really not much more than that.'

But did it not occur to him that the poor boy might merely have finally discovered a way of rebelling after years of being allowed to smoke dope, not to do his homework and play thrash techno speed metal at full volume whenever he wanted?

He's looking at his watch. He's quite interested in seeing the next match. 'Maybe if we just turned the sound down?'

They even advertise his Radio 4 programme Home Truths on telly for goodness sake! So what is his problem? Why did he change his name? Why did he change his accent? He's not actually from Liverpool you know - somewhere much posher. And what's he doing interviewing people with terminal illnesses on Radio 4 anyway? Why can't he stick to what he's good at, playing that dreadful racket on Radio 1? And then there was the diatribe by Julie Burchill, who practically accused him of being a racist and a paedophile. fields.headline: The loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: Baise-moi
fields.trailText: Baise-moi
fields.body:
Qu'est-ce que c'est que ça? A French film that's causing no end of a commotion in the cafés of Paris and which has become a major embarrassment for the French government.

Tell me more. Well, Baise-moi means 'fuck me' and tells the tale of two women who go on the rampage after one is brutally raped and the other witnesses a violent shooting. It was given an over-16 certificate, with the proviso that it carry a warning about 'an uninterrupted sequence of particularly crude sex, and images of particular violence that could profoundly disturb audiences'. This wasn't warning enough for the far-right pressure group Promouvoir, which has forced the state council to overturn the classification and withdraw the film. Jean-Luc Godard and Claire Denis, among others, have joined a demonstration outside the MK2 Odéon cinema, which has refused to stop screening the film. Its two female directors, Virginie Despentes and ex-porn star Coralie Trinh Thi, claim that the decision amounts to a revival of post-war censorship.

But aren't the French quite 'comme ci, comme ça' about this sort of thing? They were - but Paris film-makers are now worried that a precedent has been set whereby far-right-wing groups can dictate content. The affair has also upset the culture minister, Catherine Tasca, who'd cleared Baise-moi for over-16s on the advice of the censorship board, which included church advisers.

Will we be able to see what all the fuss is about? Certainly - British film distributors Optimum are in negotiations. Bizarrely, there is a plan to change the title to Rape me , which is deemed less controversial. Managing director Will Clarke believes that 'films like this can perform an important function' but have to be 'decent artistically'.

So is it a quality piece of work, 'artistically' done? Apparently not - it was universally panned by the French press. The directors must be relieved by Promouvoir's intervention.

webTitle: The way we live now: Westway

fields.headline: The way we live now: Westway
fields.standfirst: What are we like?
fields.trailText: What are we like?
fields.body:
Do they mean us? We all want to know - it's the national equivalent of the 'Does my bum look big in this?' question, and one that came to mind when a recent poll revealed that 40 per cent of us regard the BBC as our 'top export'. For much of the globe, that means the BBC World Service - the semi-autonomous section paid for by the Foreign Office which was set up in the anxious years prior to the Second World War to propagate the morals of Empire, Queen and Flag. Things might have changed a bit at the World Service's Bush House HQ, but its broadcasts are still our front parlour, the bit of ourselves we invite the world and his granny into for a shuftie and a cuppa. So what does it reveal about us to its 151 million listeners around the globe (plus handfuls of British insomniacs)?

Well, there's the obvious stuff: its high-quality international news, delivered so clearly a half-deaf dog could follow it. And the less obvious stuff: the way they tell the time, for a start. Where you or I would say 'six o'clock', the World Service version is 'six hours GMT'. I asked the World Service about it, but they had no idea why they did it. I have a theory, though - that it was a cunning wartime invention to unmask Nazi spies. Undercover British agents would ask suspect strangers what time it was. If they replied, 'Four hours GMT, old chap,' it would be, 'Straight to pokey for you, matey.'

And then there's Westway . You've probably never heard of it but it's the World Service's twice-weekly, 15-minute soap which went on air in November 1998. 'The one and only global drama,' they blurb it.

So what does the world see through this window into modern Britain? A health practice set in Notting Hill. Or rather a Notting Hill of the imagination, in W15, with an imaginary tube station, Westgrove Park. It does, however, have a realistic flyover - the one from which it takes it name. You can see all these, plus the Catholic church and the Green Man pub, on the map at its website, www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/arts/features/westway, where you'll also find pictures of the cast in character.

It's flagrantly multicultural. There are Nigerians, Catholics, a Parsee and his wife Janet, an 'unconventional nurse with roots in Scotland and Bombay'. An aid worker assures me the West African accents are embarrassing, but that's probably more of a problem for us than it is for the rest of the globe - we must never forget that the seemingly racist 70s sitcom Mind Your Language was a giant international hit.

Like all soaps, Westway started with a bang. Well, a baby - a 12-year-old girl having an emergency birth in the health centre itself, her offspring the product of stepfather rape. Its setting may be a modern twist on the BBC's original urban radio soap, Mrs Dale's Diary , but a tourist brochure, it ain't.

Nor is it very Notting Hill. Missing are antique shops, crack dealers, the Cobden Club, Trustafarians, London's largest Portuguese community and fashionable restaurants - 192, Julie's, etc - with tables full of BBC hobnobbers. Westway characters never bump into well-known locals like Ruby Wax or Robbie Williams. Nor does Julia Roberts choose it as a place to disappear into anonymity. 'Though we did contemplate having her break her ankle and pop into the centre,' says Westway creator and editor David Hitchinson, who promises future celebrity guests. Instead you get solid English actors enunciating very clearly. Mel the receptionist is played by Clare Perkins as a young Barbara Windsor, only black this time. Jamshed the health centre manager is supposedly voiced by Paul Bazely but, Parsee or not, his outer-London sullenness makes him sound a dead spit for Paul Merton. The cry of 'Jam-shed!' is to Westway what 'Rickeee!' was to its Eastern cousin.

What does the world see of us in it? That we go to the pub a lot - something that attracts complaints from Asian listeners. That we have the same problems as everyone else, though maybe more of them. In a handful of episodes, I checked incontinence, failed pregnancy, teenage homosexuality, Hindu/Muslim conflict, loss of libido, depression, dodgy passport dealing and confusion over London's new phone codes.

Listeners may or may not find it improves their English, but they'll certainly become fluent in Soapish, learning phrases like 'Some people!', 'Sorry isn't good enough, Jamshed, it's just not good enough!' and 'Don't give me your guilt trips, Joy.' They'll also pick up the odd neologism, like 'You jammy dodger!' - actually, I think that one's another cunning World Service trap for any Nazi spies still hanging around.

It doesn't do badly at all by us. As David Hitchinson says, 'Our job is to present a slice of contemporary life. We're not saying that really is how it is here.' Although its relative grubbiness has upset older expats, it has found a new, younger, less British global audience - 10,000 pieces of email and snail mail have arrived since it started. It's apparently big in China's Guanjong Province and a cult among Seattle truckers. To a lot of people, Westway is probably a postcard from a promised land of sorts.

It can certainly entrance. I learned this from a conversation with an Englishwoman who'd recently spent some time with 10- to 12-year-old girls in a refugee camp on the borders of Sierra Leone and Liberia. They told her tales of absolute horror, then said Westway was their favourite programme and asked her to take their picture and pass it to the cast. Apart from seeing a facile link with Westway 's opening rape-and-birth scene, though, it's beyond me what these young Sierra Leoneans make of the show. As is what they might make of the real Notting Hill. What I do know is that if they ever make it there, they'll have every reason to consider themselves the dictionary definition of a jammy dodger. Or they'll get arrested as a Nazi spy.

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... immortality
fields.trailText: ... immortality
fields.body:
They say life is not a dress rehearsal - but there are, in fact, opportunities for a few changes of costume and script. Needless to say, the metaphyiscal nature of immortality means that the following costs are only approximate.

Most mainstream religions recognise that life after death is always the most popular part of a belief system. Consequently it is, to an extent, a sellers' market. Christianity, for example, claims that whoever believes in the Son of God 'should not perish, but have everlasting life' (John 3:16). Great - except 'it is easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God' (Matthew 19:24).

Eastern religions, such as Buddhism and Hinduism, are a bit more flexible. The Tibetan Book of the Dead (£7.99) outlines the correct, if complicated, procedure for transcendence.

If these religions run established stalls in the afterlife marketplace, then cults are the shadowy crack dealers. Aum Shinrikyo, the Japanese cult that used sarin gas in Tokyo, promises ultimate happiness (but worldly possessions must be donated to the cult). The Raelian Movement believes that the cosmic being 'Elohim' will soon arrive by UFO. It is offering the first human cloning service (£137,000 per clone) and espouse free-love and 'sensual meditation'.

Scientologists assert that we are all 'thetans', immortal spirits who have 'forgotten' we are immortal. Don't worry, Scientology can remind you. For a price! Annual membership is £205, but it costs much more to progress to each new level of awareness through 'auditing': you'll have to spend £685,000 to become a Gold Patron Meritorious. (Although it is only £6,850 to become a new Crusader.)

Scientists, pragmatically, have kept faith with good old liquid nitrogen. Cryonics is the freezing of your corpse (or parts thereof) until technology exists that can revive you. Whole-body suspension and storage is just £92,500, while brain-only suspension is £10,250. Those on a budget can preserve a DNA sample for £100. But how difficult will it be to fit into a futuristic society? Particularly when you look like a zombie.

Bible £5.99
Tibetan Book of the Dead £7.99
Cult membership life savings
Cloning £137,000
Scientology £3,500 to £685,000
Cryonic society membership £205/year (student rate £37/year)
Whole-body suspension £92,500
Head-only suspension £48,000
DNA £100

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: After weeks of turmoil and uncertainty following the departure of its chairman and star fund manager, Jupiter is trying to reassure its investors in an advert headed 'Performance as usual'.
fields.body:
After weeks of turmoil and uncertainty following the departure of its chairman and star fund manager, Jupiter is trying to reassure its investors in an advert headed 'Performance as usual'.

The advert, which has appeared in the personal finance sections of several newspapers, including Cash, says: 'The key to successful fund management is a dedicated team of fund managers working to a clear and consistent strategy. This formula has been the secret of Jupiter's outstanding performance over the past decade. And all the ingredients for continued achievement remain firmly in place.'

Jupiter's claims have startled one Observer reader, who says: 'Performance as usual? I don't think so - not if you are one of the thousands of investors who put money into the Jupiter Global Technology fund which was launched last February. The fund has lost up to 35 per cent of its value, leaving it near the bottom of the technology unit trust sector.'

In fact, the fund is thirteenth out of 16 similar technology funds over the period since its launch, turning £1,000 into £795, excluding charges, for its unlucky investors.

So what has happened to Jupiter's formula for success when it comes to the technology sector? Steve Glynn, Jupiter's marketing director, says: 'The timing of the launch was unfortunate. It happened just at the peak of the market. That said, we made it clear that it was a volatile market and that investors should take a long-term view.'

He points out that the fund has outperformed the average of its two benchmark indices, Nasdaq and TechMark, and that over the two months to 17 July the fund actually went up in value by 16.4 per cent.

Justin Modray, of Bath independent financial adviser Chase de Vere Investments, says: 'This fund hasn't got a long enough track record to judge its performance yet. The fund manager may have a style which will work well long-term, but which doesn't suit the short-term market.'

He advises existing investors that it is too early to jump ship, but warns them to keep a close eye on the fund's progress. For those who want to invest in a technology fund, he suggests Henderson Global Technology and Société General Technology, both of which have a longer, more stable record.

 Seen an advertisement or mailshot that looks too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch, Observer Business, 119 Farringdon Road, Loncon EC1R 3ER.

webTitle: Speed king who's slow at spending

fields.headline: Speed king who's slow at spending
fields.standfirst: Jackie Stewart tells Natalie Sutton he's still scared of bankers
fields.trailText: Jackie Stewart tells Natalie Sutton he's still scared of bankers.
fields.body:
Jackie Stewart is slowing his pace a little at 61 following a a glittering motor racing career in which he was world champion three times and founded and ran his own grand prix team. He sold out and it became Jaguar Racing, of which he is a director and a consultant.

It's a change from 18-hour days which used to test his stamina. He attributes 'any success I might have achieved' to his 'focus, commitment and dedication, which almost override any of my other inadequacies. It's single-mindedness and enthusiasm that make businesses work.'

Jackie is dyslexic, and claims that his education was 'zero to nil'. But, he says, he has always been very good at attention to detail, self-discipline and compartmentalising, particularly when dealing with finances.

'As a professional sportsman you are hopelessly spoilt. You sometimes make hideous amounts of money with no apparent difficulty simply because God gave you a natural talent and ability that allows you to do things that most people only dream of.'

'As you become more successful you then earn more money. As you earn more money it gets more complicated because then it's no longer a case of worrying because you're dealing with a hundred pounds or a thousand pounds - it can become hundreds of thousands, or even millions.

'The people you choose for advice make the difference between whether that money grows for you, or it's just kept secure.

'I was blessed with being able to do certain things but that does not give me a passport to expect things to be equally easy in other areas. I always go to experts - I like the idea of going to somebody who is already proven and who hasn't slacked off.'

For someone associated with a glamorous world, he is remarkably frugal. 'I never ever spent, in one year any more than I earned, ever. For many, many years I saved 50 per cent of my annual income - all household expenses, all educational expenses, all travel expenses, all living expenses.

'When I was racing, there was a two out of three chance that you were going to die if you lasted five years. My investments had to be very conservative. I had easy cashflow but it had to be put into very safe, solid stuff. I worried about what would happen to my wife and two sons if I were killed.'

Jackie acknowledges that his origins made him careful with money and good at business. 'The Scots are very canny and very cautious, and That's been a great asset. I've passed it on to my sons. They are not like the kids of some wealthy people, who run into problems with money. My wife has been a very good mother and has guided them strongly.

He is a little bit more relaxed about money now, because of accumulated wealth. 'I don't have a yacht, I've never had a racehorse. I've got most things I want.'

Yet he admits a mild fear of bankers. 'My father had a wee business which wasn't doing very well. Going to see the banker was like going to see the devil. I still have to take a Valium before going into a bank. Now I'm getting quite clever with those cashpoint things and I don't have to go into the bank. It doesn't make me flinch at all. I've got myself trained!'

'I've never been refused credit on my American Express card,' he says, with apparent surprise but a twinkle in his eye. 'I've got one of those green ones. The platinum one costs more... why would I want one?'
