webTitle: Painful wait for justice after accident at work

fields.headline: Painful wait for justice after accident at work
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
Industrial accidents have forced me to accept early retirement after 20 years as a care worker.

The last injury was in March 1998 when I had to move a 20-stone stroke patient and damaged my spine. I was employed by a local authority and the industrial injuries doctor said it was clearly a case of gross negligence as my employer sent me to a do a job without knowledge of what would be involved.

I am claiming on my employer's insurance, with Zurich Municipal. In December 1998 they said they were looking in to it but I worry they will soon say I have left it too late.
EK, Sidmouth

On 5 June, Zurich Municipal told me that a date had been arranged for your examination. They admitted a breakdown in communication; while you were waiting to hear from them, they assumed that you had 'lost interest' in the claim.

By 26 June, you had still heard nothing and this time Zurich said there were few specialists in the UK qualified to examine injuries like yours. They said they were still trying to find a specialist who was geographically close until I reminded them that they had given you the name of someone nearby on 19 April and you had confirmed you would attend. On 30 June, Zurich promised to chase its claims handler.

Ten days ago, you received an appointment - for 15 November. Then you will have to wait for the consultant to send in his report, so it is likely to be the New Year, nearly three years after your accident, before Zurich tells you whether or not it will meet your claim.

This is an appalling delay, but it cannot be time-barred by the courts' three-year restriction because you have already started your claim. Consultants are paid promptly for medical examinations; insurance companies suffer no worse inconvenience than unclosed files. But the people who have suffered pain and injury are forced to wait years for justice because the law demands that disputed claims go to court.

Exchanging cash: Which card is best?

The Royal Bank of Scotland has increased the loading it adds to the exchange rate when I use my debit card abroad from 1.75 per cent to 2.65 per cent. I wondered whether it would be more economical to use my HSBC Switch card, but the information line told me there was a charge of £1.50 per transaction. Which is the best deal?
PW, London

You have been confused by the £1.50 charge. You pay HSBC 1.5 per cent, minimum £1.50, for cash withdrawals (but not when buying goods) on plastic; HSBC also imposes a 2.25 per cent loading on debit and credit cards used overseas.

Most banks charge 2.75 per cent. Royal Bank of Scotland's debit card loading now matches its credit card and is more expensive than HSBC. You pay 2.65 per cent plus an administration fee for cash and purchases. The debit card fee is an extra 2 per cent, minimum £1.50 and maximum £4. The credit card costs 1.5 per cent, minimum £1.50 with no maximum.

Nationwide has the best deal because it has no loading on debit or credit cards used abroad and charges just 0.5 per cent, minimum 50p, for cash on its credit card but nothing for cash on the debit card.

Two signatures: Request refused

My partner and I require that both our signatures are put on our NatWest cheques. This works well.

We recently arranged a flexible Woolwich Open Plan Reserve Account, but when we insisted that both our signatures be needed on cheques, the Woolwich refused to allow it. This goes against the sensible way in which we run our finances. Can you help?
CP, Milton Keynes

Woolwich says the reason it cannot accept cheques only if signed by both of you is because you each have a cheque guarantee card. If one of you writes a cheque in a shop backed by the cheque card, the bank has to honour that cheque. NatWest confirms that it, too, cannot accept two signatures from customers who have cheque guarantee cards.

Pension cut: Wrong figure

In February, I decided to retire at the end of May. I contacted Pearl about my pension and the representative gave me a figure of £103,373. But when Pearl sent the discharge form, I was dismayed to find that the fund value had reduced to £72,503. I have tried without success to obtain a satisfactory explanation and have had to delay my retirement.
AM, Merthyr Tydfil

Pearl says a clerical error produced the wrong figure in February. Its representative claims he told you he thought it looked odd because you had received a much lower quotation the previous November and that he would go back to check.

This is no more than I would expect him to say, but the Pearl is not going to pay you a higher pension based on a miscalculation. If you want to pursue this, talk first to the Occupational Pensions Advisory Service on 020 7233 8080.

Writeback: Bags of trouble

Airlines' responsibility for lost or damaged bags continues to concern readers.

PG, of Lymington, writes: 'I am pursuing a claim against an airline for the theft of my Mini-disc Walkman from my hold baggage. The airline has offered a settlement based on the weight of the missing item, a paltry sum. I have read the legislation and found that the restriction of liability is based on the weight of the package or checked baggage. In your reply to AH of London, you apply the limit to the Walkman's weight rather than the weight of the item of checked baggage. Who is correct?'

The Hague Protocol, which covers airlines' responsibilities, says: 'In the case of loss, damage or delay of part of registered baggage or cargo, or of any object contained therein, the weight to be taken into consideration in determining the amount to which the carrier's liability is limited shall be only the total weight of the package or packages concerned.'

It is not clear whether 'package' means 'baggage or cargo', or the object inside.But my understanding is that, if the whole suitcase goes missing, you can claim for the weight of the bag. But if one item in the case is damaged or stolen, you can claim only for the weight of the individual article. Worse, this is the maximum that airlines can be forced to pay. And they can argue that, if the item had an inherent defect, they are not liable; airlines have argued that being fragile is itself an inherent defect.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

The last injury was in March 1998 when I had to move a 20-stone stroke patient and damaged my spine. I was employed by a local authority and the industrial injuries doctor said it was clearly a case of gross negligence as my employer sent me to a do a job without knowledge of what would be involved. I am claiming on my employer's insurance, with Zurich Municipal. In December 1998 they said they were looking in to it but I worry they will soon say I have left it too late. EK, Sidmouth On 5 June, Zurich Municipal told me that a date had been arranged for your examination. They admitted a breakdown in communication; while you were waiting to hear from them, they assumed that you had 'lost interest' in the claim. By 26 June, you had still heard nothing and this time Zurich said there were few specialists in the UK qualified to examine injuries like yours. They said they were still trying to find a specialist who was geographically close until I reminded them that they had given you the name of someone nearby on 19 April and you had confirmed you would attend. On 30 June, Zurich promised to chase its claims handler. Ten days ago, you received an appointment - for 15 November. Then you will have to wait for the consultant to send in his report, so it is likely to be the New Year, nearly three years after your accident, before Zurich tells you whether or not it will meet your claim. This is an appalling delay, but it cannot be time-barred by the courts' three-year restriction because you have already started your claim. Consultants are paid promptly for medical examinations; insurance companies suffer no worse inconvenience than unclosed files. But the people who have suffered pain and injury are forced to wait years for justice because the law demands that disputed claims go to court. Exchanging cash: Which card is best? The Royal Bank of Scotland has increased the loading it adds to the exchange rate when I use my debit card abroad from 1.75 per cent to 2.65 per cent. I wondered whether it would be more economical to use my HSBC Switch card, but the information line told me there was a charge of £1.50 per transaction. Which is the best deal? PW, London You have been confused by the £1.50 charge. You pay HSBC 1.5 per cent, minimum £1.50, for cash withdrawals (but not when buying goods) on plastic; HSBC also imposes a 2.25 per cent loading on debit and credit cards used overseas. Most banks charge 2.75 per cent. Royal Bank of Scotland's debit card loading now matches its credit card and is more expensive than HSBC. You pay 2.65 per cent plus an administration fee for cash and purchases. The debit card fee is an extra 2 per cent, minimum £1.50 and maximum £4. The credit card costs 1.5 per cent, minimum £1.50 with no maximum. Nationwide has the best deal because it has no loading on debit or credit cards used abroad and charges just 0.5 per cent, minimum 50p, for cash on its credit card but nothing for cash on the debit card. Two signatures: Request refused My partner and I require that both our signatures are put on our NatWest cheques. This works well. We recently arranged a flexible Woolwich Open Plan Reserve Account, but when we insisted that both our signatures be needed on cheques, the Woolwich refused to allow it. This goes against the sensible way in which we run our finances. Can you help? CP, Milton Keynes Woolwich says the reason it cannot accept cheques only if signed by both of you is because you each have a cheque guarantee card. If one of you writes a cheque in a shop backed by the cheque card, the bank has to honour that cheque. NatWest confirms that it, too, cannot accept two signatures from customers who have cheque guarantee cards. Pension cut: Wrong figure In February, I decided to retire at the end of May. I contacted Pearl about my pension and the representative gave me a figure of £103,373. But when Pearl sent the discharge form, I was dismayed to find that the fund value had reduced to £72,503. I have tried without success to obtain a satisfactory explanation and have had to delay my retirement. AM, Merthyr Tydfil Pearl says a clerical error produced the wrong figure in February. Its representative claims he told you he thought it looked odd because you had received a much lower quotation the previous November and that he would go back to check. This is no more than I would expect him to say, but the Pearl is not going to pay you a higher pension based on a miscalculation. If you want to pursue this, talk first to the Occupational Pensions Advisory Service on 020 7233 8080. Writeback: Bags of trouble Airlines' responsibility for lost or damaged bags continues to concern readers. PG, of Lymington, writes: 'I am pursuing a claim against an airline for the theft of my Mini-disc Walkman from my hold baggage. The airline has offered a settlement based on the weight of the missing item, a paltry sum. I have read the legislation and found that the restriction of liability is based on the weight of the package or checked baggage. In your reply to AH of London, you apply the limit to the Walkman's weight rather than the weight of the item of checked baggage. Who is correct?' The Hague Protocol, which covers airlines' responsibilities, says: 'In the case of loss, damage or delay of part of registered baggage or cargo, or of any object contained therein, the weight to be taken into consideration in determining the amount to which the carrier's liability is limited shall be only the total weight of the package or packages concerned.' It is not clear whether 'package' means 'baggage or cargo', or the object inside.But my understanding is that, if the whole suitcase goes missing, you can claim for the weight of the bag. But if one item in the case is damaged or stolen, you can claim only for the weight of the individual article. Worse, this is the maximum that airlines can be forced to pay. And they can argue that, if the item had an inherent defect, they are not liable; airlines have argued that being fragile is itself an inherent defect.  Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. webTitle: Camera vanished on the beach? Tell us more...

fields.headline: Camera vanished on the beach? Tell us more...
fields.trailText: People claiming on travel insurance policies may soon have their telephone calls bugged by a lie-detecting system.
fields.body:
People claiming on travel insurance policies may soon have their telephone calls bugged by a lie-detecting system.

Truster Pro, a digital voice analysis system that can pinpoint increases in anxiety and excitement during a conversation on the phone, is being sold to general insurance companies in the UK. Lee Marks, director of Spymaster, the surveillance equipment specialist promoting the system, claims Truster Pro is 98 per cent accurate. He says the system can be applied equally effectively to all forms of general insurance claim. 'Although the fact that a person has been identified as lying by Truster Pro cannot be used in a court of law, it will help insurers identify claims which warrant further investigation,' he says.

The system works by detecting small changes in the sounds made by a person's vocal chords. When a person speaks, air is pushed up from the lungs into the vocal chords, making them vibrate at a specific frequency. But when a person feels stressed, for example when he or she is lying, the amount of blood in the chords drops, making them produce a distorted sound wave.

Personal insurance fraud is estimated to have cost insurers more than £645 million last year, according to figures compiled by the Association of British Insurers (ABI). Travel insurance fraud alone accounts for about £50m. Many people regard making a dishonest claim as a reasonable way to recoup some of the premiums they have paid over the years, not realising that the cost is passed on to all policyholders in the form of higher premiums. Marks says: 'Insurance fraud is a major issue - it's almost a national sport.'

However, although Truster Pro sells for just £4,000 - a mere snip for the average insurer, companies are wary of admitting interest. John Wagstaff, manager of crime and fraud at the ABI, says: 'There is no scientific evidence that this works, and I'm not sure how we'd use the information.'

Bill Trueman, head of fraud at Direct Line, agrees that the technology needs further testing before insurers take it up. 'I don't think we could afford to use the technology to make judgment on our customers. If it did work, though, it would be nice.'

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Bonus time at Skipton | Perks for all | Early present
fields.body:
Bonus time at Skipton
Skipton Building Society is taking the unusual step of paying one-off bonuses, averaging nearly £170, to its members even though it has no plans to convert to a bank.

The society has made £50 million on the sale of its share dealing service, Dealwise, and will distribute the money to members. The society denies this is an attempt to bribe customers to support its mutual status.

'If we didn't do anything and just sat on the extra £50m profit, we would have been accused of sitting on capital. We believe this is a positive and moral stance,' the society says.

A third of Skipton's 450,000 members will not receive the special bonuses because they will go only to savers who had accounts on 30 September 1996 and maintained membership until 19 July this year. The same dates apply to mortgage holders.

A total of 300,000 people will get the bonuses, which for savers will be 4 per cent of their total savings balances on 30 April this year. The minimum amount will be £5 and the maximum £500. Borrowers will receive 0.4 per cent of their loans. Again the maximum is £500, so a member with savings and a loan could receive £1,000.

Savers will receive their money when interest is due on their accounts. Borrowers can have their September mortgage payments reduced or have the sum used to reduce their mortgages.

The special payments are sailing into uncharted tax waters; there have been no such payments in the past. Flotation windfalls have always been subject to capital gains tax, but few society investors are ever liable for CGT, which means that few have paid tax on their windfalls. Savers who are taxpayers will have to pay income tax on their windfalls, although Skipton says that the number affected is 'less than the majority'.

Many people will have the money paid into a Tessa or Isa; others are children who do not pay income tax anyway. Skipton does not expect borrowers to have to pay interest.

However, the Inland Revenue rarely approves groundbreaking schemes but waits until they have been put in place before examining them.

Perks for all
A new guide to share perks is available from Premier Asset Management. Among the perks available are 10 per cent off holidays from companies in the Airtours group and 10 per cent off flights and holidays for owners of at least 200 shares in British Airways. Shareholders in housebuilder Barratt who have a minimum of 1,000 shares for 12 months before completion of a purchase, will get a discount of £200 for every £25,000 on a new home. Redrow Group offers 1 per cent off the price of a new home if you hold at least 2,500 shares for 12 months.

The guide costs £2.50 but is free to the first 200 readers applying. Tel: 0800 212577. You can also email perks@premierfunds.co.uk

Early present
Bradford & Bingley customers can expect conversion windfalls in time for Christmas. The society's 2.5 million savers and borrowers voted in favour of flotation last week; shares should be distributed on 4 December.

Savers must have at least £100 in an account at midnight on 3 December 2000. Those with mortgages must have a loan outstanding at that time. Anyone whose loan is due to be paid off before then can keep a minimum of £100 on the account to get the windfall.

Yorkshire Building Society is promoting a deal giving B&B borrowers 1 per cent off B&B's standard mortgage rate (currently 7.64 per cent) for two years, with arrangements to allow B&B borrowers to keep £1,000 on their mortgage accounts until they receive their free shares.

Borrowers unmoved by Yorkshire's offer should consider remortgaging in the New Year. If history repeats itself, B&B's rates will not be attractive compared with building societies and internet and telephone banks.

Members will be entitled to 250 shares. Those with borrowings and savings receive 500. B&B's advisers estimate that 250 shares will be worth between £647 and £815, but some analysts say they could be worth less than this in six months' time.

Like most societies that have converted, the first-named individual on a joint account will receives shares. So the estranged wives of men named first on a former matrimonial mortgage will miss out. But children whose accounts are held in trust in the name of a parent will receive shares.

Tel: 0845 6011456

Get that tax back
Thousands of employees could find that they are still due a repayment from the Inland Revenue for the tax year 1998/99. The Revenue has been slowed down by computer problems and has yet to process the PAYE and National Insurance deductions of 1.3 million employees for that year.

Paul Falvey, tax partner at accountant Grant Thornton, urges anyone who thinks they may have overpaid in that year to look at their records: 'Write to your tax office setting out the reasons why you may have overpaid.' Many employees slightly over- and underpay each year because of the way medical insurance and other benefits in kind are calculated.

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: The Newcastle Share Tracker Mortgage
fields.trailText: The Newcastle Share Tracker Mortgage
fields.body:
Contact 0191 244 2468 or any branch of the Newcastle upon Tyne building society.

Aim To allow homebuyers to benefit from a rise in the FTSE 100 index without using a single penny of their own money.

Bells & whistles Borrowers choose a 0.65 per cent discount or one of 0.75 per cent which lasts five years (those who opt for the bigger discount pay a £350 completion fee).

How does it work The mortgage 'tracks' the FTSE 100 index from 1 October 2000 to 30 September 2005. If the index rises by 50 per cent or more from its starting level at the end of this time, the borrower gets a 'cashback' equal to 10 per cent of the loan (up to a £25,000 maximum). Clients can use the money to reduce their mortgage. If the index doesn't rise by 50 per cent or falls below its starting point, there is no impact on the loan. Barclays Capital says the 50 per cent threshold would have been achieved in 73 per cent of all five-year periods from 1990 to 30 June 2000.

Clients may borrow up to 85 per cent of their home's value.

Minimum Mortgage of £15,000; maximum £250,000.

Charges Legal and valuation fees and early redemption fees of 2.5 per cent for the first two years, 2 per cent for the third, 1.5 per cent on the fourth and 1 per cent on the fifth.

Tax No tax is payable on the cashback bonus.

Risk None, if you were intending to take out a variable rate mortgage anyway, low if you wanted a discount mortgage, and medium in terms of the investment risk.

Should you borrow? Phillip Cartwright of Bath independent mortgage broker London & Country Mortgages says: 'It's a gamble. In terms of what it can give you if the market rises, it's the best. But it is only suitable for borrowers who can put up with not knowing if they'll get the money or not.'

Ray Boulger of London firm John Charcol agrees. 'I would equate it to investing in premium bonds. You surrender some of the ongoing benefit of a lower discount rate for the chance of a big bonus at the end,' he says.

Points out of 10 Cartwright - 8, Boulger - 6.

fields.headline: £750 'gift' from Uncle Gordon
fields.standfirst: Pensioners may not see much of the largesse, says  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Pensioners may not see much of the largesse, says Neasa MacErlean.
fields.body:
You may not have followed every word uttered by Chancellor Gordon Brown last week when he announced his Comprehensive Spending Review, but what it amounts to is that about £750 per head extra is to be spent by the Government on your behalf over the next three to four years. The big question is whether you will feel £750 better off by 2004.

Since a huge chunk of the money is going to education, you are more likely to notice it if you have children. Of the total £43 billion public spending plans announced last Tuesday, more than a quarter - £12bn - is going that way. Many educationalists have responded with delight. Extra money to universities may stave off the need to increase fees for undergraduates. And a typical secondary school in England will see its direct government funding rise from £40,000 to £60,000 next year.

School heads have a much freer rein in deciding how to spend this direct funding than they have with the money they get from the local education authorities, their main source of funding. Many heads are likely to spend it on repairing their dilapidated buildings. Much of this £12bn will be spent compensating for a period of very tight financing after Labour took office.

As with education, much of the other spending will be catching up after a period of austerity. The 4,000 new police officers will merely restore numbers to 1993 staffing levels - 128,000.

Even so, we are all likely to benefit from this large injection of public spending, says Carl Emmerson of the Institute for Fiscal Studies. 'It is inconceivable that there won't be an improvement in public services,' he says. The more open question for him is when these improvements will show through. It could be that there is little noticeable difference in some areas for the first couple of years - road-building, for example, or the £270m going towards starting banking services in post offices.

But the Chancellor's speech is just as interesting for the areas he neglected. 'It doesn't augur very well for pensioners,' says Mervyn Kohler of Help the Aged. 'The Chancellor's ann ouncements were about how we carve up the growing wealth of the nation. But where were pensioners? There was a deafening silence.'

The spending review would not have been the place for an announcement on increases in the basic state pension, for instance - since that rise is usually part of November's 'uprating statement' or possibly included in the Budget - but commentators were surprised that Brown did not make more encouraging noises to this important part of the electorate.

But there will be more news for the elderly later this week when the Department of Health unveils the way it will use its extra £13bn allocation. Plans will include, in the Chancellor's words, a 'major package of investment in services for elderly people - including the Government's response to the Royal Commission on Long-Term Care'.

Help the Aged and Age Concern suspect that this announcement will be less generous than the solutions suggested by the Royal Commission. If the Government were launching a very attractive package, it would probably have made the announcement separately in order to reap the political benefits rather than let it be wrapped up in general news about the future of the National Health Service.

Also disappointed were representatives of those on low incomes and benefit claimants. While the Chancellor announced a 0.75 per cent increase for social security payments, over and above inflation, this is more projection than plan. Social security rises are announced on a yearly basis, usually in an uprating statement in November.

But Martin Barnes of the Child Poverty Action Group feels that more should still have been said last week: 'If the Government cannot be more radical at this time - given the buoyant economy - whenever can it be radical? This is a golden opportunity to tackle poverty once and for all. We are concerned that in recent months some Ministers have seemed embarrassed to talk about poverty.'

But Barnes expects that the November statement could be 'like a mini-Budget for social security'. He believes political pragmatism will encourage Brown to announce an above-inflation increase in the basic state pension.

But will the £43bn lead to inflation and to increases interest rates? Charles Levett-Scrivener of independent financial adviser Towry Law would not be surprised to see higher mortgage rates by the end of this year.

webTitle: Going abroad hit my finances hard

fields.headline: Going abroad hit my finances hard
fields.standfirst: ... and being a housing worker is no guarantee of an end to housing worries, Sheila Tolley tells  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: ... and being a housing worker is no guarantee of an end to housing worries, Sheila Tolley tells Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
Sheila Tolley

Age 40

Lives in Manchester

Occupation Regeneration manager

Earns £31,000

Mortgage £20,000

Debts £14,750

Investments None

Pensions 12 years' contributions

Aims to Reduce debt and reorganise housing

Two years ago, Sheila Tolley packed in her long-standing job with a housing association and flew to South Africa. She hoped to find work in a township but had nothing lined up: 'I went out not knowing what to expect.' She landed up in Ivory Park, a large township between Johannesburg and Pretoria, managing a project to transform tin shacks into homes. They completed 450 in a year. But then funding ran out and she felt that because of the political tension she should return home.

Sheila now has a six-year contract working on urban regeneration in Salford but earns £2,000 a year less than the housing association paid, with no company car or health insurance. Her budget is tight because, while abroad, she earned a local wage and her debts, including £5,300 on her Visa card, grew.

Her main worry is her own housing. When a relationship broke up some years ago, she had to sell a jointly-owned semi, leaving insufficient funds to buy a place on her own. So she chose a two-bedroomed flat on a shared equity basis. She bought half the flat in 1989 for £24,500 with a £5,000 deposit. Four years ago, she borrowed another £6,000 to put in a new bathroom and kitchen. 'I have no desire to move but I am contemplating whether to buy the other half or perhaps an additional quarter share.'

She is not convinced this is right, given her earnings and debts, but fears it will become too expensive if she delays: 'The price of the additional share will rise, as flat prices in Manchester are fairly buoyant.'

Buying more would push up her mortgage repayments but reduce the rent on the remainder. She also has to pay for the valuation and remortgaging costs but can offset the money spent on improvements. Another option is to keep just half and buy a small investment property to rent out.

Housing is not the only call on her spare money: 'I would like to pay some extra money into my pension and clear my credit card bill.' She also owes her parents £1,500; £750 to a previous employer for half the course fees for an uncompleted masters degree, and £200 a month for her car for the next three years.

She wonders if she should pay the National Insurance contributions she missed while abroad. 'My desire is to get back into overseas development work, perhaps in a position which allows me to continue to live in the UK or an overseas job that pays me sufficiently to allow me to keep my home in the UK without having to rent it out.' But, realistically, she says: 'Both options will be difficult to achieve, as salaries in the sector are poor and because I went into this line of work late in life at the age of 38.'

Adviser 1: Danielle Leich

Purchasing the remaining half of her flat doubles Sheila's outgoings - a big jump for anyone - but she can afford another quarter share and to repay her debts faster. It is important to clear the debts quickly.

She should check her Visa APR as rates vary and she may find lower rates by transferring the debt to another card. Barclays charges only 5.9 per cent on transferred balances. Many credit card companies offer introductory rates, such as Nationwide's 3.5 per cent, for the first six months, but she should check what rate applies after this. Sheila might consolidate her debts to one lender at lower interest, but she should continue paying the same amount to repay the debt faster.

Everyone can miss five years National Insurance contributions and still qualify for the maximum pension. To work out if catching up is worthwhile she should complete form BR19 (available from any Benefits Agency, or call 0191 218 7585). The Agency forecasts pension entitlement, details missed payments over the last six tax years, and advises what is needed to make up these contributions. They will show the impact that missing payments have on the final pension.

For a second property, she needs a deposit and money for conveyancing. Mortgage rates are higher for investment property. Rental income is taxable and she faces capital gains tax when the property is sold.

 Danielle Leich works for PriceWaterhouseCoopers.

Adviser 2: Ian Millward

Sheila has £400 a month to spare, which allows her to pay off her debts and boost her pension. As she owns only half her flat, she will earn just 50 per cent of any rise in property value which suggests that she should buy more as soon as possible. On paper at least, she can afford the mortgage on her present income.

It is important she clears her debts and, when increasing her home loan, she might be able to roll her expensive short-term debt into the mortgage. She would pay more interest in the long run but her monthly outgoings would be minimised now. With a fixed-rate mortgage she knows exactly what her outgoings are for a few years.

As she was working while in South Africa, she can pay class II National Insurance contributions at £2 a week to make up the shortfall. This has recently been reduced and will cover sickness, health pay, maternity leave and the state pension, so could be worth doing.

If she does work abroad again, she probably cannot afford the flat without renting it out, so she should check rent levels. If the rent would meet her new higher mortgage payments, she knows that the costs of her home could be met from rental income.

It is sensible to increase pension contributions, either as added years or through AVCs, to protect her future security.

 Ian Millward works for Bath-based financial adviser Chase de Vere.

fields.headline: Hunt for your hidden riches
fields.standfirst: Billions are lying unclaimed.  Jill Insley  on how to claim your share
fields.trailText: Billions are lying unclaimed. Jill Insley on how to claim your share.
fields.body:
Assets worth more than £15 billion lie unclaimed in Britain's financial institutions - and some of it could belong to you.

These riches include shares worth about £3 billion, life and pension policies valued at £4bn, and dormant savings accounts worth £5bn. The National Lottery has unclaimed prizes totalling £316m.

It may seem incredible that people have mislaid all this wealth, but it is easy to lose track of investments. You may have moved house and forgotten to tell the relevant institutions your new address. You could have lost the paperwork. A company may have merged with another, changing its name without your knowledge. Or a spouse may have died without telling you about a policy or investment.

So how do you check?

Assets register

Details of life insurance policies and pensions are on the Unclaimed Assets Register, established by insurer AON. It aims to add unclaimed shareholdings soon.

For £15 - £1.50 of it goes to charity - the register matches claimants' details to lists of unclaimed policies supplied by insurers. Twelve leading companies are taking part so far, including Standard Life, Zurich, Legal & General and Prudential.

Try to supply current and past addresses, maiden and married names and details of the policy or insurer. Visit the website www.uar.co.uk or call 0870 2411713.

National Savings and Premium Bonds

About £2bn lies in dormant Post Office accounts and Savings Certificates. If you recall investing in National Savings but can't remember withdrawing it, phone 0191 386 4900 for Savings Certificates, or 0141 649 4555 for other National Savings.

If you've held bonds for a long time and have never won, perhaps you've failed to tell Ernie of a change of address. If you have your numbers, check the website, www.nationalsavings.co.uk, or write to Premium Bonds, Blackpool FY3 9YP.

Windfall shares

Millions of building society conversion shares have yet to be claimed. Three years after conversion, the new plcs may sell unclaimed shares, but the proceeds and dividends must be kept for a further nine years (most put the proceeds into a charitable trust). The companies no longer have to send out their annual report and accounts to 'phantom investors'. But they must make 'reasonable efforts' to find them and inform them of their entitlements, and give three months' notice in the press that they will sell the shares.

Abbey National: The first society to convert, in 1989, sold unclaimed shares in 1992 for £100m. Very little cash has been claimed since.

There is just one year left to act, but chancers be warned: Abbey will charge a £11.75 search fee, refundable only if you qualify. Anyone still holding their 100 Abbey shares could now sell them for £754, but if yours were among those sold in 1992, you will receive just £385 in cash. Call 0870 532 9430.

Alliance & Leicester: About 68,000 ex-members have yet to claim shares now due to be sold on 27 September.

Each is entitled to 250 shares, worth £1,269. You must have been the first-named holder of a mortgage or share account which held at least £100 between 14 October 1996 and 24 February, 1997. Phone 0870 900 7700 or visit www.alliance-leicester.co.uk.

Woolwich: Some 40,000 people have not claimed shares now worth £72m with dividends, and the former society has advertised its intention to sell them.

You must have been the first-named holder of a mortgage or share account holding £100 at midnight on 31 December 1996 and on the same day a year later, plus £1 in a share account from then until conversion. Phone 020 8308 8900 or visit www.thewoolwich.co.uk.

Halifax: The third anniversary of this conversion was on 2 June, but the bank has not yet announced that it will sell unclaimed shares. It is still looking for 150,000 shareholders, whose shares are worth £186m.

You must have had a mortgage or £100 in a share account on 25 November 1994 and again on 12 December, 1996, and have kept that account until conversion. Call 08705 522566.

Northern Rock: Only 6,000 people have failed to claim shares. To qualify, you must have had a mortgage on 2 April 1996, 31 December 1996 and 22 August 1997, or £50 in a share account on 2 April 1996, £100 on 31 December 1996, and £1 from then until conversion. Savers and borrowers were entitled to 500 shares each, or 1,000 if they were both. Write to Shareholder Relations Department, Northern Rock, Regent Centre, Gosforth, Newcastle.

Norwich Union: Merged with CGU last May, and 18 million unclaimed shares have been sold for £4.96 each. To qualify, you must have held a with- or without-profits life or pension policy, or an annuity issued by NU Life Society, in force from 1 October 1996 to 18 April 1997. Phone 0870 6003952.

Research firms

About five specialist companies track down 'dissenting' shareholders who fail to claim their share or dividend entitlements after mergers or takeovers. They may have sat tight because they disapproved of the deal. Companies are obliged by law to maintain shareholders' entitlements for 12 years, and they must try to locate such investors during that period. At the end of the 12 years, however, the entitlements must be paid into court, which makes it difficult to claim the money.

Some research firms, such as Shareholder Communications, are appointed by companies to do the tracking. The company hands over information about the shareholder, such as the last known address, The researcher also uses electoral rolls, BT and Somerset House, and contacts neighbours or the new occupants of homes where shareholders used to live. Shareholder Communications charges 10 per cent of the value of the assets

Other firms work independently of the companies whose registers they are researching, which makes the task more difficult and expensive.

Lottery prizes

Seven people have missed their chance to become millionaires because they failed to claim on their lottery tickets in time. In Hull alone, three tickets won a total of £3,471,763, apparently unbeknown to their owners.

You have up to six months to claim after the draw. After that, your winnings go into the 'good causes' fund.

If you find a ticket up to six months old, your local retailer can scan it to see if you've won a prize. Alternatively visit the website www.nationallottery.co.uk.

webTitle: Help - how can I cut the cost of car insurance?

fields.headline: Help - how can I cut the cost of car insurance?
fields.trailText: The days when you could be fairly certain that your car insurance premium would fall, or at least remain static, have gone. The era of falling bills finished at the end of 1996, and they've been rising ever since.
fields.body:
The days when you could be fairly certain that your car insurance premium would fall, or at least remain static, have gone. The era of falling bills finished at the end of 1996, and they've been rising ever since.

The insurers are trying to claw their way back to profitability after years of intense competition in an overcrowded market, and the cost of claims has been increasing.

The average comprehensive premium for a UK driver is now £561.24, nearly 53 per cent more than in July 1994 and 4.4 per cent higher than last April, says AA Insurance Services. Year-on-year, the bills are up 20 per cent.

The first step in fighting back is to avoid automatically renewing your cover. Get several quotes. A few telephone calls could save you hundreds of pounds a year.

The AA says an average of the three cheapest quotes for comprehensive cover in its regular surveys produced a premium of £345.83 this month, saving the average driver £216 a year. For non-comprehensive cover, the saving would be almost £210 a year. The AA offers a 10 per cent discount for buying on the internet, and suggests checking premiums with a broker.

If you are unable to achieve the savings discovered by the AA survey, you may have to limit your cover. For example, cut the number of named drivers on the policy or accept a higher excess. Some companies charge less to women and the over-fifties.

A spokeswoman for the AA, which uses a panel of 20 insurers to find the cheapest deals, says: 'Just because an insurer might specialise in the over-fifties does not mean they will be the cheapest. It's best to shop around.'

People's Choice, another intermediary, says premiums for even supposedly high-risk cars can be cut by trawling the market. It recently reduced the cost gap between insuring a riskier soft-top car and the safer saloon version to only £91.86.

AA insurance Services: 0800 444 777

People's Choice: 0800 112233

webTitle: Your shopping can raise a trolley-load of cash for charity

fields.headline: Your shopping can raise a trolley-load of cash for charity
fields.standfirst: Giving to good causes needn't cost you a penny under new corporate partnership schemes  where charities have teamed up with businesses to raise money. If your budget is too tight to afford a donation, you can show generosity simply by choosing 'partnership' firms to do business with for everything from your weekly grocery shopping to insurance and banking needs. And it won't hurt a bit. Virginia Wallis reports
fields.trailText: Giving to good causes needn't cost you a penny under new corporate partnership schemes where charities have teamed up with businesses to raise money. If your budget is too tight to afford a donation, you can show generosity simply by choosing 'partnership' firms to do business with for everything from your weekly grocery shopping to insurance and banking needs. And it won't hurt a bit.
fields.body:
Before you head for the summer sales, think about providing a little retail therapy to your favourite charities as well by taking out one of the many fee-free charity credit cards. Provided you pay your bill off in full every month, it won't cost you a penny. And you'll get a warm glow from knowing that every time you use it the card issuer is adding to the £33 million that these cards have raised for charitable causes over the last decade.

The most successful in the world,according to the Guinness Book of Records, is the Halifax Visa Charity Card, which since its launch in 1988 has donated £6.4m to the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, £3m to the British Heart Foundation and £2.7m to Mencap (customers choose which charity to support when they apply for a card).

Even if you use a charity card only once, the charities involved will receive a one-off donation of anything from £1 to £10 (see table). The Co-op, for example, doubles its initial donation of £5 to for some of its cards if you apply online.

But what charities really benefit from is the steady income they get in the form of a percentage of the amount spent on the card. The most generous is People's Bank, which donates 60p to Comic Relief for every £100 spent on its Little Red Card. The United Nations Children's Fund (Unicef) gets 50p per £100 while most other charities receive 25p. HSBC, meanwhile, gives the National Trust 5p per transaction.

American Express doesn't issue a charity card as such but lets Amex cardholders convert their membership reward points into a cash donation to the Save the Children Fund - a scheme that has earned the charity £500,000 in the last four years.

Save... and let a charity prosper

Your savings can earn charities extra donations, too. For example, each time a customer opens a Call Direct account - which pays 6.8 per cent on balances of £2,500 and above - the Chelsea Building Society (0800 169 1076) donates £1 to Shelter. Until 31 July, Cheltenham & Gloucester (0800 717505) will give £1 to the National Trust Neptune Coastline Campaign when any of its UK-based savings accounts is opened - new customers will also receive two free admission tickets to most National Trust properties.

People with savings of at least £1,000 can earn 6.55 per cent and a modest donation by Bristol & West (0845 111 0114) to Challenging Childhood Cancer and Leukaemia. Customers also have the option of adding to the £250,000 that Bristol & West is committed to raising by donating the interest earned on a CLIC Easy Access Account. Birmingham Midshires (0845 602 1318) is hoping to raise £750,000 for the British Heart Foundation and has kick-started the campaign by donating £50,000. The remainder will be raised through staff fundraising events and customers donating 5 per cent of interest earned on its Heartbeat Account, which requires a minimum balance of £1,000. The interest on this 30-day notice account is 5.25 per cent, rising to 5.75 per cent for savings of £5,000 and above.

You need only £500 to open a Save the Children Investment Account with the Bank of Scotland (0800 068 2500) but the interest paid is a less-than-charitable 3.5 per cent. However, you may feel it's worth it for the £10 the charity gets when you open the account, as well as a donation equivalent to 0.25 per cent of your average yearly balance.

The same percentage donation is made by the Royal Bank of Scotland (0800 121 121) to the RNLI on its 30-day notice Harbour Account, which earns the charity £8,000 a year. You need £500 to open the account but it pays a reasonable 5 per cent in interest, rising to 5.25 per cent on £5,000 or more.

Three charities benefit from the Caring Saver Account from Leeds & Holbeck Building Society (0500 225 777), which has so far given £16,000 each to Help the Aged, Marie Curie Cancer Care and Save the Children. While the account doesn't pay huge interest (2.15 per cent on the minimum balance of £100, rising to 4.1 per cent for £2,500or more), the donation is a generous 1 per cent of average yearly balances.

The Newcastle Building Society (0191 244 2244) has two charity-related accounts: the Key Account gives 0.25 per cent of the average balance to Shelter; while Save & Care, makes the same donation to Nottinghamshire Hospice. Both can be opened with £1, require 30 days notice of withdrawals and pay 1.85 per cent on balances up to £100; 4.25 per cent on higher amounts.

Make a virtue of necessity

Next time you are shopping around for insurance, first phone a charity you support to find out about special deals. CGU donates 10 per cent to NCH Action for Children for every policy bought by the charity's regular donors. The RSPB has a similar deal for policies sold by Frizzel. RSPCA Pet Insurance (0870 242 6242) earns the charity 5 per cent of all premium income. Naturesave Policies (01803 864390) pays 10 per cent of premium income on its home and travel policies into a fund that benefits environmental and conservationist projects.

Buying any policy from Ecclesiastical is a charitable act. As well as being charity-owned, it gives 9.5 per cent of pre-tax profits to good causes.

Net gains

If you're thinking of changing your internet service provider, why not switch to www.care4free.co.uk an ISP dedicated to supporting charities? There are no charges other than the flat rate of 1p a minute for calls to connect to the Internet. Your first 10 hours online earn your chosen charity £1 but the main way charities benefit is by receiving a share of 75 per cent of all profit generated through Care4Free.

If you don't mind paying local call charges, an alternative ISP is www.4u2give.co.uk which, if it meets its target of attracting 100,000 active users, hopes to raise £1m a year for charity.

Oxfam supporters can support its work by signing up for 'Yahoo! Online with Oxfam' (0870 241 0874 or pick up a free CD from an Oxfam shop).

If you are planning to buy from the likes of Amazon, Blackstar videos and Tower Records, head for www.moneytin.com a shopping portal that diverts the percentage it receives from your purchases to your chosen charity or school. Money raised from visits to www.care2.com is donated to environmental charities.

Give your time

Oxfam estimates that each of its volunteers contributes an average £720 a year to the charity's work. At Shelter, volunteers make up 80 per cent of its staff. Without them, says the charity, it couldn't run its shops.

Eat, drink and be charitable

Buying Fair Trade produce is not the only way you can guzzle and give. SlipSunraysia Prune juice into your shopping trolley to secure a donation to the Cancer Research Campaign of 15p per litre bottle (5p per 250ml bottle); a jar of Duerr's Traditional English Marmalade earns the charity 1p. More generous is the 50p paid to Shelter when customers send back Baxter's fresh soup lids (maximum two lids per person). If you buy Duchy Originals, profit goes to The Prince of Wales Charitable Trust. Sample the Amnesty International menu at Jim Thompson's Oriental Bar Restaurant Bazaar and the charity receives £2.50. Pizza Express does its bit for Venice by adding an optional 25p donation to the bill of anyone ordering a Veneziana pizza.

2 People over 50 are nearly twice as likely to give as those under 30. The over-fifties donate an average of £2 a week more.

3 In the decade to 1996, the income of the top 400 charities rose 38 per cent, as the UK gross domestic product grew 20 per cent.

4 Lifeboats, the UK's fourth frontline emergency service, is funded entirely by charitable donations to the Royal National Lifeboat Institute (RNLI).

5 One new charity is registered in Britain every 20 minutes on average.

6 In terms of income from donations, Oxfam is the UK's largest charity, followed by the National Trust, the Imperial Cancer Research Fund, the Cancer Research Campaign and the RNLI.

7 More is invested in medical research by British charities than by the whole of the National Health Service.

8 Charities spend an average of 13 per cent of their total income on fundraising and administration.

9 The UK's most popular charitable causes are international aid, cancer, animals and children. Least popular are HIV, hospitals, education and the deaf.

10 One pound in every seven donated goes to charities relieving suffering in developing countries.

Source: Charities Aid Foundation

How to give at the office

Shame on you if you toss your used printer and/or fax machine cartridges in the bin. Not only is it unsound environmentally, but you are also depriving charities of a useful source of income. Gareth Edwards of the Royal National Institute of the Blind, estimates that the charity's recycling scheme, launched last March, will bring in £6,000 this year, rising to £30,000 in 2001.

'Donations' are made by posting spent ink-jet and laser cartridges using Freepost bags or address labels supplied by the charity. For more details, phone 01388 517 087 or email gedwards@rnib.org.uk. Free bulk collection can be arranged from businesses. A similar scheme raises money for Project Hope UK, which funds health projects in countries such as Malawi and Kosovo. Send any make of used cartridge (except Epson) in a plastic bag to: Accutec (Hope Appeal) Freepost ANG 2044, Harlow, Essex CM20 2YF. Alternatively, use recycling bins in charity shops.

fields.headline: Let's bomb them
fields.standfirst: It's 'reality TV' - but what is reality in a society warped by television?
fields.trailText: Big Brother
fields.body:
Big Brother (C4)

Watching Big Brother, Channel Four's new contribution to the fad for 'reality TV', the viewer is confronted with an inescapable moral question: is the prospect of winning £70,000 sufficient cause to be confined in a house alongside Craig, the self-confessed 'Scouser' with a habitual impatience to remove his clothes.

It's certainly minimal compensation for living with Caroline, the former marital aids saleswoman from Birmingham who boasts: 'People have described me as mad.' I also hesitate to put a figure on what it would require to get me under the same roof as Sada, the New Age author and aspirant yoga teacher. Whatever the amount, I'd feel short-changed.

For Big Brother 's 10 contestants, though, it's not really about the money. Most claimed that they had submitted themselves to the invasive scrutiny of 24 round-the-clock cameras for the 'experience'. Yes, and Miss World wants to travel and help children. Clearly the motivation here is all about exposure (in Craig's case, of his penis). As Nichola, the 28-year-old 'freelance artist' from Bolton, said: 'I applied for Big Brother because I want to be famous and I want to be rich.'

Seventy grand doesn't make you rich, but 10 weeks on TV could easily bring you fame. Traffic wardens and driving instructors have opened supermarkets on less screen time. So we understand why the participants, all previously unknown to each other, have volunteered to be holed up in a purpose-built house for as long as two- and-a-half months.

But why should we want to watch them? Going by the first instalment, the answer patently doesn't lie in the characters themselves - five men and five women in their twenties and thirties. Most of them have a surfeit of personality but precious little natural charisma, rather as if they had borrowed their identities from soap stars.

One of the ironies of modern media is that as it grows more and more pervasive its aim is increasingly to record unmediated experience. So television wants to show the world as it is, but the world as it is has been irreversibly warped by television. We're all performing a received version of ourselves. Which explains why the men in Big Brother mocked up an improvised basketball court, because that's what guys do when they bond together in (American) TV shows and aftershave adverts. And why Caroline's zany eccentricities are so painfully familiar.

There was also not much to be gripped by in the social dynamics of the group. At this early stage, it's a reasonable bet that the security cameras in the forecourt of your local petrol station contain footage with more character and tension.

Yet there is a good reason why millions of viewers will tune in. Big Brother is a guaranteed winner because each week someone loses. As far as I understand the voting system, every seven days the group members nominate two of their number to be ejected from the house and therefore ruled out from winning the prize money (which is awarded to the last person remaining at the end of the series). But the viewing public decides which of the pair actually goes.

Thus the inhabitants are forced not only to compete among themselves for attention and popularity but also with each other for the affections of the TV audience. The scenario invites the possibility of multi-levelled deceit and duplicity, and sets up a fascinating contradiction: the group is supposed to work together on various tasks yet survival comes down to the individual. For most of the introductory episode there was scant evidence of these underlying psychodramas. We saw the men smoking and letting off wind. Craig was optimistic that his laissez-faire attitude to flatulence would prove contagious. 'Only a matter of time,' he noted, 'before the birds start farting as well.' Before that moment was to arrive, we got to listen to a different kind of feminine hot air. 'I suppose we need each other gender-wise,' said one of them, very likely Sada.

A series of contrived set-pieces, including a 'spontaneous' truth game and a pointless pottery-making exercise, failed to reveal much about the 10, save what was immediately obvious - that Craig is eager to shed his underpants. And from four days of constant filming, the editor had his work cut out to assemble a watchable hour.

But towards the end of the programme, Melanie, a pretty 26-year-old investment banker, and Nicholas, a terribly Fulhamish 32-year-old City broker, began to emerge as much-needed provocateurs. When Nicholas grilled Darren, a 22-year-old bachelor and father of three children, on whether he thought he had a chance of winning and if he considered himself the token black man in the team, the pretending stopped and the game began.

Each group member gives a sort of diary testimony to camera. At Nicholas's turn, he showed an almost military appetite for the forthcoming battle. 'I think there is potentially conflict,' he declared in the methodical delivery of a group captain, 'and that will be coming down to tiredness or lack of food.'

Nicholas and Melanie were soon discussing who they thought would be dumped first. (The hot favourite was poor Tom, a sweet-natured and taciturn Irishman, who seemed to have mistakenly wandered in from the set of One Man and His Dog ). Interestingly, once the pair had acknowledged their predicament, they almost began to forget it. Melanie, a smart operator who is not to be trusted, made the tactical error of voicing her opinion of the audience: 'I think the public are idiots,' she said. She's right, of course, but we don't necessarily like to be reminded of it.

The flaw in reality TV, egregiously demonstrated in MTV's The Real World, is that the reality of the subject's situation - the omnipresence of TV cameras - is seldom if ever mentioned. Whereas in fact the sole reason for their particular reality is the TV cameras.

Second-generation reality TV, or voyeur TV as it has also been called, has acknowledged the problem by adding another purpose. In the case of the BBC's Castaway 2000, it's the anthropology of the community, a millennarian attempt to forge a new beginning on a remote island. The Americans have developed their own version of Castaway, called Survivor, set on a tropical island. But they binned the idealism and replaced it with a more ratings-friendly Lord of the Flies ruthlessness, in which each week a new Piggy is booted out.

They picked up this Darwinian twist from the egalitarian Dutch, of all people, who first came up with the format that has now been imported here as Big Brother . In Holland, where the show was something of a phenomenon, the eventual winner was a man with the improbable name of Bart Spring. Apparently he triumphed despite being deeply unpopular with his fellow house guests, although that did not prevent one of them from sleeping with him.

Strategically speaking, sexiness, or more specifically the promise of having sex, is probably the most reliable protection against being voted off. And a sort of freshers' week spirit of carnal anticipation rather clumsily informed much of the social interaction. The question is which couple among this lot would have sex with one another, and, more intriguingly, where? By rights Craig, who sees himself as an 'entertainer' and Caroline, who is easily entertained (her diabolical cackle sounds like fingernails on a blackboard), should get together. But I for one would turn the telly off.

Darren let himself down by placing a clay phallus outside the women's dormitory; Andrew is hardly a catch, having announced his intimate knowledge of South East Asian brothels; the razor-haired, face-pierced Nichola is too scary; Tom is too quiet; Sada has a boyfriend; and Anna, the former nun, is a lesbian ('Are you?' said Sada. 'Oh that's wonderful.') That leaves Nicholas and Melanie.

I sense they're both canny enough to manufacture a romance, or at least a flirtation, but too smooth to let it go any further. Not least because, as far as it's possible to tell, any further means the shower. I understand that the most frequently asked question on Channel Four's website prior to the show's broadcast was whether there would be a camera in the shower. There is and, naturally, we've already seen Craig in it, washing the mysteriously compliant Nichola.

Incidentally, the website is full of charming little details about Big Brother and the contestants, and if you are the owner of a mainframe computer with the power to run a large-scale business operation, you might even be able to download images of life in the house, should you begin to miss it between the bi-weekly shows and the nightly updates. On my small iMac, I failed to ascertain if there is a camera in the lavatory. This information may prove crucial because at the very end of last week's episode we discovered that the group had run out of toilet paper and Big Brother was not prepared to supply them with any more. Melanie responded to the news with the kind of steely pragmatism that served to increase both my admiration and suspicion. 'Just use your hands,' she said.

When it comes to reality TV, however artificial, there is perhaps such a thing as too much realism.

 Kathryn Flett is away

webTitle: How to give until it hurts a little less

fields.headline: How to give until it hurts a little less
fields.trailText: If you have spare cash to give to charity, it's worth making use of the tax breaks available.
fields.body:
If you have spare cash to give to charity, do make use of the tax breaks available. These have recently become significantly more generous than in the past.

Reforms announced in this year's Budget mean that companies can give any amount to charity and get tax relief on the full amount. The same is true for employees (and some pensioners) who are able to give through 'give-as-you-earn' schemes run by their employers. Until 2003 there's the added bonus that the Government will add an extra 10 per cent to every donation made this way. So if you give £10 a month the charity gets £11, at a cost to you of £7.80 if you're a basic-rate taxpayer; £6 if you pay tax at the higher rate. This is 'the single best way to give', says Michael Brophy, chief executive of the Charities Aid Foundation. The CAF is also enthusiastic about the revamped and simplified Gift Aid scheme, which does away with the need for regular donations to be covenanted and abolishes the minimum £250 for one-off donations. Provided charities have written confirmation that a donor is a UK taxpayer, they can now recover tax paid on any cash gift - irrespective of its size or frequency. Since it is the charity, rather than the donor, that claims tax back from the Revenue, these changes do not affect basic-rate taxpayers. However, higher-rate taxpayers may find that more of their charitable donations are eligible for the extra relief they can claim by entering details on their self-assessment tax return.

All taxpayers can take advantage of new tax relief on donations of shares, which the CAF estimates will generate 'tens of millions of pounds in charity income'. Not only will share donors be let off paying capital gains tax, they can also use the gift to reduce their income tax bill. No dealing costs are involved in transferring share ownership. fields.bodyText: If you have spare cash to give to charity, do make use of the tax breaks available. These have recently become significantly more generous than in the past. Reforms announced in this year's Budget mean that companies can give any amount to charity and get tax relief on the full amount. The same is true for employees (and some pensioners) who are able to give through 'give-as-you-earn' schemes run by their employers. Until 2003 there's the added bonus that the Government will add an extra 10 per cent to every donation made this way. So if you give £10 a month the charity gets £11, at a cost to you of £7.80 if you're a basic-rate taxpayer; £6 if you pay tax at the higher rate. This is 'the single best way to give', says Michael Brophy, chief executive of the Charities Aid Foundation. The CAF is also enthusiastic about the revamped and simplified Gift Aid scheme, which does away with the need for regular donations to be covenanted and abolishes the minimum £250 for one-off donations. Provided charities have written confirmation that a donor is a UK taxpayer, they can now recover tax paid on any cash gift - irrespective of its size or frequency. Since it is the charity, rather than the donor, that claims tax back from the Revenue, these changes do not affect basic-rate taxpayers. However, higher-rate taxpayers may find that more of their charitable donations are eligible for the extra relief they can claim by entering details on their self-assessment tax return. webTitle: Like money from the bank - up to a percentage point

fields.headline: Like money from the bank - up to a percentage point
fields.trailText: You may not be aware of it, but banks are among the country's largest supporters of charity.
fields.body:
We all know that banks are big, bad and there to be bashed. Well, most of the time. Despite their many shortcomings, banks are also among the country's largest supporters of charity. You may not like your bank, or agree with the way it does business, but it may soothe your conscience to know that indirectly you are helping to support their charitable activities.

With its stance on animal welfare, armaments, ecology, fair trade, human rights and social involvement it is not surprising, perhaps, that the Co-op also donates 2.7 per cent of its pre-tax profits to charitable causes, and is seen as one of the most generous corporate givers in the UK.

But customers of Lloyds TSB may also be pleased to learn bank charges have not been paid in vain. According to the Directory of Social Change , which monitors corporate giving, Lloyds TSB is one of the most philanthropic corporate donors and this year will make cash donations to charity totalling £31.3 million. This largesse is matched only by Barclays and NatWest - provided you add their 1999 corporate con tributions together and include non-cash donations in the form of employee time, gifts in kind and the management costs associated with their charitable activities. But the size of a donation isn't everything.

A more telling measure of a company's generosity is the percentage of its profits that it is prepared to donate.

The industry-led Business in the Community movement, whose mission is to inspire companies to make 'social responsibility an essential part of business excellence', sets a benchmark of 1 per cent of pre-tax profits. Using this standard, you can see why the Co-op has been commended by the BITC for its corporate generosity. But the Co-op lags behind Northern Rock which, as one of the top 10 givers in the UK, donates 5 per cent of its pre-tax profits to charitable causes. Barclays and Lloyds TSB only just exceed the 1 per cent benchmark, while NatWest and all the other banks have got a lot of catching up to do.

fields.headline: Ulster aims for global stage
fields.standfirst: A new, hi-tech Northern Ireland is hoping to mirror the South's success, reports  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: A new, hi-tech Northern Ireland is hoping to mirror the South's success, reports Jamie Doward
fields.body:
Jeremy Glover used to work for a Belfast advertising agency. A few years ago, while pitching for a government agency account, he tried to articulate what the province and its people stood for and how this could be communicated to foreign investors. 'Let's show the world what we are made of,' was the resulting slogan.

Admittedly this may look a little humble considering the hubris of today's advertising lexicon, but Glover would admit that Northern Ireland has not been the easiest brand to advertise abroad. 'The history of the Troubles has made us very inward-looking. It's dampened the entrepreneurial spirit.'

But things are, slowly, starting to change. Devolution and an end to violence have brought greater stability, which has in turn helped nurture a new business environment. Now, in an attempt to emulate the success of its southern neighbour, Northern Ireland is looking to ride the New Economy wave.

The success of a raft of fledgling companies - including two-year-old Blackstar, the online DVD and video retailer which Glover co-founded and which now sells to 147 countries - is helping to overcome the region's innate business conservatism.

Kim Johnston runs KJX, an e-business consultancy based in Belfast. She says: 'Northern Ireland has been very slow to catch up with the rest of the UK. People have had this "grant mentality". They've looked for money from LEDU [the local government funding agency] or the Industrial Development Board rather than go to their bank manager. For 30 years it's been very difficult to get them to change their mindset.'

Perhaps this is understandable given that the rest of the world has tried to ignore Northern Ireland for three decades. But no longer.

Canadian telecoms leviathan Nortel Networks has opened a site in Belfast which employs 1,500 people. Japanese giant Fujitsu recently announced plans to build a state-of-the-art engineering centre in the city.

Many overseas firms are attracted by the quality of the workforce. Northern Ireland is already regarded as the best place to site call centres, a fact which has not escaped the notice of technology companies who need to hire support staff.

Skilled workers tend to be cheaper here, too. In the US it costs around $130,000 to find and hire an IT graduate for a year. It costs $90,000 in Dublin; $75,000 in Belfast.

There are indigenous success stories, too. Apion, a communications software company, was snapped up by Silicon Valley's Phone.com for $240 million. Amacis, an e-business solutions provider which started from scratch, has now opened a Boston office.

Venture capital groups, if not beating a path to the province's door, are at least starting to take an interest. Last year £35m of venture capital was injected into the province - double the previous year's total. Not a huge amount admittedly, but enough to suggest grounds for optimism.

Meanwhile, two US funds are looking to launch in the province later this year, specifically targeting the technology sector.

Neil Graham, Ireland investment director with British investment fund 3i, says: 'We've been here for 25 years and it's been bloody hard going. But I've seen more technology opportuni ties in the past three months than in the previous 15. I'm relatively optimistic, but Belfast isn't going to be Dublin in five years.'

This is certainly the case while the province continues to haemorrhage skilled IT workers. Of the near 1,000 IT graduates from Northern Ireland's two universities, Queen's and Ulster, 40 per cent end up leaving Northern Ireland each year, the majority going to Dublin and England. There's a word for the latter: Nipplies - 'Northern Ireland professional people living in England'.

A recent report by the province's Software Industry Federation, which boasts 155 member companies, concluded: 'Skill shortages are affecting the growth and development of a significant number of businesses.'

This is putting it mildly. The brain drain has become so acute that the province's Training and Employment Agency placed ads in local papers at Christmas extolling the virtues of living in Northern Ireland in a bid to catch the eye of those returning to see their families. Further initiatives are planned.

Some, like Maurice Mulvenna, chief executive officer of Mineit, a company which develops database software and which emerged out of Ulster University, believe the trend can be reversed. 'Look at what happened in Dublin when the Celtic tiger got up to speed. A lot of people came back. We've got the potential to draw these people back. These are people who went away many years ago, who now want to settle down, and who are already highly skilled.'

It is not difficult to see how a return of the natives could quickly yield results. Northern Ireland, with a population of less than 2 million, is - despite or maybe because of the Troubles - a close-knit community. Ideas can be translated into practice very quickly, and new technology has the potential to help the province look outside itself in the way Dublin managed to 10 years ago.

Johnston said: 'Everyone knows everyone. We're getting to realise that we're part of the global stage.'

But Northern Ireland has a long way to go before it can emulate its neighbour.

The Republic got rich acting as a magnet for technology companies who were looking to benefit from a country which had low corporation tax and a cheap workforce prepared to bolt together bits of hardware - what became known as 'screwdriver operations'. But these businesses spawned spin-offs which concentrated on developing cutting-edge technology, which is now yielding benefits and jobs - and causes those in the North to rue a missed opportunity.

Colin Walsh, managing director of Crescent Capital, the biggest venture capital firm operating in Northern Ireland, said: 'Northern Ireland has had a strong culture of making things, much more than the South, right until the Sixties. But in the Seventies and Eighties inward investment went south.'

Northern Ireland knows it needs to learn more from the South. Many of its staple industries are in decline. Although unemployment has been falling for several years and now stands at just over 50,000 - 7 per cent of the working population - nearly 60,000 jobs are predicted to go in the next 10 years. An authoritative report by PricewaterhouseCoopers suggests that 132,000 new jobs will have to have been created by 2010 to cater for a growing workforce. And these will not come from agriculture, shipbuilding or textiles.

Gary Duxbury of Northland, a software company in Londonderry, believes the New Economy can play its part in leading the province's revival. 'England has its M4 corridor; Scotland has Silicon Glen, why can't the same happen for Northern Ireland?' Time perhaps for the province's ad agencies to dream up some new slogans.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Ashtead | Cable & Wireless | Kunick | Yule Catto
fields.body:
Shares in Ashtead are a stubborn old cuss. The stalwart of the plant hire sector has been stuck in the doldrums this year, despite a raft of upbeat brokers' reports.

The builder's mate may be unfashionable these dotcom days. But Ashtead's familiar green A-Plant diggers, compressors and power tools are vital to UK construction. Following the acquisition of BET USA from Rentokil Initial, Ashtead is also now the number four player in the United States, where more growth is beckoning.

Yet at 99.5p, the shares are worth half of what they were last year. On current forecasts, the Surrey-based plant company is now trading on a lowly five times forecast earnings, against the market average of 22 times!

The discount against other plant hire specialists, like Hewden Stewart and Aggreko, is also considerable.

True, the US has been a graveyard for many a UK corporate, but at these levels the downside is surely well factored into the price. Broker Beeson Gregory values the shares at 205p. Buy.

Turn on to C&W
Whither Cable & Wireless? Since the collapse of its merger with BT years ago, that's been one of the perennial teases in telecoms.

Over the last 18 months new chief executive Graham Wallace has been decisively ditching Lord Young's legacy of picking up telecoms stakes here, there and everywhere. After £18 billion of disposals and another £13.5bn of acquisitions C&W is now being radically transformed from a telecoms investment trust, (almost) into a truly global network operator.

Completion of the biggest step of all, the sale of C&W's Hongkong Telecom stake, is due on 17 August. And broker Salomon Smith Barney, for one, believes that will be a catalyst for a strong re-rating of the shares. SSB's telecoms team points to the 25 per cent jump in Securicor's price after it finally completed the well-heralded sale of its stake in Cellnet to BT.

In a note last week, the broker puts a £20 value on the shares, against £13.22 now. And that's without bid talk, which is likely to resurface after the HK Telecom sale.

Invest at leisure
On a rather smaller scale, Kunick is another firm that has restructured over the last year to focus on its core business: amusement machines and management of local authority leisure centres.

Kunick is one of our top gaming machine operators, with an innovative new network, Midas, for monitoring and managing machines down telephone lines. The firm also looks well placed to thrive from the Government's Best Value initiative, which affects the contracting out of council swimming pools and the like.

Kunick is never going to set the world alight. But at 28.75p, broker Old Mutual reckons they are solid value against a 36p price target.

Chemicals alert
After a rash of deals in the last two years, one 'old economy' sector that's lagged behind of late is chemicals. The disappearance of rapacious US and European bidders, for the moment at least, is one factor. Another certainly is a spate of earnings downgrades following a number of profit warnings, especially from the US.

After recent reductions in forecasts, one firm looking distinctly undervalued is Yule Catto, the speciality chemicals outfit based at Harlow in Essex. Higher raw materials costs have depressed the immediate outlook this year and the City certainly feels the company needs to refocus. Management, however, is rated strongly and recovery should feed through in 2002.

At 183p, the shares look attractive on a rating of just over six times earnings for 2002, matched by a current dividend yield of 6.5 per cent.
