fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Sin City | Drunk.com
fields.body:
Death doesn't become them
Sitting in the 'what were they thinking?' corner this week is the Times. Within the past few weeks contributor John Morgan died in tragic and mysterious circumstances, after a fall from the window of his flat. With tears not yet dry, the paper took the opportunity last week to promote 'the late John Morgan's' book - based, like his Saturday column, around etiquette and modern manners. We wonder what Mr Morgan would have made not just of the ad for his book but the rather tasteless '£2 off' offer plastered all over it. We can't think of any book of etiquette that would cover such a crass eventuality.

Sin City
One could argue that the besmirched City Slickers, James Hipwell and Anil Bhoyrul, did their old bosses at the Mirror a favour by dropping them from the acknowledgments list at the front of their new book entitled Make a Million in Twelve Months. Not so lucky were the likes of Richard Branson, Mohamed Fayed, Max Clifford and our own football columnist Charlie Whelan, who were all thanked profusely. Those familiar with the Slickers' exit from the Mirror , where they lost their jobs over trading in shares they then tipped, turned anxiously to the 'jargon-buster' section of the book and read up on the Slicker interpretation of 'insider dealing'. Here is what it says : 'Also known as insider trading, this is when individuals buy or sell shares based on information only made available to them and not the whole marketplace. It is an illegal activity in most countries although very difficult to prove, thank God.'

Not entirely technically accurate, but we get their drift.

Drunk.com
We have missed the esteemed figure of former Mirror Group boss David Montgomery on the media scene. So we were beside ourselves with delight to learn of Monty's return through the magic of Yava, a new internet company that aims to put terminals in pubs - or Punch Taverns to be precise. Yava - short for You're 'AVing A laugh, aren't you? - combines that brilliant concept of placing technology in front of the inebriated, though the business model that says people will pay as much for online porn with their pint as they will for a one-armed bandit is as yet unproven. Not, of course, that the clientele of Punch Taverns will be using Yava to access porn. They will care more about the interesting features and sports coverage.

fields.headline: Mr Diageo's thirst for power
fields.standfirst: By focusing on drink and more drink, Paul Walsh is the toast of the City
fields.trailText: By focusing on drink and more drink, Paul Walsh is the toast of the City
fields.body:
For a man who has just flogged the Pillsbury doughboy, flipped Burger King towards a flotation and merged Guinness into Bell's, Diageo's chief executive-elect keeps a pretty low profile.

Looking more like a football manager than a world spirits supremo, Paul Walsh was splashed all over the financial press last Tuesday as Diageo added £7 billion to its war chest with the sale of Pillsbury to US rival General Mills. But that leap from the dug-out was a one-off. For the rest of the week Walsh was in the US briefing staff - and far too busy to give interviews. In 18 years in the business he has never been profiled and certainly isn't seeking publicity now.

Just 45, Walsh has other priorities - namely taking over sooner than expected from veteran John McGrath, and the upcoming scrap over Seagram. Since Walsh's appointment as chief operating officer - heir apparent - in January this year, Diageo has been at the centre of a spurt of corporate activity.

'It's fair to say John's still in the driving seat, but Paul's really upped the ante,' one colleague said. And by focusing on drinks, drinks and more drinks - exactly what the City has been urging since Diageo's creation in 1996 - Walsh already has bags of goodwill in the bank.

Like McGrath, Walsh hails from the Grand Metropolitan rather than the Guinness half of the Diageo merger. It was only this year, though, that he moved on to a drop of the hard stuff, running UDV, Diageo's world-leading spirits operation.

But he has certainly got beer in his blood. An accountant by training, Walsh joined Watney, Mann & Truman, GrandMet's brewing arm, in 1982 after stints at ICL and the Co-op's soft drinks operation following his degree at Manchester Polytechnic. In the race for the top job, Walsh started on the inside track. Over the past two years, the jockeying has seen the exit of a clutch of top executives, including Guinness chief Brendan O'Neill to ICI, finance director Philip Yea and, last month, Burger King boss Dennis Malamatinas to Priceline.com, the second biggest internet firm in the US.

At Watneys, Walsh was finance director to none other than McGrath, but it has been his experience since then - three years at Intercontinen tal Hotels, then a decade at Pillsbury from 1989 - that has stood him in greatest stead. 'He's got a lot more under his belt than his age suggests,' said one leading drinks analyst. 'He's young, a motivator and experienced. He was the best man for the job.'

fields.headline: Brownfield costs hit green belt
fields.standfirst: Only compulsory purchase and regulation can keep developers out of the countryside, reports  Nick Mathiason
fields.trailText: Only compulsory purchase and regulation can keep developers out of the countryside, reports Nick Mathiason
fields.body:
Nowhere is the debate over the massive increase in the number of new homes planned more keenly felt than in the Langley Valley.

Today, this unspoilt two-and-a-half square mile swathe of picturesque North Hertfordshire countryside is home to just 200 people. Mostly, it is farmland. But in 10 years, it is feared, 10,000 homes will be built here, all on green-belt land to the west of Stevenage.

The settlement, if it goes ahead, will result in a seamless urban sprawl between Stevenage and Hitchin. Environmentalists are in uproar.

Last week, in what could be a watershed for the fate of the Langley Valley, lawyers representing North Hertfordshire District Council advised that the plan, to be developed by housebuilders Persimmon and Bryant Homes, contravenes government planning guidance and should be rejected.

Despite Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott backing the scheme, the scene could soon be set for one of the biggest planning law scraps of recent times.

There is a huge amount at stake. Friends of the Earth claims the development would involve the biggest use of green-belt land ever.

Housebuilders stand to make a fortune, as do the group of Langley Valley private landowners who have conditionally agreed to sell to the housebuilding consortium should the scheme be rubber-stamped.

Critics of the Langley plan say the proposed new homes will not be aimed at those most in need: low-income families and older people.

But at the heart of the battle for this valley lies one of the thorniest questions faced by governments, local authorities and housebuilders today: where to put the estimated 800,000 new homes that are desperately needed in the South-east.

In the three years since Labour came to power, there has been a discernible shift in government planning policy.

New Labour, driven by Prescott and Lord Rogers' metropolitan zeal, has declared that it wants to tackle dereliction and encourage the building of more homes on brownfield sites.

As a statement of intent, as soon as it came to power in 1997 the Government raised the target for new homes to be built on brownfield sites to 60 per cent - 10 per cent up on the previous figure.

In 1998, government circulars reminded councils to prevent dereliction of the built environment. Last year, Lord Rogers' Urban Taskforce published hundreds of recommendations that were widely acknowledged as the most progressive diagnosis of Britain's urban malaise to be made in modern times.

Meanwhile, a new Planning Policy Guidance (PPG) note on housing published last March asked local authorities to release land previously reserved for employment purposes for housing, to pack higher housing densities into developments and reduce land earmarked for cars.

The PPG contains the strongest weapon for preventing countryside being gobbled up for housing so far issued by Labour: the announcement of a sequential test for developments. This means that all brownfield sites have to be used for housing before greenfield sites will be considered.

It is on this point that North Hertfordshire was advised by lawyers that its massive housing plan did not conform to government policy.

The Government has largely set the planning framework by which brownfield development can smoothly proceed in a bid to create a sustainable environment.

The trouble is, the biggest housebuilders still prefer to build on greenfield sites, because brownfield sites are much more expensive to develop. They are often contaminated, or owned by several parties. Assembling sites - preparing them for housebuilding to proceed - is therefore time-consuming and costly.

In his Urban Taskforce report, Lord Rogers called for the Government to give regional development agencies and local authorities souped-up powers to compulsorily purchase land in order to speed up the assembly process.

The Government is currently studying ways of doing this but, more than a year later, it has failed to act.

However, Anthony Dunnett, chief executive of the South-east of England Development Agency and a member of Rogers' Urban Taskforce, warns that without strong compulsory purchase order powers, the Govern ment target of building 60 per cent of new homes on previously developed land will fail.

'The [housing] debate has been hijacked by "Nimby" fears and pre-election politics rather than focusing on the fundamental problem,' Dunnett says. 'The real issue is not one of numbers; rather it is one of market failure in a free-market economy. The structure of the UK housing market is one where housebuilders have no long-term interest and are driven by return on capital, which calls for minimising inventories and maximising planning gain so as to maximise short-term profit.'

Dunnett believes that only by allowing RDAs and councils to knock heads together to 'marry' sites will government brownfield targets be met.

Compulsory purchase powers are vital, he argues, because most of the vast brownfield sites in the South- east have already been developed. The solution to meeting the massive housing need in the region is to build on 'infill' sites - smaller parcels of land within town and city centres.

Housebuilders, meanwhile, are upset because they never know how many socially affordable homes to build within a housing development. New laws on the provision of affordable homes set minimum targets, but councils can order as many affordable homes as they can get away with.

But the biggest disincentive for builders to develop brownfield sites is VAT, which is charged at 17.5 per cent on refurbishing or redeveloping existing buildings, while greenfield housebuilding is exempt.

If the Government wanted to send out a signal that brownfield development is at the heart of its housing policy, it could start by addressing this anomaly.

But with the Treasury recently indicating opposition to reform, those at the sharp end of regenerating Britain's towns and cities face an uphill struggle.

Government lifts roof on housing budget

Tomorrow the Government will give details on how it will spend the 12 per cent average annual increase on the housing budget over the next three years. It has been greeted by housing experts as the most significant investment in the sector for more than 25 years.

The Observer can reveal that the Government has earmarked £2.5 billion for capital investment on housing - double the current figure. A spokesman added that there would be 'substantial funds' for building new homes.

Labour will also announce plans to fund an unprecedented stock transfer of council homes to registered social landlords, effectively sounding the death knell for direct council involvement in housing.

This will enable rundown estates to tap into private finance for renovation. But transfers will go ahead only if tenants vote for them.

Money available for new affordable housing, to rent and to buy, will be channelled through Housing Associations.

The Government will also reveal how much money it will spend on its Starter Home Initiative, the device, outlined in the Housing Green Paper published last March, through which key workers can buy a home.

Other measures will include help for poor homeowners to maintain and improve their homes, plus more money to help disabled people adapt their homes.

Another scheme to be unveiled tomorrow is called Supporting People; it aims to improve support services to those in need. The scheme will allow local authorities to fund probation, housing benefit and other social services from a single pot, thereby allowing services to run more efficiently.

Chris Holmes, director of housing campaign group Shelter, said: 'We are particularly pleased that substantial extra money for new homes is coming through, because this is an area in which the Government has not increased available resources since the election.'

webTitle: The smarter investor still steers clear of A&L

fields.headline: The smarter investor still steers clear of A&L
fields.trailText: Throg Street
fields.body:
'Accountability for end-to-end process costs', 'integrated technology architecture based on consistent middleware, data warehousing and customer relationship management', 'integrated customer access'. If management-speak were the key to success, Alliance & Leicester's 'organisational restructure' - where all these bits of jargon were coined - would ensure it was up there with the leaders.

Scratch the surface of the management-speak, however, and A&L is revealed as just another medium-sized bank desperately seeking ways to in an increasingly competitive environment. Beneath the jargon lie two old-fashioned tactics: cut costs and persuade customers to buy more.

The strategy presentation was, however, short on detailed targets and explanations of how they would be met. We have to wait until the autumn to find out the cost-cutting targets, although the new management believes, as new managements do, that there is 'considerable scope for efficiency improvement'.

The pledges on boosting revenue were likewise long on promise but short on detail. Instead of devising a stream of new products and persuading customers to buy them, it will now think about what its customers want to buy. It has divided the market into three types: those who will buy anything, those who will buy nothing unless they have to, and those who are sophisticated enough not to listen to the marketing speak.

The result, says newly-appointed group managing director Peter McNamara, will be an end to the pointless quest for market share regardless of profitability - it is unlikely, for example, to increase its activity in the remortgage market. Given the high costs of winning customers, it is clearly sensible to try to do more business with current ones. But every financial services company, A&L included, has been trying to do that for years. The test will be whether it succeeds this time.

Potentially more interesting is its decision to target the small and medium-sized business market. As McNamara points out, there have been no new entrants since the Second World War. That may be, as he says, because only the big clearing banks have the infrastructure to cope with them. But it may also reflect the difficulties of persuading small businesses to change their banking arrangements - and of making consistent profits from this sector.

A&L's ownership of Girobank and its tie-up with the Post Office give it a head start. A&L already has 40,000 customers in this sector and winning more will be easier when it can offer them cash transmission services.

It is very easy to make strategy presentations, but much more difficult to translate these into higher profits. That is the challenge for A&L. Its shares are among the cheapest in the sector and, until it can produce results, are likely to remain so.

Looking worn
Unlike McNamara, Luc Vandevelde, chairman of Marks & Spencer since February, sees no need to introduce a new strategy. He tried on the one designed by the old boss and decided it still suited perfectly. The City, however, is starting to worry that it is a bit worn around the edges and is starting to agitate for a change.

It is certainly turning into a long wait for results. The trading figures at last week's agm were dismal. Sales of clothing, footwear and furniture in the 15 weeks to last Saturday are not only down year on year - bad enough, given how dismal trading was this time last year - they are actually deteriorating.

'Trading will remain tough for the foreseeable future,' warned Vandevelde. Tell that to Next and Debenhams, which are prospering from M&S's mistakes. To be fair, the strategy - improve the supply chain, revamp the stores, produce better clothes - is the only sensible solution. The problem is implementing this: there's too little progress and what has changed is not demonstrably for the better.

Vandevelde has given the old guard, including chief executive Peter Salsbury, more than enough time to prove themselves. Now he needs to bring in new blood to produce results.

Listen to the boss
Robin Saxby, chairman and chief executive of ARM Holdings, admits it is hard to predict his business more than six months ahead. Yet the share price of the semiconductor designer is looking at least 10 years ahead. Are investors really that much more expert at judging the market than the brains behind the company?

There is no doubt that ARM is one of Britain's greatest technology successes. Its chips, which have the big advantage of needing little power to operate, have all but become the standard in the mobile phone industry. It is now taking its expertise into other areas, such as set-top boxes for digital television.

So far, there is no competitor in sight - and ARM has already signed up an impressive list of customers ranging from Siemens and Ericsson to Texas Instruments and Intel. Chip shipments have grown almost fifteenfold in the past two years and demand looks set to continue for the foreseeable future.

The trouble is, the foreseeable future is not long enough to justify a valuation of more than 300 times earnings. This column called ARM's shares expensive when they were less than a quarter of the current price. But I still cannot recommend buying.

More is less
What is the definition of a growth company? To judge by Williams' demerger plans, it is simply one which can no longer afford to pay its dividend. Williams is warning that after it splits into its two component parts, total dividends will be 'substantially less' than that paid by the combined group.

Roger Carr, chief executive of Williams, insists that the decision has been taken not because Williams overpaid in the past. Rather, it is because, as separate business, Yale and Chubb will have more opportunities to invest and so will want to pay less to its shareholders.

Williams's rag-bag of businesses has now all but gone and, following the demerger, the conglomerate tag will finally die along with the Williams name. The dividend cut is an inevitable by-product.

fields.headline: NAO to investigate mobile auction
fields.trailText: The recent lucrative auction of licences for third-generation mobile phones is to be investigated by the National Audit Office, which will assess whether the public has been best served by the process.
fields.body:
The recent lucrative auction of licences for third-generation mobile phones is to be investigated by the National Audit Office, which will assess whether the public has been best served by the process.

The Government controversially auctioned five operating licences for the new technology, raking in a windfall of £22.5 billion for the Treasury. That benefit could be weighed against the potential effect on the price of calls.

The NAO is Parliament's independent scrutineer, with a remit to audit the imple mentation of government policies, rather than the merits of the policies themselves.

Some mobile phone companies have engaged European governments in a strong lobbying effort to prevent similar auctions. Following the UK auction, where the cost of licences exceeded initial expectations by 400 per cent, Vodafone's share price tumbled by a third. Most telecommunications companies borrowed billions from the markets and threatened their credit ratings to secure funds to foot the global bill.

However, the Spanish and Finnish governments distrib uted the licences for a minimal cost using a 'beauty parade' or hybrid system, partly so as not to be seen as inhibiting the growth of the knowledge economy. Analysts predict that UK licences will prove to have fetched the highest price.

Preliminary work to see whether there should be an NAO report to parliament has already been completed, and a study could be published in January. Auditors are currently seeking experts in the complex field of game theory to assess the design of the auction.

The amount raised by the auction will not be the main consideration. 'If we do go ahead, we will look at the price, but also at how successfully the Government reaches its objective of economic efficiency and whether the sale was advantageous for consumers,' said an NAO spokesman.

Any investigation is likely to reveal the precise nature of the contract with government advisers NM Rothschild. It is still not clear whether Rothschild received a percentage commission on the unexpectedly high receipts from the sale.

fields.headline: Microsoft's Revenue deal nets complaint
fields.trailText: An exclusive deal between Microsoft and the Inland Revenue has provoked a complaint to the Office of Fair Trading about alleged anti-competitive behaviour.
fields.body:
An exclusive deal between Microsoft and the Inland Revenue has provoked a complaint to the Office of Fair Trading about alleged anti-competitive behaviour.

The complaint, supported by Basda, the computer software industry's professional body, says the Revenue is acting unfairly by promoting a Microsoft program and supplying it free to people wanting to file tax returns online.

Questions are being asked about the role of Phil Stradling, a Microsoft staff member seconded to the Revenue. He supervised the 12 months of work which created the system.

Basda's chief executive, Dennis Keeling, said it was Stradling who invited him to recruit from among his 350 company members for an official working party which originally consisted of just Microsoft and Which? Soft ware magazine. Keeling's 20 recruits were initially suspicious that they would devote time to the project to Microsoft's benefit, with no gains for themselves.

One of those companies, Forbes Computer Systems, devised the format now used by the Revenue to facilitate the Microsoft software. Managing director David Forbes is furious that his tax returns package is among those which have effectively been elbowed out of the market by the deal with Microsoft.

'The fact that the person in charge of the process is on the Microsoft staff does not look good,' he said. 'They have taken the market leader and given it preferential treatment. It has all been an absolute waste of time. We were given repeated guarantees that this would not happen. We were told it would be a level playing field.'

Basda has written to Trea sury Minister Patricia Hewitt about the row, and is threatening to pull its members out of other working groups advising Government departments on shifting more bureaucracy onto the net .

'We want a categorical assurance from the Government that this will not happen again,' added Keeling.

An Revenue spokeswoman said: 'We went with Microsoft in partnership with EDS [a separate computer company]. This is the best deal they came up with.'

She added that it was always the Revenue's intention to offer the software to file returns free in the same way that it provides paper forms without any charge.

'A deal will have been struck with Microsoft, but we would not give details out as that information is commercially sensitive,' the spokeswoman added.

webTitle: Vodafone to declare war on Orange with global brand

fields.headline: Vodafone to declare war on Orange with global brand
fields.trailText: Vodaphone AirTouch, the world's largest mobile phone operator, is drawing up a radical plan to position itself as a global brand in an attempt to drive home its credentials as the leader in the wireless telecommunications market. The move will spark an all-out branding war with arch-rival Orange as both firms try to consolidate their operations around single global business identities - shifts that will have significant reverberations for shareholders.
fields.body:
Vodaphone AirTouch, the world's largest mobile phone operator, is drawing up a radical plan to position itself as a global brand in an attempt to drive home its credentials as the leader in the wireless telecommunications market. The move will spark an all-out branding war with arch-rival Orange as both firms try to consolidate their operations around single global business identities - shifts that will have significant reverberations for shareholders.

Vodafone's shareholders will this week vote on a move to drop AirTouch from the company name. Instead the plan, which will be discussed this Thursday, is to christen the company The Vodafone Group. The change is seen as a strategic move which will act as a precursor to rolling the Vodafone name out across all of the 24 European companies in its portfolio.

For the past few months chief executive Chris Gent has expressed a desire to turn Vodafone, which has nearly 60 million users worldwide, into a global brand. Currently the raft of mobile phone companies which are owned wholly or in part by Vodafone represent a diverse set of interests. All have different names and identities, each targeting their indige nous markets.

The company consulted branding agencies before deciding to unite all its European interests under the Vodafone name. The move by the telecoms giant comes as France Télécom looks to roll the Orange brand out across Europe. The French company acquired the UK's third largest operator from Vodafone for £27 billion in May.

Orange is seen as stealing a lead on Vodafone in the race to sign up customers, thanks largely to the strength of its brand. Last-quarter figures show that in the UK Vodafone added 572,000 customers while Orange attracted 1.2 million. The experts suggest Vodafone's decision to create a 'monolithic' brand could be good news for investors.

'Our analysis shows that the value creation potential of single brands is higher than that shown by conglomerates,' said Jan Lindemann, director of consultancy firm Interbrand.

He said it was cheaper to communicate a single brand on a global basis. 'It is easier to focus on one brand than 50, providing it is acceptable to local markets. You have to think about the way the market will evolve. You have to think about the way the company will present itself on the internet.'

fields.headline: OFT targets garages
fields.trailText: The Office of Fair Trading is set to slam standards in British car servicing and repairs, complaining that garages do not offer good service or value for money, and may be putting drivers' safety at risk.
fields.body:
The Office of Fair Trading is set to slam standards in British car servicing and repairs, complaining that garages do not offer good service or value for money, and may be putting drivers' safety at risk.

An OFT report to be published within the next few weeks will criticise garages for doing unnecessary work but not carrying out required servicing.

John Bridgeman, director- general of Fair Trading, said the OFT would uphold the concerns of consumer groups and trading standards officers, who have been highly critical of garages.

The report - one of the main reports to be produced by the OFT this year - follows investigations launched into the £8.9 billion car maintenance and service industry in April last year.

Bridgeman pointed then to evidence of vehicles' faults either not being corrected or, worse, being introduced during servicing.

The inquiry focused on how badly customers were being served; what information was available to them before servicing was carried out; how easy it was to complain and whether those complaints were dealt with properly; and how customers could best be advised on choosing a garage.

Last week Bridgeman told The Observer : 'I will confirm from the work being done by the Consumers' Association that consumers are not well served in terms of standards of care offered when cars are maintained. Work which should be done is missed and and work which should not be done is done.'

Bridgeman said that people were not aware of their responsibilities, and that they were not told about them by garages: 'Garages are not basically doing much to help people, and people as a result are not serving their own best interests.'

On safety, he said: 'I don't think we have sufficient standards on this score.'

Bridgeman added that the Government should introduce regulations to guarantee better consumer safety, saying the current government's consumer White Paper could be a missed opportunity.

The OFT report will make a series of recommendations. It is likely that they will follow suggestions made by consumer bodies such as the Consumers' Association.

The CA recommends an independent scheme to monitor garages, a checking system using undercover officers to monitor safety and standards, and a strengthened system for consumers to obtain redress.

fields.headline: Pru leads race for Equitable
fields.standfirst: Speedy sale sought after Lords defeat |  European giants set to bid | £1.5bn vital for pensions
fields.trailText: The mighty Prudential is leading the £5 billion race to buy fellow insurer Equitable Life, which dramatically put itself up for sale last week.
fields.byline: Paul Farrelly, Maria Scott and Jill Insley
fields.body:
The mighty Prudential is leading the £5 billion race to buy fellow insurer Equitable Life, which dramatically put itself up for sale last week.

The Pru is understood to be using City merchant bank UBS Warburg to draw up a takeover deal. It will, however, face intense competition from European and US insurers eager to snap up the strong brand.

The sell-off follows a land mark House of Lords judgment that Equitable must honour £1.5bn of guarantees to its personal pension plan customers, a ruling that left it fatally weakened.

Equitable's advisers, Schroders Salomon Smith Barney, are now aiming for a quick sale to stop the business falling apart. Bidders are expected to sign confidentiality undertakings this week before receiving a sale prospectus in August.

The Association of British Insurers (ABI) is also urging a speedy conclusion to protect the position of Equitable's 450,000 policyholders.

According to City sources, Equitable received 10 approaches before last week's ruling, and there have been more since. Continental giants Axa and Allianz, and the UK's CGNU are also in the running, while Halifax and Abbey National expect to take a serious look.

Equitable's weakness rules out big mutuals such as Standard Life, City sources say.

Giant Dutch insurer Aegon, meanwhile, is thought to be unwilling to stump up the price. Ten days ago it pulled out of the £1bn race for Scottish Provident, which is also now being demutualised.

'The most likely buyer is somebody big who already understands the UK market,' one Equitable source said. 'The Pru's big life fund would stand it in good stead.'

The Pru has already snapped up one big mutual - Scottish Amicable for £1.5bn three years ago. Then War burg advised Amicable, while Equitable's team at Schroders were on the side of the Pru.

Last week's judgment forced Equitable to honour income guarantees on 100,000 pension policies. The insurer planned to cut bonuses on policyholders' pension funds or to pay the guaranteed annuities on the pensions, but the House of Lords ruled this unlawful.

Equitable immediately announced plans to seek a buyer, and this week will reveal details of the full cost of stumping up the guaranteed cash. The money will be transferred from policies owned by other policyholders because Equitable has no other way to pay. The sale will aim to recoup this loss and restore returns on other policyholders' investments.

Stuart Bayliss, of special pension adviser Annuity Direct, said he believed that the shortfall announced by Equitable this week could be as high as £2bn, although Equitable disputed this. The mutual said last week that it hoped to have settled on a buyer by the end of the year. However, analysts believe it will need to move more quickly than this.

Ned Cazalet, a specialist independent insurance analyst, said Equitable needed to make a decision by early autumn, or risk losing its valuable sales force. 'They will have to move quickly on this,' he added.

An executive at another insurance company said: 'The keenest players will not wait'.

webTitle: Diageo boss set for early exit

fields.headline: Diageo boss set for early exit
fields.trailText: Diageo, the world's biggest drinks group, will surprise the markets tomorrow with the resignation of John McGrath as chief executive.
fields.body:
Diageo, the world's biggest drinks group, will surprise the markets tomorrow with the resignation of John McGrath as chief executive.

The group also expects to press its interest in the £6 billion auction of Seagram's drinks division this week in a head-to-head battle with main global rival Allied Domecq.

McGrath - a key architect of the £20bn merger in 1997 between Guinness and Grand Metropolitan - had been expected to stand down next year. But, following Diageo's £7bn sale of its Pillsbury food arm to General Mills last week and the planned flotation of Burger King, he has now decided to hand over the reins early to chief operating officer Paul Walsh.

Jack Keenan, head of Diageo's spirits division, UDV, will become deputy chief executive. In this latest shake-up, UDV is being merged with Guinness Brewing to cut costs by more than £100m a year. Hundreds of job will be lost among the divisions' 30,000 staff worldwide.

With its focus now entirely on drinks, Diageo expects to sign a confidentiality undertaking this week before tabling a bid for Seagram spirits, the world number three after Allied Domecq. Diageo is also holding talks with trade partners to carve up Seagram and keep coveted brands including Captain Morgan rum, Absolut vodka and Crown Royal whisky. Potential partners include Bacardi-Martini, Pernod Ricard and Rémy Cointreau in one of the most colourful corporate battles of the year.

'Allied is still the favourite because it can swallow Seagram whole,' one City adviser said. 'But there's no doubting Diageo's determination to spoil the party and carry off even more brands if it can.'

The business is being spun off following Seagram's £23bn planned merger with Vivendi of France, announced last month. Seagram's Wall Street advisers, Morgan Stanley, are now likely to sell the drinks operation before the merger is complete; they could send out sales prospectuses within the next three weeks.

McGrath will remain as a non-executive director until next year. His retirement will mark the final passing of the triumvirate who stunned the drinks world by creating Diageo in 1997. Of the two joint chairmen at the time, GrandMet's George Bull, retired in 1998 and former Guinness chief Tony Greener handed over to former Boots chairman Lord Blyth this year. In a controversial swap, McGrath also filled Blyth's place at the chemist chain.

webTitle: Late bid for Dome goes through the roof

fields.headline: Late bid for Dome goes through the roof
fields.trailText: Ministers have been forced to postpone announcing which consortium is to take over the Millennium Dome after one potential buyer raised its bid at the last moment.
fields.body:
Ministers have been forced to postpone announcing which consortium is to take over the Millennium Dome after one potential buyer raised its bid at the last moment.

The fate of the attraction, which has cost more than £750 million, is on a knife-edge this weekend because the last-ditch move by Legacy, which is backed by the Labour-supporting property tycoon Robert Bourne, forced a Government rethink.

The Observer has learnt that a final decision on the identity of the new owner was due last Thursday. But earlier last week, Legacy approached Ministers directly with a revised bid. It is now thought to be offering about £110 million for the 43-acre site.

Legacy, with funding from Barclay Capital and support from the Open University, Sun Microsystems, BT and London University's Imperial College, wants to turn the site into a hi-tech venue where start-ups, educational institutions and established companies could foster new ideas in telecoms, IT and biotechnology.

It is thought that business rates payable to the local authority, Greenwich council, under Legacy's scheme could reach £100m over 25 years.

Remaining rival Dome Europe, meanwhile, wants to retain the venue as a tourist attraction featuring vir tual reality computer games, a Beatles' 'Yellow Submarine' and interactive art galleries. Dome Europe believes it could attract 6 million visitors a year - the same number as is now estimated will visit the current exhibition before the end of the year.

It is understood that the five Ministers who will decide the Dome's fate, including Deputy Prime Minister John Prescott and Cabinet Office Minister Lord Falconer, will now meet on Monday. The winner will be announced in response to a Parliamentary question this week, before the House of Commons breaks up for the summer recess.

webTitle: Nation ill at e-ase with itself...

fields.headline: Nation ill at e-ase with itself...
fields.standfirst: Comprehensive spending review:  Faisal Islam looks at why the e-sky's the limit
fields.trailText: Comprehensive spending review: Faisal Islam looks at why the e-sky's the limit
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is no Santa Claus, contrary to what many commentators have said of last week's Spending Review 2000 festivities. As everyone knows, Santa sports an Old Labour white beard and hands out sackfuls of presents unconditionally.

The Chancellor is much more like the tooth fairy - goodies reward departments that have gone through painful adjustments to improve their effectiveness.

He was able to announce last Tuesday's plans because of past underspends on already-tight departmental limits, but the cash is also contingent on a raft of targets designed to improve the effectiveness of public spending.

The injection of £50.5 billion of public money will be accompanied by a 'tough regime for driving up the performance of public services', says the Government. The key elements of this regime are departmental improvement targets - for example, that 80 per cent of 11-year-olds read and write to a particular level - and new efficiency targets to cut costs. Such targets will be enshrined within Public Service Agreements to be published in a White Paper this week.

But the effectiveness of the targets themselves is uncertain. 'If there was one target that was, say, a perfect measure of education, you could easily measure value for money,' says Carl Emmerson of the Institute for Fiscal Studies. 'The problem is there isn't, and the danger is that you introduce distortions.'

Thus, targeting numbers on hospital waiting lists may prove detrimental to waiting times or to clinical priorities. Similarly, reducing numbers of prisoners per cell may be ranked important, but what would be the side-effects on numbers kept on remand in police cells?

'Then if the targets have been met, what conclusion can we draw - were they too easy or were there other things that were affected?' asks Emmerson.

Furthermore, the link between achieving targets and receiving funding is unclear. If health targets are not being met, it is highly unlikely that the Department of Health would be punished - a sharp increase in waiting lists and packed emergency wards would probably result in an increase in funding. The numbers announced in the first Comprehensive Spending Review, in 1998, turned out not to be sacrosanct.

Spending Review 2000 is peppered with references to the use of information and communications technology, both as a tool to increase the performance and delivery of public services and as an end in itself.

Thirteen projects and programmes mentioned in the spending review directly relate to technology, and more detail is expected in the Public Service Agreements.

Projects include a Home Office scheme to help police analyse crime data and share it with health, education and social services, and a legal department initiative to improve information and reduce waiting times at courts. The health settlement is expected to include new initiatives on smartcards.

Technology, on which the Government already spends £8bn a year, is intended to be the cornerstone of modernising government and increasing the effectiveness of the public sector. But the experience of last year's passport and immigration fiascos, incorrect calculation of benefits for pensioners, not to mention last week's loss of 5 million tax records, have done little to inspire confidence.

A report published in January by the Public Accounts Committee, the parliamentary watchdog, detailed 25 cases over the past decade where the 'implementation of IT systems has resulted in delay, confusion and inconvenience to the citizens and, in many cases, poor value for money to the taxpayer'.

For example, following the systems problems at the Passport Office last year, the unit cost of a passport was £15.50 against a target of £12.

Public procurement disas ters are not new, and problems in delivering IT contracts are certainly not confined to the public sector. But if the Government is to put so much faith in IT, it needs to markedly improve its management of technology. And the wish to enact e-government is, of course, entirely predicated on getting technology right. At present, visions of 'joined-up government' to tackle social exclusion, drugs, crime, and urban regeneration are held back.

The government e-envoy, Alex Allan, will be enacting the recommendations of Successful IT: Modernising government in action , the Government response to critical reports from the National Audit Office and the Public Accounts Committee. The new Office of Government Commerce is responsible for developing more enlightened procedures on procurement.

The report was well-received by the 'techie' community for taking on board a broad sweep of recommendations on strategy, implementation and sourcing IT services, drawing on the lessons of the private sector as well as past difficulties.

'The root of the problem was that IT was treated like a sticky plaster that was being applied on top,' says John Higgins of the Computing Services and Software Association, the industry body. 'It has to be seen in the context of major improvements in productivity. The technology is not an end in itself.'

Part of the reason for past failures was that technological change became decoupled from broader business changes. Junior IT managers were trying to push through projects that impacted on a conservative Civil Service culture without the backing of senior civil servants.

This has changed, according to Allan. 'The key thing is that this is not going against the grain of departments. You need to lead on this from the top.' He says Cabinet Ministers have realised how critical such systems are to how their departments function.

The report also shifts the emphasis from huge projects to small ones giving incremental improvements.

'In many cases the first computerisations bit off more than they could chew,' says Dewar Donnithorne-Tait of Sun Microsystems, a former civil servant. 'They now build applications on top of existing data infrastructure, rather than using the big-bang approach.'

Failures in procurement, in shaping appropriate contracts, and adequately managing risk were also identified in those critical reports. 'There has been a tendency not to go for best value but for cheapness,' says Donnithorne-Tait.

Public sector projects are subject to strict value-for-money scrutiny on the basis of the four 'e's' - efficiency, economy, effectiveness, and equity - as opposed to private business, which concentrates on the bottom line.

A clutch of large IT services companies, such as Siemens Business Services, Andersen Consulting, ICL and EDS, have won huge con tracts to take over government systems departments under the Private Finance Initiative. All of them have had their troubles in the fallout from the major government computing failures.

The nature of the relationship between government and the major IT service suppliers is a delicate one. Already this year, the Government has abandoned efforts to seek further compensation from Andersen Consulting for problems with the National Insurance system (NIRS2), expressly because this might jeopardise the relationship with regard to other contracts.

Clear guidelines on procurement have been set up and will be implemented by the Office of Government Commerce. They will include efforts to spread procurement to smaller technology companies, especially in the development of websites. Industry experts think that if these building blocks are in place, moves towards e-government are possible, and using IT will become a sensible way to improve the effectiveness of public spending.

Indeed progress in e-government itself is one of the Government's 'tough targets' for performance. It demands that by 2005 all government services should be available electronically.

Amazingly, until last April, telephone calls to government services were counted towards the target, as they were defined as 'electronic transactions'. Unfortunately for Alex Allan, they no longer are.

Spain and Brazil set the pace

Brazil and Spain are the unlikely pioneers of e-government. 'Brazil is way ahead of the UK on filing tax receipts over the internet,' says Janice Hughes, government adviser and the managing director of Spectrum Strategy consultants, Lastminute.com's mother ship. 'Surprisingly, governments in less advanced e-economies are setting the pace in embracing the internet,' she says.

Brazilians have been able to file returns online since 1997, and can already settle bills on a secure website using their credit cards. Corporations in Brazil are obliged to file tax returns online.

'Spain is a couple of years ahead in terms of doing things online,' says Dewar Donnithorne-Tait of Sun Microsystems. Spanish citizens have been able to submit tax returns online for over a year. The Spanish national mint is leading work on digital certification to ensure the legality of online payments. Valencia and Barcelona have pioneered local e-government.

By contrast the UK government now offers a £10 discount for online filing of tax returns and promises similar measures in relation to driving licences soon. However, by 2002, a quarter of government departments must be ready for 'electronic service delivery' and all by 2005.

Although practice may be less than perfect, the UK came top in a recent study of how countries measure the extent of their e-government.
fields.bodyText: Gordon Brown is no Santa Claus, contrary to what many commentators have said of last week's Spending Review 2000 festivities. As everyone knows, Santa sports an Old Labour white beard and hands out sackfuls of presents unconditionally. The Chancellor is much more like the tooth fairy - goodies reward departments that have gone through painful adjustments to improve their effectiveness. He was able to announce last Tuesday's plans because of past underspends on already-tight departmental limits, but the cash is also contingent on a raft of targets designed to improve the effectiveness of public spending. The injection of £50.5 billion of public money will be accompanied by a 'tough regime for driving up the performance of public services', says the Government. fields.headline: Simply the vest
fields.standfirst: D'Angelo was the new Marvin Gaye. Now he's more like the new James Brown
fields.trailText: D'Angelo was the new Marvin Gaye. Now he's more like the new James Brown
fields.body:
D'Angelo Brixton Academy, London SW9

Souol revues are usually not much fun these days - gleaming, grinning, plasticised routines, with all the atmosphere of the moon. At Brixton Academy, last Wednesday, however, US soul singer D'Angelo hinted at an old-school renaissance. With all the ferocity and aplomb of a set by James Brown and the JBs, D'Angelo resurrected images of New York's Apollo Theatre.

It's odd that D'Angelo should come across like the new James Brown, because for most people he was already pigeonholed as the new Marvin Gaye. His debut album, 1995's Brown Sugar, introduced American R&B to the hip-hop influences it had previously tried its best to ignore. Alongside Lauryn Hill, Angie Stone, Erykah Badu, Maxwell and Tony Rich, D'Angelo was a musical defibrillator, resuscitating a half-dead genre. Brown Sugar also showcased a prodigiously talented multi-instrumentalist - D'Angelo was credited as composer, arranger, producer and performer. He was immediately compared with Marvin Gaye (the smoothness, the voice) and Prince (the autocracy, the shortness). The Godfather of Funk wasn't even mentioned back then.

During the five-year hiatus which followed that debut, D'Angelo kept his profile up with various guest slots on hip-hop recordings. Two such efforts in 1998 - 'Break Ups 2 Make Ups' with Method Man, and 'Nothing Even Matters' with Lauryn Hill - helped solidify his appeal to urban audiences. His latest album, this year's Voodoo , has picked up rave reviews and serious sales. In fact, it is less assured than his debut - often guilty of creating moods rather than songs. Live, however, the new material takes on another dynamic: fleshed out with horns and strings, it becomes almost animalistic.

D'Angelo's stage presence is certainly modelled on some kind of beast. Before the concert, I'd tried to guess how many songs it would take him to remove his top: I'd gone for three. In fact, five whole tracks are played before he dives into the crowd - re-emerging a minute or so later to rip off his black vest. He looks decidedly pleased with himself for showing such restraint.

Back on stage, his torso dripping with sweat, D'Angelo stares at the crowd like the growling, sexual embodiment of soul virility - prowling back and forth, left and right. He punches the air - slamming jabs and hooks into invisible opponents. The men in the crowd watch with awe at this public expounding of testosterone. The women scream as the singer flexes various muscle groups. In fact, the concert has all the anticipation of a hen night: fawning, fainting females scramble over each other to get near the stage. The last time I witnessed such scenes was at a Wet Wet Wet concert in Glasgow in the early Nineties.

'My God, he's gorgeous,' coos one girl to my left. Another turns excitedly to her boyfriend, her hands clasping his waist. 'He's really good-looking, isn't he?' she gasps. 'Much better than in his videos.' The boyfriend, suddenly conscious of his own playdough physique, wriggles his way out of her hands. 'He's not all that,' is the mumbled reply. Aggrieved, he flatly refuses to dance for the remainder of the set, narrowing his eyes meanly at the stage.

The set is elastic and a bit disjointed. New songs such as 'The Root' and 'Feel Like Makin' Love' are laboriously extended into 10-minute funk workouts. Lyrics are strangled in favour of sweaty percussive breaks. And, oddly, many songs are introduced as encores, providing a sort of perpetually delayed climax. Looking at his group - physically toned in the fine tradition of Kentucky Derby winners, but in danger of injuring themselves nevertheless - the JB comparisons are irresistible.

Only the vocabulary is urban contemporary. 'Motherfuckers in Brixton - are you ready?' yells D'Angelo, prior to the charmingly titled song 'Shit Damn Motherfucker'. In defiance of the loverman soul conventions, he does not dedicate songs to 'all the beautiful ladies' in the audience; he just swears at them instead.

The ladies don't seem to mind. At one point, a rapper appears onstage: he proceeds to stalk the breadth of the venue, screaming 'motherfucker' with increasing ferocity. D'Angelo looks on and beams with satisfaction. You have to wonder what his mother makes of it all.

'See y'all next time, Brixton,' he waves as he leaves the stage. 'It's been a perplexing performance - a strange mixture of gracefulness and grunting, sensuality and swearing. Soul veterans such as Al Green and Bobby Womack often talk about finding 'the jones' - an almost spiritual fever - during concerts. D'Angelo found it repeatedly tonight. The only difference is he'd probably call it the motherfucking jones.

webTitle: Sitting in the schlock of the bay

fields.headline: Sitting in the schlock of the bay
fields.standfirst: Cardiff's regeneration was based on high promises and ambition. so why has the practice been so pedestrian?
fields.trailText: Cardiff's regeneration was based on high promises and ambition. so why has the practice been so pedestrian?
fields.body:
It's not that the new Cardiff is so much worse than any other British waterside development that makes it such a disappointment. With its walkways and its public art programme, and its new Rocco Forte hotel with a funny roof, it's perfectly adequate by the hardly exacting standards set by Wapping, say. But what's really depressing about the place is the gap between what it could have been and what it has become.

It's the difference between Zaha Hadid's opera house that would now be preparing for its first season, if it had not been torpedoed by small-town politics and craven Millennium Commission prejudice, and the Atlantic Quay Leisure Village designed by nobody in particular, which today glowers over the entire area.

It's the difference between the kind of dignified civic spaces that Martorell, Bohigas and Mackay, responsible for the brilliantly successful remodelling of Barcelona, envisaged for Cardiff Bay and the end-product. A confused mess, dominated by a water sculpture that looks uncomfortably like a giant version of a car-dealer's totem, signals the ingratiatingly named Mermaid Quay, infested with outposts of Break for the Border and Harry Ramsden and its not so picturesque, yellow-brick terraces trying unconvincingly to knit into the remains of the old Bute Town.

This is not a fight between high culture and lowbrow entertainment. It's a sad example of a city that, given the choice between the second rate and the excellent, had no hesitation in grabbing the former with both hands. The Millennium Commission's legacy to Cardiff is equally disappointing. It decided it didn't much like the look of Hadid's architecture, but rather than say so in public claimed that it found the business plan unconvincing.

This is rich coming from the same people who signed an open-ended cheque for the Millennium Dome. But it had to spend some money in Cardiff, so it backed a new rugby stadium (architects the Lobb partnersh"p) which is now complete. With its absurdly over-excited structure, it sits on big, fat legs that rear over the surrounding streets like a sumo wrestler. It could have been so different.

Cardiff is constantly telling the world that it is Europe's fastest growing capital city. And back in the Eighties, it adopted a bold series of plans that really did seem to live up to its boasts. The Cardiff Bay Development Corporation set out to heal the city's fractured geography with a grand strategy that seemed to stand a good chance of success.

Cardiff is the product of its brief period of nineteenth- century prosperity, when the explosion in the coal and iron industry turned it from an overgrown village into the nearest thing Britain had seen to a gold-rush town. It was the place from which the coal hacked out of the Welsh Valleys was exported to the world and became the focus of a network of canals, dock basins and railways.

But no sooner had it turned itself inside out to accommodate the industrial revolution than it was beached by the tide of changing trade patterns and shifting technology, the urban equivalent of a spoil tip.

Cardiff was essentially split in two by the railway embankment built to serve the central station. To the north was the original city, its castle rebuilt in spectacular style by William Burges with some of the profits that the Marquis of Bute made from the coal trade, and a civic centre that looked a lot like a Welsh version of New Delhi with green lawns and white, stone classical architecture.

South of the railway was Bute Town and what used to be called Tiger Bay - acres of decayed housing, empty dock basins and a few relics of industrial architecture, like the striking red terracotta Pierhead building, designed in municipal gothic style for the Cardiff Railway Company. Meanwhile, the waterfront was a tidal mud flat, stained by sewage for much of the day.

The development corporation proposed two big moves. The first was the construction of a mile-long boulevard driving straight down to the bay, all the way from Cardiff's centre, with a high-tech tram system to get people there. The second was to make the waterfront a place that would be worth making the trip to see. Smelly mud flats were not regarded as falling into that category. Instead, a giant tidal barrier would make the whole bay into a permanent fresh-water lake. The ecologists weren't impressed, but despite their objections, the barrier is now complete. The boulevard, too, is rapidly taking shape.

The problem with both is in the detail. The development corporation began by looking for the best advice it could find, and has since rejected almost all of it. The boulevard was originally designed by Martorell, Bohigas and Mackay from Barcelona. But when they tried to turn their ideas into reality, the development corporation swiftly got rid of them, watering down the boulevard into a close approximation of a by-pass and wrecking its carefully considered relationship with the waterfront. A cluster of four columns designed by David Mackay, trapped between the railway embankment, and Toys'R'Us, is all that is left of Cardiff's brave ambitions to make it into the European first division.

It was the same with the tidal barrage. Will Alsop was hired to turn simple engineering into a spectacular collection of architectural follies. Predictably, he, too, has left the scene without achieving what had been promised. If you want a reminder of what Cardiff has missed, an exhibition of Hadid's work opened last week at the Institute of Contemporary Arts in London. It shows the work she will get a chance to build in Italy and America, but sadly not in Wales. But I don't expect there will be many visitors from Cardiff.

 Zaha Hadid: Urban Architecture is at the ICA, London SW1 until 10 September.

A cluster of four columns designed by David Mackay, trapped between the railway embankment, and Toys'R'Us, is all that is left of Cardiff's brave ambitions to make it into the European first division. It was the same with the tidal barrage. Will Alsop was hired to turn simple engineering into a spectacular collection of architectural follies. Predictably, he, too, has left the scene without achieving what had been promised. If you want a reminder of what Cardiff has missed, an exhibition of Hadid's work opened last week at the Institute of Contemporary Arts in London. It shows the work she will get a chance to build in Italy and America, but sadly not in Wales. But I don't expect there will be many visitors from Cardiff.  Zaha Hadid: Urban Architecture is at the ICA, London SW1 until 10 September.

webTitle: 'A genius? No, I'm actually a fungus...'

fields.headline: 'A genius? No, I'm actually a fungus...'
fields.trailText: Stephen Merritt
fields.body:
Stephen Merritt is a man who believes in the power of high numbers. Thus his latest album is a 3-CD set (accurately) entitled 69 Love Songs. And thus his press officer has decided to schedule a similarly enormous number of interviews. However, I do have an exclusive: I am the only person to interview Merritt while he has a cold. In most articles he is labelled as 'the man with the deepest speaking voice in popular music'. For this evening only, he has 'the most nasal whine in popular music'.

Everything else written about him turns out to be true. He really is tiny and he really does pause for up to 20 seconds before answering each question. He raises his eyebrows a lot, too, and has the mordant conversational technique and effortlessly superior intellect of Marvin the Paranoid Android. When I start taking notes, he stares at my writing hand as though he has just noticed a couple of extra fingers. Is anything wrong, I ask. (Long pause.) 'Uhh_ you have_ interesting handwriting.'

I decide to take this as a compliment. I am, after all, talking to a 'genius' (New York Times), a 'visionary' (Village Voice) and 'the greatest living American songwriter' (New York Observer). He has been compared with Cole Porter, Randy Newman, Irving Berlin and Oscar Wilde. The critical reception afforded 69 Love Songs in the US dwarfs his healthy press profile on this side of the pond. When he goes for a wee, I am half tempted to lick his glass of cognac in the hope of catching some of those genius germs.

Such hyperbole sits uncomfortably on the narrow shoulders of a 35-year-old man whose career to date is one of dogged underachievement - a series of patchy, obscure albums with improbably named bands such as Future Bible Heroes, The Gothic Archies and The Sixths. 69 Love Songs, recorded under the name The Magnetic Fields, is his calling card to the world, and it certainly demonstrates his mastery of pastiche. Folk, country, soul, indie rock, Eighties electronica... almost every popular music genre is included on the album.

Merritt plays nearly 100 instruments (anally listed on the CD sleeve) and his melodies are lovely, his lyrics witty and sometimes poignant. There are four guest vocalists, but Merritt sings most of the tracks in his lugubrious baritone.

The album is, he says, tongue half in cheek, 'a précis of the previous century. They could delete hundreds of records from the back catalogue. When I am king,' he adds, 'most records will be deleted. Stone Temple Pilots, for example...'

Genius or not, Merritt is an accomplished interviewee. His track record as an interviewer (he still writes about music for Time Out New York) is more chequered. 'I had a very, very bad inter view with the Spice Girls two years ago,' he reveals, face paling. 'Melanie B got vicious. There was a moment - only 20 or 30 seconds at most - when my tape recorder stopped working, and as I was trying to start it again, she asked if I'd ever given an interview before.' He stares into his spirit glass with recollected horror.

The best interview he ever conducted was with Kevin Williamson, screenwriter of Scream, the self-referential, postmodern horror movie that reinvented the genre a few years back. Merritt is extremely enthusiastic about Scream. 'In fact,' he adds, 'I would draw a close parallel between Kevin Williamson's movies and my records.'

So he regards himself as a postmodernist? He pauses. 'I would like to make another parallel: there are animals and plants, and then there are fungi which process the dead matter of animals and plants, and are indispensable to the ecosystem.'

Right. So you're a fungus?

He is silent for several seconds, eyebrow raised. 'An indispensable, life-giving fungus.'

 The Magnetic Fields play Queen Elizabeth Hall, London SE1, on Tuesday

webTitle: A slag heap, a skeleton and a dead horse. Hmm, must be Mozart

fields.headline: A slag heap, a skeleton and a dead horse. Hmm, must be Mozart
fields.standfirst: The gore and the grime may be controversial, but they're the best bit of the new Don Giovanni
fields.trailText: Don Giovanni | BBC Proms
fields.body:
Don Giovanni Glyndebourne Festival, Sussex
BBC Proms Royal Albert Hall, London (SW7/BBC2 TV/Radio 3)

Old misconceptions die hard. There are still people who think Mozart's music is pretty. You may as well believe the Medicis were kind or that Aesop had a soft spot for animals. Hard though it is to appreciate, 200 years and much treacly hype later, Mozart was one of music's most audacious risk-takers, a pioneer who blasted Viennese society with string quartets of shocking dissonance, piano concertos rude with prominent woodwind, symphonies unconventional in form and startling in their passionate intensity. It is easy to forget all that in the balm of 'Eine Kleine Nacht Musik' tinkling sweetly when the bank puts you on hold.

As for the operas, which in subject matter appear to be about trivial social con vention, here Mozart was at his most brutal and uncompromising. He wanted realism. How wrong we are to assume, as histories of opera usually do, that this commodity only came a century later with Verdi and Puccini's consumptive women, or Bizet's gypsy Carmen. Nowhere is the world more palpable or more grotesque, more tragic or more comic, than in Don Giovanni. The terrifying overture, lurching and swirling from bright to dark, major to minor, announces as much. Yet we're still locked into the belief that opera productions should observe some code of decorum (not ever an issue in the theatre). Austerity is acceptable, minimalism forgivable. But to cross into the nasty world whose court and gutter Mozart knew too well is still a crime of taste.

Graham Vick, completing his Da Ponte trilogy for Glyndebourne with Don Giovanni , does just that. You might even say he revels in bad taste, as if challenging the audience, whose dismay was audible when the curtain rose at the first night, to examine their own fragrant lives. The cause of the displeasure was Richard Hudson's set. The pure, creamy rehearsal room - also the basis for Cosi fan Tutte and Marriage of Figaro , much despised then but now surely rather fondly recalled - has been obscured by a grey slag heap, as if newly ejected at the wrong address by a subversive dumper-truck. On this pile of sterile waste, the Don plays out his games of immorality, redeemed by nothing and nobody. Hopeful white-frocked brides - Zerlina and Donna Elvira - roll in the grime, the literal sense of defilement all too acute. Overhead a half-dressed skeleton dangles, later joined by a slaughtered horse, on whose raw entrails Don Giovanni eventually sups.

Ruffled sensibilities aside, so far so convincing. Graham Vick, whose own innards have been mauled by critics over these three productions, always forces you to think. The layers of stylistic approach, lavish Spanish costumes and high wigs for the nobility, peasants in cheap jiving suits with glimpses of commedia dell'arte and Sex Pistols en route, deftly widened the scope of the piece to any place at any time. The reason, finally, the production collapsed was that the musical performance failed to vivify the stage action. True, the score explodes with violence and ferocity, but Mozart's genius wraps this fury into perfectly poised ensembles and arias. Here such refinement was in short supply.

The cast, not helped by an ailing Sandra Zelzer (Elvira), seemed unwilling to push their characters towards the requirements of Vick's mise en scène , nor draw energy from it to fuel their interpretations. So the tart humour in the relationship between the bumpkin Leporello (Alessandro Corbelli) and his macho, half-naked master (Natale de Carolis) was subdued and underplayed. If the Don fails to clutch or chill the heart, his demise becomes strangely inconsequential. Gwynne Howell as the Commendatore arrived, unusually for a heroic statue, in pyjamas and dressing gown, yet made little of the paradox. Barbara Frittoli's Donna Anna was elegant but seemed underpowered. Only Bruce Ford reached an illuminating excellence as Don Ottavio, carrying off his masked-ball drag with aplomb. Andrew Davis, perhaps recovering from his efforts at the opening of the Proms the night before, conducted a slightly sluggish London Philharmonic but Gareth Hancock's fortepiano continuo playing (with cellist Susanne Beer) always had wit and finesse.

This production is part of Glyndebourne Touring Opera's autumn programme, where a different cast may make it all cohere. Check the itinerary.

The 106th Season of Henry Wood Promenade Concerts (if we may still call them that) opened without the full-scale choral work of recent tradition. This had to wait until Mendelssohn's St Paul on the third night. Instead, Evgeny Kissin gave a stiff account of Rachmaninov's Second Piano Concerto which drew the crowds but, despite Janàc ek's Glagolitic Mass in the second half, diminished the inclusive First Night mood which a grand choral work generates - that sense that we ourselves might once have sung in it, or could one day. The first week was replete with premieres, not all well attended but full of interest. Julian Yu's Not a Stream but an Ocean, a BBC commission, paid tribute to Bach, a little too slavishly perhaps, in a BBC National Orchestra of Wales concert conducted by George Benjamin, whose exquisite Palimpsest was also played.

Joanna MacGregor spearheaded an intriguing experiment between four composers (notably Nitin Sawhney, who made vivid use of tablas) and young London musicians. Evelyn Glennie and the jazz drummer Peter Erskine gave the world premiere of another Proms commission, Mark-Anthony Turnage's sensual, sparky and eloquent double concerto, Fractured Lines . Prevented from getting to Kensington Gore owing to Wednesday's bomb scare, I heard this on Radio 3 with the bonus of catching the first Poetry Prom, a new feature, broadcast from the Serpentine. The next is at 5.30pm on Friday. Highlights this week: Ian Bostridge singing Bach on Tuesday (at 10pm) and the world premiere of Robin Holloway's Symphony on Saturday.

fields.headline: Cope springs eternal
fields.trailText: Manon | Mix
fields.body:
Manon Royal Opera House, London WC2

Mix Barbican Theatre, London EC2

The Royal Ballet and the Kirov are alternating at Covent Garden, with both companies returning under the Hochhauser banner for second seasons. Big names and blockbuster ballets should guarantee good houses through the summer. Expect plenty of cast changes, though, as injuries and cancellations play havoc with long-term schedules.

Sylvie Guillem launched the Royal Ballet's two-week programme on Monday in Manon, with Jonathan Cope replacing Laurent Hilaire from the Paris Opera Ballet. His rapport with Guillem has made theirs an exceptional partnership. Their account of the final pas de deux from Manon was the highlight of last year's reopening gala at the Royal Opera House, so it is fascinating to see how different their interpretation becomes when the ballet is given in full.

Guillem's Manon is a gambler. Her wide-eyed gaze at the start masks a calculating brain. She tries out how it feels to fall in love and in lust with Des Grieux; then, reckoning that she's had the best of him, she weighs the cost of good sex against good jewellery. She goes for the rocks, electing to become a kept woman.

Cope's Des Grieux has no way of comprehending what makes her tick. He is addicted to her, his innocence compromised. Guillem looks at his beautiful arabesques, remembers the marvellous sex and decides to have it all. She needs to take risks - until she loses everything. In extremis in the Lousiana swamp, she hurls herself against the heavens, only to slip lifeless through Cope's arms. Since Guillem is an extreme dancer, the pas de deux , instead of being a bravura display, becomes a metaphor of Manon's defiance.

Gillian Revie, making her debut at Thursday's matinée, portrays Manon as a creature of her society. Her initial shyness transmutes into slyness, as she sells herself to escape poverty. Carlos Acosta is the purest Des Grieux possible, an idealistic outsider with no idea of the price he will have to pay.

He is bent into submission by Manon's amoral brother, Lescaut. Acosta, also making his debut, had to deal with two Lescauts, for Victor Alvarez injured himself in the first act and was replaced for the second by Ricardo Cervera. Both dancers were as sharp as knives, sheathed in glittering charm.

'You can see all of life here,' proclaims Deborah Colker of her Brazilian company, celebrating summer at the Barbican. 'It's not good. It's not bad. It's incredible.' Not really. Athletic dancers are confined to a collage of sports-inspired routines in Mix, a rehash of Colker's early work. Most of the time the performers are cartoon characters, modular units of a dance machine. Only in glimpses do they reveal that they could be so much more.

The grand finale has them traversing a climbing wall, gluing themselves against gravity on its holds. Ingenious, but the equally versatile dancers in the ghastly French musical, Notre Dame de Paris , are even more daring. They dart around the rock face of the cathedral like lizards, far less predictable than the Brazilian formation team. Earplugs are advisable for both shows.
