fields.headline: When City traders wore togas
fields.standfirst: What did the Romans ever do for us? Well, according to a new exhibition, they laid the foundations for capitalism
fields.trailText: What did the Romans ever do for us? Well, according to a new exhibition, they laid the foundations for capitalism.
fields.body:
High Street Londinium, Museum of London, EC1 until 7 January

The recent history of Number One, Poultry, in the glass and concrete heart of the City of London, is well documented. In the Fifties, the site was owned by Rudolph Palumbo, son of an Italian immigrant from Amalfi, who had started out as the owner of a greasy- spoon café in Lower Thames Street and had built a vast property empire of which this site was one of unexploited gems.

On his death in 1963, the site was inherited by his son, Peter, later Lord Palumbo, the former head of the Arts Council, who then battled for more than three decades to redevelop its Victorian shop premises into what he advertised as the 'last great landmark building of the twentieth century'.

The original Mies van der Rohe office block proposed for the site was dismissed by Prince Charles as a disfiguring 'glass stump' and planning permission was refused. James Stirling then had a go, only for his plans to be described by the Prince of Wales as looking like 'a 1930s wireless', but eventually, after a series of appeals, a modified version of the Stirling building was accepted and construction began in 1994.

The ancient history of the troubled site was, however, less well known, and one of the deals that allowed Palumbo finally to get a green light for his plans was his agreement to allow - and partially fund - the archaeologists of the Museum of London to excavate the building's foundations. After so many years of procrastination, it was decided that this £3 million work would run concurrently with construction, so as the Stirling building advanced skywards it was supported on pilings while the archaeologists painstakingly sifted what was beneath it.

The site was unique in the City in that unlike the surrounding vaulted banks and monumental office blocks with their deep foundations, its Victorian buildings had very shallow basements and the ancient topography of the area was therefore undisturbed.

What also assisted in the dig was the fact that the site was on the banks of an ancient tributary of the Thames, known as Wal brook, and at depth the ground was waterlogged. The consequent absence of oxygen had served to preserve the organic material - wood and leather - found far beneath the surface and thusprovided a unique record not only of the first structures on the site, but also evidence of some of the domestic objects that give clues to daily life in that period.

The most important finds made in nearly two years of work dated right back to the first century when the area was initially settled by other immigrants from the Italian coast. Walbrook was at the heart of Roman London and Number One, Poultry was on the northern side of the main east-west road that followed the route of Oxford Street, Holborn and Cheapside.

The lower walls of entire buildings were uncovered - a series of timber-framed commercial structures that were discovered to be a bakery and a merchant's shop and some kind of public eating place or bar (an ancient precursor to Rudolph Palumbo's greasy spoon and Terence Conran's Le Coq D'Argent, which now occupies the penthouse floor of Stirling's building).

These structures offered a first thrilling glimpse of the genesis of the City and exact replicas of them have now been built in the Museum of London, with help from the production company Sands Films, which specialises in period reconstructions.

Wandering through these functional mock-ups, with their axe-cut green oak beams and their rough plaster walls, you get some real, if distant, sense of the particular foundations of the old City. Unlike any contem porary native buildings, the three shops were prefabricated; they also introduced the concept of corners to the ancient British, who had always made circular dwellings.

They are structures that were put together to order and in a hurry; they are redolent of new ideas of mass production and efficiency. The Romans of 40AD wanted to develop London quickly as their northern trading hub and there was apparently a mini-frenzy of Docklands-style property speculation around this time. Buildings were going up everywhere as traders sought to capitalise on the arrival of goods from throughout the empire.

Museum of London director Simon Thurley says: 'The only conceivable reason why the Romans would have attempted to create this new city in Britain was commercial [they introduced a market economy and coinage to the country] and so what you see in these preserved buildings is a vivid snapshot of something like a Wild West gold-rush town.' The Romans thus came to the original square mile for the same reason people have come to it ever since - to make money.

The original speculators were more likely to be Britons than imperial expats - and their profit-making was short-lived (boom and bust was, from the outset, apparently in the script). The new city was partially destroyed by fire in the Boudiccan revolt in AD60, from which much of the material collected - which includes remnants of 1,250 oak timbers and more than 5,000 artefacts - originally dates. The reconstruction is the central part of a large-scale attempt to understand some of the fabric of routine lives of this crucial time in the City's genealogy - and to this end the exhibition also includes the intricate imported pottery, the carved lamp holders and the cosmetic sets (combined tweezers and ear cleaners) that were removed from the site.

It is ironic, perhaps, or maybe fitting, that at a time when London is undergoing an almost unprecedented redevelopment, our know-ledge of its ancient past should be so enhanced. But one of the by-products of the current National Lottery-funded golden age of capital projects in London, such as the new Covent Garden and the Millennium Bridge, has been the opportunity to excavate key historical sites for the first time.

The material collected from Number One, Poultry has thus been supplemented by evidence of some of the other spectacular discoveries of the past few years: the fourth-century sarcophagus of a Roman woman in Spitalfields, the site of an adjacent contemporary 'tower block' near the present Leadenhall Market and the remains of an enormous first-century amphitheatre under the courtyard of the Guildhall, a mile or so north-east of Poultry where the original Russell Crowes may have strutted their gory stuff.

fields.bodyText: High Street Londinium, Museum of London, EC1 until 7 January The recent history of Number One, Poultry, in the glass and concrete heart of the City of London, is well documented. In the Fifties, the site was owned by Rudolph Palumbo, son of an Italian immigrant from Amalfi, who had started out as the owner of a greasy- spoon café in Lower Thames Street and had built a vast property empire of which this site was one of unexploited gems. On his death in 1963, the site was inherited by his son, Peter, later Lord Palumbo, the former head of the Arts Council, who then battled for more than three decades to redevelop its Victorian shop premises into what he advertised as the 'last great landmark building of the twentieth century'. The original Mies van der Rohe office block proposed for the site was dismissed by Prince Charles as a disfiguring 'glass stump' and planning permission was refused. James Stirling then had a go, only for his plans to be described by the Prince of Wales as looking like 'a 1930s wireless', but eventually, after a series of appeals, a modified version of the Stirling building was accepted and construction began in 1994. The ancient history of the troubled site was, however, less well known, and one of the deals that allowed Palumbo finally to get a green light for his plans was his agreement to allow - and partially fund - the archaeologists of the Museum of London to excavate the building's foundations. After so many years of procrastination, it was decided that this £3 million work would run concurrently with construction, so as the Stirling building advanced skywards it was supported on pilings while the archaeologists painstakingly sifted what was beneath it. The site was unique in the City in that unlike the surrounding vaulted banks and monumental office blocks with their deep foundations, its Victorian buildings had very shallow basements and the ancient topography of the area was therefore undisturbed. What also assisted in the dig was the fact that the site was on the banks of an ancient tributary of the Thames, known as Wal brook, and at depth the ground was waterlogged. The consequent absence of oxygen had served to preserve the organic material - wood and leather - found far beneath the surface and thusprovided a unique record not only of the first structures on the site, but also evidence of some of the domestic objects that give clues to daily life in that period. The most important finds made in nearly two years of work dated right back to the first century when the area was initially settled by other immigrants from the Italian coast. Walbrook was at the heart of Roman London and Number One, Poultry was on the northern side of the main east-west road that followed the route of Oxford Street, Holborn and Cheapside. The lower walls of entire buildings were uncovered - a series of timber-framed commercial structures that were discovered to be a bakery and a merchant's shop and some kind of public eating place or bar (an ancient precursor to Rudolph Palumbo's greasy spoon and Terence Conran's Le Coq D'Argent, which now occupies the penthouse floor of Stirling's building). These structures offered a first thrilling glimpse of the genesis of the City and exact replicas of them have now been built in the Museum of London, with help from the production company Sands Films, which specialises in period reconstructions. Wandering through these functional mock-ups, with their axe-cut green oak beams and their rough plaster walls, you get some real, if distant, sense of the particular foundations of the old City. Unlike any contem porary native buildings, the three shops were prefabricated; they also introduced the concept of corners to the ancient British, who had always made circular dwellings. They are structures that were put together to order and in a hurry; they are redolent of new ideas of mass production and efficiency. The Romans of 40AD wanted to develop London quickly as their northern trading hub and there was apparently a mini-frenzy of Docklands-style property speculation around this time. Buildings were going up everywhere as traders sought to capitalise on the arrival of goods from throughout the empire. Museum of London director Simon Thurley says: 'The only conceivable reason why the Romans would have attempted to create this new city in Britain was commercial [they introduced a market economy and coinage to the country] and so what you see in these preserved buildings is a vivid snapshot of something like a Wild West gold-rush town.' The Romans thus came to the original square mile for the same reason people have come to it ever since - to make money. The original speculators were more likely to be Britons than imperial expats - and their profit-making was short-lived (boom and bust was, from the outset, apparently in the script). The new city was partially destroyed by fire in the Boudiccan revolt in AD60, from which much of the material collected - which includes remnants of 1,250 oak timbers and more than 5,000 artefacts - originally dates. The reconstruction is the central part of a large-scale attempt to understand some of the fabric of routine lives of this crucial time in the City's genealogy - and to this end the exhibition also includes the intricate imported pottery, the carved lamp holders and the cosmetic sets (combined tweezers and ear cleaners) that were removed from the site. fields.headline: Frankly, he's diabolical
fields.standfirst: The witches are weird and witty and the music is wicked. Pity the devil lets them down
fields.trailText: The Witches of Eastwick | Henry IV, Part II
fields.body:
The Witches of Eastwick Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, London WC2

Henry IV, Part II Swan, Stratford

It's a bubbling cauldron, but it's not spellbinding. The Witches of Eastwick, the catchy and colourful new musical production from Sir Cameron Mackintosh, has lots to recommend it. What it lacks is an original pulse, and a dynamic leading man.

John Dempsey and Dana P. Rowe's adaptation of the novel by John Updike - and the Jack Nicholson movie - has a good start with its unsoppy story. The Witches of Eastwick is fuelled by sex rather than sentiment: three discontented women in a small New England town discover magical powers when they conjure up a diabolic hunk, and scandalise their strait-laced neighbours. Only in Mamma Mia! have three women supposedly past their first flush been so firmly in charge of a musical.

As the weird sisters, Lucie Arnaz, Maria Friedman and Joanna Riding are rousing: clarion-voiced and clever. Dempsey (book and lyrics) gives them sharp lines. They have sassy moments: flicking up a pert tennis dress to show off a pair of Y-fronts. And at the end of the first half - lolling together, sated in their lover's infernal mansion - this magical trio literally take off. They rise into the air and then, thrillingly, strike out across the auditorium, floating over the heads of the audience like figureheads tugging an invisible ship.

Bob Crowley's cunning cut-out design presents the perfect ironic background, in which cute white houses and a pop-up flagpole nestle among a range of breast-like hills. He creates a glitzy neon diner, and a tipsy clapboard church which collapses to spectacular effect.

Things are set for a sophisticated satirical evening. But, for all its spookiness, The Witches of Eastwick is as conventional as any completely traditional musical, the most wholesome of which harbour dark corners. It comes close to suggesting that all a dissatisfied woman needs is a good seeing to by a man; a final, saccharine chorus about finding the answers inside yourself adds insult to injury.

Rowe's music is prancing, punching, engaging: it whizzes everything along with deflating gurgles of brass, but it never sounds witchy, and always has a familiar, out-of- Chicago ring. Ian McShane is miscast as the diabolic sexpot. His singing is drab; his dancing is limp: he looks as if he had a headache even before he started on these women.

Desmond Barrit's Falstaff is, as he should be, the great bellows of Henry IV, Part II, which opened last month in the Swan, stirringly directed by Michael Attenborough. Barrit never makes you think he's nice: he plays Falstaff's moments of shabby betrayal unstintingly, without any attempt at charm. But the easy roll of his gestures and phrases marks him as the source of warmth in this abundant, melancholy play, which shifts so swiftly from the public to the intimate. He makes other characters look as if they're trying too hard. And when the ratter is ratted on, it feels not like justice but treachery. Es Devlin's cinder-coloured design, in which gold lines gleam through the grey ashes, reinforces this. When the new king appears like a picture-book monarch in stiff white robes, the sky behind him turns rosy. When he spurns his old companion, it fades to grey.

The King, David Troughton, speaking more smoothly than he did in Part I, is compelling as a man whose power is seeping away. When he takes off the crown, you feel the strain in his hands and head, as if he were removing something soldered to his scalp. William Houston's Hal, moving from nervousness to resolution, looks set to be a fascinating Henry V. Particularly now, perhaps: Prince Charles is said to have spoken admiringly of Shakespeare's understanding of what it is to be a monarch in waiting.

The most enchanting passage is provided by Benjamin Whitrow and Peter Copley as Shallow and Silence, mulling over old times and old England. Copley - gracefully capering in a long nightgown, mouthing his comrade's words as they fall from his lips, swept up like a doll into Falstaff's arms - delivers an aria of elderliness that provokes the audience to applause.

webTitle: The emperor strikes back. Helped by a cast of thousands

fields.headline: The emperor strikes back. Helped by a cast of thousands
fields.standfirst: Imperial intrigue in China, marital intrigue in Israel, satirical cats in New York. And blaxploitation is back
fields.trailText: The Emperor and the Assassin | Kadosh | Stuart Little | Fortress 2 | Shaft
fields.body:
The Emperor and the Assassin (161 mins, 12). Directed by Chen Kaige; starring Gong Li, Zhang Fengyi, Li Xuejian

Kadosh (110 mins, 15) Directed by Amos Gitaï; starring Yaël Abecassis, Yoram Hattab, Meital Barda, Uri Ran-Klauzner

Stuart Little (84 mins, PG) Directed by Rob Minkoff; starring Geena Davis, Hugh Laurie, Jonathan Lipnicki

Fortress 2 (99 mins, 18) Directed by Geoff Murphy; starring Christopher Lambert, Patrick Malahide, Pam Grier

Shaft (100 mins, 15) Directed by Gordon Parks; starring Richard Roundtree, Moses Gunn, Charles Cioffi

Writing from Cannes last year I gave rather short shrift to Chen Kaige's The Emperor and the Assassin, after seeing it with French subtitles half-way through the Festival and at the end of a long day. I was wrong. It is certainly a little too long, but the ambition and achievement put most current films to shame.

The movie, which compares favourably with Kurosawa's late epics, Kagemusha and Ran, is set in the third century BC when Ying Zheng, the King of Qin, became the first Emperor of China by unifying the seven large kingdoms that had been warring for centuries. His dynasty lasted a mere 15 years. As depicted in the film Ying Sheng's an honest man dedicated to bringing peace to his country. But he's a flawed ruler, warped by the humiliations of a period in exile and driven almost mad by the discovery that his mother has borne children to her lover, who's conspiring against him. He is driven over the edge by the revelation that his real father is not the late king but the Prime Minister (played by Chen Kaige himself) whom he's dismissed. He ends up a ruthless killer spreading death around him.

The king's antithesis is Jing Ke, a ruthless assassin who has repented of his way of life to become a man of peace. Mediating between the two is Lady Zhao (the beautiful Gong Li), the king's childhood sweetheart. She first conspires with the king to fake an assassination attempt that will provide a pretext for him to invade yet another nation, choosing the reluctant, fearless Jing Ke for the job. Then as the King's actions become increasingly brutal, encouraging extreme violence among others, she decides to plan a genuine assassination.

Visually the film, said to be the most expensive ever made by an Asian country, is stunning, with spectacular sieges and battles involving a cast of thousands, hundreds of them on horseback. The defeat of a coup, in which the insurgents are surrounded in the middle of a vast courtyard by four groups of black-clad archers and swordsmen carrying golden shields, is memorably staged. Maps figure emblematically throughout the film - the floor of the imperial map room is just big enough to contain a map of the seven kingdoms to be united; the assassin plans to conceal his sword inside a rolled-up map that supposedly represents a tract of land that is to be ceded to the king. And all this is at the service of a story that has elements of classic tragedy, is psychologically subtle, and constantly suggests modern parallels.

A similar seriousness informs Amos Gitaï's Kadosh (Hebrew for sacred), which was also shown in competition at Cannes last year. Directed by Israel's leading film-maker and co-scripted by a Frenchwoman, Eliette Abecassis, this is the third part of his trilogy of movies set in different cities, though the earlier Haifa and Tel Aviv pictures have yet to be shown here and I've seen neither.

Kadosh takes place in the Mea Shearim area of Jerusalem, centre of ultra-orthodoxy, and the picture begins with a seven-minute single shot of the elaborate rituals - prayers, washing, dressing - that Meir, a young Talmudic scholar, goes through on waking in the morning as his wife lies asleep. To a non-Jewish agnostic, it looks quaint, touching, more than a little mad.

This is not, however, sentimental Fiddler on the Roof stuff. Meir's handsome, devoted wife, Rivka, has not borne him children after 10 years of marriage, though most likely this is the result of his sterility. Rivka suffers in silence, unlike her younger sister, Malka, who wants to marry a singer and quit the community. The pressure of patriarchy, Talmudic prescriptions and unquestioned traditions, results in Malka being forced into marriage with an insensitive young scholar, and the rabbi deciding that Meir (who's his son) should divorce Rivka and marry another woman.

This is a story that makes the blood boil, but Gitaï treats it in an objective fashion, never suggesting that these people are acting in any consciously vindictive or malevolent fashion. Seeing Kadosh the same day as I read reports of the Taliban religious police arresting a Pakistani football team for playing in shorts (and shaving their heads as punishment) brought home to me with a terrible force both the tragic and farcical aspects of fundamentalism.

In a letter written in 1939 to the curator for children's books at New York Public Library, E.B. White, one of the great prose stylists of the twentieth century, remarked: 'My fears about writing for children are great - one can so easily slip into a cheap sort of whimsy or cuteness.' He was talking about Stuart Little, his story of a three-inch mouse living with a middle-class family in New York, and the pitfalls he refers to have not entirely been avoided by the people who've filmed it - a strong team that includes Rob Minkoff (director of The Lion King, screenwriter M. Night Shyamalan (author of The Sixth Sense) and John Dykstra (who won a Visual Effects Oscar for Star Wars).

The film is a neater, less mysterious, more mundane affair than White's book, but it's a lot of fun. The setting is a fairy-tale Manhattan, the digitalised animals carry absolute conviction, and there's a lovely children's boat-race in Central Park with Stuart competing against electronically controlled yachts. Alternately a sentimental celebration of family life and a quite savage comedy, it swings in the early part between a scariness that recalls The Incredible Shrinking Man (Stuart drowning in a washing machine) and a live-action Tom and Jerry cartoon (Stuart chased by Snowbell, the family cat).

The cats (voiced by Chazz Palminteri, Nathan Lane and Steve Zahn) have most of the best lines, for example when a desperate Stuart beseeches Snowbell to turn off the washing machine, the cat says: 'Why would I switch it off? It's my favourite show.' As Stuart's conventional adoptive father, Hugh Laurie - bespectacled, his hair cut short and sporting an American accent - bears an uncanny resemblance to Robert MacNamara.

Fortress 2 is about as welcome as Ishtar 2 or Rancid Aluminium 2 would be. Made on location in Luxembourg, it's an incoherent sequel to the lousy 1994 sci-fi thriller Fortress with Christopher Lambert once again a rebel imprisoned in a hi-tech prison run by the Men-Tel Corporation in an authoritarian future. The chief difference is that in the earlier film the jail was underground and this one's in Outer Space. The director is the once-promising New Zealander Geoff Murphy, who has given little guidance to Patrick Malahide and Pam Grier as the competing jailers.

The term 'blaxploitation' was coined in the early Seventies to describe the cycle of violent, sexy, ass-kicking movies launched by Shaft. Scripted by Ernest Tidyman (who that year, 1971, won an Oscar for The French Connection) this is perfunctory B-feature stuff, but important for the way it gave tough-guy roles to black actors (in this case Richard Roundtree as a New York private eye) and allowed them to out-talk cops, gun down the Mafia, and bed the black and white chicks who lay down before them.

This reissue is a curtain-raiser for John Singleton's remake starring Samuel L. Jackson, though 40 years ago it would have been suppressed in order not to invite comparisons. One of the incidental interests is noting the movies being shown in 1971 at 42nd Street cinemas near Shaft's office - such as Get Carter, and a double-bill of Patton and M*A*S*H.

fields.headline: Pick up an Angry Penguin
fields.standfirst: Arthur Boyd's vision of Australia is unbeatable
fields.trailText: Arthur Boyd and the Exile of Imagination
fields.body:
Arthur Boyd and the Exile of Imagination Australia House, London WC2, until 30 July

In 1971, after 11 years living in London, Arthur Boyd returned to his native Australia to take up the post of artist-in-residence at the Australian National University. The next year, he was back in London and then by 1974 in Australia again. He was in his early fifties, one of his country's leading painters and at a point in his life when he was questioning everything.

Some of the works that resulted from this troubled period from 1971-73 have been assembled in a travelling exhibition which is currently - and fittingly, considering how long he lived here - in London. Boyd was clearly a painter who usually wanted to be somewhere else. Distance seemed to heighten his vision, so that the bone-white sand of the outback under a blistering blue sky of a work like Hill landscape, aeroplane and book was painted under the lowering skies of England.

Most of the works are figurative, with a nude subject in the foreground and apart from one reasonably peaceful seated woman, in anguish. They run, crouch and watch with alarm burning planes, muzzled dogs, flaming books. Books are a recurrent theme, as is money; both are often on fire.

In Figure in a cave with a smoking book , a figure sits at the mouth of a cave looking up at the evening star. The landscape is bare of sources of food or any materials that the human may have brought with him other than a book, but that is burning. The desolation is total.

Boyd reacted swiftly and emotively to external influences. His early work reflected the biblical overtones of a devout yet bohemian upbringing (his parents and grandparents were artists and potters), and his earlier works reflect aboriginal poverty, the Depression and the Second World War.

So in 1972, when he was in such a vulnerable mental state, a visit to a London animal research station brought shocking results. In Woman injecting a rabbit, a frenzied nude woman plunges a syringe into a black rabbit sitting on a table. Outside the window is Boyd's beloved Australian outback, out of reach behind wire mesh. On a high shelf is a pile of money of no use to anybody, and crouched, trapped like a black devil behind the woman, is the artist brandishing his brushes, unable to escape.

In the next series of paintings (Chained figure and bent tree), the artist has become the foreground figure, wearing a wire-mesh mask which is attached to a gum tree by a taut black chain. An arid, sun-seared plain stretches to the horizon; a desolate figure is crossing it, belabouring an animal .

In stark contrast are the three pictures of England painted during the same period of territorial and emotional indecision. Boyd, who later went on to buy a farm in the area, uses a completely different palette and technique for Suffolk. There is no spatial plane, the dense green foliage fills the canvas and swamps the figures with long brush strokes. The skyline is low and grey.

Boyd, who died last year, was an almost exact contemporary of the more famous Sidney Nolan and in some respects stylistically similar. Both took part in the Angry Penguins protest movement of the 1940s, but Boyd was the more adventurous of the two, as Nolan tended to get lazy after his Ned Kelly phase. Judge for yourself; this is a rare opportunity to see Boyds en masse.

fields.headline: Moral muse
fields.standfirst: I think my friend's father is having an affair
fields.trailText: I think my friend's father is having an affair.
fields.body:
My friend and I have known each other for five years. I know her parents well and chat to them when I call round or phone. A week ago, early in the morning, I passed her father in the street. He was holding hands with a woman who was not my friend's mother. We walked past each other but I looked down. I have seen him since at her house and he is wary of me, obviously wondering if I am going to say something. Should I tell my friend or should I keep out of their business?
Y.L. of Beckenham, Kent

It's difficult to think of an innocent explanation for your observations, but let's be generous and try. Truth is often improbably defiant. This could be a case of mistaken identity; many people have alter egos who resemble them so uncannily that even acquaintances can make an error in a casual, brief encounter. This man could have a brother, even an identical twin. Are you absolutely certain, meeting him in the half-light, half-awake in the early morning, embarrassed and hanging your head down, that it really was him and not someone else?

I suspect that you are not certain, so let me do a little more speculating. Like the majority of humankind, you probably enjoy a little gossip, a chance to see behind the screens of respectable veneer and view some secret, sordid goings-on. We all indulge in this and wouldn't life be boring with out it? Hasn't the very thought given you a frisson? And - oh dear - can you admit that you'd be disappointed if some non-guilty explanation were to be produced? It's important to recognise this subconscious wish for the seamy construction to be the true one, because you have by your observations the power to cause a lot of misery and destruction.

Indeed the very possession of this power can go to someone's head, to the extent that they cannot bear to have it and not to use it. So beware.

What, then, if you really did catch your girlfriend's father in a mildly compromising situation? You assume that he has spent the night with this woman who is not his wife and one is walking the other home. Presumably his wife is aware that he is away from the house. He is adopting very risky behaviour if he prome nades openly near his neighbourhood in this friendly-if-not-quite-intimate way with his lady-friend. Some couples do have an open, free-and-easy attitude to infidelities, so it is quite possible they have such an understanding. Maybe they are remaining together only until the family are grown up and away. Maybe he's an ageing Lothario, a bit of an exhibitionist, who doesn't mind showing the younger generation that he too can be a bit of a lad.

However you come at this, it seems there are very good reasons for keeping your mouth shut. If you reveal all, and are mistaken, you'll enhance yourself in nobody's eyes. If it's an open secret, you'll appear spiteful and small-minded, an interfering busybody. If you uncover a scandal, you'll be viewed as the harbinger of retribution, and much good it will definitely not do you - or anyone else.

I think you may be young and inexperienced in the ways of the world. All is never what it seems, including the motivation for interfering in someone else's business. Wisdom is knowing when to leave well alone and say nothing; for you that starts here.

Readers' replies

Please do not interfere over what may well be a perfectly innocent action by your friend's father - you could arouse suspicions and doubts which could destroy the family. Instead of jumping to what you see as the obvious conclusion that you have witnessed an infidelity, consider other possibilities. I am recently widowed and find, in common with many other widows of my acquaintance, that most of all, I miss a strong arm to give me a friendly hug or a sympathetic touch of the hand.

An understanding - married - male friend will hold my hand or give me a reassuring hug when he sees me looking particularly lost and alone. It does not mean he plans to leap into my bed.
D.E. of Dyfed

Next week's dilemma

I've been seeing my girlfriend for four months and at the beginning of the relationship I was happy and madly in love with her. However, things have progressed and as she has become obviously attached to me, my feelings for her have diminished. Although I still fancy her, I know that we do not have enough shared interest between us. Is it just the usual question of cold feet or should I trust my instincts and get out before it develops into something which could hurt both of us.
E.M. OF London

 Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk. Views on each week's problem to reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal.

fields.headline: This one's a hit...
fields.standfirst: Stephen Frears's adaptation of High Fidelity is a skilled and witty triumph
fields.trailText: Stephen Frears's adaptation of High Fidelity is a skilled and witty triumph.
fields.body:
High Fidelity ( 113 mins, 15. Directed by Stephen Frears; starring John Cusack, Iben Hjejle, Jack Black, Joan Cusack

Nick Hornby's novel High Fidelity is set specifically and convincingly in London. But it touches so amusingly, perceptively and honestly on what it's like to be a confused, self-doubting young man immersed in popular culture in any large city in the Western world at the end of the twentieth century that the transposition to Chicago for the movie version involves surprisingly little reworking.

A fine American actor, John Cusack, plays the central character, Rob Gordon, dedicated, unprosperous proprietor of a specialist record store called Championship Vinyl. Danish actress Iben Hjejle plays his lawyer girlfriend, who has just left him. They are directed by an Englishman, Stephen Frears, whose last movie, The Hi-Lo Country , was an off-beat western.

The script is by four Americans, one of them Cusack himself, who has also co-produced with a couple of Britons and a couple of Americans, while the cinematographer, Seamus McGarvey, comes from Ulster and the editor, Mick Audsley, from London. They all seem very much at home in slightly rundown areas of the Windy City, though the torrential rain that frequently matches the hero's depressed states suggests it might easily be renamed the Rainy City.

Cusack has the rare ability to play characters who have a complex inner life and to suggest a sense of decency that rejects piety - his hitman in Grosse Point Blank , for instance, and the puppeteer in Being John Malkovich . His everyday neurotics are people with whom we can easily identify.

Here, he dominates the film, taking us into Rob's mind. For much of the time, he speaks directly to camera, not just in set-pieces, but while engaged in conversations or talking on the phone or walking down the street. Pop music and films are his obsessive interests, his knowledge of them encyclopedic and, since puberty, he has been troubled by girls, whom he fears, desires and tries to understand.

His tastes define him, and for Rob and the pair of geeky assistants in his shop - the aggressive, overweight Barry (Jack Black) and the shy, shaven-headed Dick (Todd Louiso) - the music and films they admire have become shibboleths to test everyone they meet. 'What matters is what you like,' says Rob, 'not what you are like.'

As many of us do, Rob seeks to impose order on his life by drawing up lists. His most extravagant gesture is to rearrange his vast collection of LPs as a form of autobiography so that he has to think of the personal association a record has to locate it. When Laura leaves him, he rejects her from a list of 'top five most memorable split-ups'. This first takes him down memory lane to recall five of his ex-girlfriends, starting with his first intense kiss when he was 14.

These flashbacks recall Annie Hall and there is a brief appearance by Bruce Springsteen in an imaginary conversation with Rob that brings to mind Woody Allen's encounter with Marshall McLuhan in that picture.

When Rob later sets about looking up the old girlfriends, we think of Julien Duvivier's romantic classic of the Thirties, Un Carnet du Bal , where Marie Bell found nothing but misery when tracking down the swains of her young womanhood.

High Fidelity is an extra ordinarily funny film, full of verbal and visual wit. And it is assembled with immense skill. There is a brilliant sequence when Rob reconstructs in his mind a conversation between Laura and their mutual friend, Liz (Joan Cusack), knowing that Laura must have touched on four key moments (those lists again) in their relationship. The film constantly cuts in mid-sentence between Rob talking to camera in a bar and the two women conversing over lunch, and a combination of astute direction, fine acting and spot-on editing gives it an easy, seamless quality.

The picture never scores cheap points off anybody, which does not, of course, mean that the characters involved do not often obtain satisfaction, if only temporarily, by thinking they have won an argument or put someone in his or her place. When Rob is putting his past in order, he often employs a form of choplogic that briefly satisfies him. At the end, both he and we, the audience, are happily surprised by the way things turn out for him and his assistants, Barry and Dick.

Catherine Zeta-Jones plays Charlie, the hollow sophisticate, memorable break-up number four, who helps Rob see the vanity of the world, and it is good to see her mixing with people her own age.

fields.headline: Gentlemen prefer brains
fields.standfirst: Farewell, trophy wife. Today's tycoon is looking for a mature woman with intelligence, power and money of her own the second time around. The question is, what's in it for her?
fields.trailText: Farewell, trophy wife. Today's tycoon is looking for a mature woman with intelligence, power and money of her own the second time around. The question is, what's in it for her?
fields.body:
It isn't quite a trend yet, but people are talking - and scratching their heads. It seems that when tycoons get around to replacing their original wives these days, more and more of them are choosing to forgo the usual gorgeous twentysomething trophy.

They're opting instead for women who are as old, as brilliant and as successful as they are, and sometimes even every bit as unattractive. It's enough to make Ivana Trump feel quite perturbed. Even Petronella Wyatt confessed in the Spectator lately that she was worried. 'Bang go my chances of marrying a millionaire,' she wailed.

Famous examples include Jurgen Schremp, head of the Daimler-Benz empire. He recently left a wife said to have many enviable trophy attributes, to live with his personal assistant, a woman of his own age who had previously been thought to be married to her job. Then there is Tony O'Reilly, whose second wife is not just as old as he is, but also just as rich, if not richer. Her name is Chryss Goulandris, as in 'Greek shipping magnate'. Friends say she has no qualms about baring her brains in public.

In the US, meanwhile, the ideal corporate wife is no longer the sort of woman you used to see on the arm of Ivana's father Donald Trump. She is more along the lines of Carolyne Roehm, who runs her own clothing business, even though her husband is Henry Kravis of Goldberg, Kravis Roberts, the leveraged buy-out firm.

Or Audrey Butvay Gruss, whose marriage to the owner of a private investment company has not in any way eroded her commitment to her own thriving cosmetics concern, Terme di Saturnia.

Rupert Murdoch's new wife Wendy Deng is out of a similar mould. She may be young, but she is in no sense a bimbo. Ms Deng is a former company vice-president, multilingual and highly competent. She's pretty, yes, and slim, but less glamorous than his second wife, Anna, and is more likely to be seen dressed demurely in long skirts and high necked blouses than fake-tan and Versace.

It is said that the thing Murdoch found most attractive about her was not her looks but her business acumen and her understanding of China and the Far East, where much of his business is based.

In every sense of the word, these women are assets. The more there are of them about, the more social observers are falling over each other to explain what a mogul might see in them.

And so now we know that, actually, the trophy wife was never all that good a deal. She may have been an older woman's walking, talking nightmare, and she may have filled lesser males with an insatiable longing and a keen understanding of the limits of their buying power. But at home she was often skittish, expensive, and boring.

The older trophy, by contrast, can really be 'there for you'. She will not yawn when you talk shop in bed because that's all she wants to talk about anyway. And when you are too tired to go out dancing, she would never think of pouting or kicking up a fuss, because she knows exactly how you feel.

So you have to wonder why it took so long for her to come into her own. When I think back on all the trophy couples I've known, the defining trait of the men is a terrible loneliness. After the honeymoon is over, they feel their age keenly. They live their lives perched on a cliff, surveying an age gap that seems to get wider with every year. As their energy wanes and their young wives get restless, they talk about longing to be understood and appreciated. Most of all they long for a woman who will share their interests, make them feel safe and loved, bring their experience to bear on the problems that plague them, and illuminate all discussions with helpful suggestions and sparkling insights.

I mean, who wouldn't? I wouldn't dream of suggesting that these are the only things a spoilt, rich, older man might long for. Hardly a day goes by without some well-meaning male friend waving a neo-Darwinian tract in my face, while explaining why it is that red-blooded men will always lust most after nubile young women. But even they occasionally concede that there are needs and needs, and that the right sort of older woman might make a better and more sympathetic companion.

If I can get them to admit that older women have always had a lot to give to a relationship, they will usually go on to claim that men have often shied away from the joys of mature love in the past because they are afraid that if they do take an older, not quite decorative wife, their colleagues will laugh at them. However, if the older trophy wife goes from social oddity to unquestioned fixture, we could see the trend trickling down to the lower echelons, and the marriage prospects for all women over 40 could become much, much brighter.

If that's what women want, that is. Me, I'm not convinced. When I look back on what's been said so far about the older trophy phenomenon, the first thing I notice is that most of the talk is about the pros and cons for the men. There's next to nothing about the women. What's in it for them?

They have flash jobs already, so it's can't be reflected glory they're after. And they have bank accounts that are bursting at the seams, so they can't be desperate for the money. You have to hope that it's love that's made them take these men on. And you can only assume that they, too, find it lonely at the top. And long for someone who really understands what ails and inspires them and crave companionship. But they almost certainly go into their marriages expecting the caring and nurturing and pillow shop-talk to work both ways.

And if you ask me, an overweening CEO who is used to being waited on by a full-time wife and an army of ardent secretaries, is the least likely candidate for this sort of twenty-first cen tury egalitarian give-and-take. His own importance might be enhanced by the important woman on his arm, but only if she goes along with the myth that she is not quite as important as he is.

What a lot of these guys are after, I suspect, is a high tech, intellectual version of the wife who always knows when to bring them their slippers. This is a hard enough job if you have all the hours in the day. But why would any woman with her own business empire want to drag herself home in the evening to spend the next six hours reflecting her husband back at twice his size?

If you ask me, the older trophy phenomenon does not look like progress. It looks like yet another frying pan leading on to yet another fire. It's probably just as well - when you count the number of lonely millionaires who have not been beating my door down lately with offers of marriage - but honestly, genteel poverty looks like heaven in comparison.

So I'm sorry boys. I know I'm incredibly successful and just the right age. But you are going to have to count me out.

She may have been an older woman's walking, talking nightmare, and she may have filled lesser males with an insatiable longing and a keen understanding of the limits of their buying power. But at home she was often skittish, expensive, and boring. The older trophy, by contrast, can really be 'there for you'. She will not yawn when you talk shop in bed because that's all she wants to talk about anyway. And when you are too tired to go out dancing, she would never think of pouting or kicking up a fuss, because she knows exactly how you feel. So you have to wonder why it took so long for her to come into her own. When I think back on all the trophy couples I've known, the defining trait of the men is a terrible loneliness. After the honeymoon is over, they feel their age keenly. They live their lives perched on a cliff, surveying an age gap that seems to get wider with every year. As their energy wanes and their young wives get restless, they talk about longing to be understood and appreciated. Most of all they long for a woman who will share their interests, make them feel safe and loved, bring their experience to bear on the problems that plague them, and illuminate all discussions with helpful suggestions and sparkling insights. I mean, who wouldn't? I wouldn't dream of suggesting that these are the only things a spoilt, rich, older man might long for. Hardly a day goes by without some well-meaning male friend waving a neo-Darwinian tract in my face, while explaining why it is that red-blooded men will always lust most after nubile young women. But even they occasionally concede that there are needs and needs, and that the right sort of older woman might make a better and more sympathetic companion. If I can get them to admit that older women have always had a lot to give to a relationship, they will usually go on to claim that men have often shied away from the joys of mature love in the past because they are afraid that if they do take an older, not quite decorative wife, their colleagues will laugh at them. However, if the older trophy wife goes from social oddity to unquestioned fixture, we could see the trend trickling down to the lower echelons, and the marriage prospects for all women over 40 could become much, much brighter. If that's what women want, that is. Me, I'm not convinced. When I look back on what's been said so far about the older trophy phenomenon, the first thing I notice is that most of the talk is about the pros and cons for the men. There's next to nothing about the women. What's in it for them? They have flash jobs already, so it's can't be reflected glory they're after. And they have bank accounts that are bursting at the seams, so they can't be desperate for the money. You have to hope that it's love that's made them take these men on. And you can only assume that they, too, find it lonely at the top. And long for someone who really understands what ails and inspires them and crave companionship. But they almost certainly go into their marriages expecting the caring and nurturing and pillow shop-talk to work both ways. And if you ask me, an overweening CEO who is used to being waited on by a full-time wife and an army of ardent secretaries, is the least likely candidate for this sort of twenty-first cen tury egalitarian give-and-take. His own importance might be enhanced by the important woman on his arm, but only if she goes along with the myth that she is not quite as important as he is. What a lot of these guys are after, I suspect, is a high tech, intellectual version of the wife who always knows when to bring them their slippers. This is a hard enough job if you have all the hours in the day. But why would any woman with her own business empire want to drag herself home in the evening to spend the next six hours reflecting her husband back at twice his size? If you ask me, the older trophy phenomenon does not look like progress. It looks like yet another frying pan leading on to yet another fire. It's probably just as well - when you count the number of lonely millionaires who have not been beating my door down lately with offers of marriage - but honestly, genteel poverty looks like heaven in comparison. So I'm sorry boys. I know I'm incredibly successful and just the right age. But you are going to have to count me out.

webTitle: So you can act? Join the queue

fields.headline: So you can act? Join the queue
fields.standfirst: A new television series reveals the grim truth about the modern acting profession. Underpaid, underemployed and misunderstood, actors have never had it so bad
fields.trailText: A new television series reveals the grim truth about the modern acting profession. Underpaid, underemployed and misunderstood, actors have never had it so bad.
fields.body:
In Budd Schulberg's classic fictional account of Hollywood, What Makes Sammy Run? first published in 1941, the hero, Sammy Glick graduates from a local newspaper in New York and moves out West as a screenwriter. 'No more peanuts for me,' he declares to his newsroom colleagues. 'From now on, it's 250 bucks a week, starting a week from Wednesday.'

Glick is eventually ruined by Hollywood. 'All the glory and the opportunity, the push and the speed, the grinding of gears and the crap.' Almost 60 years on, Schulberg's bleak vision of the movie industry is still a powerful metaphor for the acting profession around the world.

If anything, the situation for actors in particular is even worse. In Britain, over 90 per cent of them are unemployed at any given time. Yet while the number of graduates pouring out of drama and stage schools continues to rise, the opportunities are dwindling. And finding out about openings is harder than ever if you're not already one of the lucky 10 per cent.

But it's not all bad news. 'Resting' actors are about to be offered a new networking opportunity and they won't have to be a member of Soho House to use it. It will be available on the internet. Launched in September, sofamouse.com will allow would-be stars to post their CVs online and live video feeds will register British acting talent directly to American producers. And perhaps, more crucially, sofamouse.com will advertise non-skilled jobs for resting professionals.

'Actors rarely hear about work being offered; to an extent getting work still depends on who you know. The film community is still very difficult to break into,' says Oliver Montgomery, an actor himself and one of the site's founders. He estimates that there are just under one million people in Britain looking for work in and around the acting industry. 'Hopefully, we'll register around 100,000 of them by the end of the year,' he says. 'We'd like to think that we could make a big enough impact to get a lot of employers regularly advertising jobs on our site.

'It's a hard thing for actors to admit to themselves - that they might have to look for other work when the parts don't come in,' he adds. 'Meanwhile there are employers out there who are looking for gregarious people to host corporate parties and work with children. It's a sad reality of the profession that's quite hard for most thespians to admit to.'

Montgomery's entrepreneurship may offer hope to out-of-work actors but in reality it's unlikely to make a huge difference. There are already numerous acting industry websites. The best way for an actor to get work is to be in a job already. Successful actors are the new aristocracy.

Top British casting agent Joyce Nettles, who is featured in a candid four-part Channel 4 documentary Starstruck, thinks we have too many actors. Having worked on films such as Lars von Trier's Breaking The Waves and his upcoming Dancer In The Dark, Nettles is a veteran agent with vast knowledge of British acting history. In the first episode she holds up the first published edition of the Actor's Directory, which is an industry manual for producers and agents. The slimline book, now 30 years old and barely 60 pages long, has been replaced by Spotlight 's eight volumes: each as thick as the London telephone directory.

Nettles argues the profession has been cheapened by inadequately trained actors and fame-seekers. 'I was trying to make a point,' says Nettles. 'That perhaps there are too many actors. Does that mean there is more choice? It's like walking into a supermarket and seeing 50 different kinds of crisps. Do we need them all? What's wrong with just having the basic choices? With all these actors looking for work, it's apparent that not all of them are going to be successful. Let's face it, most directors would still rather cast a soap star. Or someone who has been in a film before. No one is prepared to take a chance with fresh faces anymore.'

The statistics speak for themselves: over 90 per cent of actors earn less than £12,000 a year. Regular work is a rarity for most of those without proven names. Stars who come armed with track records and fit certain stereotypes get lucrative parts. Says Nettles: 'You can't fund projects these days with actors just starting out. Even independent cinema now demands stars willing to take a cut in pay. Even in Britain, bankability is the current obsession.'

Hollyoaks ' executive-producer, Phil Redmond, disagrees. 'I don't think there are any more people trying to break into acting,' he says. Last March Redmond held a series of nationwide auditions for four parts in Hollyoaks and 40,000 potential candidates flocked to casting sessions in London, Edinburgh, Chester, Cardiff and Belfast. 'I remember interviewing people back in the days of Grange Hill and we'd have just as many candidates. I just think the acting profession is better organised now, so perhaps the jobs are snapped up more quickly. And let's face it, there is less work for actors unless you're a name.'

However grim the twenty-first century may look for actors, the sofamouse website should probably gear up for hundreds of thousands of hits. As Starstruck shows would-be actors are prepared to put themselves through all manner of degradations to gain that elusive first break. Renee Simone, aged 18, is a Hollywood hopeful who is featured in episode one. In an effort to mould her into the conventional film beauty, her manager has already forced her to lose 55 pounds and ordered an entire makeover. Simone, almost always on the brink of tears, has yet to win an audition.

'Right now, she's more of a character actress, unfortunately,' says her manager Carolyn Divine coolly. 'She's not the little hot cheerleader girl that the guys are all after. And when you hear that enough, you think, "Right, we have to do something about this" '. The programme shows Divine sending Simone out for a variety of alternative roles which she describes as 'freaks and geeks'. Simone finally breaks down in tears. 'I just want this so bad,' she cries. She never gets it. Divine dumps her.

'I think the once noble profession has undergone a radical change in the last decade,' says Emma Hewitt, series director of Starstruck and once an actor herself. 'People now are more concerned with being stars and being famous. And that entails being famous for anything. So with a profession that suddenly stops revolving around artis tic merits and concentrates on chasing the limelight - what kind of people are you going to attract? And acting does attract a certain kind of brutality: the criticism is often overwhelming. Does that mean the profession has been cheapened? I guess it does.'

Hewitt says she used the series to articulate her own experiences of the acting trade. It makes for troubling viewing. 'These people are disturbed,' she says. 'After all, what kind of person does it take to get on screen? It's about more than just attention-seeking. These people genuinely feel they have a gift to share with cinema-lovers. Imagine their disappointment when they're not given the chance.'

Fay Ripley, who is starring in the third series of Cold Feet, takes a less elevated view of her trade than Emma Hewitt. 'I don't think acting ever was a noble profession,' she says.

'It's a profession obsessed by how you look,' argues Ripley, soon to appear with David Baddiel in a British film The Announcement . 'I'm not thin enough, and have had people tell me that. British producers and agents can be quite brutal about how they perceive you: once you're linked to a certain type of role, then that's pretty much it for most of your career. In fact, in one case, I was even asked if I could pin back my ears for a part.'

Other revealing interviews in Starstruck are with performers such as Richard Dreyfuss, Mel Gibson, Amanda Donohue, Mickey Rourke, Tracy Shaw, Rufus Sewell and Burt Reynolds. They show how little things have changed since Schulberg wrote about Hollywood 60 years ago. Says Dreyfuss: 'You come out the other side, completely changed as a human being. I think I was happiest when I was chasing my ambitions at the age of 20. I certainly wasn't happy when I achieved them. That's the price you pay for it. It took me years to adjust to that.'

Renee Simone please take note.

 Starstruck starts on 16 August on Channel 4

fields.headline: Gomorrah belongs to me
fields.standfirst: Summer in Ibiza. Is it really the seething cauldron of drugs and sex that a recent survey claims? Our intrepid reporter  Phil Hogan  ventures bravely into the fleshpots to find out
fields.trailText: Summer in Ibiza. Is it really the seething cauldron of drugs and sex that a recent survey claims? Our intrepid reporter Phil Hogan ventures bravely into the fleshpots to find out.
fields.body:
It's the Sodom and Gomorrah of activity holidays! The Xanadu of unrestraint! The Mecca of being sick in public! Try saying 'Ibiza' without summoning images from the throbbing black heart of this summer-long Eden of rave, whose growing apocrypha tells of nightclubs packed to the rafters with naked, writhing voluptuaries, tattooed and tongue-pierced, stuffing their faces with ecstasy and shagging doggy-fashion on the dance floor in scenes of debauched Bacchanalian excess reminiscent of Caligula's Rome and those off-season weekends in Butlins that used to be so popular with off-duty estate agents.

Gleeful TV bonkumentaries such as Ibiza Uncovered and The Dog's Balearics nightly recount for us the adventures of intoxicated young Brits being up at all hours, taking their shirts off and urinating in the bougainvillea. So widespread is the island's infamy that even dedicated avoiders of Europop have heard and been irritated by that song 'Whoaaah, I'm Going to Ibiza'.

And now, if more discarded underwear were needed to be thrown on this bonfire of inanities, an astonishing study from the Liverpool John Moores University has revealed that people between the ages of 19 and 21 are more likely to drink lager, take drugs and have more than one sexual partner in Ibiza than back home in Rhyl or Huddersfield, where they've got their mums shouting at them to get up for work.

And so it is that I set out in the spirit of open-minded journalistic inquiry to this El Dorado of unspeakable filth to answer the one question ringing in my ears - 'Can any package destination really be this much fun?' - and in the process perhaps stay there for the rest of my life, leaving my wife and children in penury.

So where better to start than the MTV Ibiza 2000 live dance music festival, an all-night binge of the senses whose inaugural blast last year attracted 12,000 hardened ravers, their minds crackling with pharmaceuticals, locked as one to the beat, impervious to the call of bedtime, drawn helplessly to wearing those trousers that unzip at the knee and don't need ironing.

I'm patrolling the vast crater of a disused stone quarry outside San Antonio, watching as these saucer-eyed hipsters of hedonism come streaming in between two giant, yellow, inflatable beer bottles, descending into the dustbowl arena, crowding the two stages. The sun is on its way down, turning the hills pink; a digitised, pulsing din strafes the air (tooosh toooosh toooosh); the lighting man sends lava-lamp patterns splatting against the towering sandy crag behind us. It's very atmospheric, though a bit on the noisy side.

Apparently, every world-famous DJ no one normal has never heard of is on the bill tonight. DJs are the new rock stars, though you wouldn't know it. Our current one is sitting up there looking like a bus driver waiting for the lights to change. But they are geniuses of a sort, apparently. It is an art. A girl, noticing my notebook, drifts into my orbit wearing underwear and feathers, so I ask her what's so special about DJs. She's not sure. Some DJs can play two records at the same time, she says.

'Ha-ha, it sounds like it too,' I joke, not joking at all, of course.

The crowd is warming up but no one looks remotely prepared to take their clothes off in a spontaneous frenzy, despite the flitting presence of Karen, The Observer 's photographer. We go to the bar. Clearly, the key to having a good time here is in trying not to recoil physically from the music if you can possibly help it. I do blame myself for letting rave culture pass me by to the extent that I am quite unable to grasp the complex aesthetic criteria whereby 'dance music' was able to qualify at some point in history as 'music'. It seems that the evolution from hip-hop to trip-hop to dip-dop was over before I had a chance to appreciate the fine distinction between one subgenre of endless repetition and another.

Still, the beer is cold, the evening is young. Plenty of time yet to have my drink spiked with mind-altering drugs and, who knows, perhaps contract a sexually transmitted disease. Meanwhile, Karen is trying to get me to dance for the camera. No way.

The Artful Dodger comes on stage with Craig David. I'm not sure which one is singing what, but someone at the bar tells me this is UK garage crossover disposable two-step with R&B vocals. 'Thanks,' I say, scribbling 'tuneless' in my notebook, before moving down to the other stage where the DJ is hiding (with good reason) behind his decks playing a speeded-up recording of someone sawing a plank of wood. It's funny everybody looking at a stage with nothing happening on it, though the lighting man is doing a grand job with whirling sunflowers and little beams darting around in the smoke desperately searching for points of interest.

A young woman in sequinned hotpants strides past with flashing red devil's horns on her head. I make a mental note to take a pair home (horns, that is, not hotpants or young women).

'Are you feeling READY... ' the DJ is yelling.

'Are you KIDDING?' I feel like yelling back.

But this is before I discover the chill-out zone, which is located in its own little, self-contained canyon. There's a bearded percussionist in a turban and a sax player and Christmas baubles hanging up and fairy lights (don't ask me). It's pretty funky. It has a very gentle 'vibe' (as I keep hearing people say with no sense of embarrassment). Goateed youngsters are lying about the slopes, understandably entranced, and it occurs to me that many of them may never have seen a proper musical instrument before. I tap my foot rhythmically for a good 15 minutes before returning to the main arena and drinking a further 12 pints of beer.

Tooosh toooosh toooosh... I decide it's time I visited a nightclub, if only to find a toilet that has a light inside and some semblance of hygiene. It takes me a while to locate Karen, who is busy trying to get a shot of a reveller's thrusting pelvis, and we get a cab to Pacha, a club at the other side of the island, where London's Ministry of Sound do a Friday night residency.

Hang on, I'm wondering... isn't this the place with the live sex show where everyone slithers about in shaving foam? No, it is not. This one is quite classy in a glittery, ostentatious way. It's still got the exploding music that punches your eardrums out the minute you get through the door, but the dancing is relatively restrained, with many yachty-looking punters happy to shuffle around without quite leaving the bar (four quid for a bottle of Becks).

Yes, there's a couple hired to undulate energetically at either end of a small stage, and a seven-foot-tall transvestite catwoman stalking about in so much designer Bacofoil you can see your face in her, but it's a knowingly cool gathering. I plunge into the crowd on the dancefloor to see if I succumb to inner seminal forces beyond my control, but the music is like standing next to a helicopter, and it's not long before I am blown headlong back into the periphery by a gale of decibels.

A young man sidles up and asks if I've got any pills. Blimey!

'Sorry,' I say. 'But put me down for an Anadin if you find some.'

The club won't let Karen take pictures, though God knows they haven't got that much to hide. So off we go. At the entrance they're selling T-shirts with the message 'Fuck the tan' - quite subtle by local standards of T-shirt humour, which I have noticed generally runs along the lines of 'Viagra is for pussies' or 'Masturbation is no crime'.

It's about 4.30am when we arrive back at the festival, which from the road sounds like what dustbin-making factories must have sounded like before the Noise Abatement Act. Back inside, the crater has reached an infernal level of tumult. We have missed Underworld, which I'm sure is a huge pity because apparently they are household names in some households, notably (according to the blurb) for their masterpiece Dubnobasswithmyheadman, which was the best album since Screamadelica. Damn. Still, never mind.

'Are you with me, IBIZA?' the DJ is shouting. We are with him, it turns out.

He puts a new record on (or possibly the same one) and the crowd go berserk, jigging up and down and fisting the air and sitting on each other's shoulders. I notice (now that I am safely drunk) how every 'mix' has these bleepy, sinewy passages that are used to build quietly before crashing without warning back into numbskull hammer mode, which as anyone who has ever thrown a stick for a dog will know, is a not very sophisticated way of getting an audience to beg, but what joy ensues! What release! What ecstasy! Well, I mean for everyone else.

The moment that I might have taken part in the dancing - which, like any other abandonment of human dignity, is something I feel is best done in the privacy of your bedroom - has passed without incident. Perhaps tomorrow.

A silver blonde passes in a skirt made out of silver medallions and silver boots that glow in the dark. Someone else is wearing a sieve on her head. But disappointingly, most of the crowd are no more visually arresting than me (T-shirt, unflattering shorts), though I suppose I am at least distinguishable by having my fingers stuck in my ears.

Then, as if from nowhere, I spot my first pair of bare breasts. Yes! Admittedly, they do belong to someone on stilts and have been painted green to reduce the likelihood of unwelcome erotic attention, but even so they must surely still count as a sighting. My work is surely done for the day.

The ground, I note, has become a layer of squashed plastic bottles which makes staggering extra difficult. I've also reached that point in the day where I am required to remember the name of my hotel.

On the way out I see Boy George leaning against a car. It must be gone six.

'Night, Boy George,' I shout. This is how bad things are.

'Night,' he shouts back.

TOOOSH TOOOOSH TOOOOOSH... Four hours later, I'm out of bed, thanks to the complimentary wake-up call coming from the poolside sound system under my hotel window, which this morning is broadcasting the usual beach-groove-megamix cacophony plus an organised laughing and bellowing contest for younger people.

The bad news is I've missed breakfast. The good news is, I seem to be already dressed, so I put my sunglasses on and take my hangover for a walk along the parched strip of road outside in the baking heat. Union Jacks hang from the balconies, bar after bar offers snotty eggs and bacon, sausages, beans, Premiership football, karaoke, curry, fish and chips and live music with Martin and Phil every night.

I find a Spar and buy a loaf of bread, a nectarine, a Diet Coke and, as an afterthought, some deodorant that I should have bought yesterday. I take a surreptitious sniff at an armpit. I wonder if this is why no one has invited me to have casual sex with them yet.

I walk back along the beach eating and watching a group of Spam-coloured British hooligans fry in the heat. I toy with the idea of stopping to ask whether they have taken part in any scenes of outstanding vulgarity during their stay, but I can't quite trust myself to find the right words.

I go back to bed for the day.

In the evening we're back bright-eyed and kicking up dust at the quarry for a night of pop music, which doesn't augur terribly well for bad behaviour but you never know.

Geri Halliwell comes on wearing a wedding dress for no reason other than to have it ripped off by a quintet of muscular dancers. Mind you, she does look fantastic for a woman of however old she says she is, and her voice sounds too good to be true (though this turns out to be because she is miming) and if there isn't much of a crowd this evening, it will look great on MTV once they've edited the emptiness out. 'Cómo están?' shouts Geri, who is half-Spanish.

'Sorry?' replies the audience, who aren't.

After much forced 'partying' at the hands of our DJs for the evening, headliners Five take to the stage for a masterclass of identikit boy-band choreography (those heads hung in shame, that backwalking shimmy, those Ali G hand signals, that baggy clomping about punching the air).

'Give me the chance to prove I'm real...' one of them mimes, his face contorted with emotion.

I scan the audience expectantly. Still no one throwing up.

I at last oblige Karen with some novelty dancing of my own, before the pair of us take off down the hill to San Antonio, famous for its marauding gangs of overweight louts and slappers competing to affront public decency, the girls in strappy shoes and boob tubes, boys in replica football shirts - Chelsea, Wolves, Rangers.

They look at me bewildered. No, no, they explain. One of them has just got a 2.1 in his finals at university. Damn.

'Having a good time?' I ask.

'Wicked!' they cheer.
