fields.bodyText: It's the Sodom and Gomorrah of activity holidays! The Xanadu of unrestraint! The Mecca of being sick in public! Try saying 'Ibiza' without summoning images from the throbbing black heart of this summer-long Eden of rave, whose growing apocrypha tells of nightclubs packed to the rafters with naked, writhing voluptuaries, tattooed and tongue-pierced, stuffing their faces with ecstasy and shagging doggy-fashion on the dance floor in scenes of debauched Bacchanalian excess reminiscent of Caligula's Rome and those off-season weekends in Butlins that used to be so popular with off-duty estate agents. Gleeful TV bonkumentaries such as Ibiza Uncovered and The Dog's Balearics nightly recount for us the adventures of intoxicated young Brits being up at all hours, taking their shirts off and urinating in the bougainvillea. So widespread is the island's infamy that even dedicated avoiders of Europop have heard and been irritated by that song 'Whoaaah, I'm Going to Ibiza'. And now, if more discarded underwear were needed to be thrown on this bonfire of inanities, an astonishing study from the Liverpool John Moores University has revealed that people between the ages of 19 and 21 are more likely to drink lager, take drugs and have more than one sexual partner in Ibiza than back home in Rhyl or Huddersfield, where they've got their mums shouting at them to get up for work. And so it is that I set out in the spirit of open-minded journalistic inquiry to this El Dorado of unspeakable filth to answer the one question ringing in my ears - 'Can any package destination really be this much fun?' - and in the process perhaps stay there for the rest of my life, leaving my wife and children in penury. So where better to start than the MTV Ibiza 2000 live dance music festival, an all-night binge of the senses whose inaugural blast last year attracted 12,000 hardened ravers, their minds crackling with pharmaceuticals, locked as one to the beat, impervious to the call of bedtime, drawn helplessly to wearing those trousers that unzip at the knee and don't need ironing. I'm patrolling the vast crater of a disused stone quarry outside San Antonio, watching as these saucer-eyed hipsters of hedonism come streaming in between two giant, yellow, inflatable beer bottles, descending into the dustbowl arena, crowding the two stages. The sun is on its way down, turning the hills pink; a digitised, pulsing din strafes the air (tooosh toooosh toooosh); the lighting man sends lava-lamp patterns splatting against the towering sandy crag behind us. It's very atmospheric, though a bit on the noisy side. Apparently, every world-famous DJ no one normal has never heard of is on the bill tonight. DJs are the new rock stars, though you wouldn't know it. Our current one is sitting up there looking like a bus driver waiting for the lights to change. But they are geniuses of a sort, apparently. It is an art. A girl, noticing my notebook, drifts into my orbit wearing underwear and feathers, so I ask her what's so special about DJs. She's not sure. Some DJs can play two records at the same time, she says. 'Ha-ha, it sounds like it too,' I joke, not joking at all, of course. The crowd is warming up but no one looks remotely prepared to take their clothes off in a spontaneous frenzy, despite the flitting presence of Karen, The Observer 's photographer. We go to the bar. Clearly, the key to having a good time here is in trying not to recoil physically from the music if you can possibly help it. I do blame myself for letting rave culture pass me by to the extent that I am quite unable to grasp the complex aesthetic criteria whereby 'dance music' was able to qualify at some point in history as 'music'. It seems that the evolution from hip-hop to trip-hop to dip-dop was over before I had a chance to appreciate the fine distinction between one subgenre of endless repetition and another. Still, the beer is cold, the evening is young. Plenty of time yet to have my drink spiked with mind-altering drugs and, who knows, perhaps contract a sexually transmitted disease. Meanwhile, Karen is trying to get me to dance for the camera. No way. The Artful Dodger comes on stage with Craig David. I'm not sure which one is singing what, but someone at the bar tells me this is UK garage crossover disposable two-step with R&B vocals. 'Thanks,' I say, scribbling 'tuneless' in my notebook, before moving down to the other stage where the DJ is hiding (with good reason) behind his decks playing a speeded-up recording of someone sawing a plank of wood. It's funny everybody looking at a stage with nothing happening on it, though the lighting man is doing a grand job with whirling sunflowers and little beams darting around in the smoke desperately searching for points of interest. A young woman in sequinned hotpants strides past with flashing red devil's horns on her head. I make a mental note to take a pair home (horns, that is, not hotpants or young women). 'Are you feeling READY... ' the DJ is yelling. 'Are you KIDDING?' I feel like yelling back. But this is before I discover the chill-out zone, which is located in its own little, self-contained canyon. There's a bearded percussionist in a turban and a sax player and Christmas baubles hanging up and fairy lights (don't ask me). It's pretty funky. It has a very gentle 'vibe' (as I keep hearing people say with no sense of embarrassment). Goateed youngsters are lying about the slopes, understandably entranced, and it occurs to me that many of them may never have seen a proper musical instrument before. I tap my foot rhythmically for a good 15 minutes before returning to the main arena and drinking a further 12 pints of beer. Tooosh toooosh toooosh... I decide it's time I visited a nightclub, if only to find a toilet that has a light inside and some semblance of hygiene. It takes me a while to locate Karen, who is busy trying to get a shot of a reveller's thrusting pelvis, and we get a cab to Pacha, a club at the other side of the island, where London's Ministry of Sound do a Friday night residency. Hang on, I'm wondering... isn't this the place with the live sex show where everyone slithers about in shaving foam? No, it is not. This one is quite classy in a glittery, ostentatious way. It's still got the exploding music that punches your eardrums out the minute you get through the door, but the dancing is relatively restrained, with many yachty-looking punters happy to shuffle around without quite leaving the bar (four quid for a bottle of Becks). Yes, there's a couple hired to undulate energetically at either end of a small stage, and a seven-foot-tall transvestite catwoman stalking about in so much designer Bacofoil you can see your face in her, but it's a knowingly cool gathering. I plunge into the crowd on the dancefloor to see if I succumb to inner seminal forces beyond my control, but the music is like standing next to a helicopter, and it's not long before I am blown headlong back into the periphery by a gale of decibels. A young man sidles up and asks if I've got any pills. Blimey! 'Sorry,' I say. 'But put me down for an Anadin if you find some.' The club won't let Karen take pictures, though God knows they haven't got that much to hide. So off we go. At the entrance they're selling T-shirts with the message 'Fuck the tan' - quite subtle by local standards of T-shirt humour, which I have noticed generally runs along the lines of 'Viagra is for pussies' or 'Masturbation is no crime'. It's about 4.30am when we arrive back at the festival, which from the road sounds like what dustbin-making factories must have sounded like before the Noise Abatement Act. Back inside, the crater has reached an infernal level of tumult. We have missed Underworld, which I'm sure is a huge pity because apparently they are household names in some households, notably (according to the blurb) for their masterpiece Dubnobasswithmyheadman, which was the best album since Screamadelica. Damn. Still, never mind. 'Are you with me, IBIZA?' the DJ is shouting. We are with him, it turns out. He puts a new record on (or possibly the same one) and the crowd go berserk, jigging up and down and fisting the air and sitting on each other's shoulders. I notice (now that I am safely drunk) how every 'mix' has these bleepy, sinewy passages that are used to build quietly before crashing without warning back into numbskull hammer mode, which as anyone who has ever thrown a stick for a dog will know, is a not very sophisticated way of getting an audience to beg, but what joy ensues! What release! What ecstasy! Well, I mean for everyone else. The moment that I might have taken part in the dancing - which, like any other abandonment of human dignity, is something I feel is best done in the privacy of your bedroom - has passed without incident. Perhaps tomorrow. A silver blonde passes in a skirt made out of silver medallions and silver boots that glow in the dark. Someone else is wearing a sieve on her head. But disappointingly, most of the crowd are no more visually arresting than me (T-shirt, unflattering shorts), though I suppose I am at least distinguishable by having my fingers stuck in my ears. Then, as if from nowhere, I spot my first pair of bare breasts. Yes! Admittedly, they do belong to someone on stilts and have been painted green to reduce the likelihood of unwelcome erotic attention, but even so they must surely still count as a sighting. My work is surely done for the day. The ground, I note, has become a layer of squashed plastic bottles which makes staggering extra difficult. fields.headline: Don't mourn only for Sarah
fields.standfirst: Sarah Payne has become an icon of grief for the nation. But our tears for her don't absolve us of the responsibilities we have to all children
fields.trailText: Sarah Payne has become an icon of grief for the nation. But our tears for her don't absolve us of the responsibilities we have to all children.
fields.body:
There's a long bank of flowers on the A29, on the edge of the field where Sarah Payne's body was found. They lie there in their ribbons and cellophane wrappers, some already fading in the July heat. And there are soft toys, too; hundreds of them among the flowers. Teddies and clowns, hedgehogs, vivid dinosaurs and Beanie babies with bright eyes; some are new, others old and squashed flat by another child's hugs. Someone has put candles there; there are a couple of childish tapestries spelling out Sarah's name in clumsy running stitch; a couple of small wooden crosses.

It is a shrine. People make their way here as if they were on a pilgrimage. The road is jammed in either direction; an adjacent field has been made into a special car park. They leave messages. Some are written to the Payne family, expressing sorrow for their loss. Most are to Sarah herself, notes she'll never read like the toys she'll never hold.

Few directly acknowledge her death - most talk to her as if she were still alive; they soften the monstrosity of the tale, and its savage ending. They tell her that they know the man will be caught and punished, though they say no punishment could ever, ever be enough. 'Sweet Dreams, Little Princess', they say 'Sleep Tight'. Or 'Sarah, here's a teddy to cuddle while you sleep'. They talk of the beautiful garden that she's in now, safe at last.

They leave the prayers that we know from childhood:

Now I lay me down to sleep,
I pray the Lord my soul to keep.
And if I die before I wake,
I pray the Lord my soul to take.

Or the poems that never fail to touch our soft, unstructured yearnings:

Do not stand at my grave and weep,
I am not there, I do not sleep.
I am a thousand winds that blow,
I am the diamond glints on snow.
Do not stand at my grave and cry.
I am not there. I did not die.

There are dozens of messages that seem to be trying to cheer her up. One child writes: 'One day you and your mummy and daddy, your brothers and sister will be together again. That's something you can look forward to.' There's a card signed in wonky writing by children who sound as if they knew her and it's like one of those leaving cards everyone signs. 'I'll miss ya!' one child writes; another says: 'I'm sorry you're gone'; another: 'Don't worry, Sarah.'

Well, she won't worry now. That's over. And if they speak to her in the present tense, they also speak to her in tones of great intimacy. Darling, they call her, sweetheart, treasure, little love. Her mother came here and laid her own bouquet, but almost all the messages read as if they had been laid there by her mother. For the people who arrive, bearing their offerings, behave as if they had known and loved Sarah Payne. They weep and hold on to each other for comfort. Strangers console each other, united by their common sorrow and their common, spitting hate ('may he rot in hell').

One woman, standing next to me, breaks down. 'I can't read any more,' she says, bending over in grief. Later, I see her being led away, held up by her husband. The scene is inevitably poignant, but also deeply disturbing in the way that the mass outpouring of grief at Diana's death was disturbing.

In our secular age, when we have lost the formal consolations of ritual, we find new ways to express our fears and our griefs. Certain events become emblematic. Certain people become icons. Sarah Payne, eight years old, with a shining face and gaps in her teeth, is innocence destroyed. She is the lost child, sanctified by her dreadful death. She is every parent's worst dream. The A29 pilgrims have come here to mourn her, and because they imagine it happening to their child or grandchild.

But the grief we feel as voyeuristic strangers is weirdly pleasurable, in a throbbing, melancholy way - like weeping our eyes out at a film. We want to be close to tragedy, while remaining far off. We want to experience it as if it is our tragedy too; our loss, when, of course, it isn't. Real bereavement is very different from this glut of salt tears.

'A nation weeps,' reads one card. Yes, but why exactly does a nation weep over the death of this one little girl? Other children have been murdered this year, and we didn't hear much about them, certainly don't cry for them or remember them by their names. Partly, of course, it is because of the narrative grip that the Payne story has held on us over three weeks. If it had been scripted for a Hollywood tearjerker, it could hardly have been more consummately powerful. An eight-year-old is playing with her brothers and sister in a field on a summer's day, close to her granny's house - this scene is like a metaphor for innocence and carefree youth; think of ears of corn, poppies, floaty cotton dresses, young and happy voices carried by the wind.

She falls over, hurts her knees, decides she wants to go home. That's the last we see of her. A white van is spied, driving past the place she would have been. For 17 days, the police search for her. With each day, the agony of the family increases. The media quickly respond to the public emotion, and ratchet it up. Every paper carries her picture: the wide smile, eager face. There are other pictures too - like the one of the mother, Sara, walking along a beach holding her other daughter clutched to her breast. It's an image of both absence (the little girl is not Sarah) and of presence. We have snatches of Sarah's character: how she's a chatterbox. How she's their little princess. The parents give press conferences, clinging to each other, but impressively strong and desperately hopeful - their hope becomes like a prayer. It's as if they believe strongly enough that she is alive, then she will be. She'll be alive because they love her so much and want her back so much.

We all know how that feels - we've all imagined losing our children; we've all turned round and seen the space where the body should be, in a supermarket, on the street. That gulp of pure terror. It's a primitive, visceral terror lodged in the deep structure of the brain.

For 17 days, Sarah is like a ghost in our world: alive and not alive; somewhere but invisible. She haunts us. Then her body is found, naked, in a field of long grass and tall flowers, rather like the field where she was lost. There's a report that, a few miles from here, some campers heard someone screaming in the night. Later, a single black shoe is found, in a hedge. The agony is being drawn out. We think of Sarah and we think of our own loved one. We imagine Sarah's last moments (the screams, the nakedness), and we superimpose images of our own children on her face.

This is the stuff of nightmares and of fairytales. Hansel and Gretel, Red Riding Hood, Persephone: the witch in the hidden house, the wolf in the dark forest, the beautiful girl snatched down into an underworld. The child that is snatched from us. The child that is lost. The child that is calling out for us but we can't hear. The child that needs us, but we're not there. Intolerable. Thus the murder of Sarah Payne has become an instant human myth of innocence destroyed, and also of an unquenchable, never-ending bereavement that her family will feel.

The clichés of redemption (time heals, that kind of thing) won't do here. There's no getting over this one, only through it. I remember A.S. Byatt, whose son was killed in a car crash when he was 11, saying that it took her the span of his life over again to find life in any way bearable. She said that she knew he was dead and that wishing him back wouldn't work, so she used to pray that she would go mad, and in her madness think he was alive again.

Jonathan Dollimore, in his fine book, Death, Desire and Loss in Western Culture, makes the point that only humans experience the death of children as unbearable. Animals habitually lose half their offspring, or more, and hardly notice. But even in times when parents could expect to see several of their children die, it has never been acceptable to us. There is no sadder poem in the English language than William Wordsworth's about his dead daughter, 'Surprised by Joy'.

We are alienated from nature, at war with death. Sarah Payne's death brings it home to us that human life is tragic, even while the messages pinned on to the flowers dodge this truth by invoking God, the arms of Jesus, sleep, dreams, beautiful gardens and angels.

The death of James Bulger caused the same level of horror and sorrow and emotional identification. I think that was not just because he was murdered by two small boys, but because he was caught on video. We could watch him leaving us, over and over again, on a loop: the toddler putting his trusting hand in the hand of the murderer, and being led away. The grainy image was like a home movie, except home movies always capture happy moments. And with the Bulger murder, as with Sarah Payne's murder, we are suddenly made to feel terrified about the safety of all children, as if no one is safe, innocence is in peril, and terrible men lurk in the long grass, watching, waiting. Strangers feel compelled to come up to you to tell you to keep an eye on your son or daughter: don't let them out of your sight for a minute, not round that supermarket aisle, into that hollow tree, over the brow of the hill. Don't leave them alone for a second, in case the bogeyman should get them. I've heard that some parents are now buying their toddlers reins, so they can literally keep a grip on them at all times.

We should let go of those reins, allow our children to play in the cornfields. In this country, between five and seven children are murdered each year by strangers. Between 60 and 80 are murdered by their family. Thousands more are abused. Tens of thousands go missing; there is now a ghost town of runaways in our midst. It might be hard to dwell upon Sarah Payne's death, but it's hard in an easy, lazy, self-pleasing and self-deluding way for it feeds our willingness to think of the world as a Manichean place of good and bad, innocence and evil, bright day and pitch night.

It is far easier to think about the stranger in a white van and wish him dead, than to think of the father, the stepfather, the family 'friend', the social worker, the priest; all the people like us. Or to think about all of those children in care. Or to think about all of those children who live in poverty. With Sarah's murder, we can feel drenched in sorrow and outrage, and put flowers on a bank and weep and turn back with shuddery relief to the ones we love.

What about all the other children, whose names we don't remember, whose stories we don't read, whose graves we don't mark, whose loss we never weep over, and who we'd rather prefer not to think about because their tragedies are more complicated and confusing, and come uncomfortably close to us and are still going on, day after day.

There's nothing we can do for Sarah Payne, but we could help those other children, if only we put our collective will to it. And with Sarah Payne's death, we can loudly shout (as some journalists have inevitably been doing) for the return of capital punishment. Death's too good for him, monster, animal, fiend. But if the death penalty is wrong, it's wrong for the worst person in the world. It would be far more useful if we were calling for a review of the way we treat active paedophiles, who are rarely cured of their perverse sexuality, and who are often let out of prison after light sentences, only to re-offend. That's too pragmatic, though. It doesn't satisfy the pleasure of hatred and the primitive desire for revenge.

On that road to Pulborough, on the A29, I was momentarily reminded of Anne Frank's museum, with its extension, its toilets and its souvenir shop: the necessary tourism of grief. But of course, the extraordinary power of Anne Frank is that she stands for millions of slaughtered children. Through her individual story, we read the history that we must never forget.

Sarah Payne stands for no one but herself: a bright, sweet girl loved by her family and friends, whose life was cut short. The meaning that we give to her is the meaning we bring. She stands for our terror. The lost child; the child who never comes home, and you have to wait the rest of your life never to see them again.

The scene is inevitably poignant, but also deeply disturbing in the way that the mass outpouring of grief at Diana's death was disturbing. In our secular age, when we have lost the formal consolations of ritual, we find new ways to express our fears and our griefs. Certain events become emblematic. Certain people become icons. Sarah Payne, eight years old, with a shining face and gaps in her teeth, is innocence destroyed. She is the lost child, sanctified by her dreadful death. She is every parent's worst dream. The A29 pilgrims have come here to mourn her, and because they imagine it happening to their child or grandchild. But the grief we feel as voyeuristic strangers is weirdly pleasurable, in a throbbing, melancholy way - like weeping our eyes out at a film. We want to be close to tragedy, while remaining far off. We want to experience it as if it is our tragedy too; our loss, when, of course, it isn't. Real bereavement is very different from this glut of salt tears. 'A nation weeps,' reads one card. Yes, but why exactly does a nation weep over the death of this one little girl? Other children have been murdered this year, and we didn't hear much about them, certainly don't cry for them or remember them by their names. Partly, of course, it is because of the narrative grip that the Payne story has held on us over three weeks. If it had been scripted for a Hollywood tearjerker, it could hardly have been more consummately powerful. An eight-year-old is playing with her brothers and sister in a field on a summer's day, close to her granny's house - this scene is like a metaphor for innocence and carefree youth; think of ears of corn, poppies, floaty cotton dresses, young and happy voices carried by the wind. She falls over, hurts her knees, decides she wants to go home. That's the last we see of her. A white van is spied, driving past the place she would have been. For 17 days, the police search for her. With each day, the agony of the family increases. The media quickly respond to the public emotion, and ratchet it up. Every paper carries her picture: the wide smile, eager face. There are other pictures too - like the one of the mother, Sara, walking along a beach holding her other daughter clutched to her breast. It's an image of both absence (the little girl is not Sarah) and of presence. We have snatches of Sarah's character: how she's a chatterbox. How she's their little princess. The parents give press conferences, clinging to each other, but impressively strong and desperately hopeful - their hope becomes like a prayer. It's as if they believe strongly enough that she is alive, then she will be. She'll be alive because they love her so much and want her back so much. We all know how that feels - we've all imagined losing our children; we've all turned round and seen the space where the body should be, in a supermarket, on the street. That gulp of pure terror. It's a primitive, visceral terror lodged in the deep structure of the brain. For 17 days, Sarah is like a ghost in our world: alive and not alive; somewhere but invisible. She haunts us. Then her body is found, naked, in a field of long grass and tall flowers, rather like the field where she was lost. There's a report that, a few miles from here, some campers heard someone screaming in the night. Later, a single black shoe is found, in a hedge. The agony is being drawn out. We think of Sarah and we think of our own loved one. We imagine Sarah's last moments (the screams, the nakedness), and we superimpose images of our own children on her face. This is the stuff of nightmares and of fairytales. Hansel and Gretel, Red Riding Hood, Persephone: the witch in the hidden house, the wolf in the dark forest, the beautiful girl snatched down into an underworld. The child that is snatched from us. The child that is lost. The child that is calling out for us but we can't hear. The child that needs us, but we're not there. Intolerable. Thus the murder of Sarah Payne has become an instant human myth of innocence destroyed, and also of an unquenchable, never-ending bereavement that her family will feel. The clichés of redemption (time heals, that kind of thing) won't do here. There's no getting over this one, only through it. I remember A.S. Byatt, whose son was killed in a car crash when he was 11, saying that it took her the span of his life over again to find life in any way bearable. She said that she knew he was dead and that wishing him back wouldn't work, so she used to pray that she would go mad, and in her madness think he was alive again. Jonathan Dollimore, in his fine book, Death, Desire and Loss in Western Culture, makes the point that only humans experience the death of children as unbearable. Animals habitually lose half their offspring, or more, and hardly notice. But even in times when parents could expect to see several of their children die, it has never been acceptable to us. There is no sadder poem in the English language than William Wordsworth's about his dead daughter, 'Surprised by Joy'. We are alienated from nature, at war with death. Sarah Payne's death brings it home to us that human life is tragic, even while the messages pinned on to the flowers dodge this truth by invoking God, the arms of Jesus, sleep, dreams, beautiful gardens and angels. The death of James Bulger caused the same level of horror and sorrow and emotional identification. I think that was not just because he was murdered by two small boys, but because he was caught on video. We could watch him leaving us, over and over again, on a loop: the toddler putting his trusting hand in the hand of the murderer, and being led away. The grainy image was like a home movie, except home movies always capture happy moments. And with the Bulger murder, as with Sarah Payne's murder, we are suddenly made to feel terrified about the safety of all children, as if no one is safe, innocence is in peril, and terrible men lurk in the long grass, watching, waiting. Strangers feel compelled to come up to you to tell you to keep an eye on your son or daughter: don't let them out of your sight for a minute, not round that supermarket aisle, into that hollow tree, over the brow of the hill. Don't leave them alone for a second, in case the bogeyman should get them. I've heard that some parents are now buying their toddlers reins, so they can literally keep a grip on them at all times. We should let go of those reins, allow our children to play in the cornfields. In this country, between five and seven children are murdered each year by strangers. Between 60 and 80 are murdered by their family. Thousands more are abused. Tens of thousands go missing; there is now a ghost town of runaways in our midst. It might be hard to dwell upon Sarah Payne's death, but it's hard in an easy, lazy, self-pleasing and self-deluding way for it feeds our willingness to think of the world as a Manichean place of good and bad, innocence and evil, bright day and pitch night. It is far easier to think about the stranger in a white van and wish him dead, than to think of the father, the stepfather, the family 'friend', the social worker, the priest; all the people like us. Or to think about all of those children in care. Or to think about all of those children who live in poverty. With Sarah's murder, we can feel drenched in sorrow and outrage, and put flowers on a bank and weep and turn back with shuddery relief to the ones we love. What about all the other children, whose names we don't remember, whose stories we don't read, whose graves we don't mark, whose loss we never weep over, and who we'd rather prefer not to think about because their tragedies are more complicated and confusing, and come uncomfortably close to us and are still going on, day after day. There's nothing we can do for Sarah Payne, but we could help those other children, if only we put our collective will to it. And with Sarah Payne's death, we can loudly shout (as some journalists have inevitably been doing) for the return of capital punishment. Death's too good for him, monster, animal, fiend. But if the death penalty is wrong, it's wrong for the worst person in the world. It would be far more useful if we were calling for a review of the way we treat active paedophiles, who are rarely cured of their perverse sexuality, and who are often let out of prison after light sentences, only to re-offend. That's too pragmatic, though. It doesn't satisfy the pleasure of hatred and the primitive desire for revenge. On that road to Pulborough, on the A29, I was momentarily reminded of Anne Frank's museum, with its extension, its toilets and its souvenir shop: the necessary tourism of grief. But of course, the extraordinary power of Anne Frank is that she stands for millions of slaughtered children. Through her individual story, we read the history that we must never forget. Sarah Payne stands for no one but herself: a bright, sweet girl loved by her family and friends, whose life was cut short. The meaning that we give to her is the meaning we bring. She stands for our terror. The lost child; the child who never comes home, and you have to wait the rest of your life never to see them again.

fields.headline: Blair binge gives Flametree cheer
fields.trailText: It has been a month since The Observer caught up with the staff of Flametree, who seem to be multiplying fast. Only a couple of months after its site launched, Flametree has already outgrown its offices in London's Victoria and is now hunting for new premises.
fields.body:
The story so far: Flametree.co.uk is an internet company looking to build a portal to help working women 'balance their lives'. Formed by two friends, Jayne Buxton and Rosemary Leith, Flametree has secured nearly £1 million in private financing and the site is now up and running. The company's backers include Ally Svenson, co-founder of the Seattle Coffee Company.

 It has been a month since The Observer caught up with the staff of Flametree, who seem to be multiplying fast. Only a couple of months after its site launched, Flametree has already outgrown its offices in London's Victoria and is now hunting for new premises.

Nothing too expensive, mind. The company does not intend to blow its financing on a plush office suite.

Fortune seems to be smiling on the start-up. Euan Blair's imbibing activities focused the national attention on teenage drinking and parental responsibility, issues which Flametree's array of experts were well qualified to talk about. As anxious parents clicked on to the site looking for guidance on how to keep young Johnny off the Special Brew, Flametree was able to reorientate the Web pages so that they offered advice, case studies and features devoted to the tricky subject of teenage dipsomania.

The site is now generating 24,000 page impressions a week, a figure that delights the founders. Rosemary says: 'The most interesting statistic is that the average time on the site is 14 minutes. With some other sites people just spend 20 minutes a month.'

This all bodes well when it comes to selling advertising and sponsorship space, though this is still no easy feat. The pair admit finding sponsors is time-consuming. 'It's building a relationship' Jayne says. 'It's not like asking somebody to buy a month's supply of water. It's a much deeper, potentially more interesting but therefore more complex area.'

Flametree's portal provides links to a range of e-commerce partners. The childcare link is proving very popular, and Ten UK, an online company which can help you with everything from finding a nanny at short notice to ordering flowers and food for a dinner party, is also benefiting from its alliance with Flametree, which takes a commission for any new custom it generates.

Given the fact that the company is still finding its feet, emphasis is currently on prioritising. Flametree's founders know they cannot do everything perfectly from the start, so they are using focus groups to decide which parts of the site they should concentrate on improving. 'You've got to concentrate on the core before you start branching out,' Jayne says.

The site's forums are running smoothly, and its webmaster has so far not felt compelled to throw anyone out of the discussion rooms. Chris, Flametree's content and technology manager, has programmed the site's software to alert him if the forum users type one of four banned swear words, but no one has yet felt the urge to be profane.

However, some of the topics discussed are creating a stir. One woman's suggestions that the best way to get children to go to sleep was to zip them into tents generated an uproar.

Getting the site listed with the search engines is now proving one of the firm's biggest challenges. 'It's a real marketing exercise,' Jayne says. The trick is to create the right key words so that search engine users will find the site. 'Do it incorrectly, then you've had it,' says Chris sternly. Companies which are too 'enthusiastic' with their descriptions can fall foul of the search engines - a serious no-no.

But, all in all, things are going well. 'There's a rhythm to it,' says Rosemary.

webTitle: Putin tells world leaders to log on

fields.headline: Putin tells world leaders to log on
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Vlad@kremlin.gov.ru may soon be swapping messages with Tony@no10.gov.uk after a proposal yesterday by Russian President Vladimir Putin that the leaders of the world's most powerful nations should start communicating by email.
fields.body:
Vlad@kremlin.gov.ru may soon be swapping messages with Tony@no10.gov.uk after a proposal yesterday by Russian President Vladimir Putin that the leaders of the world's most powerful nations should start communicating by email.

Putin's attempt to propel the group of eight into cyberspace took leaders by surprise at the Okinawa summit and threatened to expose the digital divide in their own ranks.

The Russian President may come from the poorest of the G8 nations, but as a former head of the KGB intelligence service he is well versed in information technology. The same cannot be said of all G8 leaders, several of whom are barely computer literate.

Prime Minister Tony Blair has only recently completed a crash course on the internet and writes most of his correspondence in long hand.

Earlier this year French President Jacques Chirac had to ask what a mouse was. And the Japanese Prime Minister, Yoshiro Mori, only sent his first email last month.

With information technology as the main theme of the summit, the leaders gave a cautious welcome to Putin's initiative. Blair's spokesman said an email network between the leaders would probably be largely symbolic. 'Email is not the most secure form of communication,' he noted.

Despite their own lack of cyber savvy, the G8 heads unveiled a plan to set up a new body to tackle the 'digital divide' - the growing gap between those benefiting from the internet revolution and those being left behind. One of the roles of the 'dot force' (Digital Opportunity Taskforce) would be to promote the use of information technology in developing countries.

Poverty-reduction campaigners said the resources would be better used to relieve the debt of poor nations. 'The poorest people in the world cannot eat lap tops,' said Ann Pettifor, UK director of Jubilee 2000.

fields.headline: Trouble with Harry
fields.standfirst: Has Hollywood tamed the net star?
fields.trailText: Has Hollywood tamed the net star?
fields.body:
Back when the internet was still a novelty, Harry Knowles was one of its early stars. Fat, ginger, bespectacled, from the depths of Texas and proud of it all, he was dubbed the man Hollywood was scared of. Not that anyone really was afraid, of course, but Knowles's website - Ain't It Cool News - made a name for itself with casting rumours, reports on yet-to-be-made scripts and, most importantly, reviews from test previews.

The studios reputedly warned staff to look out for an overweight guy hiding his hair under a baseball cap sneaking into the supposedly secret screenings. It was all written up romantically, Harry as a shining example of how the net meant fan power could triumph, the hick who beat the supersmooth Hollywood PR system.

Now you no longer had to read dull trade magazines to find out about next year's films, or the films that never got made. Harry became so famous he made the leap to appearing in movies himself, getting an embarrassing bit part in The Faculty . That might have been the moment of hubris, because three years on everyone hates him. He is accused of egomania (the little cartoon Harrys all over Ain't It Cool), stealing scoops, taking too many freebies from studios, dishonestly hyping friends' lousy scripts and being involved in video bootlegging.

Film Threat magazine has just finished an exhaustive and exhausting three part investigation into Knowles's crimes and misdemeanours, and most other internet movie sites have had their say.

Harry says the accusations are rubbish. The scoops and freebies are no different from other journalists' work. And the allegation of bootlegging refers to an employee and had nothing to do with Harry. Harry says they are all just jealous.

But the real problem might be even simpler. In the beginning, Knowles was popular because he was just another movie fan, if a very resourceful one. Now he's a guy with PR contacts who makes money from writing about films. He has metamorphosed from a lovable enthusiast into something else.

Although he strenuously avoids the tag and all the baggage involved, not to mention the troublesome hang-ups about conflicts of interest and checking your sources, Harry Knowles has to face the truth that he is now just another film journalist.

fields.headline: Anarchists in summer of protest
fields.standfirst: Mass demonstrations to target Brighton Labour conference and IMF meeting in Prague
fields.trailText: Anarchists and anti-capitalists are gearing up for a summer of protest in Britain in the run-up to a big global demonstration expected in Prague when the International Monetary Fund meets at the end of September.
fields.byline: Kamal Ahmed and Kate Connolly in Prague and Burhan Wazir
fields.body:
Anarchists and anti-capitalists are gearing up for a summer of protest in Britain in the run-up to a big global demonstration expected in Prague when the International Monetary Fund meets at the end of September.

A key target for the British groups, which caused mayhem in central London in May when the Cenotaph and a statue of Winston Churchill were defaced, will be the Labour Party conference in Brighton.

In an advertisement in the New Statesman, a group describing itself as Brighton 2000 calls on supporters to gather on Sunday 24 September, the day that the Prime Minister is expected to arrive.

Some demonstrators are expected to move straight on to Prague for the IMF meeting, which opens two days later.

'Brighton rocks against Blair,' says the ad. 'Blockade Labour's party conference in solidarity with the 26 September shutdown of the IMF meeting in Prague. Protest against privatisation, to tax the rich and for asylum seekers' rights.'

'We obviously can't detail what plans we have for the conference,' said a spokesman for the London-based Brighton 2000. 'But activism in the country over the last year has developed a track record in mass action. Our actions at the Labour conference will prove no different.'

The internet is the major way of drumming up support for the various protests. In the run-up to Prague (S26 as it has become known), groups such as Global Exchange and Tradewatch have started partnering activist organisations across the globe using translators to help spread information.

Other protests planned for this summer include a mass walk on 1 August from Aldermaston to Faslane in Scotland, culminating in a blockade of a Trident submarine base two weeks later.

On the same day, cycle rides highlighting inner-city pollution are planned to hit London, Copenhagen, Geneva and Berlin. The cyclists plan to place themselves strategically in large groups around key spots in each city. The aim will be to halt private traffic.

In Prague, officials are bracing themselves for the arrival of tens of thousands of anti-globalisation activists who plan to turn the IMF and World Bank meeting into an embarrassing shambles. More than 20,000 demonstrators are expected for what will be the Czech capital's first large-scale protest since the 1989 popular revolts which transformed the economy from Communism to free market economics.

Authorities fear a humiliating repetition of the events outside the World Trade Organisation in Seattle last November but have been accused of planning to adopt similar heavy-handed methods to those used by the Communist regime to crush their critics.

The Interior Ministry has ordered the closure of all theatres during the conference for fear that protesters will use them as platforms for their demonstrations, as dissidents such as Vaclav Havel habitually did in the run-up to the Velvet Revolution.

The Education Ministry has insisted on the evacuation of all schoolchildren and has granted a special holiday to educational establishments during the week-long conference.

'There is a fear for pupils' security as they could become witness to mass protests of opponents of globalisation,' a spokesman said. An exodus from the city is expected following an advertising campaign urging them to leave to ease traffic congestion and reports in national newspapers telling them to barricade all doors and windows against 'barbarians'.

Security will be tight at the former Communist Party's Palace of Culture, now called the Congress Centre, where an estimated 23,000 delegates will gather.

Eleven thousand police strengthened by a 5,000 back-up team of soldiers and special officers will be drafted in to keep the peace.

Czech authorities are in close contact with Interpol and the secret services in other countries and their security strategy has been boosted by the FBI's timely decision to open an office in Prague to help the fight against terrorism, extremism and economic crime.

Twenty-four police officers received FBI training in Washington during the IMF and World Bank conference in April and the following month Louis Freeh, head of the FBI, visited Prague to discuss contingency plans for the conference which has been five years in the making.

Protesters say opposition towards them is growing. 'We have had our phones bugged, our emails infiltrated, and we've been videoed during meetings,' said Chelsea Mozen, international media co-ordinator for the protest ers. Mozen has given up a social policy job in Washington to go to Prague for the protest. An international gathering of organisers in June held at a farmhouse outside Prague was videotaped and observed by men with binoculars from a rooftop, said Mozen.

Rumour has reached the protesters that even the Czech Republic's borders will be closed in an attempt to stop undesirables from entering to disrupt the event, which is expected to net the country over $80 million.

Martin Shaw, a 35-year-old electrician from London who has moved to Prague for the conference, said he distrusted the authorities' offer to 'house' the protesters in the monolithic but now derelict Strahov Stadium.

'I won't be staying there, because it's far from the conference centre, and I wouldn't put it past them to try and trap us there so that we don't get in the way of the unelected, unaccountable bunch of men who will be making decisions for the whole world,' he said.

After the London protests Blair described the action as 'beneath contempt' and Home Secretary Jack Straw said that the organisations involved were guilty of 'criminality and thuggery masquerading as political protest'. More than 400 police in riot gear finally broke up the demonstrations after stones were thrown.

Sussex police have launched Operation Otter to tackle the expected trouble in Brighton, which could include sit-down protests, 'guerrilla gardening', targeting of retailers and attempts to stop delegates entering the conference.

Flashpoints

 1 August: Mass walk sets off from Aldermaston, Berkshire, to Faslane, Scotland, for attempt to blockade Trident base

 1 August: Cyclists plan to blockade traffic in London, Copenhagen, Geneva and Berlin in pollution protest

 24 September: Labour Party conference, Brighton

 26 September: IMF/World Bank meeting, Prague

Security will be tight at the former Communist Party's Palace of Culture, now called the Congress Centre, where an estimated 23,000 delegates will gather. Eleven thousand police strengthened by a 5,000 back-up team of soldiers and special officers will be drafted in to keep the peace. Czech authorities are in close contact with Interpol and the secret services in other countries and their security strategy has been boosted by the FBI's timely decision to open an office in Prague to help the fight against terrorism, extremism and economic crime. Twenty-four police officers received FBI training in Washington during the IMF and World Bank conference in April and the following month Louis Freeh, head of the FBI, visited Prague to discuss contingency plans for the conference which has been five years in the making. Protesters say opposition towards them is growing. 'We have had our phones bugged, our emails infiltrated, and we've been videoed during meetings,' said Chelsea Mozen, international media co-ordinator for the protest ers. Mozen has given up a social policy job in Washington to go to Prague for the protest. An international gathering of organisers in June held at a farmhouse outside Prague was videotaped and observed by men with binoculars from a rooftop, said Mozen. Rumour has reached the protesters that even the Czech Republic's borders will be closed in an attempt to stop undesirables from entering to disrupt the event, which is expected to net the country over $80 million. Martin Shaw, a 35-year-old electrician from London who has moved to Prague for the conference, said he distrusted the authorities' offer to 'house' the protesters in the monolithic but now derelict Strahov Stadium. 'I won't be staying there, because it's far from the conference centre, and I wouldn't put it past them to try and trap us there so that we don't get in the way of the unelected, unaccountable bunch of men who will be making decisions for the whole world,' he said. After the London protests Blair described the action as 'beneath contempt' and Home Secretary Jack Straw said that the organisations involved were guilty of 'criminality and thuggery masquerading as political protest'. More than 400 police in riot gear finally broke up the demonstrations after stones were thrown. Sussex police have launched Operation Otter to tackle the expected trouble in Brighton, which could include sit-down protests, 'guerrilla gardening', targeting of retailers and attempts to stop delegates entering the conference. Flashpoints  1 August: Mass walk sets off from Aldermaston, Berkshire, to Faslane, Scotland, for attempt to blockade Trident base  1 August: Cyclists plan to blockade traffic in London, Copenhagen, Geneva and Berlin in pollution protest  24 September: Labour Party conference, Brighton  26 September: IMF/World Bank meeting, Prague

fields.headline: Hacker threat to Whitehall revealed
fields.standfirst: Special report: privacy on the net
fields.trailText: The security of Government internet and email services is a shambles, raising serious questions about national security, according to one of the Government's most senior advisers on electronic protection.
fields.body:
The security of Government internet and email services is a shambles, raising serious questions about national security, according to one of the Government's most senior advisers on electronic protection.

Deri Jones, the head of Europe's biggest internet security testing company, which supplies services to a series of government departments as well as the Bank of England, Powergen and British Gas, said tests had revealed gaping holes at the heart of the Government's computer services. He said hackers - and unauthorised Government officials - would find it easy to get into many of the Government's most sensitive internet sites.

Jones accused officials of being complacent about security issues. They were too busy fighting turf wars over who has the most complex internet sites to realise that threats from outside individuals were real and that malevolent insiders could be having a field day.

The Government's supposedly secure intranet service, GSI, which links departments, is thought to be particularly vulnerable.

The news comes days after a confidential memo by Tony Blair detailing the failings of the Labour Government was leaked to the press. It was the first time the personal correspondence of a serving Prime Minister has been passed to the media. Damaging memos from Blair's senior polling adviser, Philip Gould, have also appeared in newspapers in the past month, provoking fear in Downing Street that a mole is operating at the heart of government. All the files containing the sensitive information are thought to have been collated electronically.

Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, who was one of the recipients of the memos, has raised concerns that hackers or unauthorised officials have been gaining access to confidential files.

Blair has now ordered an overhaul of electronic security at Downing Street, demanding tighter 'copy to' lists - groups of people who are automatically sent sensi tive documents. 'We had actually been relaxing the sense of central control in Government,' a Cabinet source said. 'Now that will be reversed.'

John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, and Gordon Brown, the Chancellor, have demanded that there are fewer written memos and have said that if people like Gould, an inveterate memo writer, have to make their opinions known, they should do it verbally.At a meeting of the Parliamentary Labour Party last week Prescott and Brown agreed with the mood of the meeting that it was time to move away from memos criticising the Government's performance.

'It was clear what they thought,' one senior backbencher at the meeting said. Jones's company, NTA Monitor, which provides security advice and equipment for the Cabinet Office, the Office of Fair Trading, the Department for Education and the Government's publishing arm, the Stationery Office, surveyed 16,000 organisations in Britain last month.

Of the groups tested, more than a third of Government departments and linked organisations failed the most basic security test - the email relay vulnerability test. That compared with just one in five university sites and one in four commercial sites.

 Ken Livingstone added to the troubles by saying Blair's inner circle was 'like a mirror image of the old Militant tendency'. The London Mayor told, BBC2's Around Westminster programme: 'They have no life outside politics, they require total compliance with the line, and they are devoid of humour.

'These are not people you should let run a country. They shouldn't even let them run a political party. If the Prime Minister was to cut himself free of that we wouldn't have many of the problems we've currently got.'

webTitle: Mitchell to join internet incubator venture

fields.headline: Mitchell to join internet incubator venture
fields.trailText: Northern Ireland peacemaker George Mitchell is joining Axiomlab, the latest 'internet incubator' to come to the market.
fields.body:
Northern Ireland peacemaker George Mitchell is joining Axiomlab, the latest 'internet incubator' to come to the market.

The former Democratic senator heads Axiomlab's board, which includes top UK executives from Microsoft and Cisco Systems.

The venture is raising £5 million at 5p per share, valuing the company at £13m on the Alternative Investment Market this week. Unusually, the firm will restrict its investments initially to start-ups in Scotland and the North of England.

'We see a gap in the market in areas that badly need such investment,' said founding director Fred Mendelson. 'Each region will also have its own heavyweight investment panel, and we already have backers such as Royal Bank of Scotland, Scottish Mutual and Apax.'

Axiomlab is the brainchild of Mendelson - a 37-year-old Oxford graduate, Harvard MBA and former McKinsey management consultant - and Ray Ingleby, a self-made multi-millionaire.

The flotation bucks the trend of growing disappointment with certain so-called 'incubators'.
